I want to preface this by saying that I have had some *GREAT* times at the 
FMR's Wicked put on a couple of years ago. 

Some things Wicked has going for them:

1) A KILLER sound system.
2) Competent DJ's

The other side of the coin:

1) Too many fashion mavens and gangstas at the parties.
2) The Rock'n'Roll Superstar Syndrome of the DJ's.

Cover for most of the parties hover around $15 which is a bit much for 
King Street nowadays IMO.

>   This is the Magical Grapefruit of Love.  It has been bequeathed upon you
>by someone who thinks you are really cool.  This person might be
>your boyfriend, girlfriend, lover, pal, homie, Hausfrau, neighbor or
>someone else you don't even know.  This person finds you rather
>interesting, possibly even attractive, and just generally thinks you're a
>pretty good excuse to be alive.  Whether this person actually IS attracted
>to you is another question.  This is merely a token of affection for you
>to wonder at and appreciate.  The proper response, upon reciept of the
>Magical Grapefruit of Love is a hug, or a message of thanks, if this
>person is too far away to hug within a week of reciept.  Basically, the
>Magical Grapefruit of Love is a way to say "Hey, you're really damn cool,
>and I want you to know that."  Sorry if you were disappointed that there
>is no actual citrus fruit contained in this letter.  Unfortunately, at the
>time of writing, that miracle of science that allows grapefruit to travel
>through telephone lines had not been perfected.  But be consoled by the
>fact that someone thinks you're really a rockin' guy/gal, and would most
>likely help you out if you had a flat tire somewhere in the same state (or
>within a one or two hour radius, depending on the size of your state).
>    The sender of the Magical Grapefruit of Love only asks one thing of
>you-- (besides the aforementioned hug) that you bequeath this Grapefruit
>of Love on someone else.  The Magical Grapefruit of Love grows in power as
>it is shared, and someday you may recieve this Magical Citrus Entity
>again.  Send it on.  Remember the elation you felt the first time you
>received it?  If you send it on, you may feel this again.  This is not a
>chain letter.  Nothing bad will happen to you if you don't send it on, but
>think of the bright spot it might put in the day of someone you think is
>extra marvelous.
>
>
>						-Le Renard Noir

> Very simple. Go to Burning Man? See the Ultra-Elite Bus away from 
> everyone else that was invitation-only? Go to Tribal Future? See the 
> private Wicked encampent away from EVERYONE, and I mean EVERYONE, 
> including every single other DJ that weren't Wicked crew? I didn't come 
> to this conclusion alone, or for no reason.

The "ultra-elite" bus - is this that silver bus that somebody named JB 
drives around?  Indeed, this bus is elite.

Once I got on that bus and there were some pretty cool people there. 
I had heard from those the bus had snubbed that this was a scary bus and 
that only really cool people were allowed to get on it.  But my friends 
and I sneaked aboard.

It was cosy inside and there were some people handing around a 
a bottle of wine.  We settled in for a while and started 
chatting with the bus-people.  They did not seem stuck up and showed no 
sign of getting ready to kick us off the bus.  We started to relax.  

Then this incredibly freaky and annoying man started to go off about an acid 
trip he had at Burning Man.  This guy just went on and on and on.  He
was manic- he was out of control.  He resisted all attempts at changing 
the subject.  Pretty soon, the bus was empty and that was the end of my 
encounter with the bus and its passengers.

____

At Burning Man I hear that THE camp to be at was the WBLights RV circle, 
covered by a now legendary parachute.



-Ann

> WELCOME TO THE USGS NORTHERN CALIFORNIA SEISMIC NETWORK
> 
> a member of the Council of the National Seismic System
> 
> Below is a list of magnitude 2 or greater earthquakes recorded by the
> 
> USGS Northern California Seismic Network during the last 3 days.  All
> 
> times are in UT a.k.a.  Greenwich Mean Time.  This is 8 hours ahead of
> 
> PST or 7 hours ahead of PDT.  Note that recent earthquakes may have
> 
> multiple preliminary locations.  This catalog is valid for Central and
> 
> Northern California (approximately north of San Luis Obispo along the
> 
> coast and 37 degrees N at the Nevada border).
> 
> Similar catalog information is available via finger quake@ these machines:
> 
> geophys.washington.edu, fm.gi.alaska.edu, eas.eas.slu.edu, gldfs.cr.usgs.gov,
> 
> seismo.unr.edu, eqinfo.seis.utah.edu, scec.caltech.edu, tako.wr.usgs.gov
> 
> WWW access: for these lists, maps, and more go to http://quake.usgs.gov
>

At 3:26 PM 12/1/95, Ann Elizabeth Loraine wrote:
>At Burning Man I hear that THE camp to be at was the WBLights RV circle,
>covered by a now legendary parachute.

They had a cool set-up (gotta say the trampoline was a nice touch), but
really that only furthers the elitist mentality.

Being at Burning Man was legendary.  No matter where your camp was, whether
it was at WBL, Wicked, F-8, ravers camp, main camp, Rhea and T-Fred's car,
our rental van, the Syntonic Circle, at the mud baths, the outrageous car
park, alone on the playa, or somewhere under that amazing double rainbow,
it was an incredible experience.

As Kerouac wrote: Comparisons are odious.

I think New Moon needs to set up a shrine of unparalleled proportion next
year, and I for one will help.

Take care of those colds people.  And hey...let's be freaks out there!

Love ya!

Tony

Ok things are getting too wacky here for me not to respond.
Black Adder, I was personally part of the putting on the Tribal Future
party in Mendicino along with the other Ameba posse: Mark, Allen, Tracy as
well as help from many others. The was no private encampment for anyone!
everyone was free to set up camp wherever they wanted. The only
restrictions from going to visit anyone anywhere were they ones you
apparently put on yourself:). One of the great things about that party was
the fact that it was totally outdoors on some beautiful land where anyone
COULD go anywhere. I know of no one else who felt left out from anything
there.
As for Burning Man, I'm confused as to the bus you are refering to. In the
Wicked Camp, there was a group of RV's scattered about. One of them was
The one I rented. It was completely open to ANYONE who felt like coming in
to visit and pick up some amazing cooked food. I can't think of any one
bus or RV that would be considered the "wicked bus". Markie was on ours,
Garth brought his jeep, and CB's silver bus that Ann was freaked out by
was not even at Burning Man!
In the future try to analyze just who really puts up the barriers you
perceive. Maybe the solution to dissovling them comes from yourself;)

andrew

> there.
> As for Burning Man, I'm confused as to the bus you are refering to. In the
> Wicked Camp, there was a group of RV's scattered about. One of them was
> The one I rented. It was completely open to ANYONE who felt like coming in
> to visit and pick up some amazing cooked food. I can't think of any one
> bus or RV that would be considered the "wicked bus". Markie was on ours,
> Garth brought his jeep, and CB's silver bus that Ann was freaked out by

I never stated there was a "private" encampment. Just that the wicked 
crew set up camp away from everyone else. This in and of itself is not 
something a group should be dissed for. It's certainly a free country and 
everyone should camp where they want. 

However, this was combined with previous negative experiences surrounding 
Wicked including seeing a member of another production company(a very 
nice and caring person) in tears at Burning Man because they attempted to
bring the various sound systems together and were rejected by the Wicked crew 
for reasons of petty ego. There are other reasons and incidents including 
the whole FMR thing, but it is not my wish to air other peoples' dirty laundry
here. They can speak for themselves if they wish. 

> In the future try to analyze just who really puts up the barriers you
> perceive. Maybe the solution to dissovling them comes from yourself;)
> 
> andrew

I do not make baseless assertations.  

Since you are asking me to do something reasonable, I ask you to do the 
same. In the future, consider the possibility that although your 
perception of a person/event/thing differs from that of another, that 
that person is not wrong because their perception or experience differs 
from yours. 

                                        Black Adder

Hey all: 
Yes I did, sometime this afternoon.. it felt like the old warehouse 
building that I was in (SoMa), was feeling a bit of its age.  I remember 
hearing a creak on one end of the office, but not really that much of 
movement. The person next to me said, "Did you feel *that*!?", his eyes 
really big and scary.  To me, someone was just re-adjusting the ceiling or 
something. Intereseting, but not as exciting as it could have been!

cheers,
mrfrog

On Fri, 1 Dec 1995 blkadder@value.net wrote:
> > bus or RV that would be considered the "wicked bus". Markie was on ours,
> > Garth brought his jeep, and CB's silver bus that Ann was freaked out by
> > was not even at Burning Man!
> 
> I never stated there was a "private" encampment. Just that the wicked 
> crew set up camp away from everyone else. This in and of itself is not 
> something a group should be dissed for. It's certainly a free country and 
> everyone should camp where they want. 
>
Umm, Hmmm, well I was at Tribal Future, (and I guess I could be considered
part of the Wicked Crew) but as far as that party was concerned, Wicked 
as a group or posse or Crew did not attend, the Wicked sound system was used
and the Engineering crew that goes out with it was definitely there, 
Garth was there (not as "Wicked" but as Garth) and I guess some people who
regularly attend Wicked parties were there as well, I forgot my sleeping
bag and didn't even set up camp, I know garth set his camp up on the "hill"
but maybe he wanted a little privacy :)  I think you are mistaking people
who have been partying together for several years as some sort of elitism,
there are people who I see at parties that I have been seeing for over
4 years, I don't even know there names some of them but to me they are like
family because they have been there when I had some truly wonderful
experiences,  there is a level of trust and a bond that you develop
with people that you have strong experiences with.  You kinda know they
will look out for you and you for them, it's almost an unspoken thing, but
you et them use your tent or hang out in your van because you know they will
watch out for your stuff when your not there (as if it was their own)
I guess the word is Family (some of you remember when we used to refer to
the entire Scene as The Family)  In any event maybe the vibe you are feeling
has something to do with the fact that you are not a familiar face and 
people don't know you, I'm aware of the rockstar energy that you are talking
about and I must say that for them most part, it is energy that people
PROJECT on the Wicked DJs.  Iv've known them all for a few years and some
of them I've become good very good friends with and I must sy that of all
of the DJs around they seem to be primarily concerned with playing their
music and throwing their parties.  They are human, they are not angels 
(nor are they devils as some would have you believe) they are just people 
with the same quirks, and failings and amazing qualities as you and me.
THe major difference is that they take what they are doing seriously,
they are professional DJs, that is what they do, and how they make their 
livelyhood, they are also having a great-time doing it.  (It seems that
in our culture if someone is following their dream and they are happy and
are making ends meet financialy, someone will have a problem with it)

 
> However, this was combined with previous negative experiences surrounding 
> Wicked including seeing a member of another production company(a very 
> nice and caring person) in tears at Burning Man because they attempted to
> bring the various sound systems together and were rejected by the Wicked crew 
> for reasons of petty ego.

Umm I'm just going to be blunt here, frankly you don't know what the fuck 
your talking about.  The person who had that idea may have been coming 
from a good place but they definitely were not a sound engineer and 
frankly they haven't been throwing parties long enough to see the full
ramifications of their "good ideas".  Not all at burningman was sweetness and
"Light" but there wasn't any greater or lesser battle of egos then there is
at any event, with 400 square miles of space, a solution existed and was
found that seemed to make all of the owners of the respective sound systems
happy.  Maybe that person's agenda was not satisfied but then they have a 
whole year to plan for it this time, instead of trying to instantiate
a dream at the last moment with no logistics or planning.

The bottom line at Burning Man is that the Wicked Crew was there to deliver
The Music,  it is a passion for them,  they may choose to work with or
without other groups based on their perception of whether those groups
have the same passion and logistical tenacity, (in full moons past,
we have done everything from playing in full on rain showers to facing
a hoard of riot police with dogs and clubs and guns).  One of my
most amazing memories at Burning Man was to see this desert rains storm
come up on Saturday night while Garth was playing and THE PARTY CONTINUED,
some attendants (and it wasn't someone that I think you would consider
part of the elite possee:) materialized some tarps and shielded Garth
and turntables from the wind and rain so that he could keep playing 
(which he did!) With thunder and lightning all around.  Maybe it is that
bond that is between Wicked party-goers and the producers that seems to
either enthral or piss-off certain people.  In March wicked will have 
been throwing parties in San Francisco for 5 years, there aren't many 
promoters around who have been here that long, the only ones that I can
think of is Choice (Gathering, Vision), Funky Techno Tribe and of course
Preston, when you've been doing it that long, you know what works and most
of all what doesn't work (because you have been down that path before)
It is very important to us that the party go off and that they are 
consistant,  in the current climate in SF it is VERY difficult to
have a consistant good quality outside of the Club VEnue, this sucks 
frankly but ask yourself or others when was the last time that a Wicked 
didn't happen or when people didn't get a full night of music and dancing 
for their money.

WE take our Music seriously.

> There are other reasons and incidents including 
> the whole FMR thing, but it is not my wish to air other peoples' dirty laundry
> here. They can speak for themselves if they wish. 
> 
Oh really? Well I know at least Jeno and Markie are on the list (as well as
myself) Please feel free to speak your mind, I'm all ears, or if you
prefer you can send private e-mail to myself or wicked@cyborganic.com
or info@wicked.com

> > In the future try to analyze just who really puts up the barriers you
> > perceive. Maybe the solution to dissovling them comes from yourself;)
> > 
> > andrew
> 
> I do not make baseless assertations.  
> 
Perhapse not, but you do make assertions without knowing many of the 
facts about which you speak.

> Since you are asking me to do something reasonable, I ask you to do the 
> same. In the future, consider the possibility that although your 
> perception of a person/event/thing differs from that of another, that 
> that person is not wrong because their perception or experience differs 
> from yours. 

Consider Black Adder that I have known many of the people about which you 
speak for several years, consider also that I have seen many people come
around Wicked hang out and leave, either disgruntled or just fade away,
in 90% of the cases, they projected some for of demigod status on one of 
the members and were disappointed when the person didn't live up to the 
image that they had decided to set for them.  Fortunately the Wicked DJs
are not rockstars and don't desire to be, maybe other people that hang 
around them might want to turn them into that because they want the 
presteige of being with "the boys in the band" but that is thier problem,
I have seen for myself that these guys (as much as is possible for any
object of hero worship) have shunned this type of attention, usually the 
person giving it either steps it up or goes away mad, The Boys simply 
continue to play records, THAT is what they are about.

or anything like that although if people didn't recognize you they might
watch you a little, I think you have a serious inferiority complex
when it come to "Wicked" and you really shouldn't why many of the wicked
posse can't even spell :)

> The "ultra-elite" bus - is this that silver bus that somebody named JB

lady.  How would you feel if someone just walked into your living room?

rave you need to make some adjustments but bear in mind that there is 
nothing going on here any more than someone looking out for their own

(for good or ill) is not just an adventure but a way of life :)

That's the one thing that scares the shit out of me about San Francisco - 
the Earthquakes!  I'm counting the days that I can move out of Sacramento 
and into the City, yet every single time I'm driving over the Bay Bridge 
I say to myself, "god, please don't let there be one NOW!"   I also got a 
bit nervous while in that warehouse that Family and F&F was held in.  
There was a warning on the door before you went inside that said 
soemthing to the effect of, "this building is earthquake condemned, 
enter at your own risk."   I'm scared about it, but what can you do?  
Absolutely nothing.  I've decided to just live it up until *that day* 
arrives.  

love,

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Dec  2 11:06:12 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA04152; Sat, 2 Dec 1995 11:06:12 -0800
Received: from dons.ac.usfca.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA04141; Sat, 2 Dec 1995 11:06:09 -0800
Message-Id: <199512021906.LAA04141@taz.hyperreal.com>
Date: Sat, 2 Dec 95 11:01:54 PST
X-Sender: lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Matthew D. P. K. Lanier)
Subject: xntrk!
Cc: tripje00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-

i went to xntrk last night, and found it to be a rather cool experience.  i
got to meet wayne, ricki, and tim (sfravers) there, and, once again, felt
rather connected to the scene that i had left for a semester.  hope to see
you all at gathering!
at first, xntrk had more of a club feel, with the normal groups of men in
circles watching one person dance and try to impress women, and with huge
numbers of people that i'm sure must have slipped the guards something to
let them in, despite the 18+ rule.  that was during carlos's set.
when tony came on, WOW! the atmosphere changed.  with the change from heavy
house to somewhat trance-like stuff, the dance floor was transformed into
what i had remembered from past raves: a bunch of people dancing without
trying to impress each other.  i was much happier.
lights were cool, but nothing too phat.  visuals were boring, with the
now-expected clips from the 1950's sub-conscious that have become so "retro
and alternative!"  it shut down at 3:45, for some reason, and they were
quite unkind about it.  i wish it could have gone on for longer, but hey, i
had a blast.
i would recomend parties by these people more, except for the steep price
tag and the unavability of water (except for $2 a bottle!!}  they need more
visuals, and to get a larger chill space, it was rather crouded.
THE FRUIT WAS A GREAT IDEA!  free fruit was given out around 2:30, a perfect
suplement to my alrEady vitamin dEfEciEnt body.

that is the review of XNTRK.  IF YOU HAVE NO INTEREST IN PSYCHOLOGY NOR THE
PERSONAL JOURNEY OF RAVERS, READ NO FURTHER.  MATT


if you do have interest in my story at XNTRK, read on, for it is a HAPPY one.

for the past 3 months, i have been suffering from an incredible depression
from a number of factors: bad living arrangements, bad relationship with
some friends, removal from a choir that i loved, you know, all factors that,
alone, might not phase you, but together, can drive you crazy, as i have
been.  thus, i have not been to a rave for 3 months, because i haven't been
able to make it to one, and because i didn't feel i had the energy to do so.
life was not a bowl of cherries.

so, last night, my girlfriend tells me "Matt, you must go to a rave.  you
hate living without raves, so GO!! NOW!"  so, i did.  i got there, (insert
review from above).  I was sober for the first while, feeling afraid to do
anything for fear of what my emotional state would do.  but then, i decided,
this rave is going to be a turning point in my life, in some way: tonite,
either i'm going to go crazy and lose it totally, or i'm going to begin to
enjoy life and LIVE again!  i thought about it, and decided that i trusted
where i was enough to give it a try.  so i did givE it a try.  I thought,
I'm going to trust myself to have the right reaction, and i'm gonna trust
the people around here to help me take care of myself.

just as i was starting to peak and getting to that "I need to be with
someone NOW" phase (i don't know if other people go through that, but i
definitely do) i went to sit in the chill room.  now, normally, i don't just
walk up and talk to people, but there was a group of people that just looked
inviting.  so i went up to them, offered some of my aroma-therapy (from the
body shop) and started hanging.  they were the coolest ravers i have met in
eons!  i told them i was alone and wanted to hang, and they told me to stay
with them, and we'd keep each other company.  that was the biggest gift i
had been given by anyone in a long time.  needless to say, at that point, my
whole mindset shifted from "life sucks" to "people can be cool if you let
them"  to "WOW!"  

so we hung, gave back rubs, and exchanged phone numbers and all that stuff.
if was a very healing experience.  they would not let me go anywhere without
making sure that i came back to be with them more.  it was just what i needed.

so, to clare, a 17-year old brit, thanks for making my night.  and to josh,
a typical 20-something, thanks too.

thanks for listening to my story.  now i remember why i rave.  because i
love people, i love life, and i love myself.


peace, love, and utter happiness-

matt


matthew d. p. k. lanier
vox 415-666-5659

"Peace within us, peace over us, peace under our feet.
peace behind us, peace around us, let all around us be peace."
     - David Haas

On Sat, 2 Dec 1995, ameba wrote:

> Cool - Spaz controversy. Wicked bashing is too fashionable. Lets get into SPAZ dirt.... What's all this United Systems stuff?
> 
> allen@ameba 
> 
> 
O.K. I knew this would happen, that's why I was frettin' putting out that
post.  To make it short, there was some talk of changing the SPAZ name
to United Systems, but some of us felt that ALOT of hard work was put
into making SPAZ as a name and concept, so why should it change?
Let me state that I believe in the United Systems concept and for it to
happen their has to be MORE then one sound system involved (united is
a grouping of something isn't it?)  Basically we felt you can't call
something United Systems and keep having Aaron bring his soundsystem
ALL the time - that guy does so much for the scene and he seems to get
no respect, except from his mates of course. 
 O.K. I really don't want to stir anymore dirt up ALLEN :)
so, I'll put in a blurp for my web page - Shakti Science, which will
cover my label (1st release - Space Farm - Egyptology VOL. 1), SPAZ
Shakti Science and Planet 6 studio, sound files, etc.  I'm even thinking
of uploading the diary I wrote when me, Aarron, Jen, Jake (Subtropic),
Danya, and Lisa (Aarron's sister) traveled from New York to San Francisco
in fall of 1992.  I do remember some pages mentioning the Charter Oak
parties, 1st TAZ party, general collective mayem!  You want to see dirt...  :)


peace out
Liquid Acrobat
Shakti Science Studio

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Dec  2 15:06:06 1995

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: this elitist dj stuff...
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9512021458.A19759-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I've read both Black Adder and Geoff White's sides of the story and both 
have valid points.  
I agree with Geoff in that it is the people that project the "rock star" 
image onto the dj's - however I think that some of these dj's project an 
attitude that perpetuates that image.  Let me explain myself:
Right off the top of my head I can think of 2 big name dj's that do not 
have that unappoachableness about them:  Carlos and Tony.  Know why?  
Because they come out and join us ravers in dancing before or after their 
set. They "become one of us" so to speak.  Carlos is always so 
enthusiastic about the music and he cheers and really gets into it.  He 
smiles at people and is very open and friendly to anyone who comes up to 
talk to him.  Tony is just plain sweet - he's out there dancing with the 
rest of us and you go up and talk to him and he greets you with a hug or 
a hand shake.  

Now I have *YET* to see Garth or Spun out there dancing with the rest of 
us.  I always see them on the side having some serious conversation or 
looking solomn.  Just their aura about them is rather intimidating.  This 
is purely *my* perception, for I'm sure that it is not that way with 
other people.  I feel much more at ease with *anybody* - dj or no dj - 
that is smiling and looking like they are having a good time.  This may 
just be Garth or Spun's personalities - and there is nothing wrong with 
that - but I can see how their aloofness along with their high demand at 
different venues could cause many people to think they are on a rock star 
trip.  And of course it is not *their* problem that people think that way 
about them - I don't *dislike* them for being that way, I could just 
never go up and talk to them.  I just listen to the music they spin, 
dance, have a great time, and socialize with the many other people there 
who have more inviting personalities!  Long live diversity.....

love,
Amy

|     |U|     |         sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu

On Sat, 2 Dec 1995, Amy R Starkey wrote:
> 
> Now I have *YET* to see Garth or Spun out there dancing with the rest of 
> us.  I always see them on the side having some serious conversation or 
> looking solomn.  Just their aura about them is rather intimidating.  This 
> is purely *my* perception, for I'm sure that it is not that way with 
> other people.  I feel much more at ease with *anybody* - dj or no dj - 
> that is smiling and looking like they are having a good time.  This may 
> just be Garth or Spun's personalities - and there is nothing wrong with 
> that - but I can see how their aloofness along with their high demand at 
> different venues could cause many people to think they are on a rock star 
> trip.  And of course it is not *their* problem that people think that way 
> about them - I don't *dislike* them for being that way, I could just 
> never go up and talk to them.  I just listen to the music they spin, 
> dance, have a great time, and socialize with the many other people there 
> who have more inviting personalities!  Long live diversity.....


That's funny, because off the top of my head I can come up with at least 
4 times in the last year , the Flowerchild before last, the free 
Gathering at City Hall, the Chemical Bros. show at the Troc., & the 
last Sunset at Richmond, where there were Garth sightings of the man 
doing anything from standing around with a stack of Wicked flyers, to 
talking to somebody, to swaying from side to side, to rocking out in the 
company of mixed people. From what I've seen it looks like familar and 
unfamilar people have aproached him at times, and there always seems to 
be at least one pack of goonies present who'll shout out a "Norm" -isk 
battle cry / greating from afar.  

Yeah, I know it's rude to stare, and No, I'm not stalking the guy. It's 
just that each time I witness one of these incidents it reminds me of 
long distance letters & conversations I had with friends ((the majority of 
whom are presentlly in the dry cycle in terms raving)) who mentioned 
similar moments, that of breakdancing or something next to Garth, as one 
of the better moments of their night. You can file that memory under 
Naive Hero-Worship or Working Class Unity or whatever, but at the time it 
served as a huge ego-boost for a lot of people. I'd venture to say that 
effect still happens today.

I know of a few people that have developed some kind of personal bond 
with Garth in particular. They measure their lives in terms of how far 
they've developed between each of their experiences and the earliest of 
their benchmarks starts at a time when Garth was sporting that poffy afro 
to the nappy dreads that he has today. It's kind of like the same 
emotional attachment you get from watching Gary Collman grow up in front 
of you and every now and then you just get the urge to go up Garth and 
give the guy a donut or something.

hey guys (and i am not pointing any fingers - i am just responding after 
i can't take it anymore) - the point of this thing should not be to dis 
this party or that party.  it should be to share information and network 
about parties and sounds.  when too many people say too many nasty 
things, this just takes away the whole point of a "rave" group.  whether 
or not we agree on sounds or styles, we should at least know (i hope) that 
we all want the same results - to dance and to spread happiness.  who 
cares about the politics...

        sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: this elitist dj stuff...
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Actually, I know both Garth and Spun a bit and neither of them is 
at all stuck-up or unfriendly as Amy may have thought.  If anything,
both of them are more approachable than other people I know around
the circuit.  Tony's always been friendly, I think in part he has
had to work against the fact that when he first moved here he was
unknown and didn't have a support network to fall back on, but 
he also just seems to like being in the thick of things.  As for
Carlos, well, the man's a force of nature :)

Now Garth more or less started as a dancefloor punter like all of us,
and I've seen him kick up the dust many times when the time is right.
And Spun is a very perceptive and talkative guy too.  

Being a bit of a DJ myself, I can put myself in the shoes of those
we've known and admired.  I think with some exceptions DJs generally
are not rockstar types at all.  Certainly Djs like attention and respect,
and no DJ I know objects if someone just comes up to chat, the only
things that seem to miss the mark are people who either want to do a
little DJ adulation or else are picking an argument, and I've seen DJs
clam up immediately when people approached them that way.  

As Geoff said, for the most part you'll discover that DJs are basically
just the same as the rest of us, with all the ups and downs that offers.
Neither saints nor demons . . .

phred


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec  3 09:14:13 1995

Hello cyberfolk,

I couldn't decide on either the Troc nor Focus so I gave Wicked a whirl.

I figured out a few things through the experiance...

First: NEVER dance on a hard wood floor w/china flats on. my shoes just a
kept flying off leavin' me to dance away in my tosties...

Second: Wicked, IMOP (in my own perception), still seems a tad bit clubish
for my tastes.  Although I Love House (after all, house is where the heart
is), I saw the typical clubish 'tude being sported from a good portion of the
crowd.  I also got a few weird looks cuz of me dancin' in my tosties....

Finally: Although the tunes were decent the feedback was, well, in a word:
 Yecch.

Overall I really had a good time.  Saw a few of ya'll out there.  The $15
wasn't a big pinch from the pocketbook considering it's in support of the
scene an all. 
For all of you who might of seem me I was the guy in the black jeans, white T
shirt, Brasil cap, and Purple Long sleeve tied around my neck (don't forget
the tosties...)


=) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =)Smile'O'meter=) =) =) =) =) =) =) =)=)
=) =) =) =) 

Music:  8.5 Smiles (it got me groovin)

Vibe:    8 Smiles (lotsa vibey peoples that i watched fer a bit)

Dancing media:  9 Smiles (woulda been great if I had my white soez on)

Smiles and Hugz: 7.5 Smiles (A lil' clubby)

Overall: A strong 8.25 Fun fun fun....


In closing.  I actually enjoied reading the "Tribal Funk war" posties...  It
really goes to show how everything is really just how we each percieve things
soo differently (almost as differently as I spell things, ha ha).  Even Amy
with her Wicked posts. No one is immune to this....affliction? Blessing? 
This lil review is just sensless drivel to some("Blech, Adam never gives an
overall review that's under seven"),  To others it's an indicator ("oh, WOW,
we gotta check thiz out next time...").
but, if you take it for what it's worth...it's just words. An opinion. Im not
Siskel or Ebert.  Im not getting PAID to write these... Im just a guy that
goes to raves (picking up stray ravers here and there), dances his ass off
till he hobles his way home in the morning.  And writes what he thought about
it...  I don't go into much detail cos, well, there others that will do that
for ya...

Have a GR-R-R-R-R-R-EAT week (if it's anything like mine remember: We are
just a means to an end, which dosen't end but merges to something much bigger
than this exsistence we all call life.  What does that mean... I dunno (well
I do really.  But I wouldn't want to spoil it so you go fig.),


Spins,

Adam

I would just like to take this moment to apologize for the recent flame 
war which hopefully most of you ignored. 

I still feel the way I feel. A hint to all: Telling someone "they don't 
know what the fuck they are talking about", does not generally endear 
them to your point of view.

It always facinates me how people can focus on one negative aspect of an 
otherwise neutral/positive post, get bent out of shape, and the fur just 
starts flying. 

I am sure most of you don't care. DON'T! It is all a bunch of bullshit 
anyways, and will suck the energy right out of you if you let it(I'm 
learning) :)

Have a *GREAT* Day

                                            Black Adder

occureded on sfraves.  could it have occured by private e-mail?  some
arguements that i have gotten in over sfraves i have continued, quite
vivaciously, over my private e-mail.  just a suggestion, that could benefit
us all.

was sig around the fire and sing happy songs.  but disgression is needed at
times to protect the innocent.

peace, love, and arguments-

Sun, Dec 3, 1995 1:52 AM EDT, Kevin Keiper wrote:

>the point of this thing should not be to dis this party or that >party.  it
should be to share information and network about >parties and sounds.  when
too many people say too many nasty 
>things, this just takes away the whole point of a "rave" group.  >whether or
not we agree on sounds or styles, we should at >least know (i hope) that we
all want the same results - to >dance and to spread happiness.  who cares
about the politics...

Hey, thanks for posting this. I was reading the whole Wicked debate last
night and rolling my eyes. That comment about them being superstars may have
been "innocent", but what kind of a thing is that to post on a public list?
It's a bunch of gossip and hearsay. Wicked always throws a good party-that's
all I care about. 

Let me share a story with you all. When I first subscribed to  sfraves, a
friend of mine (who once subscribed, then cancelled) said to me, "You don't
want to get involved with those people. They're a bunch of whiners." When I
pressed him further for details, he said "Oh, they whine about the music,
they whine about the parties, they whine about the dj's, they're never happy
with anything." I didn't see it at first, but I am starting to. 

I have my sfraves laminate, but I haven't been wearing it. That in itself
should tell you what my mixed feelings are about our little group. I would
like to suggest that before we start posting gossipy crap, we should sit down
and think "Who is going to read this?" and "What kind of impression is this
going to make?" I am all too aware that there are plenty of legitimate gripes
about the scene. I feel It's OK to post a few critical comments about a party
you didn't like. A rave review, which encompasses the positive and negative
comments about a party is fine w/ me (like the one Adma just wrote). But
let's try to keep the bitchy comments to ourselves, shall we? 
Happy to just be alive,
MsPhink

ms phink wrote
> I would like to suggest that before we start posting gossipy crap, we
>should >sit down and think "Who is going to read this?" and "What kind of
>impression is >this going to make?"

ive gotta disagree with you on that one...i don't want to belong to a list
where everyone censors their comments according to what impression they are
going to make...its not a bad thing to have a discussion and disagree, in
fact, it gets people thinking about what the hell is going on...so...i
don't think people have to resort to mean comments, but at the same
time..im certainly not going to tailor my comments for this list..i will
endure the flames thanks...
btw..i CAN see both sides of this..i have seen the wicked crew seeming like
they are rockstars, etc...but as a dj, i think people like to project this
image on to you and most dj's i know aren't necessarily that into going out
or dancing even though they like the music..usually, they are a bit quieter
than you're average raver-but most don't have an attitude if approached...
gotta put in my two cents i guess..but i hope it ends here
**starEyes**

YAH! Best $8.00 ever spent.  Woulda gladly payed another $8.00 to hear
him spin for another hour. (That kinda musick shouldn't have to conform
to the usual "rock show" formats and timings.)

EBN was ok, IMHO, but to me their schtick is getting old hat. Cool boyz
with toyz nonetheless, but you migth get just as much out of one of
their videos as you would from their live performances. This is just my
feelings/taste so there's no point in flaming me for an opinion. (ha!).

Amazing crowd transformation from standing around observing a
"industrial" show versus people gettin' down and trance-grooving to B
de G.

Wickyhead woulda probably been better if all my raving needs hadn't
previously been fulfilled by Banco de Gaia. Wish they'd get out of 174
King Street and into some other location, and wish the security guards
weren't so keen on confiscating my hollow wooden implements of
blunting.... :-(

All in all, a good time was had but I didn't feel like sticking around
for the house to be built at wicked, because i've already seen the sky
after you blow the roof off.

When is the full moon rave? Surely Wicky_head are joking when they said
the last full moon rave for the year was last month's -- it's so nice
and warm out!!

> Amy, I have to say you are dead wrong about these guys. Jason (Spun) is 
> the most down to earth DJ I've met & three years ago Garth used to be the 
> hardest dancing guy at most parties. I'm sure most people would have a 
> hard time dancing at parties if there were all these freaks staring at 
> and whispering about you. I mean if poor Jeno started going off, half the 
> people on the dancefloor would stop to look. What a bunch of freaks :)

Hi Josh, 
I'm actually glad to know that I am dead wrong - that is why I emphasized 
that it was purely *MY* perspective that I was making my claim.  I did 
not say that these wonderful dj's *were* that way, that is just how I 
felt. I feel intimidated by Garth, Spun, Jeno, and many others and I 
cannot go up and talk to them.  That is just ***ME*** and I can't help 
the way I feel.  I'm sure they are wonderful people, but for someone who 
is -believe it or not- sometimes quite shy, I can't just go up and start 
talking. Especially when they have umpteen million people clapping them 
on the back saying, "Wow, that was a great set!"  Maybe they get tired of 
hearing that out of everyone's mouth. I don't want to sound that way.  
I want to make it clear that I am *NOT* bashing these great dj's.  Spun's 
set at New Year's Eve '92/'93 was the first time in my life I **REALLY** 
danced hard core.  I love and respect all dj's, but just like the other 
people in the world, there are some that I feel intimidated by.  That's 
all I meant. :)     Will you be at the Gathering, Joshie?

love,
Amy

I'll be damned if this group is going to be painted as a bunch of whiners.

#1.  We've been there, paid our dues, done the do, etc.  We not only
     have a right to say what we think (and to disagree with each other
     and plenty), but we have a damn *good* right.

#2.  We do pretty well managing our disputes.  Over the years, I can
     only think of a couple of times when things got out of hand.
     That's a very good track record.

#3.  Certain people within the scene are very good at pointing out the
     supposed faults of others, in part to deflect attention from 
     themselves.  I've seen it, you may have too.  Enough said.

#4.  This is certainly no exclusive club.  Anyone with access to any
     old computer and email can participate.  If we are "whiners,"
     at least we do it out in the open which is more than I can say
     for some others.

Only my own $0.02.  Spend it well :)

phred

	id TAA27919; Sun, 3 Dec 1995 19:07:54 -0800
Date: Sun, 3 Dec 1995 19:07:54 -0800

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Wicked facts.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I have been going to Wicked for a number of years (I'm embarassed to admit
how long), and know the people who are involved with the posse/party.

First I want to say that I have found them not to be stuck up.  If
anything, shy would be an appropriate description of how they act in
public.

Wicked has never tried to rip anyone off.  Wicked was the last party to
raise the cover to their party to $15.  This took them YEARS to do.  Wicked
gives back to the community in the form of FREE FMM's (Full Moon Massives).

Once you get to know them, the people involved with Wicked are genuinely
nice.  When I first got involved w/ the scene here in SF, there was a
Wicked clique, but the boys (i.e. the DJ's) really never got caught up in
that shit.  It was something that formed around them.  It happens to all
parties/crews if they last and gain a rep.  But Wicked itself is about
music, period.  Other people have other motives, but theirs remains true.

I don't understand the bs surrounding them.  It's actually funny.  I've
heard more DJ's and promoters talk shit about them, people who are
disgruntled over whatever talk about them, old-timers bust their balls etc.
Basically I've heard much more about them from others than the Wicked crew
themselves.  I have yet to hear ANY of the Wicked DJ's dis anyone publicly.
I doubt they really give a shit about anything other than their music.
Kinda takin' the high road on that one.  Admirable.  Especially considering
the shit-talkin' do nothings who foist thier exepctations upon them, and
when they don't live up to that external ideal, they are immediately
faulted.

Fact is, the celebrity is created by YOU, those who have nothing better to
do than talk about them.  Those who have nothing better to do than pass
judgements on people you know jack shit about (how many of you have sat
down with Markie, Jeno, Garth, Thomas, Neil, GeoffW, Stephanie, Monya, etc.
about what Wicked is all about?  I doubt many have.).  Sad.  What's even
more sad is the total lack of historical perspective, but this is a problem
exists in the national conscious as well, too big to go into here, suffice
it to say, some history would do well for many  on this list.

Muthafuckas put on a free party every month, and yet they STILL aren't
doing the right thing because they didn't dance next to you.  Muthfuckas
have kept thier prices reasonable for years, and yet you will hear cries of
$15 is too much.  Muthafuckas throw a consistently good party, and all you
hear are the moans and groans of physically challenged griping about them
using a smokey venue (one of the three they can use at ALL).  Muthfuckas
give you all a Wednesday party, and people gripe that it's on the same day
as another club.  Muthfukas buy a brand new trubosound system, and people
complain it's too loud, too soft, to trebbly, too whatever.  Complain,
complain, complain.  Just goes to prove, there will always be something.
With that in mind is it any wonder they have a give-a-shit attitude at
times (essential for underground parties, which BTW they've done their
share of here in the city), THERE WILL ALWAYS BE SOMEONE COMPLAINING ABOUT
SOMETHING SO WHY BOTHER EXPLAINING YOURSELF?

Gripe, bitch, moan, groan, throw onto them all your expectations, continue
to judge w/o ever talking to any of them, bag, slag, bust balls
whatever...there will always be something not to like.

This PLUR shit spouted on this list is another artifact. Peace, Love,
Unity, Respect...maybe we need to add tolerance (severaly lacking here at
times), to that near-religious acronym.  Otherwise it ain't for shit.

Funny BS on the street:
Funny how some DJ's use to worship, even idolize the Wicked posse.  When
these folx found out how human the Wicked crew was, you heard all kinds of
verbal nastiness about them...from the same people who worshipped them a
few years ago.  It must be terrible to build up these mythic expectations
of a group of people, only to be let down by their humanity.  Oh, not to
worry, just blame them for failing to live up to your expectations.  What a
wack ass sorry punk bitch way to be.

Party:
Unlike others who merely wish to bring in new talent, Wicked did it again
by bringing in Roger S.  Good show, although the mix wasn't as tight as
Little Louie a few weeks back.  Jeno had his typical good set.  Roger S.
was fine, Astral Matrix was great, Garth did a nice intro for Roger S.
went home and talked about the lack of women at this particular Wicked with
some of my crew.  This Wicked seemd to be boys night out (witness the
thrall of men surrounding the decks this time), shirts were optional.

Near gripe:
Dear stinky people who really think it's ok not to take a bath for a few
days, take off your shirt, and start to sweat and dance at parties: please,
take a bath.  Next time I smell one of you, I will point it out in a most
direct manner.  I have enough olfactory assualt with the constant smoking
while dancing, weed, general humidity, and that stinky Wicked net, without
having to smell some dude/dudette who has the notion that bathing is a sin
against nature.  With that said, I KNOW nothing will come of this.  But I
had to say it anyway, for all the stinky people in the house.


To all the Wicked crew an posse, nice one.  To all do nothing,
back-stabbing, griping, bitching, moaning, groaning, detractors...bugger
off.

Out,
John

THANK YOU JOHN! for hitting the muthafuckin nail on the head!

i love you man:)

andrew

> 
> I have been going to Wicked for a number of years (I'm embarassed to admit
> how long), and know the people who are involved with the posse/party.
> 
> First I want to say that I have found them not to be stuck up.  If
> anything, shy would be an appropriate description of how they act in
> public.
> 
> Wicked has never tried to rip anyone off.  Wicked was the last party to
> raise the cover to their party to $15.  This took them YEARS to do.  Wicked
> gives back to the community in the form of FREE FMM's (Full Moon Massives).
> 
> Once you get to know them, the people involved with Wicked are genuinely
> nice.  When I first got involved w/ the scene here in SF, there was a
> Wicked clique, but the boys (i.e. the DJ's) really never got caught up in
> that shit.  It was something that formed around them.  It happens to all
> parties/crews if they last and gain a rep.  But Wicked itself is about
> music, period.  Other people have other motives, but theirs remains true.
> 
> I don't understand the bs surrounding them.  It's actually funny.  I've
> heard more DJ's and promoters talk shit about them, people who are
> disgruntled over whatever talk about them, old-timers bust their balls etc.
> Basically I've heard much more about them from others than the Wicked crew
> themselves.  I have yet to hear ANY of the Wicked DJ's dis anyone publicly.
> I doubt they really give a shit about anything other than their music.
> Kinda takin' the high road on that one.  Admirable.  Especially considering
> the shit-talkin' do nothings who foist thier exepctations upon them, and
> when they don't live up to that external ideal, they are immediately
> faulted.
> 
> Fact is, the celebrity is created by YOU, those who have nothing better to
> do than talk about them.  Those who have nothing better to do than pass
> judgements on people you know jack shit about (how many of you have sat
> down with Markie, Jeno, Garth, Thomas, Neil, GeoffW, Stephanie, Monya, etc.
> about what Wicked is all about?  I doubt many have.).  Sad.  What's even
> more sad is the total lack of historical perspective, but this is a problem
> exists in the national conscious as well, too big to go into here, suffice
> it to say, some history would do well for many  on this list.
> 
> Muthafuckas put on a free party every month, and yet they STILL aren't
> doing the right thing because they didn't dance next to you.  Muthfuckas
> have kept thier prices reasonable for years, and yet you will hear cries of
> $15 is too much.  Muthafuckas throw a consistently good party, and all you
> hear are the moans and groans of physically challenged griping about them
> using a smokey venue (one of the three they can use at ALL).  Muthfuckas
> give you all a Wednesday party, and people gripe that it's on the same day
> as another club.  Muthfukas buy a brand new trubosound system, and people
> complain it's too loud, too soft, to trebbly, too whatever.  Complain,
> complain, complain.  Just goes to prove, there will always be something.
> With that in mind is it any wonder they have a give-a-shit attitude at
> times (essential for underground parties, which BTW they've done their
> share of here in the city), THERE WILL ALWAYS BE SOMEONE COMPLAINING ABOUT
> SOMETHING SO WHY BOTHER EXPLAINING YOURSELF?
> 
> Gripe, bitch, moan, groan, throw onto them all your expectations, continue
> to judge w/o ever talking to any of them, bag, slag, bust balls
> whatever...there will always be something not to like.
> 
> This PLUR shit spouted on this list is another artifact. Peace, Love,
> Unity, Respect...maybe we need to add tolerance (severaly lacking here at
> times), to that near-religious acronym.  Otherwise it ain't for shit.
> 
> Funny BS on the street:
> Funny how some DJ's use to worship, even idolize the Wicked posse.  When
> these folx found out how human the Wicked crew was, you heard all kinds of
> verbal nastiness about them...from the same people who worshipped them a
> few years ago.  It must be terrible to build up these mythic expectations
> of a group of people, only to be let down by their humanity.  Oh, not to
> worry, just blame them for failing to live up to your expectations.  What a
> wack ass sorry punk bitch way to be.
> 
> Party:
> Unlike others who merely wish to bring in new talent, Wicked did it again

I was feeling a bit guilty about the last message I posted. I hope I didn't

I have a question: 
What is your favorite thing to do *after* a rave? Or what has been your most
memorable post-raving experience? I usually come home and listen to music
until I fall asleep. I also like reading comic books and other literature
that doesn't make me think too hard. Going to The End Up is also a fun
post-raving activity!! Anyone else???

Recently , MsPhink posted a new question to ponder:
> 
> I have a question: 
> What is your favorite thing to do *after* a rave? Or what has been your most
> memorable post-raving experience? 

 Usually , I'm hungry! I go eating at Sparky's if I'm in SF before other
restaurants are open. In the east bay , I eat at Mamma's Royal Cafe
for breakfast - I usually sleep in my truck until they open at 8AM.
On the coast , I eat at Zachary's after a FMR or some other beach/Santa
Cruz event.

 If I'm going to drive home straight afterwards, I have lots of coffee!
If not , I don't have caffiene with the meal - after the meal , I find
someplace to park and snooze for an hour or two. I like Ocean Beach as
a safe place to park and sleep in the morning.

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Forward:
Re: ECSTASY: ANOTHER UK DEATH!
A previous UK death was reported due to drinking 26 pints of water. To
die of drinking too much water is almost certainly due to compulsive
behaviour due to being scared about not drinking enough, and probably 
the
E numbing the warning discomfort that you would normally feel. You 
should
not worry about drinking too much water if you are aware of what you 
are
doing, or if any friends are looking after you. Its much more likely 
that
you will dehydrate by not drinking enough.
More on my site about the recent death
from Nicholas Saunders
--------------------------------------------------
Details of my new book Ecstasy and the Dance Culture; the entire book E
for Ecstasy; tests on 30 samples of Ecstasy (illustrated) and more can 
be
found on my site: http://www.cityscape.co.uk/users/bt22/
---- End Forwarded Message

Sorry, this'll be the last forward from alt.raves, I promise!  But I 
thought it was cute, and had to send it along.  Maybe we should send 
him a pamphlet about our local chapter?  :)

WHAT'S A RAVE?  I HEARD THAT ALL THESE PEOPLE DRESS UP IN BLACK AND DO
SUMMERSAULTS DOWN REALLY BIG SAND DUNES.  THEN THEY EAT PIZZA AND DRINK
SODA; MAYBE EVEN GO FOR A SWIM IF IT'S NOT TOO COLD.  I WANT TO KNOW IF
THERE'S A MEMBERSHIP FEE AND IF THERE ARE ANY LOCAL CHAPTERS.  THANKS.
                                    HORTON LANCASTER
                                    HENRRY00@DONS.AC.USFCA.EDU
---- End Forwarded Message

Hey

I did end up checking out VRave, actually, but I like the idea of doing 
channel #sfraves better.  VRave appears to have people from all over 
the world (from what was mentioned in the FAQ), and it was very 
difficult to get a word in edgewise, and to even get someone to respond 
to something I'd say.  Kind of a lack of the community feel I think 
everybody here's used to, since it's so big, so hence my like of the 
#sfraves channel idea.  Somebody should start it up!  What do you all 
think?


-S

Went with two friends who wanted to see EBN and didn't care about BdG
(thought it would be too ambient), and left the show talking only about how
great BdG was. I think _that_ is a great compliment.

And hats off to the dude running the lights. The lights became part of the
music and vibe - he was playing them like an instrument.

The whole show was great with the exception of the stupid video crew taping
EBN with a LIGHT ON THEIR CAMERA! Not only did they ruin the projections
and blind many of us, but they annoyed EBN as well.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec  4 08:59:32 1995

EBN was really cool overall, and I'm glad I saw them.  I wasn't into thier
music at all, and would probably never listen to thier cd, but thier whole
show was multimedia, and totally sinc'd up.  It made for a really cool
effect, I just wish they played music I was into.  Wouldn't pay to see them
again though, but am glad to have seen them once.

Now Banco de Gaia......whoaaaa.....let me tell ya......definately one of the
top three shows of my life.  It was neat to see the room transform from this
hard core industrial, dark, harsh, sreaming pit, to a totally spacious,
colorful, beautiful space.  It honestly felt like the room got bigger when
he came on.  Great light show.  I achieved probably one of the highest
*sober* states of consciousness that I have ever been to, and felt high as a
kite.  It was definately better than any drug experience I've had.  *Much*
respect goes out to him.

Subject: Re: Post raving fun
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 1:59 AM 12/4/95, MsPhink@aol.com wrote:

>I have a question:
>What is your favorite thing to do *after* a rave? Or what has been your most
>memorable post-raving experience? I usually come home and listen to music
>until I fall asleep. I also like reading comic books and other literature
>that doesn't make me think too hard. Going to The End Up is also a fun
>post-raving activity!! Anyone else???
>MsPhink


I'm psyched someone asked this, and the timing couldn't be more appropo.
Personally, after 8 hours or more of dancing and very loud music, I tend
not to focus on what music to listen to, but rather how to gently land my
heart, mind and soul back down to earth from it's ethereal orbit.  What I
have found is this concoction of a soft landing pad:

Soft music (jazz, ambient) on the car ride home.
Get home, don't wake up roommates. (They may hold is against you and do all
the dishes in the house when they get up.)
Check messages.
Put down a handful of vitamins with some juice.
Put on soft music in bathroom.
Run bath, add lots of aromatherapy relaxing bath oil (Body Shop, or not)
Soak in bath with lover (if one is available) for at least 20 minutes.
Get out of bath and wrap yourself (and your lover), in terry cloth.
Go into room, close shades tight.
Lay down, and give eachother (or yourself, if that's the way it goes) a
foot massage for at least 10 minutes on each foot.
Snuggle (or not) and crash until an hour before Simpsons, make dinner and
eat it watching Simpsons, then back to bed.

There you have it!

Other options?  Go to your friend Gerrard's place and soak in his hot tub
with Brian McGonigle and a couple of beers, listening to the fresh BIOJeff
tape from the night before.

Either way, hot water is crucial.

Peace ya'll!

Tony

P.S.  Burning Man option:  Drive 80 MPH across the playa on any misc.
vector heading South (?) toward the hot springs, park, strip, and walk
headlong into the soft, hot mud.  Cover yourself in the grey slightly
sulfer smelling ooze and lay on the ground while the sun dries your caked
skin, making wierd patterns in varoious shades of grey on your skin.  Sip
margarittas if you brought them.  Back in the water for a soak, then back
to the camp for a nice steaming cup of mushroom tea and a happy hardcore
brownie.  ;^)  Take a nap, get up, walk over to each camp and tip your hat
to everyone you see, thank the promoters, visit the WBL camp, bounce on the
trampoline for a bit, and let them paint your naked body.  Marvel at the
beauty of everything and everyone and then go dance until it starts to rain
and dance some more building huge platforms of mud on the botom of your
shoes.



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec  4 10:32:47 1995

Subject: Re[2]: IRC channels?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     Hyperreal runs a chat system that was ostensibly set up for 
     net-ravers.  People from all over the world log into it, but 
     suprisingly few from the San Francisco area (although this number is 
     growing).
     
     Granted, it's not always so wonderful there -- jerks abound, just like 
     on IRC, but maybe an influx of people who really are into raving and 
     the net would help.  To get to it, type
     
        telnet hyperreal.com 7283
     
     The 7283 is incredibly important, it won't work without it.  To 
     remember this number, notice that "7283" spells "rave" on a telephone 
     keypad.
     
     If you've never been there before, type 
     
        new
     
     at the login prompt, and answer the questions.  If you have any 
     problems, email vrave@hyperreal.com and Bella and/or Andrew, the 
     administrators, should get you straightened out.
     
     Laura

John and Larry wrote:

>Recently , John S. Lee posted -
     
>> Peace, Love, Unity, Respect...maybe we need to add tolerance (severaly 
>> lacking here at times), to that near-religious acronym.  Otherwise 
>> it ain't for shit.
 
>PLURT! An acronym that demands an exclamation point!
     
>Sounds good - I like it .....
     
     
>Larry "PLURT!PLURT!PLURT!PLURT!PLURT!PLURT!PLURT!PLURT!" Ching 
>larryc@netcom.com

>PS - Are the ideals of "Respect" and "Tolerance" seperate , such that
>both must be promoted as distinct and seperate? Hmmmm ...

I definately consider tolerance to be a form of respect.  Sort of like when 
someone says "I don't agree with you, but I respect your opinion" -- 
they're *tolerating* that person's opinion, too.

Actually, now that I've thought a bit more, tolerance is a combination of 
peace and respect:  respect for someone else's ideas, and a peaceful 
attitude toward something that one may not like or agree with.  
Furthermore, people can be tolerant of each other in the spirit of unity, 
and/or because they want to spread love rather than argue/make someone feel 
bad about something.

So, to me, tolerance is one of the things that you find/achieve/express as 
a result of acting with peace, love, unity, and respect.

Laura

Shawna wrote:


>I did end up checking out VRave, actually, but I like the idea of doing 
>channel #sfraves better.  VRave appears to have people from all over the 
>world (from what was mentioned in the FAQ), and it was very difficult to 
>get a word in edgewise, and to even get someone to respond to something 
>I'd say.  Kind of a lack of the community feel I think everybody here's 
>used to, since it's so big, so hence my like of the #sfraves channel idea. 
>Somebody should start it up!  What do you all think?

Vrave supports named channels.  Move to another channel via the /c command,
and then use the /N command to name the channel "sfraves hangout and party
planning" or whatever it is you want.

And as for community, there is a VERY strong community attached to vrave.  
It's more global in feel, that's true, but there are people that travel all 
over the US and even the world to visit and meet each other, and groups of 
people that have started and maintained both virtual and off-line 
friendships that have gone on for years.  In some ways it seems a bit 
fanatical :-)

Channel 01 on vrave is a zoo, that's for sure:  for some reason people hang 
on that channel and never get off, and it's difficult to get into the 
chaotic conversation.  That's why that channel is called "The Madhouse." 
But 98 other channels are available, and there's nothing stopping people 
from colonizing other areas.


One thing I vastly dislike about IRC is that every time I've tried to get 
into the #rave channel, the channel op locks it.  I don't understand what 
this person has against me, because I've never actually been able to get 
into #rave long enough to talk to anyone except for once, and that one time 
I couldn't tell if anyone could see what I was typing, even though there 
were only 4 other people on.  It was extremely frustrating.  Every time I 
tried after that I'd get a message saying the channel was locked and I 
needed an invitation to get in.  Talk about elitism.

Laura

At 7:07 PM 12/3/95, John S. Lee wrote:

>Muthfukas buy a brand new trubosound system, and people
>complain it's too loud, too soft, to trebbly, too whatever.  Complain,
>complain, complain.

Well I'll steer well clear of the bulk of this rant, however, I must take
exception here.

After nearly a two year break I finally returned to Wicked on saturday
night  and the shit was:

                          WAY TOO FUCKING LOUD.

Even with ear plugs my ears are still ringing and HURTING two days later.

Personally, I'm a little freaked about it... my hearing is getting fucked
and it pisses me off that people don't take this shit seriously; there is
NO REASON to subject people to that kind of damage. I did everything I
could to escape it... I moved back as far as I could, off to the side as
far as I could, upstairs etc., and finally, in pain I left.

This is a real concern (or should be) to everyone in this scene John, and
you calling people concerned about their damaged hearing "complainers"
doesn't do anyone any good, in fact, I suggest it does just the opposite.

This (sfr) has been and *should be* a forum for people to communicate their
concerns about the environments they encounter at parties to the people
throwing the parties, it's called feedback.

In all relations feedback is essential process and, IMO, your efforts at
intimidating and namecalling people into silence diminish the value of this
forum, so bugger off yourself.

Not to mention the fact that I know what compressed distortion sounds like:
DOGSHIT, and I heard plenty of it the other night.

So, to all the Wicked crew an posse: turn it down, *please*, you'll sound
better and we'll hear longer.

take it easy
ethan

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec  4 11:07:12 1995

	id AA818103891 Mon, 04 Dec 95 11:04:51 
Date: Mon, 04 Dec 95 11:04:51 
Message-Id: <9511048181.AA818103891@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re[2]: EBN / B de G
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     (Old raving fart mode on)
     
     I remember going to little warehouse parties in Providence, Rhode 
     Island, back in 1992...EBN would do lights/visuals.  Their basic style 
     was the same as they are doing today:  lots of sampling from the 
     media, especially the news.  Except back then they were really into 
     George Bush (well, he was president, so of course).
     
     (Old raving fart mode off)
     
     So anyway, the visual part of the EBN show was great -- they've 
     evolved their basic quick-cut and paste method to use better graphics, 
     and better technical technique.  I guess that's because they've got 
     more money for better production equipment.  However, it didn't seem 
     all that different from what I remember in Providence...media 
     overload, violence, quotes from political figures, bits of sex.  I 
     enjoyed the show, don't get me wrong.  The thing that was different 
     from their old material is that they are now a full-production show, 
     and not just visuals at someone's rave.  Therefore, they had their 
     music, patter, and lighting to add to the mix.  That's what made it 
     interesting to me:  the added dimensions.  The spoken bits and EBN 
     "bumpers" really demonstrated their sense of humor, too.
     
     I wasn't too thrilled by EBN's music, but if the show is taken as a 
     whole (and it should be) it was cool.
     
     Banco de Gaia made me very happy.  Techno/ambient acts live usually 
     leave me with a "well, I could have heard this at home" feeling, but 
     the lights really made the show work.  
     
     As Niels said, it was the best $8 I'd spent in a long time.
     
     Laura

From: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)
Subject: Re: Wicked facts/ear damage
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: <Windows Eudora Version 2.0.2>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>After nearly a two year break I finally returned to Wicked on saturday
>night  and the shit was:
>
>                          WAY TOO FUCKING LOUD.
>
>Even with ear plugs my ears are still ringing and HURTING two days later.
>
>Personally, I'm a little freaked about it... my hearing is getting fucked
>and it pisses me off that people don't take this shit seriously; there is
>NO REASON to subject people to that kind of damage. I did everything I
>could to escape it... I moved back as far as I could, off to the side as
>far as I could, upstairs etc., and finally, in pain I left.

Ear damage should be a real concern for all those involved in this scene.  I
started wondering about mine last year, and made an appointment with my
doctor for a hearing test just to see.  The test noted that I have sustained
some damage to both ears.  My hearing hasn't dropped below normal levels,
but in the frequency range that includes the kinds of sounds heard at a
rave, one of my ears is nearing the boarderline.  ***My doctor noted that
the kind of damage we sustain from loud music is irreversible!!!!!!*****  So
the doctor took molds of my ears and had custom ear plugs made for me.
Since I dj, my insurance paid for them because the damage is considered an
occupational hazard.  They are called "Rock Star Sound Suppressors" and they
work really well.  They suppress the sounds from loud music that will damage
your ear, but let the other sounds through.  I've dj'd with them on and they
really help suppress the sound from the monitor which can become painfull
after a while, and I can hear well enough to beat match.

Many of our lives are built around music.  What would YOU do if You lost
your hearing.  Think about it.

Rick


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec  4 11:31:25 1995

> Personally, I'm a little freaked about it... my hearing is getting fucked
> and it pisses me off that people don't take this shit seriously; there is
> NO REASON to subject people to that kind of damage. I did everything I
> could to escape it... I moved back as far as I could, off to the side as
> far as I could, upstairs etc., and finally, in pain I left.

[...]

> Not to mention the fact that I know what compressed distortion sounds like:
> DOGSHIT, and I heard plenty of it the other night.

Hey, guys!  The red LEDs don't mean "this party is k00l, d00d", they 
mean "your sound is fucked up"!  Red is *bad*.  Bad, bad, bad, bad, bad.

Heavily distorted sound is much more damaging to the ears than clean
sound at the same volume level.  If it hurts even with earplugs I'm glad
I wasn't there.  Tinnitus *sucks*, ladies and gentlemen.

And I feel it necessary to point out that _any_ sound system at _any_
massive is loud enough to cause hearing damage.  Props to F&F for always
providing excellent clean sound at reasonable levels.

E*A*R brand foam earplugs are your friend -- $0.25 per pair at most
drugstores (they come in the little blue cardboard packs).  I always
leave a few pairs in my jacket.  Remember that if you don't insert 
them correctly (fully blocking the ear canal), they aren't actually
helping.

If you forget, take two squares of TP from the restroom (four if it's the
really thin institutional stuff).  Take one (or two) and start folding it
over until you get a square about 1/3" on a side.  Saturate with water
(hold under sink), squeeze some out, and press across ear canal to seal.
Note: Do *NOT* roll it up and wedge it way in there, as you may not be
able to retrieve it, and it will leave little bits of TP in there even
if you do, and you'll have to get your ears irrigated (blech).

// g

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Banco and Wicked
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Saturday night, towards the end of a dinner party and a bottle of merlot,
with Banco de Gaia's Maya playing in the background, I decide that I would
let spontaneity take me by that hand, and found myself magical in the
middle of the dance floor at Banco de Gaia live at the Tracadero.  A quick
motorcycle ride, no line, no Trac hassles, and a warm fuzzy feeling inside
guided me smoothly there.

What I heard was great.  I didn't catch any of the other show EBN, and thus
only saw happy, dancing, friendly people (not that the other show didn't
have that).  I moved close to a speak, because I was really enjoying the
music, and said to myself, "Tone, when you post to SFR on Monday about how
cool this show is, make sure you tell them that the music was so good, you
felt like you could just climb right into the speak and suck-up as much of
the noise as possible, like a thristy horse at a watering hole.  Just
sucking in the music in in enormous vacuum-like sluprs."

Well, that's what it was like.  All so good...

Wicked was fun too.  There was a wall of speakers in the back that weren't
on, and I though that if they were on it would definitely be to loud, even
without them, I have to agree that the music was loud.  And that's with
wads of toilet paper jammed in my ears.

Tony

If it's in SF I take the 30 thru chinatown back home, at ~9, that will wake
you up!! and I always relize that the world is awake(and I'm going to bed),
we sit in the back open the window as wide as it goes and just look at
everyone and everything.  Another good place is to walk along Market or the
waterfront piers(the bay looks like a giant mirrior early in the morn.)
sometimes you run into people you saw durring the night and you just start
talking,it's really nice sometimes.  I usally get this wierd feeling that
all the normal people know that I've been out allnight and look at me
strange.

SeeYa 
Mark

Boy, did you miss the point.  The point was that there will ALWAYS be
something.  It doesn't matter what.  Your thing is the sound.  Other
peoples thing is the DJ's dancing next to them.  It doesn't matter much to
me.  Fact is you can't make everyone happy.  There will always be
something, or someone to cause contrary feelings.  And as it pertains to
the Wicked crew, in this town, they will never be able to do anything right
by many peoples standards.  And that was the crux of my argument, foisting
your or anyones standards on someone else and expecting them to live up to
it.

Example in point: F& F pre-sale tix.  I don't beleive in them.  I think
they're stupid, and borders elitism. What have I said about it?  Nothing.
Why?  IT AIN'T MY PARTY!(And from all accounts, people generally like the
idea!)  I have nothing to do with the running of it, I have nothing to do
with the promotions, I have nothing to do with any aspect, other than
knowing who started it, whos a part of it, and who generally attends.  How
people run thier shows is their own business.  I do not expect you & your
posse/group to live up to ANY of my standards, whatever they may be.  You
can do what you want and how you want.  As long as you're not ripping
people off, I could care less about the internal dealings/rules/regulations
about events not sponsored by myself.  I don't need to comment on every
little thing I don't like, especially where it concerns MY expectations.

>This (sfr) has been and *should be* a forum for people to communicate their

>throwing the parties, it's called feedback.

observation of late.

Ethan, you're funny.  I'm not trying to intimidate anyone, if you had these
feelings of intimidation with my post then that is your problem, certainly
not mine.  I was not namecalling anyone, there are some whiners,
complainers, and do-nothings everywhere.  What is annoying is the
namecalling perpetrated by others, who do not know the people they
namecall.  As for diminishing the value of the forum, whatever.  You have
your judgements and motivations and I have mine.  I don't spend my time
quibbling over bs in this scene.  Much like yourself, I *do* something
about it.

What diminishes the value of this list is the griping, moaning and
groaning.  I would generally have little to say about this, if these things
were in some way warranted.  But get real for a second, these things are
not based upon any real expereinces, they are based upon peoples
expectations not being fulfilled, and them blaming others for the let-down
they received.  After a while, the shit gets old, and the list gets into
the funk of "nobody does anything right" mode.
C'mon man "They're superstar DJ's cuz they don't dance in the crowd like
{name any DJ here] does!" (I know the person who posted this originally
later confessed and said it was probably a misunderstanding of the DJ's
motives in this case, but it does illustrate my point), what a load of
crap.  That would be like me going "Hey man, I finally got some time to go
to F&F.  Unfortunately the promoters are a bunch of elitist pigs.  Much
like BASS, they sell tix before the event.  Now I normally wouldn't obejct,
but I work in Santa Clara valley, I have no time to go to Solid Grooves to
get tix.  Why don't they sell them at my 7-Eleven across the street so
everyday humanity can get tix if they want!"

I illustrate F&F not filling my expectations, and them me passing judgement
on them due to my OWN pre-conceived notion of what is right.  I'm
sorry,passing judgement this way is punk ass, plain and simple.

{NOTE:  I do NOT feel that way about F&F at ALL.  I am just making a point
so disengage those flame-throwers.)

> 
> I have a question: 
> What is your favorite thing to do *after* a rave? 

Going to Wayne's place and he puts on some great ambient music.  I melt 
into the couch and we all casually talk among ourselves.  Then when I 
feel like going to fall asleep, I go upstairs and take a steaming hot 
shower then cuddle up in my sleeping bag as the ambient gives me some 
very *colorful* dreams.  Mmmmmmmm...:)

> Or what has been your most memorable post-raving experience? 

I've got 2:

1. Going to the End-Up after a wicked in August of 94.  That night I had 
met who were going to be 2 of my best girlfriends.  It was the perfect 
end to a perfect night.

2.  Burning Man!  Going back to camp after dancing to Wicked all night long. 
The sun is up and I go back and lay on a lounge chair as I watch the 
campfire. I can still hear the sound system thumping a quarter mile 
away.  I sip a beer (and I *never* drink beer!) and I fall asleep as 
the sun warms my body and friends' conversations tinkle in my ears .....I'm 
always ****so**** relaxed after dancing all 
night - I melt into anything I'm sitting/laying on.  This was heavenly!

love to all,
Amy
