                 I totlally agree, having spun parties myself. I find myself
in a somewhat different mind set , than if i came to dance. When spinning at
parties, sometimes D.J.'s look to other D.J.'s and close friends, for
support.  Sometimes when I spin at parties I'm thinking of what kind of "set"
I"ll spin, or I'm wonderin how i'm gonna start my set. or how I'm gonna my
mix my records with the D.J. 's records that's spinning before me. Other
D.J's know what that feeling is I suppose.
               So, don't take it personal if some D.J.'s seem a little
introverted at parties. they are probably just thinking to themselves.
               Feel free to talk and introduce your self, after the D.J's
after their set. I'm sure they appreciate the feed back. And I'm sure they be
happy to meet you. 
               I remember the last party I spun, after finishing my set, I
walked around and danced for a while, still hyped from the set I spun, but it
seemed that people just stared at me. i started to wonder if they heard me
"train wreck".    Or hated my set. Or the record that I played. We'll  I
guess i'm just shy, or feel more comfortable behind the turn tables. I
definatly could have used some feed back then.

I think that it's fun to have a lot of friends over before and after a long
night of raving. My place has become a kind of a post-rave/slumber party
zone as of late.

I like to come down smoothly. Eat light foods and/or drink juices, listen
to some good mellow ambient CD's, talking and cuddling are good.

Oh yeah, be sure to turn off all the telephone ringers and close all the
blinds for uninterrupted recharging.

Wake up, and, as if my magic, your Sunday's gone but you feel great again!

And Tony's suggestion about watching the simpsons are most appropriate.

later on: Spundae/Teknotika? Haven't tried that yet.

In-Reply-To: <199512032219.OAA16847@netcom21.netcom.com>

> 
> PS: M-x phases-of-moon (in xemacs) sez:
> 	Wednesday, December 6, 1995: Full Moon 5:23pm (PST)
> 
> When is the full moon rave? Surely Wicky_head are joking when they said
> the last full moon rave for the year was last month's -- it's so nice
> and warm out!!


Unfortunately this is mostlikely true, and in fact that might have been the
last Wicked Full Moon for a while.  It seems that someone has taken this
whole "who owns the FMR" thing way too seriously, to the extent that
they have made several death threats to Garth by phone (he has had to
change his phone number). Now before anyone goes off the deep end, I don't
believe that the organizers of the Goodness Full Moon or the New Full 
Moon or whatever they want to be called have had anything to do with this,
but I do believe tat the competitive and righteous vibe that has been coming
from that quarter has set some crazy person off. The lesson to be learned
here is you have to be responsible for your emminations, even if your in 
the right.   This is the first time in the 5 years of the full moon that 
any of the DJs or others involved have received death threats.  As far as 
Garth is concerned, this was the last straw for him, he no longer wants 
to do it and he feels really unappreciated.
I don't know what the rest say, but as of right now, Wicked won't be throwing
an FMR this month. As Garth was doing much of the organizing work around 
it and his friends were lugging most of the equipment his participation
and energy are really important for us to be able to throw a successful
party.

I would like to thank everyone who came out to the FMRs over the years,
keep the memories of all the good times close to your hearts, they will
be with you even when your old and grey.  Also remember and send blessings
to those who attended FMRs in the past and are not here with us now
for various reasons, especially to Mal, Trish and Al.

I would like to wish the New Full Moon people all the
best of luck, in your new endeavor, may you have all the luck that we
have enjoyed in these past 5 years and may you avoid all of the tragedies
that we also encountered.


	The torch has been passed to you now.

> >                          WAY TOO FUCKING LOUD.

> >
> >Personally, I'm a little freaked about it... my hearing is getting fucked
> >and it pisses me off that people don't take this shit seriously; there is
> >NO REASON to subject people to that kind of damage. I did everything I
> >could to escape it... I moved back as far as I could, off to the side as
> >far as I could, upstairs etc., and finally, in pain I left.
> 
> Ear damage should be a real concern for all those involved in this scene.  I
> started wondering about mine last year, and made an appointment with my
> doctor for a hearing test just to see.  The test noted that I have sustained
> some damage to both ears.  My hearing hasn't dropped below normal levels,
> but in the frequency range that includes the kinds of sounds heard at a
> rave, one of my ears is nearing the boarderline.  ***My doctor noted that
> the kind of damage we sustain from loud music is irreversible!!!!!!*****  So
> the doctor took molds of my ears and had custom ear plugs made for me.
> Since I dj, my insurance paid for them because the damage is considered an
> occupational hazard.  They are called "Rock Star Sound Suppressors" and they
> work really well.  They suppress the sounds from loud music that will damage
> your ear, but let the other sounds through.  I've dj'd with them on and they
> really help suppress the sound from the monitor which can become painfull
> after a while, and I can hear well enough to beat match.
> 
> Many of our lives are built around music.  What would YOU do if You lost
> your hearing.  Think about it.
> 
> Rick
> 
>

I think for the most part many of us who have done this for a while have

>This is true, and I'm sure jeno and markie have read this.
>I think for the most part many of us who have done this for a while have
>sustained some damage, what was the name of that doctor that you went to?

It was one of the ENT doctors at UC Davis Medical Center.  I was referred by
my primary care physician.  Check with your regular doctor and ask for a
hearing test.  Tell him/her that you are regularly exposed to extreemly loud
music and you would like to take some preventive action.  Your doctor should
refer you to an ENT (Ear Nose & Throat) doctor who will give you the test.
If your insurance wont cover it, the R.S. Sound Suppressors will run about
$50....the cost of a few records.  Totally worth it.

Rick


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec  4 14:58:46 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA20675; Mon, 4 Dec 1995 14:58:46 -0800

From: laural@inmark.com

	id AA818117720 Mon, 04 Dec 95 14:55:20 
Date: Mon, 04 Dec 95 14:55:20 
Message-Id: <9511048181.AA818117720@ugate.inmark.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re[2]: DJ eliteness?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


     Some DJs don't like to be talked to, or even approached, while they 
     are spinning.  This also includes just before and even just after 
     their set, as there's a sort of mental preparation/psyche up/wind down 
     that some go through.  You have to watch him or her and judge how open 
     he or she is to it.
     
     For example, it's really hard for me to deal with people coming up to 
     me and saying anything more than "Hi!!!" or giving me a wave or a 
     thumbs up.  Why?  Well, I've been listening to one record through a 
     headphone in one ear and another record through the other, and my mind 
     just can't make the switch to dealing with human speech.  If I 
     readjust myself to pay attention to what a person says, I lose my 
     concentration.  Sometimes it's not a big deal, but sometimes when I've 
     mixed myself into a corner (and it happens to everyone at times), I 
     really need to get the records figured out and quick before something 
     sonically unpleasant happens.
     
     I'm sure it could be interpreted as being rude -- especially when I 
     poke Brian and say "find out what this person wants and get rid of 
     them please" -- but if you've ever tried spinning on a big sound 
     system at a good-sized party, you'll understand that it's rather weird 
     when compared to doing it in your living room for 15 of your friends.
     
     I like to go out and dance like crazy to my final record so I can get 
     myself out of DJ mode and into party mode.  After that, I feel like I 
     can pay real attention to what people say to me, and can carry on 
     decent conversation.
     
     Laura

I'm glad to know that others care about their hearing.  I've always worn 
ear plugs to both raves and music shows, and my friends always think I'm 
silly and fanatical.  Now, could anyone reccomend some good (cheap) 
earplugs.  I've used the kind in the box, but they muffle everything and 
leave all the base, which still bothers my hearing.  I've heard somehting 
about "musicians" earplugs which lower the vibrations, but don't muffle 
the music.  I imagine this was what Rick was talking about, but I don't 
think I can afford to go to the Doctor and have special ones made up.

Input appreciated for the overly careful,

for my own enjoyment for about 15 months, the only public
place that I've played is at ameba and I can tell you that I can
tolerate people talking to me AT ALL! I'm such a novice that any
type of conversation pulls me out of the type of listening that is needed for
beat matching and something horrible will happen if I'm distracted
for too long!

As part of my efforts to keep SFRaves on the cutting edge :), I've
added a "shocked" version of the SFRaves home page.  To view it properly,
you need the Shockwave plug-in from Macromedia (find it at 
http://www.macromedia.com/) and the latest Netscape release (2.0b3),
(from http://www.netscape.com).  It features a semi-interactive turntable
and a simple animation.  A two-deck shockwave file is at
http://www.crl.com/~tactile/mix.html.

Unfortunately, only the Windows versions
of the Navigator and plug-in really work right now, so Mac users will
be stuck with my downloadable Director projector (from the demos page
under the SFRaves home page).  (the director file has many more features
and better samples anyway).

-Derek

After reading GeoffW's message, it's funny how many people said that there
were too many "gangster looking" people at a party.  When in fact, the real
gankers and assholes who issue death threats would probably look the
farthest thing from a gangster.  A lesson in what happens when religion
takes over.  PLUR my ass.

I was not a big FMM fan, but I've gone to one or two, but am saddened that
our scene has become so sorry that petty bs as when a party is would become
an issue. Goes to show what radical fanaticism, religion, and
self-righteousness can fertilize.

I do hope this person is somehow exposed.  And if in fact Garth got some
death threats, then there are legal devices available to him to track this
screwhead down.

This really sucks, but it was bound to come to some ending.  Too bad it had
to be on this note.

wack.  fukin' wack.

This town needs an enema,
John

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec  4 16:21:08 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA29463; Mon, 4 Dec 1995 16:21:08 -0800
Received: from jeeves.usfca.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA29454; Mon, 4 Dec 1995 16:21:04 -0800
Received: from duckman.usfca.edu ([138.202.32.150]) by jeeves.usfca.edu (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id QAA26251 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 4 Dec 1995 16:14:20 -0800
Date: Mon, 4 Dec 1995 16:14:20 -0800
Message-Id: <199512050014.QAA26251@jeeves.usfca.edu>
X-Sender: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3b4
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: reicja00@dons.ac.usfca.edu (Jake Reichert)
Subject: Re: Wicked facts.
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Well, did you ask Neil what was up?  Did you mention that the sound was too
>loud for your tastes?  Maybe next time you might want to talk with him
>about how he might do it properly.  But it is all a matter of opinion
>anyway.  What is too loud for you is fine for others.
>
>As in all things, your mileage may vary.

John, I think you've made some valid points in this thread, but I can't
agree with you on this one.  If the system is too loud for someone such as
Ethan who is exposed to loud music on a regular basis, chances are, it's too
loud.  Granted, maybe he should have talked to Neil, but he didn't.  He's
airing his concerns now, however, and I don't think it's to whine or
complain.  It was just a suggestion, and one which I, as someone who cares
about their hearing, is glad he brought up.

>>This is a real concern (or should be) to everyone in this scene John, and
>>you calling people concerned about their damaged hearing "complainers"
>>doesn't do anyone any good, in fact, I suggest it does just the opposite.
>
>Boy, did you miss the point.  The point was that there will ALWAYS be
>something.  It doesn't matter what.  Your thing is the sound.  Other
>peoples thing is the DJ's dancing next to them.  It doesn't matter much to

Actually, I think you missed Ethan's point.  He wasn't making some broad,
sweeping generalization about problems.  He's addressing a specific one, and
one that _should_ be addressed.  What if there hadn't been any water at the
venue?  By your reasoning, that's just another thing to complain about.
However, I sure as hell wouldn't attend a party without water, nor would
most people.  

I think you need to make a distinction between aesthetic complaints and
health issues.  Contrary to some people's opinions, the music volume is very
much a health issue.  Maybe it isn't as immediate as the need for water, but
it is still an issue that needs to be addressed.  If the dj's are elitist,
fine.  If the atmosphere is too clubby, fine.  Whatever.  But those things
are a tad bit less important than preserving your hearing.  20 years from
now, I know which problem I'll remember more.

>>This (sfr) has been and *should be* a forum for people to communicate their
>>concerns about the environments they encounter at parties to the people
>>throwing the parties, it's called feedback.
>
>Yeah, it's also called complaining, crying, and nagging.  Just my
>observation of late.

John, what goes on here is none of the above.  If you want to see some
serious whining, join another listserve for a few days.  I'm a pretty
tolerant person, but some, nay, almost all of the discussion on the 4AD
listserve is petty haranguing of others.  I'll give you the address if you
want.  Check out a few other listserves and you'll find the same.  I think
it's okay that people voice their opinions, as long as they're polite.  If
you didn't like the presale tix idea, I think you should have said
something.  One job of SFR is to provide a forum for discussion on
improvement of the scene, not just for spreading warm fuzzy energy around.
Personally, I'm glad when people bring up issues, and hopefully the
promoters hear them.  If they choose not to act on them, that's okay.  But
at least then they know people's concern.  It's awfully difficult to improve
a party if you don't know what needs improving.

>What diminishes the value of this list is the griping, moaning and
>groaning.  I would generally have little to say about this, if these things
>were in some way warranted.  But get real for a second, these things are
>not based upon any real expereinces, they are based upon peoples
>expectations not being fulfilled, and them blaming others for the let-down
>they received.  After a while, the shit gets old, and the list gets into
>the funk of "nobody does anything right" mode.

I will agree here.  It's easy for people to end up in this mode, a la the
discussion on how "the scene just ain't what it used to be back in good ol'
91."  Personally I don't have the time or expertise to start up a DIY, but I
can at least try to give feedback in a POSITIVE manner (and I think that's
an important distinction).  But again, I don't think Ethan's complaint came
from being let down.  It was definitely based on real experience, as you say.  

>C'mon man "They're superstar DJ's cuz they don't dance in the crowd like
>{name any DJ here] does!" (I know the person who posted this originally
>later confessed and said it was probably a misunderstanding of the DJ's
>motives in this case, but it does illustrate my point), what a load of
>crap.  That would be like me going "Hey man, I finally got some time to go
>to F&F.  Unfortunately the promoters are a bunch of elitist pigs.  Much
>like BASS, they sell tix before the event.  Now I normally wouldn't obejct,
>but I work in Santa Clara valley, I have no time to go to Solid Grooves to
>get tix.  Why don't they sell them at my 7-Eleven across the street so
>everyday humanity can get tix if they want!"

The person in question replied, as you said, that they misunderstood the
djs' actions.  I don't think it was a "load of crap".  I think it was a
genuine misunderstanding.  Thanks to all those who helped clear up that
particular issue.  But your comment above is neither helpful, illustrative
of the problem, or accurate.  It's just bashing.

>I illustrate F&F not filling my expectations, and them me passing judgement
>on them due to my OWN pre-conceived notion of what is right.  I'm
>sorry,passing judgement this way is punk ass, plain and simple.

Again, this isn't passing judgement.  I think you should have expressed your
opinions about it.  It's in how you say it, not what you say.  Here's what I
mean.

_John approaching Ethan about F&F presale tix_

Approach #1: "Ethan, I wanted to talk to you about the presale F&F tickets.
I think it's unfair because some people who would love to go just won't have
access to them." Etc.

Approach #2: "Ethan, what the fuck is up with F&F tickets?  This is
bullshit, man.  You elitist assholes are screwing up big time." Etc.

See the difference?


>about the initial post about Wicked, but when I jumped down the collective
>complainers groups throat you saw it fit to get into my shit. I guess it's
>called choosing your battles. We both have our allegiances/posses/friends.

Did it occur to you that maybe he hadn't checked his mail before that, or
didn't feel like getting into the issue until you said something he felt was
wrong?  You've made an _awfully_ big generalization here.  I didn't get into
the discussion before, and I don't have strong ties on either side of the
fence that I need to defend.  I just felt after reading this particular
message that I had something to add.  Don't jump to baseless conclusions.

>
>>Not to mention the fact that I know what compressed distortion sounds like:
>>DOGSHIT, and I heard plenty of it the other night.
>
>Talk to Neil, I'm sure he would love to hear your suggestions.  E-mail
>Wicked and let them know what you think.  You have done that, haven't you?

Since there are Wicked people who read the list on a regular basis, I think
he's made his point already.

Jake

P.S.  I'm not trying to defend Ethan persay, it's just that he seemed to be
the object of John's mild eruption (i.e. I don't believe in this "defending
your posse" ideology.  I defend whoever I feel is right, regardless of my
afilliation with them).

At 3:33 PM 12/4/95, Geoff White wrote:


>change his phone number). Now before anyone goes off the deep end, I don't
>believe that the organizers of the Goodness Full Moon or the New Full
>Moon or whatever they want to be called have had anything to do with this,
>but I do believe tat the competitive and righteous vibe that has been coming
>from that quarter has set some crazy person off. The lesson to be learned
>here is you have to be responsible for your emminations, even if your in
>the right.

I've never gotten a sense that the New Full Moon organizers have held the
opinion that their interpretation is any better than Wicked's nor that they
want to compete with Wicked. There are some personal differences between
members of both groups, but that shouldn't reflect on the groups
themselves. It seems a bit disingenuous to blame the NFM group for indirect
responsibility for the crank calls to Garth.

Joe

>After reading GeoffW's message, it's funny how many people said that there
>were too many "gangster looking" people at a party.  When in fact, the real
>gankers and assholes who issue death threats would probably look the
>farthest thing from a gangster.  A lesson in what happens when religion
>takes over.  PLUR my ass.

You know, I think this is something important.  It's one thing to spout PLUR
all the time, and it's another to live it.  I agree with John here that a
lot of people aren't very good at walking the talk.  As far as the
plur/religion thing goes, I'm reminded of the book Dune (not the sorry
imitation movie version).  It addresses the same issue, when speaking your
mind becomes heresy.  I'd say people need to remember to THINK about their
actions, something which, sadly, people sometimes forget to do.

The moral of the story is that it's easy to get caught up in buzz words.
It's one thing to say plur is what the scene's about and another to think
about what it means and apply it to your life.

>I do hope this person is somehow exposed.  And if in fact Garth got some
>death threats, then there are legal devices available to him to track this
>screwhead down.
>
>This really sucks, but it was bound to come to some ending.  Too bad it had
>to be on this note.

I was pretty pissed off when I read about this incident.  Whoever the fuck
is doing this apparently has a poor grasp on what raving (not to mention
life in general) is all about.  Can you imagine what it would be like if
different crews started going at each other's throats and shit like that for
status?

The day that happens is the day I stop raving.

Peeved,
Jake

Sometimes when we have eunf energy, a walk in the woods or to the top of a
mountain(Diablo, Tam, any hill on the penninsula) is one of my favorite
Sunday activities.(especially if my pupils are still a little dialated and
I'm extra sensitive visually).  There's something about being in harmony with
hundreds of people, then with nature.  Of course, there's the best of both
worlds after a FMM or any outdoor party in the summer when the sun's up so
early.  I also like to be alone and get all introspective about what just
happened, the beat music, hearts, and waves on the beach.
much peace, love, and laughter -kirb

On Mon, 4 Dec 1995, Joe Rice wrote:

> At 3:33 PM 12/4/95, Geoff White wrote:
> 
> 
> >change his phone number). Now before anyone goes off the deep end, I don't
> >believe that the organizers of the Goodness Full Moon or the New Full
> >Moon or whatever they want to be called have had anything to do with this,
> >but I do believe tat the competitive and righteous vibe that has been coming
> >from that quarter has set some crazy person off. The lesson to be learned
> >here is you have to be responsible for your emminations, even if your in
> >the right.
> 
> I've never gotten a sense that the New Full Moon organizers have held the
> opinion that their interpretation is any better than Wicked's nor that they
> want to compete with Wicked. There are some personal differences between
> members of both groups, but that shouldn't reflect on the groups
> themselves. It seems a bit disingenuous to blame the NFM group for indirect
> responsibility for the crank calls to Garth.
> 
> Joe
> 
> 
The crank caller specifically mentioned the fact that Garth had somehow
had a hand in the fact that a person was swept off the rocks at the last 
full moon (even though Jeno was playing at the time :) And yelled at him
about some altercation that he had between himself and the promoters of
the "alternative" full moon.

As I said, I don't believe that Claire or anyone else involved with the 
New Full Moon had anything to do with the person that made the crank calls
but they are responsible for the energy that they let out as are we all.

This is a bone that I pick with all promoters, we are responsible for the
safty of our participants as Ethan rightly notes when it comes to sound 
volume (though I think on the promoter front, Ethan and F&F are the ONLY ones
that are concerned with our hearing.

Basically the feeling is that it's not worth all of the accusations and
coulda woulda shouldas involved and definitely not worth people getting
so worked up that they would make death threats, believe me in the scene
the way it is now with all the meth abuse going on and people staying up
for 5 days straight, I would take those types of wacko threats very 
seriously.  It was only two years ago that a friend killed another friend
with a gun over something as trivial as this, meth was involved as well.

People have to realize and remember, it is afterall just a party.

I really never adressed Ethan's concern in my last post (dismissing it I
beleive).  Well I DO think that there's plenty of validity in this
statement.  I generally stay back a bit, depending on the sound.  This Sat.
was loud, no doubt.  I have always wondered about people standing or even
putting their heads in the speaker.  Little Louie was a resonable level
from my view, a some even suggested it was too low during Little Louies
set.  I don't go out that often, and when I practice it's usually at a
reasonable level.  I am starting to think about ear plugz when going out.
Gotta be able to talk to my kid without asking too many "Eh, what's that?"

I also think that the sound system they have is really geared towards
outdoor usage.

At 1:59 AM 12/4/95, MsPhink@aol.com wrote:
>I have a question:
>What is your favorite thing to do *after* a rave? Or what has been your most
>memorable post-raving experience? I usually come home and listen to music
>until I fall asleep. I also like reading comic books and other literature
>that doesn't make me think too hard. Going to The End Up is also a fun
>post-raving activity!! Anyone else???
>MsPhink

        Well, as to what i usually do, i usually end up crashing out at my
place and meditating, or reading (last weekend i tried reading Roger
Penrose's "Shadows of the Mind" about the connection b/n consciousness and
quantum physics and i actually got some of it!). I think that the post-rave
state of consisciousness is even better than the one that you have at a
rave (well, maybe not better but different, i prefer the post though).
Maybe i'll have a beer or *ahem* something smokable and just think for a
while. I find that the post-rave condition is pretty uhh hormonal so i
usually try to focus that energy into something useful as i don't have
someone to 'be an outlet with' :)
        As for my most memorable post-rave experience, i have a couple, but
one of the ones that is most interesting is going to an afterparty in NYC
last spring, finding some friends and having them offer me a joint.
Eventually we figured out that it was about 90% dust and so there i was,
alone on a Sunday morning in Brooklyn, in the subway trying to get back to
my friend's place. AND THEN there was this family going off to church at
the subway and the son (about 5 years old) kept biting the mother's hand
and yelling "gimme nibbows! gimme nibbows!" (gimme nibbles...i guess?!) I
was doing my best not to laugh, but couldn't help it when the father bends
down and earnestly says "now son, what have i told you about repeating?"
and the son looks down, pauses, then looks up and says "ummm...gimme
nibbows?"
        definitely memorable!
                brad

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec  4 18:38:14 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id SAA14226; Mon, 4 Dec 1995 18:38:14 -0800
Received: from elaine20.Stanford.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA14220; Mon, 4 Dec 1995 18:38:10 -0800
Received: (from starchld@localhost) by elaine20.Stanford.EDU (8.7.1/8.7.1) id SAA15136 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Mon, 4 Dec 1995 18:38:02 -0800 (PST)
From: Matt Kodama <starchld@leland.Stanford.EDU>
Message-Id: <199512050238.SAA15136@elaine20.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: effects of griping
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 4 Dec 1995 18:38:01 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

(my two cents on accusations that sfraves is a whine-a-thon.)

one reason to try to keep comments about performers/dj's from getting
nasty or petty is that i'd like to see them eager to post to this list too.
one of the most exciting things i see in house/ambient music is that it's a
pretty radical departure from most current music - it's less about melody
or harmony and much more about what direct sensory input (sound,
light, chest-thumping bass) is going to make your body react positively.  
starting to think about music as a direct feed to your physiology without
filtering through your cognitive centers first is the idea here that i
think is so fascinating, and what really sets "rave" music apart from all
the other exciting new music coming out.

i'd like to know whether the dj's, musicians, video artists, etc. in the
sf scene think like that, or if not what is going on behind the watch
face.  we're discovering a whole new musical/sensory aesthetic, and i for one
want to try to understand why i touches me so much.  and it ain't just the
drugs, you know.  but the more we bitch about details the less likely
people are to just toss out their speculations and random flashes of
insight - and that's too bad.

for instance, a couple of rave organizers (or promoters, or whatever)
from the uk came to campus last year just to shoot the shit and talk 
about the philosophy of what they're trying to do, and how they think it
came together synergistically with the '60s back to nature and
'trance'-endental meditation thangs - it was pretty informative, but even
more thought provoking.  why can't that be going on all the time here on
our corner of the net?  after all, i thought that's what it was for ...
*child.

-- 
***************************************************

   The  convoluted  wording  of  legalisms  grew up
around the  necessity to  hide from  ourselves  the
violence  we  intend  toward  each  other.  Between
depriving  a man  of  one  hour  from his  life and
depriving  him  of  his life  there  exists  only a
difference  of  degree.   You  have  done  violence
to him, consumed his energy.   Elaborate euphemisms
may conceal  your intent to kill,  but  behind  any
use of power  over another  the ultimate assumption
remains: "I feed on your energy."

     - Frank Herbert

In-Reply-To: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)
        "Re: Wicked facts/ear damage" (Dec  4,  2:57pm)
References: <199512042257.OAA27576@peseta.ucdavis.edu>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle), Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>
Subject: Re: Wicked facts/ear damage
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sound levels and distortion are a serious matter, and I don't think that
John would doubt, after a moment of reflection, that this is more than
a matter of "expectations not being met."  We can't let the music we
love hurt us and our friends . . . It's a matter of preparation and
keeping on top of the sound situation.  It's a responsibility I personally
take very seriously, in part because I've got a bit of tinnitus.  It's
permanent, it can't be reversed, but you can protect yourself and still
have a good time.  While overall volume is an issue, distortion is what
really does the damage.  But even the cleanest sound can damage your
ears if you're not careful and stay too close for too long.  I think
of that every time I see serious speaker-tweaker action.  Anytime I'm
within the range of the high volumes, I pop in the plugs and often,
as for example almost always on the King St. dancefloor, I keep 'em
in regardless.  

There is an organization in San Francisco called HEAR which has information
on music and hearing protection.  I don't have the phone or address but
anyone interested can contact my friend Dr. Flash Gordon (yes, that's his
real name!) at flash@well.sf.ca.us and he'll fill you in.

This is the real deal.  Preserve your hearing, it's worth it.

peace out.
p

phred

Dear All;

	Like WOW!!!, what's up with our scene, robberies, death threats,
fights, no/shitty venues, tagging, bad drugs, bad music, promoters 
overcharging & lieing about admission fees, food, ..etc, arrogant DJ's, &
vibeless parties? It's really starting to get me disillusioned, and makes
me want to become an isolationist raver. It seems the butthead quotient
has gone through the month so far this month & last month. I've talked
with a lot of people who are really unhappy with our scene right now. In 
fact my New Years resolution is to become very selective about the 
parties I go to.

	For instance, I went to DV8 Thurdays night for Lift, and the soft 
house they were playin really left me totally uninspired, in fact I 
couldn't even dance. Then Friday I went to XNTRK, thinking this would be 
a desent party considering the fact Dutch & Carlos were spinning, and it 
turned out the Dutch opened the night up, and Carlos came second, who's 
bright idea was that lineup? If it wasn't for Joe Rice Saturday night at 
966 Mission it would have been a total wash weekend.

	I'm just reaaly disgusted with the expensive parties that 
don'tdeliever what they promise. I'll be at Chrysilsis on the 9th because 
I know that will be a great party. We reaaly need a party that can get 
the good vibe going again, I hope someone will throw one soon, I would, 
but I don't think any of you would come, sorry but that's just the way I 
feel.

I dunno, Brian, but I tell myself I'm going to have a good time and I 
always do. Many people I know are griping about how shitty the scene is 
and get that faraway look when remembering the "good ole days".  I just 
don't see it!  Every year gets **BETTER** for me.  I am pretty selective 
about the parties I attend, and living here in Sacramento doesn't afford 
me the opportunity to party every weekend.  So burnout is also less 
probable in my situation.   It is, indeed very unfortunate about any 
threats, robberies, and other atrocities, but if each person tries a 
little to make the best of each situation that is under their control, 
it can't help but get better.  
Gawd, I am such an optomist - I always have been, and I'm also very happy 
with the scene.  It is all what you make of it - it is your choice, pure 
and simple.

hugs and smiles,
Amy

Mon, Dec 4, 1995, you wrote:

>Like WOW!!!, what's up with our scene, robberies, death >threats, fights,
no/shitty venues, tagging, bad drugs, bad >music, promoters overcharging &
lieing about admission fees, >food, ..etc, arrogant DJ's, & vibeless parties?
It's really >starting to get me disillusioned, 
[snip]

The fact of the matter is that the rave scene goes through its ups & downs.
As long as I have been raving (about 3 yrs., not as long as some), I have
seen my share of scary things. Because many ravers do drugs, there will
always be that element of unsavory happenings which surround the scene. I
think the sf scene has a lot more energy in the summer, people are happy when
they're outside. Things are worse elsewhere right now, Trust me. Things are
not so bad. If you're upset, laying low for a while is not a bad idea. You'll
come back when you're ready. 

We need to love and support each other. That means ravers, promoters, dj's
and everyone. We have a symbiotic relationship. We need each other. We need
to express this love and appreciation to each other. This is the way the
scene will grow and thrive. I know we can't be all warm & fuzzy all the
time.... but I like warm & fuzzy myself. 

>We reaaly need a party that can get the good vibe going again, >I hope
someone will throw one soon, I would, but I don't think >any of you would
come, sorry but that's just the way I feel.

The parties will have good vibes if we make them good vibes. Each individual
decides to have a good time, smile at everyone else, this forms a chain
reaction... next thing you know, a room full of happy people! :-) We can do
it ourselves. We don't need to wait for someone else to do it. We are the
scene. 
MooPhink

beach or go to someone's house and make a breakfast. I know I know: many 
of you are going:forget staying up any longer. But, hey I'm a hyper woman:)
                                            -Reagan> 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec  4 20:04:31 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA21302; Mon, 4 Dec 1995 20:04:31 -0800
Received: from alpha.xerox.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id UAA21297; Mon, 4 Dec 1995 20:04:27 -0800
Received: from godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com ([13.242.128.10]) by alpha.xerox.com with SMTP id <15108(1)>; Mon, 4 Dec 1995 20:03:39 PST
Received: from beluga.adoc.xerox.com ([13.242.128.26]) by godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com with SMTP id <2423>; Mon, 4 Dec 1995 20:03:29 -0800
Received: from cc:Mail SMTPLINK 2.1 by beluga.adoc.xerox.com
	id AA818136977; Mon, 04 Dec 95 20:14:57 PST
Date: Mon, 4 Dec 1995 20:14:57 PST
From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>
Message-Id: <9511048181.AA818136977@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Gangstahs, clubbiness, Wicked, and going off (long)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     I preface this message with the fact that what I say is merely my 
     perception.  Kinda sad to start a message this way but it seems like 
     we're getting kinda touchy these days...Remember folks, reading and 
     writing on this list is much like life:  Your interpretation depends 
     on your perception at the moment, in this case, it's whether you're 
     the author, the reader, or the messenger.  So what may come across as 
     flippant or comical can be insulting, depending on how you look at it. 
     How many times have you heard, "Gee, you look good today" and then 
     hear "You mean I didn't look good yesterday?".  Yep, it's about 
     perception.  Okay, off my soapbox now and onto my "vibe" review of 
     Wicked and social observations. 
     
     Wicked didn't seem to necessarily have "gangstahs" in the house but 
     rather a more clubbier, voyeristic crowd this time.  And yes, there 
     were more people of color at this party which might contribute to 
     stereotypes.  Sometimes it's hard to describe what you feel or see and 
     it may come out the wrong way.  I think we're also sensitive on how to 
     say things for fear of sounding prejudiced.  I know this because I had 
     this vibe discussion after Wicked with a few friends.  
     
     I love Wickeds when I'm able to make them perhaps because it was the 
     first rave I went off/tranced at ;) or because of all the hype I heard 
     about them prior to finally making it to one.   In any case, the 
     beauty of their parties have been not only music and dance but the 
     diverse mix of freaks who just want to get down and get funky.  
     Attitude has always been part of the mix and that suits me fine 'cause 
     by the end of the party when you look around, it's usually blown away. 
     After all, we are here to listen to good music and dance.
     
     So what did I see that I didn't necessarily like about this party?  
     VOYERS - Now I'm as guilty as the next person for sitting down and  
     checking things out or staring into space but there seemed to be alot 
     of "beautiful people" who wore cool clothes and hung out.  And yes, 
     some of these people were not your "typical" ravers.  
     
     What did I _not_ do to help turn _my_ problem around?  I didn't smile 
     or make small talk with them...nor did I get the feeling that they 
     were open to it _but_ I didn't try it either.  But think about it, 
     when you're new to any scene it takes a while to open up and let your 
     guard down.  Perhaps the "gangstah" stereotype is really just a more 
     guarded person who hasn't felt enough trust in the scene to let his or 
     her guard down.  This can be cultural, social or whatever, I've 
     observed this behavior especially with minorities (me included) at 
     other gatherings and have even been considered aloof, distant, or 
     stuck up all because I wasn't sure how to interact in a situation.  
     
     What saved me so far in the sf scene?  Reading lots of posts about 
     smiling :) %) 8) So when I finally did go out, I decided to let my 
     light shine by smiling lots.  I haven't seen posts about this in quite 
     a while.  In fact, I know when I first started going out, I was very 
     social and wanted to meet lots of people.  Now, I'm kinda burnt and 
     guarded so I'm not as social _and_ I'm happiest when I see my friends 
     at the same parties I go to.  Perhaps I need to take inventory on 
     myself!
     
     I think there was also a more "machismo/male/almost aggro" vibe this 
     time at Wicked.  It's not isolated to this party either.  I've seen 
     and felt it growing several places in the past 6+ months and it got 
     bad enough Saturday night to where a guy grabbed me while I was 
     walking by.  How did I deal with this?  I patted him on the back, told 
     him he had a nice smile (he did as he grabbed me) and told him I was 
     with someone when he asked me.  That way we both felt okay about it.  
     I know not everyone can do this but there was no sense in making it 
     worse.  At another large East Bay party (many moons ago), I recall 
     complimenting a shirtless guy about his tattoo and his response to me 
     was "and you're ugly".  :o  Unfortunately I was speechless.  Perhaps I 
     should have just smiled and remembered it was his perception.
     
     In my dance collective and even at some parties, I've heard people ask 
     how we can make parties & dances more diverse.  Well, to start, we 
     need to continue keeping an open mind to educating and welcoming 
     people into the scene.  The fact that Cool World was widely attended 
     shows that people want to see what raves are about.  I know lots of us 
     who want to share this wonderful love we feel and if we want it to 
     grow, we have to deal with the growing pains.  And if we're really 
     caring and practicing plur(t), I really think it's necessary to 
     educate newcomers especially after hearing people talk about bad trips 
     (someone I met had tried crystal for their first time and didn't eat 
     or rest enough and crashed after four days, another had taken too much 
     GHB and was temporarily blinded and stumbling).  I have problems with 
     people who go off without educating theirselves about what they're 
     doing or considering the ramifications and I know that it's my 
     problem.  I'm just glad they're able to live to tell of their story.  
     But not everyone knows where to access this info and there's alot of 
     new and young people out there who are either just going off, or 
     searching for a community that can share some values and attention 
     that they're presently not getting.  Another friend and I commented 
     that we both had a difficult time w/young kids going off at large 
     parties but we also sadly said that we didn't do anything about 
     welcoming them to the scene.  And so I ask myself why don't I and 
     would they be receptive to me.  (Light bulb flashing over my head, I 
     think I just stumbled over an answer for myself!)
     
     In any case, apologies for my ramblings but I wanted to address some 
     things that I observed and give you my input.  Sorry for sounding so 
     preachy.  Hope you all made it through this long memo and for those 
     who did, here's an equally long, virtual hug (and smile!) from the 
     universe.
     
     Hope to see some of you at MAD tonight!
     
     Love in white light,
     Diane
     
     BTW, Jeno really did it for me this time.  Even when my calves hurt, I 
     still had to get up and dance.  Thanks Wicked crew and all of you out 
     there for bringing your love to the scene.
     
     Diane

On Mon, 4 Dec 1995, Matt Kodama wrote:

> (my two cents on accusations that sfraves is a whine-a-thon.)
> 
> one reason to try to keep comments about performers/dj's from getting
> nasty or petty is that i'd like to see them eager to post to this list too.
> one of the most exciting things i see in house/ambient music is that it's a
> pretty radical departure from most current music - it's less about melody
> or harmony and much more about what direct sensory input (sound,
> light, chest-thumping bass) is going to make your body react positively.  
> starting to think about music as a direct feed to your physiology without
> filtering through your cognitive centers first is the idea here that i
> think is so fascinating, and what really sets "rave" music apart from all
> the other exciting new music coming out.

if you talk to the gateway or f&f people you may find what youre looking for!


> 
> i'd like to know whether the dj's, musicians, video artists, etc. in the
> sf scene think like that, or if not what is going on behind the watch
> face.  we're discovering a whole new musical/sensory aesthetic, and i for one
> want to try to understand why i touches me so much.  and it ain't just the
> drugs, you know.  but the more we bitch about details the less likely
> people are to just toss out their speculations and random flashes of
> insight - and that's too bad.
> 
i spin a little here and there, and i could talk for days about evolution 
and unity under one rithym(sp) and teh effects of trance on consciousness.
i also remember that "is it rave related" bit a few weeks ago, and have 
posted a lot less of that since.

> for instance, a couple of rave organizers (or promoters, or whatever)
> from the uk came to campus last year just to shoot the shit and talk 
> about the philosophy of what they're trying to do, and how they think it
> came together synergistically with the '60s back to nature and
> 'trance'-endental meditation thangs - it was pretty informative, but even
> more thought provoking.  why can't that be going on all the time here on
> our corner of the net?  after all, i thought that's what it was for ...
> *child.

>    The  convoluted  wording  of  legalisms  grew up
> around the  necessity to  hide from  ourselves  the
> violence  we  intend  toward  each  other.  Between
> depriving  a man  of  one  hour  from his  life and
> depriving  him  of  his life  there  exists  only a
> difference  of  degree.   You  have  done  violence
> to him, consumed his energy.   Elaborate euphemisms
> may conceal  your intent to kill,  but  behind  any
> use of power  over another  the ultimate assumption
> remains: "I feed on your energy."
>

yes, yes, yes, yes!  those who have been through the doors of perception,
one way or the other, have a responsibility to help 'virgins' learn how
to enjoy the ride without losing their anchor - even a near slip is one
of the most terrifying experiences you can have, and all this nancy reagan
bullshit over the years is satanic miracle-gro for THE FEAR.  ('just a simple
trip that wrecked minds' is a two-edged sword.)  i mean, obviously i'm not
suggesting  droning on endlessly about this trip or that and how to
'do it right' and generally being jackasses.  but, as long as the rave
scene has this glam relationship with recreational drugs, we need to be
responsible about taking care of our own, inside and outside of parties.

god, i need to quit blithering myself and finish my term paper.  wish me luck,
*child

Precedence: bulk


[ To sfraves mailist ]

 Since some DJs are deliberatly going into the red to get that rock'n'roll
fuzz distortion flavor to the sound , why not do what the rock guitarists
do and put a distortion unit between the mixer and the power amps? 
 The distortion that is created with these devices is of much higher quality
, and the control of the harmonics created is knob-twisting easy. Each DJ
can put in as much fuzz as they want. Also , most distortion units filter
out the tweeter-killing ultra high frequencies ( I think ).
 The only problem would be that the unit would have to be in stereo.

 You DJs out there - would you be interested in a stereo distortion unit
as I describe above? In my early days , I've built some distortion circuits
that could be duplicated and the controls ganged together ... I wouldn't
mind experimenting if anyone's interested. 

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

 My present favorite ear protection nowadays is those fish shaped foam
earplugs that sporting goods stores sell . Doesn't cut high frequencies
as badly as other foam plugs , and doesn't cut the volume as much as
those fancy tan rubberish ones with the circular ribs. I use the rubberish
ones for really severe dangerous high volume rave/rock concert situations.
 
 Wet folded/rolled bar napkins or toilet paper is also good. I prefer to
live dangerously and roll mine in a cigarette filter shape , such that I
can control how much I let into my ear canal ( the extra outside length
acts as a handle ).
 
 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Dec  5 00:51:33 1995

Good day to U all-

First of all I would like to say when I go out to a party I go out with
smiles and come back wit smiles.  i am a very optimistic person and always
look for the good in things and people.
make the best of what you got and when you got the best make it a memory.  :)

Saturday was my 20th birthday and because I am 20 now I still can't leagally
go o wicked.  Focus was at Marina Skate - I don' t really like this loation
but I knew Adrian and JJ and a few others throwing the party and I decided to
go out and show my support.  I was happy to see they did something new to the
venue by tarping off a chill area, a play area complete with a mini-house,
and the dancefloor.  I was very happy with the visuals spinning
kaladascope(sp?) and there were great lasers.
I got several happy gifts from friends -yeah!- and I was off on a dancing
frenzy as Dutch started off with some sick alien trance. I think Tony came
next but i was off in my little world for awhile and found an alien mask I
put on cuz it looked kewl.  True there weren't alot of people dancing but
this didn't sop these feet.  and true there were a lot a hoods but it's the
ghetto what do you expect? I met a lot of nice people, many newbies and told
the good little munchkins about the Gathering on the 16th.  Simon went on
after Tony and next was Dreamer.  I love Simons sets but I don't think he
should be on at the peak of the party.  I love to wind down to his music
(especilly at PreBirth).  Ghost was next - man I remember him back in the day
just goin' off with some old skool vocal house and stuff I still like him
-but to bad my ride wanted to leave in the middle.  
  The vibe wasn't there but I had a lot of phun. GK pro and Adonis have a lot
of potential I think they just need a better venue and some support and
input.  I will try to continue to support them  ReserXtion is coming up on
the 30th.

By the way does anyone know a Ryan, Clois(??big white guy w/ sm. tails), or
Laura - They go to Saint Marys Co. Really nice people and I lost this phone
#'s can anyone help please.

Sunday morning the sunrise was just full o' beauty Dark red(gothic)->bright
red/orange->golden yellow     ahhhhh!
Did any one else ove it.

I heard this the other day and think it is really pertant to the list right
now---
 ***************************************  
            IT IS NICE TO BE IMPORTANT
        BUT IT IS MORE IMPORTANT TO BE NICE

***************************************
Peace and love to you all                    Keep the vibe alive
  
 ps.  Has anyone tried Earmuffs- I wear these some times 
        They muffel the sound a little and make you feel like you are in your
own little rave with lotts of smiling faces around you.   :)  @@  (: 
         :)  \_/  (;
     ;) :0 8D :) :0 :))
                                AUSTIN

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Dec  5 01:12:27 1995

Subject: What's Happening To Our Scene? 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 5 Dec 1995 01:10:33 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3296      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 	Like WOW!!!, what's up with our scene, robberies, death threats,
> fights, no/shitty venues, tagging, bad drugs, bad music, promoters 
> overcharging & lieing about admission fees, food, ..etc, arrogant DJ's, &
> vibeless parties? It's really starting to get me disillusioned, and makes
> me want to become an isolationist raver. It seems the butthead quotient
> has gone through the month so far this month & last month. I've talked
> with a lot of people who are really unhappy with our scene right now. In 
> fact my New Years resolution is to become very selective about the 
> parties I go to.
> 
As was previously posted, everything has its ups and downs.  And as
it would seem that we are now going through a downswing, it becomes
more important than ever for each one of us who feels that gloomy
tinge of disillusionment to take the time to give credit to and 
remember what exactly it is that we feel we are missing.  It's also
very important to remember that things will inevitably swing back the
other direction, and if we want to be there when it happens, we mustn't
lose faith.  In fact, it is through this process that things will be
even better and stronger the next time around, as we will have learned
to see through all those issues that threw us off the last time.  I might
even go so far as to say that we can look at periods like this as a positive
sign that we are growing and becomming more aware, we mustn't fear them.

Where has the vibe gone?  It is still right here. It has just become invisible
until we grow strong enough to see it again.  We must resolve our fears
and tensions with all those things we consider negative and that we think
might have "killed the scene."  And then, sooner than we think, we'll
be dancing away and suddenly be filled with a forgotten passion and
remember why we were doing this in the first place.  and it won't have
so much to do with the right party, or the right new good music, or the 
right people... it will only have to do with ourself and the time when we
finally give up searching so hard for the vibe that we didn't let ourselves
see it...  that moment when you, let yourself go.

Don't expect to find it and let yourself become dissapointed... just
remember that all those things you love are out there, and that they
will find you when you are ready for them again.  You can't force it.
Like with the Full Moon situation... there are people who are trying to
force something out of the full moon ceremony, making it so important
that the simple meaning of it has become convoluted.  It doesn't matter
who... It is part of a cycle where the meaning must change in order
for meaning to get discovered.  And it may be that after a while, Wicked
will find themselves eager to reestablish their full moon, or it may be
that other people will take over and celebrate their full moon, but the
point is that when we need to celebrate the full moon, when we become ready
again, the full moon will be there and will find us with the right people
to help us celebrate it.  Did that make sense?  All these things are
happening for a reason, and the tensions need to ease for things to
become simple again... and they will, so just let them.

everything begins and ends with you.

Let yourself go.

-john.

http://www.he.net/~swoosh

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Rusty H. Hodge" <rusty@hodge.com>
Subject: Re: Ear Damage Redux
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Heavily distorted sound is much more damaging to the ears than clean
>sound at the same volume level.  If it hurts even with earplugs I'm glad
>I wasn't there.  Tinnitus *sucks*, ladies and gentlemen.
>
>And I feel it necessary to point out that _any_ sound system at _any_
>massive is loud enough to cause hearing damage.  Props to F&F for always
>providing excellent clean sound at reasonable levels.

Another thing to keep in mind about high sound levels (which I love) is
that the damage to your ears is caused by a cumulative continuious
exposure. What may be find to listen to for 30mins-1hr could cause
tremendous damage in 5 hours.

Even if you like the loud sounds, give your ears a break - especially when
you're at parties indoors.

And take it from someone who has Tinnitus on a small scale. It can be real
nasty at times, and I have a weak case of it. If you want to put some fear
in your hearts, read alt.support.tinnitus and see the horror stories.

One final note (I sound like an old man preachin' to the kids). Hearing
loss occurs 1-2 octaves higher than the frequency of the damaging sound.
This means too much bass can cause you to lose hearing in that all
important speach hearing range. While most of the music we listen to at
parties has extremely deep bass almost on a sub-sonic level, it shouldn't
impact us quite as badly. But think about it sometime. Isolate the bass
sounds, and imagine the sound two octaves up (double the pitch twice).

Final note on earplugs- There is a brand called "Docs Pro Plugs", they are
custom molded earplugs with exceptionally good audio response designed for
musicians. They have almost flat frequency response. Music stores like
Guitar Center should be able to get them for you.

--
Rusty Hodge <rusty@hodge.com>
Hodge [Interactive] Productions            801 Minnesota Ave. Studio 9
San Francisco CA 94107    tel +1.415.826.9500      fax +1.415.641.7773

You wrote: 
>
>Dear All;
>
>	Like WOW!!!, what's up with our scene, robberies, death threats,
>fights, no/shitty venues, tagging, bad drugs, bad music, promoters 
>overcharging & lieing about admission fees, food, ..etc, arrogant

>vibeless parties? It's really starting to get me disillusioned, and 
makes
>me want to become an isolationist raver. It seems the butthead 
quotient
>has gone through the month so far this month & last month. I've talked
>with a lot of people who are really unhappy with our scene right now. 
In 
>fact my New Years resolution is to become very selective about the 
>parties I go to.
>
>	For instance, I went to DV8 Thurdays night for Lift, and the soft 

>house they were playin really left me totally uninspired, in fact I 
>couldn't even dance. Then Friday I went to XNTRK, thinking this would 
be

>don'tdeliever what they promise. I'll be at Chrysilsis on the 9th 
because 
>I know that will be a great party. We reaaly need a party that can get 

>the good vibe going again, I hope someone will throw one soon, I 
would, 
>but I don't think any of you would come, sorry but that's just the way 
I 
>feel.

>	   Peace, Love & Happy Holidays From Across Cyberspace
>		  a.k.a. Brian DarknEs^2, LMT/EE/CET
>		 CT Active Voice & Fax (510)-595-7988
>	      CT Active Pager & Voice Mail (800)-590-4993
>
Dear Brian and all,

    What IS happening to our scene!? You are your own answer. This is 
definately OUR scene, but sometimes you must treat it as YOUR scene, 
independantly! You are single handedly responsible for creating the 
vibe which makes YOU happy. Personally, I am sick of people complaining 
about the parties that now have no vibe. There are enough of us that 
attend each single party every week to create the vibe we so desire. If 
each of us put forth the same amount of energy to create the vibe, as 
we use to complain about it, we could have the best vibe ever!!! I 
think it is time for you to start taking responsibility for the vibe at 
every party. 

    I keep hearing people talking about certain promoters and how their 
parties are now vibeless (T.F.). It is not ALL their fault. If you went 
to T.F. you obviously went there to have a good time. So instaed of 
trying to find every single thing wrong with the party, why not try to 
make things right! I admitt, so parties are naturally better than 
others, but each party deserves the energy that we are capable of 
giving. 

    So, what is happening to our scene? I feel, yes there have been 
some promoters who exploited the scene, but we need to get past that 
and strive to rebiuld what some people say is lost, (the vibe). Quit, 
blamming promoters, and start dancing!!! Why doesn't anyone dress up 
anymore at parties? Is that the promoters' fault too? NNNNOOOOOO! At 
the Gathering coming up in Dec. Some of the Harmony crew (including 
myself), are going to be in our crayon suits again. I would like to 
urge as many people as possible to dress up once again for this four 
year anniversary. It always make me happy to see people dress up. I can 
only assume it makes others happy to....

    And to you Brian, if you want someone to throw a kickass party, 
then why don't you try it yourself!! That is what we (Harmony) wanted, 
and tried to do. IMO, we achieved that (going by the responce from 
everyone who has been to our parties). Anyways, I gotta go do my 
finals. 

Peace, love, and vibes,

Greg :)

>I look for: 

-Lots and Lots of smiling people.
-A good Vibe as soon as you walk in the door
-A soundsystem that will blow you out of your skivvies ( bring those
earplugs, I like to rip off -little peices of my makeup sponge , you can rip
a pice off that is just the right fit and one face sponge will last awhile)
- The space (preferabaly outdoors) should b well ventilated and not to dark.
I like to See those  I am partying w/.
-The turntables and the DJ should be in sight of the dance space  and the
dancers , not so close as to disturb the DJ or skip his records , but close
enough so the freakers and their DJ can exchange energy ( a must so a DJ can
feel the energy flow from the crowd and let it shape his/ her set).I hate
when a DJ cannot be seen , it adds to the feeling that the DJ is not a part
of the crowd hence that Rock star vibe that Iv'e heard some complaints about
recently.
- The visuals should be creative and artistic. Flashing lighs give me a
headache. 
- Friendly staff ( security, barkeeps, ticket-takers, doorpeople), that are
enjoying the party they are luky enough to be getting paid to be at.
 I'm sure I havent covered everything, but dinner awaits.

                                                                            
                                                            Keep the vibe
alive;) ;)

                                                                            
                                                             little jen sus

> From: "Rusty H. Hodge" <rusty@hodge.com>
> Another thing to keep in mind about high sound levels (which I love) is
> that the damage to your ears is caused by a cumulative continuious
> exposure. What may be find to listen to for 30mins-1hr could cause
> tremendous damage in 5 hours.

Thank you very much for this info. It didn't occur to me that there
was a cumulative effect. That is why sometimes I don't think the
volume is too high, but I can really hear the damage afterwards.

Thanks for the other good info too. Last weekend I was dragged kicking
and screaming into the Sound Factory. It actually wasn't that bad
after 3am, and there was one DJ in a small room named Bruno who I
liked. Anyway, the ear damage was worse than I ever remember having
before. This is from someone who has played in a few high volume bands
along with clubbing, etc. There was something particularily damaging
about the main floor sound system there. Bring those ear plugs! I know
Bottom-of-the-Hill sells them at the bar. Maybe if everyone started
asking to buy earplugs along with their water, then dance parties and
clubs would start to have them available as a default. 

-Darrel 
darrele@netcom.com

On Mon, 4 Dec 1995, Diane Tabellija wrote:
>      need to continue keeping an open mind to educating and welcoming 
>      people into the scene.  The fact that Cool World was widely attended 
>      shows that people want to see what raves are about.  I know lots of us 
>      who want to share this wonderful love we feel and if we want it to 
>      grow, we have to deal with the growing pains.  And if we're really 
>      caring and practicing plur(t), I really think it's necessary to 
>      educate newcomers 

I agree with being open and educating newcomers.  I consider myself "new" 
and sometimes feel very out of place.  Burning Man aside, Cool World was 
my first party.  My "experienced" friends were bored after an hour and 
wanted to leave.  I told them to go even though I didn't know anyone in 
SF or Oakland. I decided I could sleep in my car before driving back to 
Fresno.  Oh joy!

Anyway, I love wandering around by myself, and the had the greatest time, 
but....nobody spoke to me unless I spoke to them first.  I smile, and I'm 
very friendly.  It seems to me that groups form and look unwelcoming.  Of 
course, to protect myself from all the flaming, this is only "my perception".

I've attended Funky Techno since then and feel a little more at ease, but 
not much.  I love it that people hand out candy (don't ever eat a 
Pepermint Patti on E...it took forever to chew).  I want to make new 
friends, but I don't see it happening without me making all the effort.

That's why I joined this group so I could possibly meet some people 
before The Gathering.  Maybe I need to go to smaller parties.  I hear 
these are better for meeting people.  You think??

Marty




especially after hearing people talk about bad trips 
>      (someone I met had tried crystal for their first time and didn't eat 
>      or rest enough and crashed after four days, another had taken too much 
>      GHB and was temporarily blinded and stumbling).  I have problems with 
>      people who go off without educating theirselves about what they're 
>      doing or considering the ramifications and I know that it's my 
>      problem.  I'm just glad they're able to live to tell of their story.  
>      But not everyone knows where to access this info and there's alot of 
>      new and young people out there who are either just going off, or 
>      searching for a community that can share some values and attention 
>      that they're presently not getting.  Another friend and I commented 
>      that we both had a difficult time w/young kids going off at large 
>      parties but we also sadly said that we didn't do anything about 
>      welcoming them to the scene.  And so I ask myself why don't I and 
>      would they be receptive to me.  (Light bulb flashing over my head, I 
>      think I just stumbled over an answer for myself!)

   The  convoluted  wording  of  legalisms  grew up
around the  necessity to  hide from  ourselves  the
violence  we  intend  toward  each  other.  Between
depriving  a man  of  one  hour  from his  life and
depriving  him  of  his life  there  exists  only a
difference  of  degree.   You  have  done  violence
to him, consumed his energy.   Elaborate euphemisms
may conceal  your intent to kill,  but  behind  any
use of power  over another  the ultimate assumption
remains: "I feed on your energy."

     - Frank Herbert

Gyro-tron. Im sure you've all seen em. Big thing you stand in and it 
spins around inside another ring, inside another ring. Anyway, I liked it. 
And so did the couple hundred people who rode it :)
The coolest thing are allllllll the people totally going off when Im 
playing music. Absolutely nothing beats dj-ing infront of a couple hun 
people and having them scream at the top of their lungs and jump
up and down after a nice rise.

hey everybody,

just thought i'd once again say something nice about MAD, such as:  it
was a lot of fun yet again.  i wasn't there long..just mostly for alex'
set.  

i have to admit that after the FnF halloween party and three weeks of MAD,
plus hearing ethan at the New Full Moon on the beach two months ago...that
now i think techno is beautiful.  whereas before i thought it was too intense
and in-your-face.  is it my imagination, or is techno..with a driving
beat..getting more complex and interesting?  i wish i had a more sophisticated
knowledge of music so that i could express what i mean.  oh well.

and for those who like salsa music- and you know who you are! - bahia cabana
does a salsa band thing saturday night.  

-Ann

one of the characters on the spot quoting their friend describing it

> > ***Posted December 5th, 1995
> > [Image]
> >                                                                [Image]
> >                                12/4/95
> >
> >
> >
> > "A Rave is about overloading your senses to a point where the distinct
> > lines between sight and sound, touch and smell, start to blur. The
> > music is techno, with a beat that's got so much base it changes the
> > rhythm of your heart. The walls are covered with tapestries of
> > brilliant colors and an orgy of projections: computer graphics, oil
> > lamps, etc. The drugs are uppers... meth, speed, ecstasy. Even the
> > dancing is about changing your physical state. Everyone pounds it out
> > on the dance floor until their pulse is racing and their limbs are so
> > worked that they're moving on their own. It's just another part of the
> > sense experience."
> >

Subject: sfraves = virtual magazine (semi-rave related)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 6 Dec 1995 00:48:05 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hi!
at the risk of doing this flame-analysis thing to death, one last set of
observations.  i know, this particular horse shouldn't be beaten much more, 
so feel free to delete this now.  :(

i was thinking that the sfraves list is basically an on-line magazine of
artistic reviews.  there's also a lot of other communication going on, but
that's at least a big part of it.  thinking about it that way, maybe we
can get some mileage out of journalistic practices.  so what does that
mean?

(1) party reviews:
no self-respecting print mag would try to function without an editor, but
we do.  that means every one of us has to step it up and try to act as an
objective editor for what we write as reviews of parties.  and, just
because you're a smart and open minded person, doesn't mean everything you
want to write about a party is objective.  i just read an interview with
stanley crouch, who is a jazz drummer and onetime critic for the village
voice.  (check out his recordings - he goes off!)  he said sometimes he'd
hand in copy for a review, and his editor would come back and say,
stanley, this is crap.  don't embarrass me and you by trying to get me to
print this shit.  (an example of something they did print - crouch started
a review with something like, "to begin with the n----r just can't write."
imagine what they didn't print!)  that didn't mean stanley didn't have
something to say that was worth reading - he just hadn't gotten it right.

i'm not saying you shouldn't voice personal opinions - i want to hear those
too!  but, we maybe we should just try to clearly separate the objective
opinions we can fairly voice from our personal beefs.

(2) responding to reviews:
in print mags, i guess this is a letter to the editor, and only the most
coherent or interesting replies get printed.  if what i have to say about
a review isn't of general interest, or is blatantly inflammatory, maybe i
should send it directly to the author.

so, if that made sense to you, cool.  if not, i'm accepting letters to my
editor right now - hit that reply button and flame on!
matt.

-- 
***************************************************

   The  convoluted  wording  of  legalisms  grew up
around the  necessity to  hide from  ourselves  the
violence  we  intend  toward  each  other.  Between
depriving  a man  of  one  hour  from his  life and
depriving  him  of  his life  there  exists  only a
difference  of  degree.   You  have  done  violence
to him, consumed his energy.   Elaborate euphemisms
may conceal  your intent to kill,  but  behind  any
use of power  over another  the ultimate assumption
remains: "I feed on your energy."

     - Frank Herbert

***************************************************

the starchild mothership can be reached at 493-4099

person.  You really don't have much sense of the spiritual ravers do 
you?  If you knew what that part of raving was about you would know 
that someone who felt that way wouldn't threaten anybody.  It's

practical joker.

of most ravers I've met is anything BUT religion.  In fact it's the 
absence of religion.  The belief that each human is a complete 
individual totaly seperate yet completely united with everything and on 
his or her OWN Path.  There is no religion or organization or 
fanatisism in this.  

At least no more fanatisims than your constant habit of taken  
agressive stances on issues and spreading negative vibe.

Whew!

Just spent 2 hours wading through the 300 posts that accumulated while I
was away in LA for the past few days. I must say my mind is numb from all
the arguments and counter-arguments and meta-arguments.

What I did not find as I waded through the thousands of words written by
our members over the past few days is much new info about *MUSIC*. I'm
wondering if anyone has gotten their hands on any particularly vicious new
choons lately and would care to share their discoveries with the rest of
us. Any takers?

Also, I'd like to suggest a fresh start. Maybe we could all take a deep
breath, come back to the present, and let go of whatever particular
storyline we happen to be currently preoccupied with.

I'd also like to suggest that we consider doing a *FREE* SFR-sponsored
party in the near future. This would be an excellent opportunity to come
together, reconnect with each other in a direct, personal way, blow off
some steam, and celebrate our mutual passion. I would be more than happy to
lend some organizational energy to this endeavor. If there are any others
interested in this idea, please contact me and lets see if we can make
something happen.

Maybe we could call this party "FRESH START". Just an idea...  =o)

Peace & love,
ek

Subject: Rave Spirituality (was Re: Talk about gangstahs!
To: sequoia1@ix.netcom.com (Chris Chervin)
Date: Wed, 6 Dec 95 10:38:17 PST
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199512061600.IAA15826@ix.ix.netcom.com>; from "Chris Chervin" at Dec 6, 95 8:00 am

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Chris:
>  The spirituality 
>of most ravers I've met is anything BUT religion.  In fact it's the 
>absence of religion.  The belief that each human is a complete 
>individual totaly seperate yet completely united with everything and on 
>his or her OWN Path.  There is no religion or organization or 
>fanatisism in this.  

Chris, it seems that there has always been a small group of people
in the rave scene who have some kind of fear of the spiritual side of 
raving.  They periodically attempt to project an image of intolerance 
and oppression upon those who would try to perpetuate the concepts of
PLUR, as though they are thugs who will hold a knife to your throat
and force you to accept a hug from them or something.  Maybe it's just
because PLUR sounds too much like a slogan, and slogans are too easy
to repeat in a shallow and insincere context.

It also seems that that rave spirituality can come in different
flavors.  For example, I think that the Wicked DJs (especially at the
FMRs) promote a vibe more condusive to an individually intense trip
that is more transcendental, more beyond ourselves, where the journey
you take is more important than the friends you make along the way.  
Unity takes place on another plane of existence with a little 
less of the warm fuzziness perhaps; earthbound smiles don't hurt, but
but may not be quite as important.  Just my perception, this kind of 
thing is very subjective.    

There will always be hypocrisy from people who speak idealistically.
I see it in myself all the time.  I like the PLUR message, yet always 
loving and being at peace with everyone isn't just boring, it also
denies the diversity and balance that makes things *real* for me.
So to some extent, I lack the desire to fully live the ideals I favor.     

I think most people who speak PLUR are really just saying, "let's try 
to focus more on the positive things that bring us together."  Perhaps
there are PLUR fanatics around, but I've never encountered any.  Yes, 
I find it annoying when someone thrusts their grinning face 5 inches
from mine and say "c'mon smile" while I'm dancing.  But somehow, I've
managed to survive such unprovoked attacks.                                   

Overall, I think our scene is blessed with positive energy.  Despite
the occasional sniping and a few scenesters with personal agendas, 
there is still an amazing lack of competition between the parties 
here.  Anyone who thinks that they are going to get anywhere with an 
"us vs them" attitude is sorely mistaken because there does seem to be a 
Karma thing at work - those clued into (at least part of) the community 
vibe instead of just their own seem to have an easier time making good
things happen.

Of course, actions mean more than words.  Like this list: SFRavers get
accused of whining or being negative, yet the true achievement of this 
list has been to bring people together.  Which doesn't mean we all have 
to agree, or even like each other.  It's easy to feel Unity on the dance 
floor with people you never have to talk to.  Here, I have a sense of 
connectedness with people that i don't even *want* to be connected with!  
Now that's significant; and it also happens to be an example of PLUR, 
in *action*, freely chosen by all who care to participate.

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

	id MAA17321; Wed, 6 Dec 1995 12:29:22 -0800
