Message-Id: <199512062029.MAA17321@ix13.ix.netcom.com>
From: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)
Subject: Beautiful things (non-rave) (long)
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Hey

Been noticing everybody seeming kinda down & snippy lately.  A lot of 
people seem unhappy about a lot of stuff, and a lot of people seem 
unhappy about that fact!  Bad vibes, & complaints about bad vibes. I 
was thinking about it last night, and instead of retaliating with more 
complaints about complaints about complaining, I figured I'd start out 
a whole new post on an entirely new subject.  Everything seems awfully 
negative to me at times, not just sfraves, but work, friends, and life 
situations in general.  Sometimes I forget about the stuff that makes 
all that junk worthwhile.  For some reason a List popped into my head 
last night, and that list made me remember why I really love life.  
It's a list of all those things I think are beautiful.  Not just "oh 
that's pretty" beautiful, but the kind of things that give me the 
occasional inkling of understanding as to why I'm really here.  This is 
my list, thought I'd share it if you all don't mind.  

1) The look on someone's face when you give them a small gift for no 
reason (anybody who's ever gotten a cup of water, walked up to some 
unknown raver on the dance floor who just look like they could use 
water, and offered it to them probably knows this feeling!)

2)  The ocean in some parts of the world where the water is so 
incredibly cobalt blue that you just can't believe it's occurred 
naturally.

3)  That place where the ocean meets the sky in the middle of a 
spectacular sunset.

4)  Instantly clicking with someone you just met five minutes ago.

5)  An incredibly good book that goes on for 400 pages.

6)  Scoring that A in a class you really worked your ass off for.

7)  Really understanding that you've only got a limited amount of time 
on this earth with the people you really love (friends, family, 
anybody) and making the most of your time with these people (first part 
can be negative, but the second part is what makes it beautiful to me).

8)  Trees, especially those certain trees that have that ancient 
positive energy older than generations of Man that you can just feel 
when you touch them (those of you who understand this one, you know 
about these trees!)

9)  On extremely rare occasion, finding a person who really lives by 
what they believe in.  A lot of people complain about those who spout 
PLUR and don't live it as well, but honestly, with ravers and the rest 
of humanity, there are very few people who actually live by what they 
believe in.  Don't begrudge, but forgive, those of us who don't do it 
as well, it's not an easy burden to bear for those few who can. 
(preachy but true)

10)  And not least, lying on your bed at 1:00 am some night, listening 
to music, and really understanding what all these things mean to you 
and how they make your life worth living.

Just wanted to share, I apologize for it not being rave-related, but I 
somehow felt that it was needed (for me at least) after what appears to 
be a slump for the list.  We all need to be reminded of those beautiful 
things which make us happy to be here after all is said and done.

Love
Shawna

Wed, Dec 6, 1995, lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM wrote:

>Of course, actions mean more than words.  Like this list: SFRavers get
>accused of whining or being negative, yet the true achievement of this 
>list has been to bring people together.  Which doesn't mean we all have 
>to agree, or even like each other.  It's easy to feel Unity on the dance 
>floor with people you never have to talk to.  Here, I have a sense of 
>connectedness with people that i don't even *want* to be connected with!  

>Now that's significant; and it also happens to be an example of PLUR, 
>in *action*, freely chosen by all who care to participate.

I went to the sfr party this summer at Bonny Doon that was in honor of Brian
& Laura's wedding. This was before I subscribed to the list, someone else
invited me. When I arrived with my 3 friends, we set up our blanket to the
right of the main crowd. I immediately felt self-conscious, as I felt
everyone was staring at us to try and determine who we were. In spite of this
fact, no one came up to us to say hi or anything. I also felt that everyone
else was being really cliquish in their sub-divided little groups. I don't
know what I expected from an sfr party- I guess I was half hoping to see
everyone holding hands in a big circle and dancing around. I know I should
have taken it upon myself to introduce us; but I was feeling really
intimidated by everyone. I didn't go away from that party with a very good
feeling, but I thought maybe once I am "in the know", it will be easier. 

It is pretty obvious to me that we're kind of stuck with each other here
online. But does that mean when we go to a party, someone says "Oh, there's
so-and-so, the jerk I don't agree with" or is there really a sense of PLUR
among each other? Do we forget all of the disagreements once we're out and
about? This is what I am hoping.... 

I'm sorry I said the sfravers are a bunch of whiners. Obviously this didn't
jibe well with everyone. I thought as long as we're picking apart the scene,
we might as well start with taking a look at ourselves. This seemed to be a
bit too difficult for some people, so I won't be making any more criticisms
of this group. I don't want to wind up in the "most hated" catagory or
something. 

I hope to be at Come/Unity tonight. Look for a very tall man with blonde
hair, and I will be somewhere around there. I am 5'10" with short blondish
hair. I will try to wear my bright ass-yellow Jujyfruits t-shirt. Yes,
wearing my sfr laminate as well with pride. Come by to say hello, or at least
come by say you want to kill me! :-)

MsPhink

MsPhink says:
> 
> I went to the sfr party this summer at Bonny Doon that was in honor of Brian
> & Laura's wedding.
> [...] no one came up to us to say hi or anything.

I was there and I'd say that no more than 1/2 the attendees were sfravers.
I introduced myself to at least 5 people I didn't know.  Then I got tired
of the social stuff and spent the rest of the day dancing.

> I also felt that everyone
> else was being really cliquish in their sub-divided little groups.

This happens at every party, unfortunately, to varying degrees.  Mainly
it's because people just don't seem to be compelled to leave their
social comfort zones.  But nearly everyone I approached was receptive to
me; except for one person who totally dissed me.  This was a surprise
since I had always thought highly of his net-personality.  I guess the
feeling wasn't mutual.

> It is pretty obvious to me that we're kind of stuck with each other here
> online. But does that mean when we go to a party, someone says "Oh, there's
> so-and-so, the jerk I don't agree with"

Uh, er, well, I can feel that way sometimes, though it usually takes more
than a disagreement for me to think someone's a jerk.  But then, some of 
my best friends are jerks.

>  or is there really a sense of PLUR
> among each other? 

I think so.  

> Do we forget all of the disagreements once we're out and
> about? This is what I am hoping.... 

No.  Isn't one of the points of PLUR to accept each other even when
we disagree?  One thing I've discovered is that when I'm raving with
people, whatever garbage we may have posted recently seems to mean very 
little compared to what we are sharing at the moment.  
 
> I'm sorry I said the sfravers are a bunch of whiners. Obviously this didn't
> jibe well with everyone.

Blanket stereotypical statements rarely do.  BTW, if you check the 
archives and did some statistical analysis I'd bet you'd find that by far 
most posts about parties and DJs are positive, sometimes nauseatingly so.    

>  I don't want to wind up in the "most hated" catagory or
> something. 

You'll have to work harder to achieve that.  And even then, no matter
how long-winded, self-aggrandizing, attitude-laden and rave-irrelevant
your posts may be, there will always be someone out there who will like
them.  There's no accounting for taste.

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

Thanks, I had tears by the time I got to #3.

Rick

>Hey
>
>Been noticing everybody seeming kinda down & snippy lately.  A lot of 
>people seem unhappy about a lot of stuff, and a lot of people seem 
>unhappy about that fact!  Bad vibes, & complaints about bad vibes. I 
>was thinking about it last night, and instead of retaliating with more 
>complaints about complaints about complaining, I figured I'd start out 
>a whole new post on an entirely new subject.  Everything seems awfully 
>negative to me at times, not just sfraves, but work, friends, and life 
>situations in general.  Sometimes I forget about the stuff that makes 
>all that junk worthwhile.  For some reason a List popped into my head 
>last night, and that list made me remember why I really love life.  
>It's a list of all those things I think are beautiful.  Not just "oh 
>that's pretty" beautiful, but the kind of things that give me the 
>occasional inkling of understanding as to why I'm really here.  This is 
>my list, thought I'd share it if you all don't mind.  
>
>1) The look on someone's face when you give them a small gift for no 
>reason (anybody who's ever gotten a cup of water, walked up to some 
>unknown raver on the dance floor who just look like they could use 
>water, and offered it to them probably knows this feeling!)
>
>2)  The ocean in some parts of the world where the water is so 
>incredibly cobalt blue that you just can't believe it's occurred 
>naturally.
>
>3)  That place where the ocean meets the sky in the middle of a 
>spectacular sunset.
>
>4)  Instantly clicking with someone you just met five minutes ago.
>
>5)  An incredibly good book that goes on for 400 pages.
>
>6)  Scoring that A in a class you really worked your ass off for.
>
>7)  Really understanding that you've only got a limited amount of time 
>on this earth with the people you really love (friends, family, 
>anybody) and making the most of your time with these people (first part 
>can be negative, but the second part is what makes it beautiful to me).
>
>8)  Trees, especially those certain trees that have that ancient 
>positive energy older than generations of Man that you can just feel 
>when you touch them (those of you who understand this one, you know 
>about these trees!)
>
>9)  On extremely rare occasion, finding a person who really lives by 
>what they believe in.  A lot of people complain about those who spout 
>PLUR and don't live it as well, but honestly, with ravers and the rest 
>of humanity, there are very few people who actually live by what they 
>believe in.  Don't begrudge, but forgive, those of us who don't do it 
>as well, it's not an easy burden to bear for those few who can. 
>(preachy but true)
>
>10)  And not least, lying on your bed at 1:00 am some night, listening 
>to music, and really understanding what all these things mean to you 
>and how they make your life worth living.
>
>Just wanted to share, I apologize for it not being rave-related, but I 
>somehow felt that it was needed (for me at least) after what appears to 
>be a slump for the list.  We all need to be reminded of those beautiful 
>things which make us happy to be here after all is said and done.
>
>Love
>Shawna  
>
>

greetings all sfr's!

i'm new on this list, but not to the rave community. it saddens me to read
such a general sense of unsatisfaction of our scene. one common theme being
people feeling isolated even at a party. that sounds hard to believe, but
i've felt this way too. however, i still get the feeling that there's a lot
of positivity and optimism from the people writing these letters. here's an
idea: what about a preparty get-together somewhere in the city (e.g. cafe'
bastille, or somewhere similar to kickit) . This would be a good way for
those of us feeling isolated to get familiar with one another before we rave.
 Just an idea i thought i'd send out there. let me know what you all think
and i hope to meet you sfr's sometime soon.

two fingers and a thumb (peace, I'm out)
Theron

> > I went to the sfr party this summer at Bonny Doon that was in honor of Brian
> > & Laura's wedding.
> > [...] no one came up to us to say hi or anything.
> 
> I was there and I'd say that no more than 1/2 the attendees were sfravers.
> I introduced myself to at least 5 people I didn't know.  Then I got tired
> of the social stuff and spent the rest of the day dancing.

Then there are some of us who are just plain kinda shy - like me!  You 
all learned about *that* during that imfamous dj elitist thread I posted. 
(sheesh, I learned my lesson!)  I think that the laminates are a godsend 
in a way, for people like myself who have a hard time just going up to 
people and introducing myself.  With a person I haven't met with laminate 
on or something else similar to me (like a cool tongue piercing!! :P) it 
gives me better grounds to come up and talk to them.  There is already a 
sort of bond.  I am probably the most un-stuck   up person I know, EGO is 
a nasty word in my vocabulary.  It goes both ways, too.  If a person just 
comes up and starts talking to me, I'll talk right back, with happiness.  
Voila my 2 cents.

love love love,
Amy

New hot tracks?  Thought ya'd never ask :)

I agree with Joe, Dave Angel's new album is excellent.  I know
Soundworks has it because I got mine there.  Now that he's dropped
the mad-techno thing and starting making the music he clearly wants
to, it's a new step up.  Excellent, jazzy, deep.

Jacob's Optical Stairway, "Solar Feelings" remixes on R&S.  Nice package,
two *excellent* junglist style remixes from Claude Young. 

Storm the Funk, a three-track EP on Ferox.  Excellent minimalist stuff
without being too cold.

Astral Matrix, "Torture Vibes" and "Pieces."  I know that lots of you
have heard these.  Andrew calls this style "acid lounge" ;-)

Just about anything recently on Direct Beat from Detroit: Aux 88 and
Yanu in particular.  

Freeform Dub, by Simon Pyke, on Skam95.  Check the cool Braille
lettering on the sleeve :)  Excellent EP, this track is the best.
*Real* dub instead of the clanking stuff people are passing off
as "electronic dub" these days.

"Military Jazz," Plug 2, on Rising High.  This is Wagon Christ/Luke Vibert
under a different name.  An excellent mix of well constructed jungle drum
riffs with cool/weird bop jazz breaks.  He was quoted in one of the
magazines saying he was having "too much fun" making jungle tracks and
was forcing himself to go back to work on Wagon Christ projects!

"Pushin' Right Along," Trip ta Funk, on Organico.  I don't know how new
this is but I just got it recently and it's excellent trippy-dub.
I like Sunshine's Thanks and Praise mix especially.  

"Floribunda," Mother
s Pride, on Skinnymalinky (what the hell's a "skinnymalinky"?!).  This
might be one of my two or three favorite records of 1995, along with
LTJ Bukem's "Horizons."  In the jazzy-housey-tribaley groove with an
awesome key shift.  I'm finding a lot more of this loose/jazzy stuff,
the new Atlantic Jaxxx label is good for that too.

"Flight 727," Jay Ray, on Championsound.  Greeeeeen vinyl :)  Excellent
acid-trance, but at the slower Hardfloor pace.

"Techno City 95," Model 500, on Metroplex.  Juan Atkins updates the
classic and gives it a truly amazing atmospheric treatment.  I've mixed
this everywhere from -6 to +4 and it sounds great every time.

I'm not finding a lot I currently like in the standard house/progressive
house vein, but a few here and there.  Kult Records from New York is a
real good label for that right now.  Doran and Paul Grogan's label
Rampant from LA continues to put out high quality releases.  The West
Coast as a whole is jumping right now, I must say!

I'm getting ready to put together another "best of" annual summary.
It's kind of a cliche to do those but it's fun.  '95 has been a weak
year overall for me for new releases, but as always there is a lot of
good stuff when you dig deep enough.

phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Dec  6 16:01:58 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA05113; Wed, 6 Dec 1995 16:01:58 -0800
Received: from nova.unix.portal.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA05085; Wed, 6 Dec 1995 16:01:41 -0800
Received: from jobe.shell.portal.com (jobe.shell.portal.com [156.151.3.4]) by nova.unix.portal.com (8.6.11/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA25105 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 6 Dec 1995 16:00:25 -0800
Received: (grigsby@localhost) by jobe.shell.portal.com (8.6.11/8.6.5) id QAA25198 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 6 Dec 1995 16:00:17 -0800
From: Grigsbeast <grigsby@shell.portal.com>
Message-Id: <199512070000.QAA25198@jobe.shell.portal.com>
Subject: More Ear Damage Questions
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 6 Dec 1995 16:00:16 -0800 (PST)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951206120023.11000A-100000@apollo> from "Sun Kim" at Dec 6, 95 12:00:59 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1718      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> > Heavily distorted sound is much more damaging to the ears than clean
> > sound at the same volume level.  If it hurts even with earplugs I'm glad
> > I wasn't there.  Tinnitus *sucks*, ladies and gentlemen.
> 
> Can you explain to me why distorted sounds damage your ear more than 
> clean sound?

(Note: I have forwarded this to the list, since it's a good question.)

"Clean" musical reproduction at a given power level has a certain
distribution of frequencies (low sounds vs. mids vs. highs).

Distorted reproduction, in the case of overdriven amplifiers, means
clipping: the amp cannot reproduce the peak of the input signal, and
chops off the top and bottom.  This introduces high frequencies into
the sound that were not there before -- if you clip a sine wave (no 
frequencies higher than the fundamental tone) you get a square wave, 
which contains every 2nd harmonic over than the fundamental, i.e. a lot
more highs.

Our ears do not hear high and low sounds equally: they are most sensitive
to the area between 1 KHz and 5 KHz, an area above most musical notes but
smack in the middle of the range of frequencies introduced by clipping.

(This, incidentally, is why it is much easier to hear a whisper than a 
mumble over long distances, and why a distorted rock guitar _sounds_
much louder than an acoustic guitar even though you haven't turned your
stereo up at all.)

Therefore, clipping is taking sound frequencies that were distributed 
in a certain way from low to high, and concentrating much more of them in
the ear's most sensitive range, which can cause an otherwise safe sound
level to become dangerous, or a dangerous sound level to become more painful.

I hope this makes sense,

// g

just wanted to share two of things which reminds me of how wonderfull
the world is:

1)  climbing to the top of the highest thing around (works best if it is
	a mountain) and looking out over everything and knowing that this
	is YOUR world to experience, enjoy, care for, and to love.

2)  waking up cuddled up with the person you love knowing that whatever
	happens today, no matter how bad life gets; you will always have
	that someone there to make it all better and to bring a ray
	of joy into your life.

Received: from [204.212.196.121] (also-57.ppp.hooked.net [204.212.196.121]) by mom.hooked.net (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id UAA16669 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 6 Dec 1995 20:44:06 -0800

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Wed, 6 Dec 1995 21:44:31 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: scavelti@hooked.net (Stephan & Lydia)
Subject: Re: Earplugs (more info)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> I've heard somehting
>>about "musicians" earplugs which lower the vibrations, but don't muffle
>>the music.  I imagine this was what Rick was talking about, but I don't
>>think I can afford to go to the Doctor and have special ones made up.
>
>My doctor made no effort to verify if I was telling the truth about being a
>musician/dj, and being a musician/dj is why I got them paid for by my
>insurance. You could try that yourself.  If you had to pay it would be
>around $50.
>
>Rick

Hi all,

        I got a pair of musician's earplugs 6 years ago for use in band
rehearsal's & gigs. They have special attenuators with a very flat response
(they lower the volume without changing the overall balance of sound). I
don't go anywhere without them and would highly recommend them to everyone
on this list. I got mine at UCSF medical center audiology dept. Tony Wills
is the contact there at 415-476-5101. You may think of the $120 they cost
as being too expensive but if you look at it in relation to the very high
possibility of permanent hearing loss I think they are relatively cheap.
Look at it this way, if you pay $10-$15 for each rave, you could cut back a
bit over a few months and easily make up for the $120. That to me is a
small sacrifice for saving one of our most important senses. I think the
organization H.E.A.R. also has special earplugs available which might be
less expensive. Do whatever you must but protect those little ears so you
can continue to enjoy all the incredible music out there.

Love Lydia

>      I think there was also a more "machismo/male/almost aggro" vibe this

>      bad enough Saturday night to where a guy grabbed me while I was 
>      walking by.  How did I deal with this?  I patted him on the back, told 
>      him he had a nice smile (he did as he grabbed me) and told him I was 
>      with someone when he asked me.  That way we both felt okay about it.  
>      I know not everyone can do this but there was no sense in making it 
>      worse.  
 
hmmm...just have to comment...not to say "you shouldn't have done it that 
way" or anything, cuz you were there and i wasn't and it's really up to 
every individual how they want to deal w/ unwanted sexual advances, but 
my  2Cents is that preserving this boy's "manhood" by complimenting him, 
etc. is not exactly going to teach him not to touch women w/o asking 
first/at least inititating conversation w/ them.  sometimes it does make 
sense to make a situation "worse" if it's going to teaching someone 
something.

all i know is i feel like it's sort of my conditioned response in social 
situations to make everyone, including someone who's put his arm around 
me when i didn't invite it, at ease, instead of being like "yo, excuse 
me!" and i usually feel shitty later if i didn't say something more 
direct.  

i know we're all s'posed ot be all "lovey huggy" at raves, but a lot of 
times i think it's just an excuse for men to get a feel.  i know that as 
i've partied more, i've grown more and more discerning about who's going 
to get a hug.  (and it ain't gonna be someone who whines when i don't hug 
him!)

monicat

Really?  You mean if you buy into the concept of PLUR totally, there is no
chance of you getting religious or fanatical about a concept, no matter how
noble?  Is PLUR really all that infallible that even it cannot be misused?


>It's obviouse that who ever did this is either crazy or just an immature
>practical joker.

I am in no position to asses ones sanity, nor do I know how mature this
person is/was.  For all I know it coulda been Bob Dole who made the call.
Maturity has little to do with a death threat.  Death itself is another
matter.  I think a person made a threat.  You can treat this as heavily or
as lightly as you want.  I would just be sure that the threat is not real
before letting my guard down completely.

>As for fanaticism and religion where do you see this?

The question is, how can you not?

>The spirituality
>of most ravers I've met is anything BUT religion.  In fact it's the
>absence of religion.  The belief that each human is a complete
>individual totaly seperate yet completely united with everything and on
>his or her OWN Path.  There is no religion or organization or
>fanatisism in this.

Where there is an idea, there is the possibility of fanaticism.  I would
never be so bold as to second guess human nature.  All people need is a
flag, the color, or slogan after that is just a motivational device.  PLUR
is no exception. No human idea/concept or thought is immune from this IMO.
It's just where we are as a species today.

>
>At least no more fanatisims than your constant habit of taken
>agressive stances on issues and spreading negative vibe.
>
>chris

Or so you perceive.  In any case, I was not the one who made a death
threat, I was not the one who had petty rivalries with promoters, dj's or
whatnot, I was not the one to cry about someone doing a party the same day
as me, I was not the one who disses people behind their backs only to
remain silent when I meet them, I am not the one to talk about doing
something and not do it, I do not level criticism w/o offering a solution
of some sorts.  I dunno, I see more negativity in your indictment than in
mine.



"PLUR my ass!", I said.  What does it mean?:

Maybe I meant that there are fanatics who buy into this concept so much
that maybe they only apply it to their circle of friends.  And if they feel
an external force is acting to the contrary, they see fit to pay
retribution in some form, to defend and pepetuate the ideal as they see it.


Maybe I meant that this scene talks much about ideas and not living up to
them.  PLUR being no exception (I mean c'mon; another flyer reads "Printed
On Recycled Paper" w/ the recylce logo, and another , and another, and
another, all over the floor...oh look, there's another).

Maybe I meant that there are those who have yet to understand and live the
ideal.

Maybe I meant that there are clueless people in our scene, and nobody
attempted to educate them. Or maybe an attempt to educate someone failed.

Maybe I meant PLUR is near impossible in a scene where money is involved
(in this society, money is a constant; no such thing as free, another nice
ideal).

Maybe I was mad.

There are many possibilities.

I don't talk about PLUR, I don't even use that acronym other than here on
the list.  I do however *LIVE*, as close to the ideal as possible, instead
of spouting it as some meaningless group of letters (which mean NOTHING,
NOTHING unless it is lived, not talked about, LIVED!).  I don't use it to
beat people over the heads with as some ideal we should all strive for.
Nope, I have always thought, the best way to aspouse an ideal is to live
it.  Nothing is more genuine than that.  You gotta walk the walk, or make a
good attempt to.

In any case, thanks for the reply, and the feedback.

Peace out,
John


A real indictment, if you wanna call it that:
What I find funny, the level of criticism raised against some who question
others complete misinformation, yet allow people to use the word "gangstah"
with near impunity.  Also amusing is the way people allow such
disinformation to be debated as though it were truth, and when some people
ciriticize the dis/misinformation, they are the ones labelling others
"negative" or "vibe killers" (is labelling PLUR?). Another rib-tickler is
how people find the tiniest thing to crticize here in our scene, and yet
remain so myopic as to not see the variety that surrounds them (remember
the "there's no techno in SF", stuff a short while ago?).  One for the
funny bone is how any negative comment, even if it is, god forbid,
constructive, is once again labelled "negative" for no other reason than it
said something contrary to others beliefs.

I dunno...I just wanna take a shower, I'm going out to dinner.

Ciao!

From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Solution to a plague that will divide us all
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My brothers and sisters,

After some self-examination, and introspection, along with some of my own
brand of self-criticism, I have come to a conclusion;I am a hypocrite.

I have for years preached the credo, I have even lived the credo of which I
spoke, but I have come to realize, that even after all of this, my deep
faith in my own lived convictions was but an edifice; it must be dealt
with.

Yes, I have talked, and even acted on my own behalf in this matter, but I
have NOT, I repeat, NOT taken any ACTION to make my deeds a reality, a
tangible reality.  So I confess to you, my brothers and sisters, so that I
may find some compassion within you, that I might find the will and
strength to take that final step.  Yes, that final step from living my
words, to acting on my words.  Making my words *LIVING ACTION*. I like to
call my step, LA for short, but bear with me, please.  I have been remiss,
and I will correct my mistake with great vigor.

For years I have lived and breathed the credo, now I offer my soltution for
one and all.  A solution to a plague that will, eventually, destroy the
house we have all built.  Yes, my brothers and sisters,  I am taking my
credo and making it real.  BBYR, or better said "Bathe Before You Rave",
will now be a reality at every event I attend!

For years, now I have taken showers or baths in preperation for my long
nights of crackerjacking and raving.  My preperation has guaranteed a
certain comfort level, to those around me for 8 hours straight (or 8 hours
gay as it may be) while dancing, and most certainly for the 4 hour brain
cooldown at various dens on iniquity (like the onld DNA).  From here on in,
all of you, especially my most odiferous, funk laden,
sosmellynotevensageorganjacansupressthaFUNK, bothers and sisters can rest
assured, that I will act.

LABBYR - Live Action Bathe Before You Rave

I will:

-Notify my brtheren of thier funk, lest they sin against thy neighbor.
-At holiest of holies events I will carry perfumes, soaps, and other sundry
items to releive my bretheren of thier plague, so that their days might be
long, and odor free.
-At holiest of holies, bring in at least 2 portable showers, and baths for
those who offend, to continue to attend.  So sayeth me.
-Provide for thy bretheren that which they may not possess; give them water
and soap.
-Provide copius incense for those unknowing of the offense they offer their
bretheren.
-Be kind in the notice, but quick in the delivery of the cleansing.  Do
unto them, as you do unto yourself everyday.
-Be sure to bring a high powered water hose; for some funk of thy neighbor
may require drastic measure, so sayeth me.
-And lastly, a sprinkle a day helps keep odor away.

Oh yes my brothers and sisters, I do have a calling, and cleanliness before
raving is thy name!

Yours in the wash,
The Reverend Chief Boot Nocka

I seal my covenant with thee, now pass the Irish Spring!


A quick note:
You know, I have wondered what in the hell happened to my booty and bra
girls of late.  Man, I remember many an e filled night watching hte bodies
of so many fine sisters and sistahs shaking, moving, and grooving, in
nothing but underwear (usually cheap, unless they are a dancer or something
;).  Of late this hardly happens, even if it's friggin' 150 F in the place.
And it was through examining this that I figured out the reason, and came
up with the pact of cleanliness I share with you all.  The reason is sweaty
unshowered shirtless brothers and brothas, plain and simple.  Hell, if *I*
was a B5 kickin' betty, I damn wouldn't want some smelly dude trying to;
freak me, talk to me, bump into me with his sweaty chest.  And why do guys
see it so fit to take of their shirts in the first place?  I guess it's one
of the unsolved mysteries of our time!  I guess the booty and bra bettys
will come back when dudes decide to clean up their act; literally!


Many smiles to you all! :):):)

And yes, I'm a bit anal about the whole thing, but damn, my shit rarely
stinks! ;)

Peace out,
John

This is a great idea.  It is also kind of what a lot of us envision for 
the New Full Moon party that is now in its third month.

What we want to do with the Communal Full Moon is bring together lots of 
different groups with different sounds, such as gateway, sfraves, friends
and family- which has always been a very sfraves-oriented party but 
includes lots of people, hence the name...), new moon, frequency 8, j & k 
sound, to name a few of the tribes that are involved.

Central again to the fledgeling full moon is the idea that we give lots
of dj's, lots of styles, a chance to be heard.  Techno and electronic
music is evolving SO FAST right now.  I don't want to miss a thing.

Love,

Ann

> 
> >The spirituality
> >of most ravers I've met is anything BUT religion.  In fact it's the
> >absence of religion.  The belief that each human is a complete
> >individual totaly seperate yet completely united with everything and on
> >his or her OWN Path.  There is no religion or organization or
> >fanatisism in this.
>

IMHO Spirituality is the Direct Experience of the Divine, once you
start to put it into words and point of view it becomes Religon.

A couple of years ago, when I was in my speaker tweeker phase
(as some of you remember :). I remember one night when I had my head in a 
bass bin:) and there was this guy next to me and we were both totally
grooving to this fairly hard Techno song (It was a Toon Town :) and
we both looked each other in the eyes and each of us Knew, and each of
us knew that the other Knew, and it was the most Beautiful Thing;
that, for me, is the spirituality behind the experience of raving, now
when I talk about it, even the assertion that I just made about it,
well, then it becomes something religeous (or at least philosophical).

I still see that guy every now and then at parties and we both remember
each other and that experience, we generally give each other a big hug,
(and if you saw this guy, you wouldn't think we were friends, he doesn't 
look like a "raver", he looks more like someone on 90210 and hugging a big
black guys would seem to definitely be out of charecter for him :)
but for me, he demonstrates more Peace Love Unity and Respect by his 
actions then I have seen by folks' actions around here of late, (myself 
included). When we see each other, we both still know that the other Knows.
We don't talk about it or give it a name or acronym or anything but the
experience bonds us and it always will, till we're both 90 years old.



 
> Where there is an idea, there is the possibility of fanaticism.  I would
> never be so bold as to second guess human nature.  All people need is a
> flag, the color, or slogan after that is just a motivational device.  PLUR
> is no exception. No human idea/concept or thought is immune from this IMO.
> It's just where we are as a species today.
> 

So true, witness what just happened a few days ago with the FMR, I, 
feeling in the right come up against some other folks who also feel
in the right, (this is how wars start folks).  Now both sides are "good"
people, (and I really mean this, as far as the whole FMR thing, I know
Claire et. al. and she truly is a wonderful person)  I also know that
I am not an evil person and I know many of the wicked crew and they are not
evil people, but guess what? When we all decide that we are right in our 
stance, then we do really stupid things, we seperate ourselves from the
"evil ones" (first mistake, evil is a disease, it can infect anyone and 
any society, do you believe that even the majority of the population
of Nazi Germany were evil people? I bet not, but look what happened to 
them because they went along with a bunch of people who thought (with some
convoluted logic) that they were doing the right thing), make them wrong
and ourselves right and seek to destroy the external evil instead of 
eradicating it from our own hearts.

> >
> >At least no more fanatisims than your constant habit of taken
> >agressive stances on issues and spreading negative vibe.
> >
> >chris
> 

John is a warrior, he has strong opinions and voices them. I have never
heard him say anything negative about anyone that he would not say to their
face, IMO this is a good trait that many could follow, we don't always agree
but then I know at most times EXACTLY where john is comming from, most
peple are covert in their aggression, John is out with it and then it's over.
If john is going to make a death threat, he will make it to your face,
not call you up on the phone anonnymously :)


> Or so you perceive.  In any case, I was not the one who made a death
> threat, I was not the one who had petty rivalries with promoters, dj's or
> whatnot, I was not the one to cry about someone doing a party the same day
> as me, I was not the one who disses people behind their backs only to
> remain silent when I meet them, I am not the one to talk about doing
> something and not do it, I do not level criticism w/o offering a solution
> of some sorts.  I dunno, I see more negativity in your indictment than in
> mine.
> 
> 

Some folks have to realize that there are some people around who have been
going out for a very long time, jsl, even though he doesn't go out too
often anymore did his fair share of "jackin" and has been a party promoter
both here and in L.A. (I'm not sure about the L.A. part :) He used to do 
parties with the late Will Hicks who some of you dearly remember, most of 
these events happened before many of you subscribed, during a time when
PLUR was experienced as opposed to being talked about, (in fact, this list
is the only place that I have ever heard it used :).  He like I, know
many of the people who are the "ring leaders" of the SF Scene, there are
events, situations, alliances, love affairs, break-ups, feuds, politics
(all the elements of human nature) that cause many of the events that
shape what some refer to as Our Scene, 99% of the people on this list
know less than 1% of all of these actions, which are the primary shaping
forces behind what everyone else perceives. I, who know many of the players
only know maybe an order of magnitude more (which brings my knowledge
to about 10% :), when I was going out three times a week (a necessity,
if you want to REALLY be in the know), maybe I knew about 30% of all of the
stuff, but believe me there are somethings that I wish that I could have 
stayed naieve about (and I'm sure JSL can support that). Most of these 
things can't be talked about on the list for various reason, some things
are very personal and would ruins people's lives, some things might land 
people in prison or worse, sometimes some of it leaks through, (like the
death threats which I should not have posted about, sorry Garth :) and
it always gets distorted and twisted and turned into a religeous argument :)

Geoff:
> IMHO Spirituality is the Direct Experience of the Divine, once you

But since the "Divine" exists in everything, wouldn't any direct
experience/connection with music, people, nature, etc. be spiritual?
Surely you're not suggesting "You either see God or you don't".

> when I talk about it, even the assertion that I just made about it,
> well, then it becomes something religeous (or at least philosophical).

Yeah, PLUR is really a philosophy.  And (while I'm harping on 
definitions) religion is the institutionalization of spiritual philosophy.
I don't think PLUR has been institutionalized in the scene - there's
no structure of enforcement, or written doctrine, or any established
protocols of implementation beyond "let's try to be nicer to each other."
How frightening.  Am I missing something?

JS Lee:  
> > Where there is an idea, there is the possibility of fanaticism.  I would
> > never be so bold as to second guess human nature.  All people need is a
> > flag, the color, or slogan after that is just a motivational device.  PLUR
> > is no exception. No human idea/concept or thought is immune from this IMO.
> > It's just where we are as a species today.

Very true.  I guess I no longer build my opinions around worst case
scenerios.  3 days ago I received a phone call from someone trying to
convert me to Christianity.  She took my name from the phonebook because
"it looked Jewish".  This incident reaffirmed my distrust for *anyone* 
who touts the name "Jesus" because in my experience such people seem to
be more prone to fanaticism.  Yes, *any* idea can be used abusively.  So 
should we distrust of all people who express ideas?

> [good 'ol days drivel deleted]
> PLUR was experienced as opposed to being talked about,

Why do you see these "opposing" one another.  Is it wrong to try to
talk about our experiences?  Or must these these amazing feelings
remain only in the unspoken realm of "knowing looks".  I agree that
words limit and reduce the meaning of such abstract concepts.
Nevetheless, the path to understanding and enlightenment can't 
always be pristine.  I also don't believe that our everyday verbal
plain of existence is something distinct and separate from the
spiritual.

>(in fact, this list
> is the only place that I have ever heard it used :).

It gets debated on other rave lists as well as alt.rave.  Maybe
PLUR is just a net thing, which (surprise) is limited to mostly words.
It has always been a criticism of computer & net users that we
use this technology *instead* of actually experiencing life.  Well
here we all are... these lowly words must be doing something for us.  

> > "PLUR my ass!", I said.  What does it mean?:
> 
> "Get out on the Dance Floor!" :)

Agreed :)

> "Action!, not words"

Let's remember that Communication is an action, too. :)

Lee

> ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>    ******   ********   **************
>   ********  *********  **************
>   **        **      **      ***               POLICY POST
>   **        **      **      ***
>   **        **      **      ***               December 6, 1995
>   **        **      **      ***               Number 32
>   ********  *********       ***
>    ******   ********        ***
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>   A briefing on public policy issues affecting civil liberties online
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------
> CDT POLICY POST Number 32                      December 6, 1995
> 
> CONTENTS: (1) House Conferees Approve Sweeping Net-Censorship Proposal
>               * White Proposal Approved, Then Gutted by Religious
> Conservatives
>               * 2 Liberal Democrats Abandon the First Amendment
>               * Senate Passage Expected Without Substantial Amendment
>               * Court Challenge Likely
> 
> 
> This document may be re-distributed freely provided it remains in its
> entirety. Excerpts may be re-posted by permission (editor@cdt.org)
> -------------------------------------------------------------------------
> 
> (1) HOUSE CONFEREES APPROVE SWEEPING NET-CENSORSHIP PROPOSAL
> 
> House Conferees Approve Sweeping Net-Censorship Proposal
> 
> By a razor thin margin, members of the House Conference Committee on
> Telecommunications Reform have approved a broad proposal to censor
> constitutionally protected speech on the Internet. The provisions adopted
> today would make the Internet and Interactive media the most heavily
> regulated medium in the United States, and severely threaten the future of
> free expression and democratic values in the information age.
> 
> The proposal, if agreed to by the full conference committee, would impose
> $100,000 fines and prison terms for anyone who posts any "indecent"
> material, including the "7 dirty words", the text of classic works of
> fiction such as The Catcher In The Rye, or Ulysses, artwork containing
> images of nudes, rap lyrics, in a public forum.
> 
> CDT strongly opposes the legislation agreed to by the House conferees
> today. We believe this proposal threatens the very existence of the
> Internet as a means for free expression, education, and political
> discourse. The proposal is an unwarranted, unconstitutional intrusion by
> the Federal government into the private lives of all Americans.
> 
> Indecent material is constitutionally protected speech which the Supreme
> Court has ruled can only be restrictive through the "least restrictive
> means". Material that has been considered "indecent" has included, among
> other things:
> 
> * The so-called "7 dirty words"
> * The Catcher In The Rye
> * Sex and AIDS Education literature
> * Photographic, sculpted, and painted images of nudes
> * Rap Lyrics
> 
> Posting any of the above materials in a public forum would be illegal under
> the provision approved today. Although it is unrealistic to expect that
> Federal law enforcement has the resources to go after each and every
> violation, the threat of $100,000 fines and 2 year prison sentences will
> result in a severe chilling effect over all online communications.
> 
> CDT will devote all our efforts in the coming weeks to ensure that the full
> conference committee does not endorse the approach approved today by the
> House. We are also committed to fighting this battle all the way to the
> Supreme Court, if necessary, to ensure that these provisions are
> overturned.
> 
> The text of the proposal will be placed on CDT's net-censorship web page
> (URL below) as soon as it's available. CDT will also post a detailed
> analysis of the bill soon.
> 
> WHITE PROPOSAL ADOPTED, THEN AMENDED TO INCLUDE INDECENCY STANDARD
>  2 LIBERAL DEMOCRATS TIP THE SCALES IN FAVOR OF RELIGIOUS-RIGHT
> 
> At today's meeting of the House and Senate Conference Committee members,
> Rep. Henry Hyde (R-IL) offered his proposal to prohibit the transmission
> and display of indecent material online, and grant the FCC new authority to
> regulate the Internet. As expected, Rep. Rick White (R-WA) offered his
> alternative, based on the narrow and constitutional "harmful to minors"
> standard and provisions to encourage parental control, not government
> censorship. The House conferees then adjourned to a private room, away from
> the press and television cameras, to vote.
> 
> The Conferees voted 20 - 13 to accept the White proposal. However, Rep.
> Goodlatte (R-VA) offered an amendment to substitute "indecency" for the
> "harmful to minors" standard in the White proposal. The Goodlatte amendment
> was approved on a vote of 17 - 16 and the "harmful to minors" standard was
> replaced by the blatantly unconstitutional "indecency standard".
> Representative White did NOT vote for the Goodlatte amendment.
> 
> Amazingly, two traditionally liberal democrats, Reps. Pat Schroeder (D-CO)
> and John Conyers (D-MI) voted for the "indecency" standard! Had either of
> these members voted the other way, libraries, schools, and even parents who
> allow children to access the text of The Catcher In The Rye online would
> not now face $100,000 fines and prison sentences. Schroeder and Conyers
> should be ashamed of themselves for not standing up for freedom of speech
> and democratic values at such a critical moment, and for assisting the
> campaign of religious conservatives to impose their moral values on the
> Internet without regard for long-standing constitutional principals.
> 
> Representative White should be commended for his efforts to craft a
> constitutional proposal which preserved freedom of speech and relied on
> user empowerment over government control of online content. He deserves
> great credit for his commitment to protecting the Internet and preserving
> freedom of speech, and his willingness to stand up to religious
> conservatives. Unfortunately, the critical element of his proposal which
> made it constitutional was removed over White's objections.
> 
> NEXT STEPS
> 
> The provision approved today by the committee is similar to the Exon/Coats
> CDA in that it relies on the "indecency" standard and contains defenses for
> online service providers. The Senate is likely to adopt the proposal with
> only minor changes. Senator Exon expressed optimism at today's conference
> committee meeting that the issue would be resolved soon, perhaps as early
> as Friday.
> 
> The Senate conferees are reviewing the language agreed to today by the
> House conferees. The House and Senate must each agree on the provisions
> before the final bill can be voted on. CDT will keep you informed of
> developments on this issue as they occur.
> 
> FOR MORE INFORMATION
> 
> Visit CDT's net-censorship issues web page:
> 
>     http://www.cdt.org/cda.html
> 
> ###

-- 
Mike Lasmanis     | "The real voyage of discovery consists not in seeing
mikel@cctech.com  |  new landscapes but in having new eyes."  Marcel Proust

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Dec  7 12:38:22 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA05736; Thu, 7 Dec 1995 12:38:22 -0800
Received: from netcom17.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA05729; Thu, 7 Dec 1995 12:38:17 -0800
Received: from localhost by netcom17.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id MAA01146; Thu, 7 Dec 1995 12:36:24 -0800
Message-Id: <199512072036.MAA01146@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Mixer fuzz boxes!
Date: Thu, 07 Dec 95 12:36:24 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Consider getting a professional outboard compressor and/or "tube
distortion" box. These typically fit into a single rack space.

Depending on how fancy you get, you can find units that give you the
kind of compression/distortion you get from recording a really hot
signal onto an analogue tape (a weird electromagnetic hysteresis effect
that is kinda hard to reproduce electronically), soft limiting, or
guitar fuzz (aka tube distortion). sometimes these functions are
combined into multi-effects boxes, but IMHO, a real tube or FET driven
into distortion sounds far more euphonic than the 90's digital
equivalent from a multi-efx box. However, if you do use a vacuum tube
(it's actually a very simple circuit if you're an electronics buff)
remember that it may sound pretty strange in live situations because
vacuum tubes can act like microphones when they get vibrated by bass
(gives you feedback).

oh, as with all pro audio equipment, this shit ain't cheap.

poke around in http://www.sweetwater.com and you may find what you
need. sign up for their catalog so you can drool over all the latest
audio stuff that you can't afford...

NP: "We Come Back (exclusive dub plate remix)" by Drum & Bass.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Date: Thu, 07 Dec 95 12:48:04 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Why doesn't anyone dress up 
> anymore at parties? Is that the promoters' fault too? NNNNOOOOOO! At 
> the Gathering coming up in Dec. Some of the Harmony crew (including 
> myself), are going to be in our crayon suits again. I would like to 
> urge as many people as possible to dress up once again for this four 
> year anniversary. 

I don't usually dress up because i go to raves so I can dance. And when
I dance hard for hours on end, I sweat like a pig. So simple clothing
(e.g. t-shirt, light pants) are in order lest i want to come out
looking like a drowned rat in the morning.

Show me a well ventilated party where they keep the windows open all
night, let you walk in and out, and I'll be far more inclined to wear
some weird clothes. All my raving experiences have shown me that this
is probably the hardest thing to predetermine, so I just wear stupid
lamo clothes that I feel comfortable in while sweating.

And yeah, maximum respect goes out to those that can wear weird clothing,
dance like maniacs, and come out looking fresh in the morning. I can't.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

> -At holiest of holies events I will carry perfumes, soaps, and other sundry
> items to releive my bretheren of thier plague, so that their days might be
> long, and odor free.
> 
> -Provide copius incense for those unknowing of the offense they offer their
> bretheren.

I don't know about you or other sfraves, but an overabundance of
perfumes and incense can give me a major splitting headache, get me
sneezing and my eyes watering, etc. I guess this is just another in a
long list of allergies. At least foul smelling BO doesn't do that to
me. 

So in addition to John's list, please, if you can't take a shower,
please don't bathe yourself in cologne. It can really do a number on
some of us.

Better yet, how about having raves in venues where there's adequate
ventilation and some reduction of crowding. I thought last weekend's
wicked @ 174 King street was nasty for those reasons. ANd when
everybody feels like a caged rat breathing someone elses anal vapours,
it gets hard to let the vibe flow.

At 4:48 PM 12/6/95, Fred Heutte wrote:
>New hot tracks?  Thought ya'd never ask :)
>
>I agree with Joe, Dave Angel's new album is excellent.  I know
>Soundworks has it because I got mine there.  Now that he's dropped
>the mad-techno thing and starting making the music he clearly wants
>to, it's a new step up.  Excellent, jazzy, deep.
>

Dropped the mad-techno thing? He's always done jazzy, deep tracks, except
for maybe the 1st Voyage w/CJ Bolland on R&S. The New Orchestrations EP on
FNAC, The Family EP on Apollo, and the Royal Techno EP on Rotation are all
beautiful records.

I just got a new shipment from Detroit, and the Electronic Warfare double
on Underground Resistance is an excellent collection of electro and techno
grooves.

For mellower techno vibes grab the Titonton EP on Metamorphic (Dan Curtin's
label) There's one absolutely stunning slightly acidic track on there that
really swept me away upon first listen.

For straight up dancefloor eruption check out the two releases on Dirty
House records (Australia via Detroit).

In a local vein, Darren and La Paix have done an excellent three-tracker to
be released by SFRaver and F&Fer Jamie Spence on his own Belief Systems
label. A new definition of the San Francisco sound - if you blindfolded me
I would have sworn this was a Pure Plastic or Plink Plonk record. It should
be out in a month or so - bug your local store to get some copies.

Joe

I love this list.

First mudslinging, then fingerpointing, then reconciliation, and
finally...concensus? 

Perhaps, at least until the next "thing" urks someone.

I was talking to someone I bumped into the other day on Hippy Hill in GG
park. The subject came up of "the underground". The quote was made:

"San Francisco... just a bunch of alternative idealists..."

Hmmm....  ;)
 

So I get this email. EDF has it worked out that all you need to do to
complain to the Feds about things is send an email to their new service. It
then gets turned into a fax and sent to the appropriate person. Now I have
no excuse not to bitch to someone. 

Gotta love modern technology.

later...

Jonas

>
>Environmental Defense Fund
>Action Alert -- URGENT
>
>To:       EDF Activists
>From:     William Roberts, EDF Legislative Director
>Date:     December 6, 1995
>Subject:  Action Alert System Improvements
>
>
>Next week, the week of December 11th, we'll be testing a new
>automated Action Alert system that will greatly simplify and
>improve the way you can then respond to EDF Action Alerts.
>We hope you'll agree to "test drive" this new system and give us
>feedback on ways to make it better.
>
>Here's how the improved response system works and what we would
>like you to do:
>
>     *  We have created an automated system that let's you
>        respond to an alert by creating a message to your legislator
>        on-line.  All you need to do is choose the "Reply" option in
>        your email software, type your message and send it off.  It's
>        important that when you choose "Reply" that you also choose
>        NOT to attach the original message, if your software presents
>        you with that option.  Your response will be transformed into a
>        fax and automatically forwarded to the appropriate legislators.
>
>
>     *  When you receive our Action Alert next week on the International
>        Dolphin Conservation Program Act, we ask that you respond to the
>        Alert as soon as you can.  Instructions will also be included with
>        the alert message for your convenience.
>
>Once you've responded to the Alert, please write us at
>Congress@edf.org and let us know what you thought of the new system.
>Were the instructions clear?  Did responding on-line, as opposed to directly
>placing phone calls as we have asked in the past, make it easier or more
>difficult for you to take action?  Etc.  Also, if you have any suggestions,
>comments or questions, please let us know those too.
>
>We appreciate your willingness to help us during this test phase.
>Your participation and constructive feedback are invaluable to us in
>guaranteeing that our new upgrades are user-friendly, as well as efficient.
>
>Once again, thank you in advance for your assistance.  We'll be in
>contact with you next week.
>
>

	id OAA12932; Thu, 7 Dec 1995 14:42:29 -0800
Message-Id: <199512072242.OAA12932@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, idm@hyperreal.com
Subject: favorite compilation CD of the month
Date: Thu, 07 Dec 95 14:42:28 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The other day, on a whim I picked up "S.U. Corporation Presents Dub
Plate Selection" STHCCD15. (S.U. Corporation are the people that put
out strictly hardcore and strictly undeground compilations). I picked
it up at Reckless for $28.50 and I was thinking to myself, you are a
complete ninny for paying this much for a single UK import CD.

But then I got it home, and now I can't get it off my CD player.

It's got a nice mix of really fast beats, fast sequencer trix (gating/
echoes/reverses etc) combined with dubby effects, people with jamaican
accents saying things like "come selectah", occasional house diva
vocals, and slow melodic/bass riffs. I guess you could call it jungle
or drum&bass, except that most jungle bores the shit out of me -- this
doesn't, because the dub factor makes it musically interesting.
Bass-ically, it makes me want to dance around the house, turn it up to
deafening volumes, and when I'm in my car, I tend to find myself
driving over 90MPH when I listen to it.

Track List (*'s denote my favorites):

1. (*) Selecter -- Gangster Sound (Dub Plate)
2.  How Many Ways -- Just Intelligence (Dub Plate)
3. (*) We Come Back -- Drum & Bass (exclusive dub plate remix)
4. (*) Big Request -- Gangster Sound (Exclusive Dub plate remix)
5. Illusions -- A Sides (exclusive dub plate remix)
6. (*) Sax -- Jazz Vibes (exclusive dub plate remix)
7. Exclusive -- Xclusive (exclusive dub plate remix)
8. Volcano Style -- Urban Jungle (dub plate)
9. Fire -- BDP (dub plate)
10. (*) Feel Good -- The Dominion (dub plate)
11. (*) No War Business -- Xclusive (dub plate)
12. Searchin Hard -- Uncle 22 (dub plate)

I actually like the tracks produced by Drum and Bass and Gangster Sound
the best. #4 has some really outlandish mixing going on, stuff that I
would never think would work together (really fast beats combined with
a slow disco bop) slid together with niceness. #6 is acid jazzy with a
twitchy beat; kinda strange/interesting... #11 is a harsh & noize laden
onslaught of dub that rocks hard and then goes into this smooth piano
riff that floats you away while the vocals have some guy in a jamaican
accent talking gibberish about rude boys, wickedness, and "no war"... 

Where should I look for more trax by these artists?? Which DJs are
likely to play this style of music in the bay area??

Other things I'd like to find on this label:
	* Illegal Pirate Radio volume 3 (STHC CD 9)
	* Intelligent Drum and Bass volume 2 (STHC CD 12, 13)
	* Ravelation live at Wembley "easter bank holiday '95" (STHC CD 11)

Anybody seen these in the Bay Area? Where?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
=  Niels Mayer   http://www.cyborganic.com/People/niels   mayer@netcom.com  =
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

 by EDEN1.HAC.COM (PMDF V4.3-13 #5884) id <01HYJ57JFCV4000S6H@EDEN1.HAC.COM>;
 Thu, 07 Dec 1995 16:01:48 -0800 (PST)
Date: Thu, 07 Dec 1995 16:01:48 -0800 (PST)
Subject: Galileo Probe enters the Jovian atmosphere!
To: socal-raves@ucsd.edu, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-Id: <01HYJ57JI1B6000S6H@EDEN1.HAC.COM>
X-Vms-To: EDEN1::IN%"socal-raves@ucsd.edu",EDEN1::IN%"sfraves@hyperreal.com"
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

we had a piped-in broadcast from JPL here at work; about a half-hour
  ago, the Galileo probe entered the Jovian atmosphere (3:15 PST)

there are _NO_ pictures coming back, unfortunately; the probe was too
  small to fit a camera in it; however the mother craft in orbit has a
   set of cameras, so maybe we'll se something from it.

the probe is already gone; indeed, it had melted only just after the
  first telemetry reached earth, due to the propagation of light from
    jupiter on the other side of the sun (over 600 million miles away)
going down thru jupiter's atmosphere is like going through 3 or 4 separate
  earth-ian atmospheres, although composed of hydrogen, methane, and
    even water vapor...
after that, the vapors get so dense they are more like water; that's 
  when the probe started to heat up, supposedly; after that, the
    temperature in the inner atmosphere(s)/ocean(s) gets so high, that
      the parachute on the probe starts to melt; and then the aluminum
        parts on the probe melt, too.

telemetry from the spacecraft still in orbit will be relayed back all
  during december and into january; there's the problem of jupiter going
    behind the sun, which will blank out telemetry possibly for a time,
      so it's redundantly being sent back to earth again in january

lemme tellya folks, that's one remote location!  can you imagine a
  rave on a hovering platform somewhere in the upper atmosphere, with
    rainbow-colored clouds above and below as far as the eye can see.....


Dave Scruton

Not to mention lightning bolts hundreds of miles long, arcing from storms
thousands of miles tall!

When people ask me if I have any really far-out plans for my life, my usual
answer is, "Go hang-gliding in the storms of Jupiter."  It's a big universe
out there, and who knows where we'll all be in 50 or 100 years?

One thing, though--wherever humans are, music and parties will also be
there....

Rob
Rob Jellinghaus		robj@best.com

Date: Thu, 7 Dec 1995 15:57:48 +0100
From: Janelle Brown <janelle@hotwired.com>
To: everyone at wired and hotwired
Subject: Protest!

If you haven't heard already, we are organizing a protest against the
Communcations Decency Act and the impending removal of our First Amendment
rights on the Web.  Although we are still in the planning stages, the basic
idea is to have a demonstration at noon in South Park on Monday, December
11.  We want speakers, we want media attention, we want a huge turnout of
angry Americans making themselves visible *outside* of cyberspace.

We need help doing this:  We need people to volunteer their time this
weekend to help us make signs and fliers.
We also need to spread the word so that we can have a protest large enough
to receive national media attention. We have the most powerful
communication tool in the world at our fingertips - lets use it to spread
the word and stop Netizens from being apathetic about their rights.

We need everyone to take a few minutes of their time to back us. The
freedom of the medium that we work in is on the line.  So are our rights as
American citizens.  If you can help with anything, please contact Todd
Lappin (our point man at telstar@hotwired.com) and let him know exactly
what you can help us with.

Thanks.


****

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Dec  7 17:10:33 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA02532; Thu, 7 Dec 1995 17:10:33 -0800
Received: from aoaioxxysz.organic.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA02524; Thu, 7 Dec 1995 17:10:29 -0800
Received: from aoaioxxysz (localhost [127.0.0.1]) by aoaioxxysz.organic.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with ESMTP id RAA24578 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 7 Dec 1995 17:10:18 -0800
Message-Id: <199512080110.RAA24578@aoaioxxysz.organic.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Recent ace purchases (Was: Re: FRESH START (Records!)) 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Thu, 07 Dec 1995 07:38:07 EST."
             <v01510100acec29849f92@[204.191.83.195]> 
Date: Thu, 07 Dec 1995 17:10:17 -0800
From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@organic.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I've been chained to a computer at work, so I haven't been able to listen to
as much of my cool vinyl as I would like, but when I do, stuff that's been
sneaking onto the tables with regularity is:

Alec Empire -- Generation Star Wars (Mille Plateaux)

Ace props to Minor for recommending this one to me. This is very high in my
list of best albums of 1995. Fucked-up acid, fast swing-beat hardcore,
bizarre breakbeats, and occasional moments of wickedly beautiful melody.
Nothing like anything you'll hear at parties in SF, but one of the best
mutant techno albums I've ever heard.

Spooky -- Stereo (Generic)

Once upon a time, Spooky were part of the near-legendary Guerilla
progressive-house stable (along with React 2 Rhythm, DOP, and Superreal),
and cranked out many tracks (including the near-legendary "Little Bullet" in
all its incarnations) that were at various points West Coast staples.
Therefore, I was very (pleasantly) surprised to discover that they've
completely changed directions. The lead, eponymous track on this EP is an
amazing piece of breakbeatish melodic trance. It always gets me dancing
around the apartment (a neat trick, that, considering how cramped my
apartment is).

Accelerator -- Accelerator II (Reload)

I know for a fact that much of the msuci that I spin irritates SF crowds.
Well, this is some of the stuff that irritates people the most and I LOVE
it. Cold, dark sterile techno with fucked-up beats and ominous sounds. This
music is the exact antithesis of everything warm and cuddly, and it does
something weird to my head. I totally dig this shit, and someday you will
too. :) I don't give up easily.

Mike Dearborn -- Razor Sharp / Moments (Djax Up-Beats)

Tons of traxxy uptempo Chicago acid. If any of you know and love Armani,
these doublepacks will both get to you. They were surprisingly cheap at
Rasputin's, and they're full of solidly-constructed, designed to mix
songs. That said, they gain most of their value in the mix, and aren't
exactly great for home listening.

V/A -- Supermarkt (Disko B)

A great compilation of stylish, minimalistic German hardcore and techno.
Among the numerous DJ Hell collaborations (I really don't think that guy
makes any of his own music -- the styles on his tracks are too disparate,
and every track lists different writers) are some totally bizarre tracks by
people like Patrick Pulsinger (a master of lo-fi, dirty acid) and Robert
Gorl (formerly of that wacky group DAF -- anybody here remember
them?). Again, this stuff is hard, stripped-down, and fast.

Felix da Housecat -- Thee Metropolis Present Day (Radikal Fear)

Felix Stallings is an amazingly prolific guy, and I like almost everything
he does. His music spans the house spectrum -- from deep through fruity
through acid through hard. "Thee Metropolis" is an excellent and
representative cross-section of his sound. There are some cool diva tracks,
some interesting experiments with sound, and some patented Felix
weirdness. Great for home listening late at night.

Hard Hop Heathen -- Bastik Beats (Concrete)

Man, I remember when Omar Santana was busy trying to convince the East Coast
that he was the Dark Lord of Hardcore. It's funny to hear his recent stuff
in that light -- Bastik Beats is funked-out hard hop indeed, but it floats
along at an amiable 115 BPM and really isn't that different from what the
Chemical Brothers and Depth Charge have been up to recently. It's a montage
of old hip-hop samples put together with skill and precision, and is very
much tilted towards the dancefloor.

For you CD / cybertrance fans, I have one sterling recommendation:

V/A -- Trancesylvania 4 (23 Frankfurt)

If the Frequency 8 folks (hello!) don't have this one in stock, pester them
to get it. I was lucky, and got my copy for $8.99 at the Tower outlet down
the block. The compilation is 3 CDs full of Goa-style music. After looking
at the weird little squiggles on the CDs, I've decided that the three discs
are broken down along house, trance, and acidtrance lines, but they're very
loosely grouped. The types of music represented are breathtaking -- from the
stripped-down house of Future Sound of Lisbon through the outta hand
speedtrance of Ravers' Nature. I don't normally get into the whole Goan
sound, but I really like this compilation. The people putting it together
obviously care about what went onto the compilation, and it made the
all-nighters I've pulled in the last week that much easier to deal
with. Artists on the compilation include the Prodigy, Joey Beltram, Felix da
Housecat, Emmanuel Top, and a whole slew of German trance artists. It's
worth getting for the Ravers' Nature track, which would ordinarily be the
sort of track that makes me reach for my gun, but for some reason this one
works for me -- 180 BPM and insanely cheerful.

yrz,
ozy

ozymandias G desiderata      ogd@organic.com       Ravers Suck Our Sound
(415)284-6888     http://www.organic.com/Staff/ogd/       ::AOAIOXXYSZ::

At 3:39 PM 12/7/95, Michal Migurski wrote:
>>> well amy, you didn't seem all that shy went you came up to me and
>>> introduced yourself (it was at the outdoor thing by sly park, can't
>>> remember the name).  :-)
>>^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
>>(It was Elevation).... anyways, if neither you or I had on our
>>laminates, it would have been more difficult for me just to come up to ya
>>and start talking.  When I see an sfraves laminate, it is like an
>>automatic ice breaker for me, so for those whom I have met via an sfraves
>>laminate, I don't seem shy, but ask me to go up to someone else, who I
>>don't know the first thing about, and introduce myself - I get all
>>intimidated and I clam up.  Don't know why, I just do. :)  Any others out
>>there like that?
>
>Yeah, yeah!
>
>I'm so timid when I'm in big groups of people... So I retreat into myself
>and close my eyes and just dance... but still trying to overcome shyness,
>so maybe that's why I like going out-- Just trying to get over some
>shortcomings and have fun.
>
>-mikey.

        Well, i sort of used to be like this. Sometimes i still am
(depending on my surroundings) but here's a little mini-revelation (or is
that ravelation? haha) that has allowed me to become more extroverted.
        One time i was at a party and ended up talking to one of the djs (a
pretty big name from the detroit area) and i was nervous and it was just
worse when he seemed to be really snobby. Every time i talked i thought "oh
shit, that sounded dumb" or "that sounded weird" or something but
eventually i realized that he wasn't a snob, he was even more shy than i
was! Eventually we started really talking, had a beer and found out that we
both went to the same grade school in Guelph, Ontario :) I almost lost it!
ha ha He says "oh and you rememebr Miss Collins? i got the strap from her!"
and i said "me too!"
        Ok, enough tangents, the thing that i realized though is that being
confident about yourself is partially knowing yourself, and your good
qualities and partially realizing that often the way in which you envision
someone else affects your behaviour and words. Like when i was talking to
this guy i was thinking "shit, this is the same guy who did ____" or
whatever and i really built him up, but when you see everyone on an equal
footing as you, just different, everyone has something valid to say, and
everyone's experiences and thoughts are valued (at least by me :) or i sure
do try!)
        Most of all here's a crucial, but simple revelation: if you go up
to soemone and start talking to them just in the name of friendliness
(lecherous come-ons might be an exception to this) and they dis you or
brush you off there's a number of things that may be going on:
        1)they are shy
        2)they're a dork (but no-one is a dork forever :) )
        3)they're lost in their own thoughts (and/or are on something that
isn't conducive to talking.)

        I know from personal experience what all three are like, for #2 i
can only feel bad for them not feel hurt because THEY are the ones that are
missing out on the most amazing thing about life: other people. :)
        For #1 what i try my best to do is make people feel at ease and not
seem intimidating, that's the worst when you're shy :( When someone just
_listens_ to what you have to say it means a lot, right? is anyone
listening? hahaha
        well, i hope this helped some people, i know that i spent too many
years of my life avoiding eye contact, walking with my face down, blushing,
etc etc and relying on things to pump me up enough to be able to talk to
people.
        And when i meet some of you, don't worry, i won't bite (unless i'm
payed well that is ;)
        peace,
                brad

At 3:07 PM 12/6/95, Amy R Starkey wrote:
>sort of bond.  I am probably the most un-stuck   up person I know, EGO is
>a nasty word in my vocabulary.  It goes both ways, too.  If a person just
>comes up and starts talking to me, I'll talk right back, with happiness.
>Voila my 2 cents.
        That's me too, though i do my best to go out and actually start up
conversations with people (knowing that if i dont' do it i shouldn't expect
others to) but about Ego, it's weird, i've been realizing that it's pretty
useless in the big picture and a lot of it is what cuts us off from each
other. Ego is the simple statement of "this is where i am and you are not"
you know? When you are egoless (which is, for me, synonymous with ecstatic
and not necessarily pharmaseutically based too :) you are at one with
everything, you don't worry about going up and talking to someone because
they're just a part of you! :) Egos and the conscious/rational part of your
mind structures a lot of your life so you can get shit done but i try my
best not to cling to these arbitrary things too much :)
        peace
                brad

Precedence: bulk

hellllo all

>It's got a nice mix of really fast beats, fast sequencer trix (gating/
>echoes/reverses etc) combined with dubby effects, people with jamaican
>accents saying things like "come selectah", occasional house diva
>vocals, and slow melodic/bass riffs. I guess you could call it jungle
>or drum&bass, except that most jungle bores the shit out of me -- this
>doesn't, because the dub factor makes it musically interesting.

there is a lot of jungle that falls into the above category...in fact, im
surprised that you haven't heard more of it by now.....to everyone...here
my list of all the dj's i know of who play almost all jungle in the Bay
Area:
*starEyes (myself)-mostly hardstep and some intelligent and ragga,as well
as old breaks
*Alex- up and coming intelligent selector...maximum respect
*Thad- darkside master...rollin deep
*Flux- the mash up sounds of the hardstep
*Siobhan
*U.F.O.
*Jonah Sharp- ambient jungle?
*Ocean
*Gamall
*Barry (Primal)-harder stuff, i think
*Malcolm (Primal)-all different styles
there are a couple more i'm sure but i don't know them
anyone who wants to hear some different styles check out me and Thad at
'Nuff Respect...Saturdays...Your Mama's Cafe...Oakland...5-9...also over
Christmas break Alex and Thad will be taking over for us there....


>Where should I look for more trax by these artists?? Which DJs are
>likely to play this st be on dubplate and therefore they were only given
>to DJ's...I have never seen nor heard of any of these artists except on
>this CD...they are not "major" jungle artists...probably only released
>stuff on thi s label...i hesitate to recommend the comps i like cuz i am
>still not sure what style you like...i guess mixtapes would be better....
If you are looking for things with a lot of ragga toasting...like if you
are into the dancehall turned jungle vibe than the top cat vs. general levy
album is pretty decent..it gets a little tiring listening to all that
toasting...shy fx's album is supposed to be good...also D'Cruze's and T
Power's new one....anyone who has more questions on certain jungle CD's or
DJ's..feel free to e-mail me and i will probably be able to sort you out
with some info....:) good luck...and happy bopping all :)

**starEyes**
Biggin' up da jungle vibe '95
maximum respect la massive, chicago, london massive SEEN!

   Well, I failed my duty this week. I missed Come/Unity and didn't get
   too many new flyers for this week. (the line was too long) 
	
   I'll try to pick some flyers up Friday morning and send out an addendum. 
   There seems to be quite a bit of stuff on the list anyway; maybe Chrysalis
   will be the pick of the litter. Some of the other parties may be good,
   but like like $20 affairs.
   
                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html
