Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Thursday, December 7th - _La Bouche_ and _Max-A-Million_
   live at the Rage, Sacramento. 18+, doors at 8pm. $14 for 21+, $16 for
   18+. DJs Michael Hayes & David X spin euro, hi-nrg & jungle. 1890
   Arden Way, Sacramento. directions: 916.929.0232
   
   Thursday, December 7th - Vivid Studios and the NAMES Project
   Foundation present a _Fabulous Benefit_ to launch the AIDS Memorial
   Quilt Website
   Josh Jones & Human Flavor, Fantasy, Gavin, Consciousness Lab Ambient
   Sound Research, and Spesh of Trip 'n Spin. 8pm-2am, 21+, $15 before
   10pm (includes food and drink), $10 after 10. 1015 Folsom.
   
   Friday, December 8th - _Planet Rock_
   Tony & Karizma, DJ Dan & Donald Glaude on 4 decks, Galen, DRC, Matthew
   Gadfathar, DJ Trance, Thee-O, and a live performance by Rebirth
   (featuring DJ Trance + Xpando). Jungle/Hardcore w/R.A.W., Dieselboy,
   Demigod, Shobhan, U.F.O & Noel. 415.437.6939 916.650.8707
   
   Friday, December 8th - _Ultimatum_
   DJs Dimitri (Amsterdam), Mark Lewis (LA), Jeno, Henrik, Pete Avila. At
   the Sound Factory, 525 Harrison. $10. 415.974.9389
   
   Friday, December 8th - United presents _The Sacred Hoop_
   The Sacred Cast: Graeme, Dutch, Ethan, LA's Doran, Simon, Tobin, Jon
   Williams, Nikki Rivera. presale tix $15 at Housewares & In Tha Mix.
   9pm-6am. 415.675.0360 415.535.0230 916.498.8810
   
   Saturday, December 9th - _Smarties_ - "sugar for your soul"
   DJs Scot, Karizma, Tony, Barry Weaver, Jeno, Donald Glaude, Garth and
   guest "sugar daddy". Eye Candy by Synergy. Laser Flavor by Hollywood
   Dog. 415.437.5503 916.484.4006 800.204.3986 408.345.2399 510.464.4677
   
   Saturday, December 9th - Bagok Tribe presents _Intoxication_
   Dreamer & Spinbadd on 4 turntables. Garth, Simon, Glen Garcia (NY),
   Pete Avila; plus Jeff Miller, Sausee, Essence, E-Jay, Ivo.
   415.437.6905

   Ethan, John Carel, Erika, Minor Minor & Monty. Ambient by Claire,
   Consciousness Lab Ambient Sound Research. 10pm-7am, in SF.
   415.536.9453
   
   Saturday, December 9th - Another nite of _Good Times_
   Funkyassdeepdiscohouse w/Julius Papp & Jay-J on 4 turntables, plus
   Chris Lum. Art showing by Peter Macon. Jazz by Miquel. End of
   Stevenson off 10th (between Market and Mission). 21+, $7. 415.487.6221
   
   
   Friday, December 15th - _A Single Red Light _
   DJs Chris Lum, Miquel, Dave Paterson, Reuben Mancias. 415.998.9515

   10pm-5am. in San Jose. 408.496.1631 510.247.6099 415.437.5784

   Tony, Josh, Doran, Spun, Jeno, Garth, Markie, Jon Williams, Doc
   Martin, Ethan, Jeffery. 415.522.3994 415.905.9629
   
   Saturday, December 16th - club Freaky
   House, trance and hip-hop w/DJs Dutch Boy, Monkey & Crust. All ages,
   benefits LYRIC. At Waking Dream, 2815 18th St, SF. $5. 415.487.5187
   
   Saturday, December 16th - _Mission Vortex_: A Healing Rave
   An evening of ritual, healing arts & self-expression. 350 tix
   available. 7:30-10pm mass healing. 10pm-> healing rave w/DJ Cheb i
   Sabbah. 510.428.1961

   Rich/B Lustmord)
   The film that inspired the music will show at 6pm and 9pm; Robert and

   Beats, Acidjazz, Soul, House w/dj's Miquel, Mind Motion, Dedan &
   guests. 9th & Howard, SF. 510.980.4574

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@netcom.com
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Saturday morning - "The Uncle Noah TV Show" 6-9am, KDVS 90.3,
       Davis.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

On Wed, 6 Dec 1995, Chris Chervin wrote:

> t.  Can you imagine what it would be like if
> >different crews started going at each other's throats and shit like 
> that for
> >status?
> >
> >The day that happens is the day I stop raving.
> >
> >Peeved,
> >Jake
> 
> 
> That's the day you should go underground.  The people who only put on 
> free or very cheap parties are the people who won't go after other 
> crews for status.  Underground crews (Gateway, F&F,and many others) are 
> doing it for one reason only.  It has nothing to do with money or 
> status or being cool or what have you. One reason only.  consiousness 
> revolution.

definetly, thats what we do it for :-) (rave, dance, dj, promote...)
and all the others involved,too. i never seen a more devoted group working 
*toghether* because its better (and cheaper) that way.
much love, appreciation
	evolution with a smile :) tom

> 
> love chris
>

> have even more fun.... and they do it for free."

'Sup everybody,

I'd like to hold an initial meeting at my place this coming Monday at 8pm.
A number of people offered to DJ and or help with carrying out various
tasks as necessary. For the sake of efficiency I'd like to suggest that we
try to keep this meeting to people that have experience and or resources
for putting a party together (i.e. people with knowledge of
locations/logistics and people with access to equipment like sound, lights
and visuals).

I would appreciate if people interested in attending would respond to me
via email so I have some idea of how many folks to expect. If there are
people who really want to come but can't make it at that time, let me know
ASAP. If there are many folks in that situation I'll try to reschedule, but

Hey, here's the get down fer me....

I like to dance, and dance hard. Just ask the many of yous that have seen or
met me. I enjoy groovin to a state of satori, which is attainable with or
without drugs.  But, the body is just like any other mechanism that once gets
running for extended periods of time...gets hot.

I get hot, 
               filthy, 
                         sweaty, 
                                      gooey hot.  
I look like a wet chicken...

So what is one to do.  Hmmmm....  I take off my shirt.  at least my
persperation evaporates at a quicker pace that way...  Sorry to the ones I
offend who think im trying to "strut my stuff".  I'm just trying to cool
down.  I mean I also dance with my shoes of at times... It's not to show of
my cool guy toes, nor is it to send stinky fumes into the crowd....  I feel
more comfortable being one with mother earth that way and I also am able to
keep my dexterity in check as well...

So, for what it's worth,  Im not one of the beautiful people... I get dirty.
 Get dusty. 
I kick up sand and make a mess of myself...  But the most important aspect
is... I have a good time...

Peace and peanutbutter,


Adam

From: Ann Elizabeth Loraine <anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Message-Id: <199512080715.XAA00644@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Communal Full Moon Project review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 7 Dec 1995 23:15:21 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 3986      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello everybody,

Last night, starting about 11, the Communal Full Moon project got 
underway at an East Bay location.

The party was a renegade, and there was some worry about whether the 
officers of the law might chase us away from our choice spot under some 
trees by the water.  There were some patrol cars spotted nearby, but the 
music was low enough and there were no cars parked close by, and so their 
suspicions were not aroused.  The voicemail instructed us to park a ways 
from the party, and there were people on hand to tell those that came to 
close where to park.

At the party's peak, there were maybe 150-200 people there.  A good 
number, with many newer ravers in attendance.  I talked with some who 
told me about  their perspective on the rave idea and what party's should 
be about.  Such as music and dancing and enjoying life!

The biggest treat of the evening for me was getting to hear Mars, of 
Frequency8, play.  I'd never heard him before, and he lived up to what my 
friend M. had told me- that he rocked her world the other night at 
Tecknotica.  (sorry if i spelled it wrong!)  He played for a solid two 
hours and maybe more.

After Mars, another dj played.  Unfortunately, I didn't get her name, but 
I liked her set, as well.  Housey, but fast with a little trippy jazzy 
stuff thrown in, as well.  Then Robbie Hardkiss- I think it was him!- 
went on.  Again, a good set from an ace dj.  I liked the way he 
controlled the energy of the music.  Slow, even, mellow for a time, then 
a slow build to faster, higher energy stuff.  It was perfect for the time 
of day- about 4 in the morning or so.  It was music that was kind to my 
tired, happy body.

By then most everyone was laying about on completely soaked blankets, 
talking and enjoying each other and the music.  There were a few people 
dancing- including Robbie!- who was having a blast.

Just before dawn, the organizers called everybody to the spot in front of 
the dj for a vision circle.  One person was the moderator- he had 
experience with this kind of role and he led us through a short 
meditation and said a few words about the chi, and the energy each person 
has to work magic in his or her own life.  Without going on and on, he 
let us in on a secret to living well, which I much appreciated.

The party organizers also explained a bit about what raving is about to 
them.  My friend Todd talked about wanting to see more recycling at 
raves, mostly the water bottles that always turn up by the tens or 
hundreds when the party's over.  One person talked of having been part 
of the rave community for many years- and having gone through a period of 
not liking it, because it didn't seem to be heading in a positive 
direction.  He said that friendship restored him.
  
One person talked about what the vibe- everybody who has been 
to a rave has some idea of what this is and what it feels like- and how 
the vibe is what makes a party good or not-so-good.  Once you've been to 
or have helped out with a lot of parties, I guess your idea of what this 
is- and of how to create it- gets more and more right on.  I liked being 
let in on what motivates people to throw parties...it makes you realize 
how different personalities and relationships combine to make it happen.

Some of us from the New Moon brought an altar, in addition to the one 
Clair and Gateway  set up in front of the dj.  On the New Moon 
altar, there was a size eleven, red, high-heeled shoe, rye grains in a 
bowl, candles, satin and silk flowers scented with perfume, among other 
things.  And it was round, in honor of the moon.

The most magical moment of the night for me came at around 2 am, when it 
was clear that we could stay where we were as long as we wanted.  The 
whole thing kind of came together at the last minute, but it worked, 
thanks to the combined efforts of many people.

Sorry this is so long-winded.  It was a big night for me!

And thank you so much for a wonderful time,

Ann

> There is nothing wose than the minor explosion of methane produced 
> adjacent to the genitals by one 
> who consumes to many beans!  Ever heard of the fruit farts, or the green 
> apple quickstep?  Aroma-assualt can come from a certain hidden orafice, 
> which is exercised profusely by vegetarians.  :)

If you remember to skim beans as you soak them you won't have a
problem.  (If you don't know what I mean and you cook beans you definitely
have a problem.)  If you remember to eat a nutritionally complete meal
(ex. beans AND rice), which takes a bit of planning for vegetarians,
then you won't have a problem.  If you don't eat one thing for
two days constantly, you won't have a problem.  If you do all this
but still use Beano, you won't have a problem.

The worst aromas I've ever experienced came from a meat-eater.  It's
a nutrition thing, not a veggie vs. meat thing.  Either can undergo,
shall we say, incomplete combustion.  >%^)

// g

PS: If you're trying to knock out a cold with megadoses of Vitamin C,
be careful with the time-release stuff.  If you take too much C, though
no harm will come, you will be fearsomely stanky.  Whoooo-eee!  We're
talking eye-watering, hi-octane, butt-burning, jet-propelled gut bombs 
here.  Don't even think about public appearances for several hours.

go go go go go !  if you are in sf on monday, read on....

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 8 Dec 1995 10:28:59 -0800 (PST)
From: telstar@wired.com
To: fight-censorship+@andrew.cmu.edu, cyber-rights@cpsr.org
Subject: NETIZENS!! SF RALLY AGAINST CENSORSHIP


Spread the word!


                *** NETIZENS!! RALLY AGAINST CENSORSHIP ***


Amendment I: "Congress shall make no law ... abridging the freedom of
speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble."


     **PROTEST ** PROTEST ** PROTEST ** PROTEST ** PROTEST ** PROTEST **

It's like illiterates telling you what to read. On December 6 members of
the House Conference Committee on Telecommunications Reform approved a
proposal to censor free speech in cyberspace. If the measures are adopted,
the Net and online media will become the most heavily regulated media in
the United States. They *will not* enjoy the First Amendment freedoms now
afforded to print media. Instead, online publishers and users will be held
to a vague and patently un-Constitutional "indecency" standard. "Violators"
will be subject to fines of up to $100,000 and prison terms of up to five
years.

In response, ALL members of the Bay Area media, online, Internet, new
media, and telecommunications communities are invited to participate in a
protest rally to express our outrage that the politicians in Congress
(which is not even connected to the Internet!) are attempting to destroy
our First Amendment rights in cyberspace, and directly attack our
livelihoods.

Help stop the demagogs in Washington! There is nothing "decent" about
denying free speech to us, our children, and our children's children.
Preserve our Constitutional rights! Join us!

WHEN: Monday, December 11, 1995  12:00 - 1:00 PM

WHERE: South Park (between 2nd and 3rd, Bryant and Brannon) San Francisco.

SPEAKERS: To be announced

BRING: Attention-grabbing posters, signs, and banners that demonstrate your
committment to free speech and expression, and your feelings about
Congress.

FOR UPDATED INFORMATION: http://www.hotwired.com/staff/digaman

(Although this event is being organized in the offices of Wired magazine
and HotWired, we are *actively* seeking participation and support from all
members of the local community. Please forward this message to anyone you
think should attend, and to all relevant news groups.)

CONTACT: Todd Lappin -- 415-222-6241 -- protest@wired.com

###

this censorship is gone alittle to far. Take for instance, by what they want
to censor, "The 7 Dirty Words" Half of which or said on daytime T.V....What
about some of the some of these classic books that have been made available
online (can't remember titles now) but there probally the ones they wanted to
band several years ago. And for those of you who have kids, they need to do a
book report and you don't have a Encyclopedia at home, You decide to jump
online because you know they have an online Encyclopedia. By your surprise
by looking at it online you might be breaking a law. They have nude sculpture
pictures in there, carved by a famous sculptor from 1700 or so. They also
might have nude painting from famous Artist. These are just two examples of
what they would be censoring. If they said those are part of history we can
get rid of those. then, a few thousand people whould say HEY, if those can be
kept there then what's the difference between that and a nude picture of say
Pamela Anderson for instance. The censorship board( or whoever) will say, but
that is ART, US History, the Past, and your picture is pornography. BUT wait,
is it really. a picture of some nude female or male standing just like they
would for a painting or what not would be they same thing, but from the
present time and painted or sculpted by Joe Smoe, who decide to put it on a
Web Page to show that he/she has talent. They would have to take off alot of
thing on the net that have to do with The woulds history. What about online
dictionary even. They have most of those "7 Dirty Words" in them also. Anyone
can walk into any library or bookstore and pick up or look at something that
would be on an Online Censorship Hitlist. Does this mean they would have to
Censor library and bookstores too. 
 
They can not pass this and have it stick. Too many people and too many
different Companys, Schools and whoever need the Online service too much.
 
 
I hope I made some sence, I think faster then I type. But point is, they
would have to censor to much of This world's History because it would fall in
the censorship catagory because of it content, and not the Meaning of what it
really meant in History, CONTENT is the key word why this will not happen.
TOO many people can and will have the right to complain.
 
Tim (knucklehead) Sorry for posting this Here. I'm not in a very happy mood
today, not because of this censorship (I know it won't happen) but it about
alittle of everything.

be warned - this really isn't rave-related at all, except that i think
most of you sfravers are pretty thoughtful and intelligent people with
eclectic interests (smooch!).

EMMANUEL KANT PHILOSOPHY LECTURES - WED/THU 13th/14th - THOMAS NAGEL
====================================================================
sorry if i'm chafing people by posting something so tangential, but i
think a few of you might be interested.  i first got interested in the
rave scene when i saw another visiting speaker last year - fraser (clark i
think?) - so i guess you really never know what you're gonna learn when
you go to a philosophy thang.

ANYWAY - tom nagel is coming to campus (stanford) next wednesday and
thursday.  he hasn't released an abstract yet (i've been bugging the
dept. secretary every morning) but his field is the philosophy of mind and
consciousness.  i've read three of his papers this term, and i'm prepared
to call him brilliant.  some of what he writes about is inspired by
philosophical science fiction concepts, which i think is cool too.

if you're interested, mail me and i'll send you the details.  or if you go
dancing wednesday and thursday instead, try to think a deep thought or two
for me!
matt.

------------starchld@leland.stanford.edu-----------
the starchild mothership can be reached at 493-4099

On the same subject, have you heard about AOL's indecency filter?  
Aparently, AOL supports some kind of text filter which does not allow 
certain documents/messages/files to be transmitted if they contain any of 
the 'naughty words' which the AOL bigwigs have deemed inappropriate.
The word 'breast' happens to be on that list.
This resulted in shutting out hundreds of women looking for info or 
discussion groups related to breast cancer issues.

What's going on here?

Have no fear, my shy ones, there is much positivity still out there.  
Unfortunatly I will not be here for the gathering anniversary this year.  
Last years was my first E-xperience and after a year of weekly injestion 
of the majick love potion, I am going sober for awhile.  While I was in 
my home town of LA I went to a Fresh Produce Party, sober and had a 
fuckin blast.  It is so reasurring to be able to still have much love 
without substance.  I waited a long time to do drugs, when the music and 
love was my drug.  We should all keep drugs to a moderate intake, to 
preserve our sanity and keep it real.  However, candyflipping is on my 
X-mas agenda... Anywho, although drugs happen to be alot of the 
motivation for smiles in our scene,  keep in mind that some of those 
smiles are straight from the heart.  I love your all.

Peace,
Jamie  Spunk@Cats.ucsc.edu

Well, as much as I try to follow my newest motto, DON'T HESITATE, there 
are still times when I just cannot make the eye contact.  Wouldn't it be 
nice if we could just lose all our inhibitions?   I for one have a  
difficult time distinguishing the vibe I am recieving from certain 
people.  I am very close with my friends, kisses and hugs galore, but if 
a stranger comes up and gets fresh, I simply assume he is interestd in 
more than friends.  I have ended up getting into some pretty lame 
relationships this way, and since then have tried to not think anything 
of these, shall I say hedonists(?).  Anyways,  drugs play a large part in 
how I infer different peoples first impressions.  I am on a sober trip 
right now, and find it easier to deal.  Enough rambling...if anyone has 
had similar experiences hooking up with people at raves I would love to 
hear your story.  Mine are too complicated, but if you share these 
feelings let me know.  

Peace, Jamie

Speaking of "Fresh Start," that was the name of the very first party 
that some of the now promoters of Harmony were involved with. It was a 
little party on the beach. (In fact, it was the only beach party that 
any of us have ever done that did not get busted!!!) (That is why we 
don't do BEACH parties anymore... we ALWAYS get busted!)

I think this idea is great! I would personally love to participate in 
any way!

Peace, love and a fresh start!,

Planet Rock
==========

With all my WEB WEAVING WORK,  I hardly had time to put up a review.
I went to "Planet Rock" this Fri. night,  thanx to the door person who put me
on the guest list.   Their $20 price to get in was a bit steep,  especially
if we
all had to drive way out to Pittsburgh.

Lyon's were doing security,   and their presence was always felt,   but they
were fairly laid back.   The venue was a roller rink,  I remember being in
this venue before a few summers ago.

In the main room,  really good trancey house.    Tony was seen behind the
turntables (All 4 of them).

In the Hard core room (Yes,  amazingly enough,  a hard core room),  was
RAW, spinning some sick jungle.

For the most part,  crowd was young,   vibe was "so so",   nothing
spectacular,
just really good music in a place big enough to hold about 1500 to 2000
people..

Venue:  7  - good on ventilation,   kept things cool
Visuals: 8 - Excellent computer animated graphics, lasers, projections, etc.
Music:  9  - Excellent variety... Jungle, Happy Hard, Rotterdam Hard,  Hard

Trance,  dub and House.

Sound: 7 - Excellent clean thumping sound.   The adjacent Jungle room
system was slightly distorted as they competed for sound space.   Both
systems essentially in the same room,  separated by plastic curtains,  not the
best damper of sound.

Promoters:  I met Mike,  I think I got his name right.   Seemed to be
interested in wanting to know what I thought of his party.    I was a bit put
off by not knowing the true cost to get in.   Promoter guested me right on the
spot.   Thanx..

Demigod literally WENT OFF...   He started off at a blazing 160 BPM,  playing
some totally new kind of "Happy Hard core".    Lots of chipmunk type voices,
pounding "Doof Doof".   I went totally insane...  Nate,  the friend who took me
there, was hopping around with a "shit eaten" grin on his face.   I was
literally bouncing off the walls....  He covered just about every type of Hard
Core I've ever been exposed to...  I'm just going to have to go down to LA and
go to nothing but the Hard Core raves.   We just don't get enough of it...  :-)

Later on,  Demigod went into this rather silly song that lost my interest,  as
the beats stopped,  and he transited into more Jungle.   By that time the live
band was playing in the main room.   xPando and ReBirth was rocking the
place down,  playing some insane trancey house.   I was constantly going
back and forth,  sampling the Jungle and the live band as much as I could.

Later on,  DJ Dan started up,  so I decided to go and chill for a while and get
more liquids in my system.   That was the time,  I met the promoter.   He
says that he intended on having a closer venue,  but at the last moment,
pulling out.    So they got the Pittsburgh Roller rink instead.   At first,
they
weren't going to do the 2nd room,   but then decided to do it at the last
moment.    It got off to a late start,   but they were letting people in,
slightly
after midnight.

It continued until about 6:30 or 7:00 am,   then they unplugged the turn
tables and the sound sent screeching to a halt.    I like the way they turned
on the light just before it ended.    Overall,  a little pricy...   try to
have price  on flyer or info line...  We want to know the cost before
traveling so far...

Crunchman
http://www.well.com/user/crunch    <--- CHECK this out !!!!!

Precedence: bulk

my review of the "hardcore" room at Planet Rock (where i was camped out for
most of the evening):
-R.A.W.
On first and rocked the place like he usually does...played a set of
"classics"...basically old school breaks and some even housier breaks
thrown in...interesting ...and of course...all his cut up mixes and tricks
made it that much better...i felt pretty lucky to see this as R.A.W. would
never play this kind of set in L.A.. a major departure from his usual
hardstep jungle and one of the best times ive seen him play in about 3
years

-U.F.O.
A shame he only got to spin for about 15 minutes but the out of town dj's
were given precedence due to the late start...played some good hardstep
although the system kept cutting out...nice one

-DemiGod
Not a big fan of gabber but this would have been one of his better
sets..played a lot of the big gabber tunes that keep l.a. hardcore kids
screaming for more including the current favorite that crunchman found
cheesy which would be "wonderful things" by charly lownoise/mental
theo...this was about the only song i could get into...

-Dieselboy
Tearin' set of the new hip-hop influenced jungle and jump up hardstep
sounds...very clean mixing and played all my current favorites....:) check
him out (good tape as well...) it was a shame he had to play after demigod
and while dan was spinning as i think a lot of people missed it...oh well

-Thee-O
Thee-O is well known in L.A. for always having a new tape to pass out and
for his seamless mixing of trance..well, im not into trance really but if
you were i think this set was typical of his usual seamless style...

that's all i heard...i agree that the price was way too steep and a lot of
the people there seemed like they thought they were the shit...but overall,
worth it to hear dieselboy and r.a.w.....
*starEyes*

Dear Doug,

	I'm glad you brought this up... one of my favorite things is to 
meet a bunch of groovy new people at a party, and then go out together 
for breakfast, or better yet back to someone's house for breakfast or 
just to chill out.  
	This is when some of the best conversations and connections 
happen in my experience, because everyone has the beauty and excitement 
of the rave fresh in their memories, but have calmed down enough to 
engage in real deep communication with others, minus all the distractions 
of a party.
	I wouldn't say it doesn't happen here, but I think you have to 
seek it out.  It probably goes back to the shyness thing -- I really 
appreciated Brad's comments on this, BTW.  I would guess that if people 
were not as shy and inhibited on the whole, there would be more 
post-party group activities.  I frequently try to initiate stuff like 
this myself, but not having a vehicle, I'm frequently tied to the 
schedule of whoever is driving.
	For me, the "goal" of the rave scene, beyond the immediate 
purpose of having fun, is to spread the vibe, and by that I mean more 
people, more of the time, behaving like one does on an excellent E trip, 
and not just at raves, but everywhere, all the time, sober or not.
	Two things I see as critical in accomplishing this goal:

	(1) Ending the producer-consumer relationship (thanks to Bryce 
Ryan for this invaluable idea; it's one of the real bits of wisdom I've 
picked up on this list that's stuck in my head).

	(2) Making our scene self-sufficient.  In other words, expanding 
our scope so that it is possible to live, work, and play, all within the 
boundaries of "rave." This is the idea of a commune; people can leave, of 
course, but if you don't want to, you're not forced to, because 
everything you need to live, thrive & survive you can find without going 
away all your I.D., and essentially "go underground" while maintaining a 
viable and mea the expense of other ties, would real change occur.  By 
having breakfast with each other, we can encourage this process... 

On Sat, 9 Dec 1995, Doug Zimmerman wrote:

> On Mon, 4 Dec 1995 MsPhink@aol.com wrote:
> 
> > I have a question: 
> > What is your favorite thing to do *after* a rave? Or what has been your most
> > memorable post-raving experience? I usually come home and listen to music
> 
> 
> Back east after a party it usually seemed like several friends would meet up
> at an IHOP or Denny's for breakfast and to come down from a night of 
> dancing and fun.  It doesn't seem that way much out here.
> 
> doug ) ( doug@hyperreal.com

> P.S. - Balitmore MD is the most beautiful city at sunrise, hands down =)

At 11:45 PM 12/8/95 -0800, you wrote:
>
>Well, as much as I try to follow my newest motto, DON'T HESITATE, there 
>are still times when I just cannot make the eye contact.  Wouldn't it be 
>nice if we could just lose all our inhibitions?   I for one have a  
>difficult time distinguishing the vibe I am recieving from certain 
>people.  I am very close with my friends, kisses and hugs galore, but if 
>a stranger comes up and gets fresh, I simply assume he is interestd in 
>more than friends.  I have ended up getting into some pretty lame 
>relationships this way, and since then have tried to not think anything 
>of these, shall I say hedonists(?).  Anyways,  drugs play a large part in 
>how I infer different peoples first impressions.  I am on a sober trip 
>right now, and find it easier to deal.  Enough rambling...if anyone has 
>had similar experiences hooking up with people at raves I would love to 
>hear your story.  Mine are too complicated, but if you share these 
>feelings let me know.  

I think the whole "not being able to make eye contact" thing is what bugs me
the most... I don't want to be extra shy person, but I just can't help it
sometimes. Tho' I did overcome a lot of that, at least partially, at Planet
Rock last night... went in with a really good attitude all smiles and I
think alot of people reacted well to that... but a few hours later I got
tired and stoned and as the night wore on everybody got a lot less social.
Ah well, it was a damn good party tho'.

mikey.

did anyone try to make it to the Planet rock afterparty in Berkeley? I
walked over there at about 3pm and it was e-m-p-t-y.

they gave the wrong directions!

potentially good parties ruined by technicalities like that one. Unless the
big crowd showed up after I left... I think they changed the message after I
told them about the *problem.*

so here is (hopefully) a corrected version:

> purpose of having fun, is to spread the vibe, and by that I mean more 
> people, more of the time, behaving like one does on an excellent E trip, 
> and not just at raves, but everywhere, all the time, sober or not.
> 	Two things I see as critical in accomplishing this goal:
> 
> 	(1) Ending the producer-consumer relationship (thanks to Bryce 
> Ryan for this invaluable idea; it's one of the real bits of wisdom I've 
> picked up on this list that's stuck in my head).
> 
> 	(2) Making our scene self-sufficient.  In other words, expanding 
> our scope so that it is possible to live, work, and play, all within the 
> boundaries of "rave." This is the idea of a commune; people can leave, of 
> course, but if you don't want to, you're not forced to, because 
> everything you need to live, thrive & survive you can find without going
	outside your circle of friends and family.  The real test is if 
	you can quit your "non-rave" job, drop out of school, throw 
> away all your I.D., and essentially "go underground" while maintaining a 
> viable and mea
	ningful existance.  I think this is what Tim Leary was talking 
	about back in the sixties when he urged hippie kids to "Tune in, 
	turn on, and drop out."  Leary has been labeled irresponsible for 
	encouraging dropping out of school, but as a Harvard professor, I 
	think he understood the value of a college education.  More 
	importantly, I think he correctly perceived that only by strengthening 
	and broadening your ties with the underground community, necessarily 
> at the expense of other ties, would real change occur.  By 
> having breakfast with each other, we can encourage this process... 
> 
> On Sat, 9 Dec 1995, Doug Zimmerman wrote:
> 
> > On Mon, 4 Dec 1995 MsPhink@aol.com wrote:
> > 
> > > I have a question: 
> > > What is your favorite thing to do *after* a rave? Or what has been your most
> > > memorable post-raving experience? I usually come home and listen to music
> > 
> > 
> > Back east after a party it usually seemed like several friends would meet up
> > at an IHOP or Denny's for breakfast and to come down from a night of 
> > dancing and fun.  It doesn't seem that way much out here.
> > 
> > doug ) ( doug@hyperreal.com
> > 
> > P.S. - Balitmore MD is the most beautiful city at sunrise, hands down =)
> > 
> 
> 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
P.S. - We could start our own schools, where the emphasis would be on 
teaching participants how to live their lives to the fullest, rather than 
teaching the mastery of a particular career field in order to make more 
money; we could buy our own land and establish communal raver living 
areas where everyone is able to plow the fruits of their labor into 
throwing terrific parties instead of paying it to the government in 
parking tickets and sales taxes, to be spent on Stealth bombers and 
offices full of bureaucrats...
	...(sigh) One can always dream.  Anyway, my point being that what 
happens after the party may be what has the most potential for connecting 
us...
______________________________________________________________________________
"Some people look at the world the way it is and ask, 'Why?'  I look at 
the world the way it could be and ask 'Why not?'"
______________________________________________________________________________			

Anybody remember where that one comes from?

Much love,
				*** Starchild ***

At 11:45 PM 12/8/95, Jamie Pauline Smith wrote:
>Well, as much as I try to follow my newest motto, DON'T HESITATE, there
>are still times when I just cannot make the eye contact.  Wouldn't it be
>nice if we could just lose all our inhibitions?   I for one have a
>difficult time distinguishing the vibe I am recieving from certain
>people.  I am very close with my friends, kisses and hugs galore, but if
>a stranger comes up and gets fresh, I simply assume he is interestd in
>more than friends.  I have ended up getting into some pretty lame
>relationships this way, and since then have tried to not think anything
>of these, shall I say hedonists(?).  Anyways,  drugs play a large part in
>how I infer different peoples first impressions.  I am on a sober trip
>right now, and find it easier to deal.  Enough rambling...if anyone has
>had similar experiences hooking up with people at raves I would love to
>hear your story.  Mine are too complicated, but if you share these
>feelings let me know.
>
>Peace, Jamie

        WEll hmm..i've had experiences in which i've ended up for lack of a
better word "making out" with random people at parties and for the most
part these have been positive experiences. My only word of caution is to
realize that we all have different perceptions about these things and place
different kinds of meaning on what goes on. For me it's the simple fact
that you're with someone right now and are happy to be alive and you
physically share your joy with another person. But not everyone thinks like
this so i try to keep a grip on things :) I think that if one has that four
letter acronym running through their veins one can also make decisions of
this sort...or rather, not make any decisions and just do it (well, not
"it" but just act without thinking, a very zen-like experience in which
thought and action become the same thing). Personally, i have no problem
with a whole room full of people making out just as long as everyone is
happy and it's consensual, but then again that word is rather slippery
anyways. Tough call, but yes, being sober does improve your abilitiy to
focus on future repercussions and the real nature of your feelings for
someone. Personally, if something happens with someone it IS a genuine act
of love and caring: drugs do not bring something completely foreign out of
you, they just bring buried parts of yourself to the surface so for that
time, when you're both looking into each other's eyes, the feelings you
feel are very real. The next day is a different context and therefore a
different story. :)
        play safe remember!
                brad

Dear All,
                I am considering writing a column for XLR8R magazine
regarding the Trocadero club at 4th and Bryant. Many people I know have had
problems with the attitude and actions of the staff and management of this
venue. Their attitude is, of course, their prerogative and ravers I know
who don't like it are voting with their feet. What I am concerned about is
the continued use of the Troc' as a venue for dance and underground acts
when it would appear that the club does not want the business of ravers and
clubkids. I want to bring this to the attention of record labels and
management companies who continue to book dance acts like the Dust
Brothers, Banco de Gaia, Prodigy, etc. so that the people who enjoy this
particular music get to see the bands and have an enjoyable, hassle-free
time.

        I have heard several stories, seen several posts on sfraves, and
had experiences myself. I am looking for others who have had bad
experiences (or good experiences if you think that this is not the case) at
the club. Just first hand accounts please, no hearsay!

        This is what seems to have taken place.....

        Water and Air Conditioning, made freely available at the clubs punk
and bondage events, are conspicuously absent at underground events.

        People who are dressed as ravers / clubbers are singled out and
hassled by security, while people in leather gear are welcomed. (I have
witnessed this myself)

        Girls have apparently been harrassed by the female security.

        The venue has been shut down for supposed 'noise complaints' by
police who had been at the venue for over an hour, but who didn't act until
moments after the management had recieved the balance of rent due. This has
happened on more than one occasion.

        And on a personal note...  I was booked by TVT Records to DJ
between the bands at the EBN/ Banco show last week. My name was on the
flyer, and my contact at TVT had spoken directly to George, the manager,
regarding the booking. When I arrived at the club, I was refused entry by
George himself. He said he knew nothing about the booking and was using his
own DJ. I didn't even have 8 dollars to get in and sort out the situation.
Now TVT are saying "no play, no pay".

        When I have all your responses, I will send the information to the
manager of the venue to get his comments and the venues side of the story.

        Take it easy....

        Jon Williams

to set the record straight, united systems was my idea in the fact that 
when we set out to do the oct.15t party on the beach it was just 
arron,jen of spaz and stef,rebeka, jereamy and myself of pirate audio 
assault unit. we thought that since the two crews were doing a party 
together we should call it united systems , after the u.k. crew. we 
talked with the united crew overseas and they fully supported our idea. 
at first arron and jen dug they idea and the flyers were printed up. we 
all thought this was a good way to not blow up any egoes. the party went 
off great with a good d.j. lineup and solid music, and kicking atmosphere.
the problems arose when we tried to do another party with the spaz crew. 
at a sound system meeting a bunch of spaz people showed up who were not 
involved with the parties and flipped out on the name united systems. 
excuses were plentiful but the main one was how could we be united 
systems if there was only one sound system..implying pirate audio was not 
a true system because we owned no p.a. whats interesting though is that 
spiral tribe sound system didnt own a system in the beginng either, they 
borrowed bedlam's sound system. another odd thing is that at the oct.15 
th party there only 4 d.j.s and only one was a spaz d.j. but in the end i 
decided that i really enjoyed my friendship and love for arron and jen 
more than mydesire to throw partys so i saw it best to split from working 
with them. i dig them massively but i dont care much for many of the 
other spaz people, not all of them but a few really ticked me off. so 
there is your dirt on the spaz / united soundsystem b.s. it really isnt 
much. we split off so we could salvage our friendships...much more 
important than partys. ...oh and by the way s.f....jack acid is here and 
is about to drop the massive hardcore vibe on this town, watch for gabba 
dave and jack...you've been warned.

Jack Acid Pirate Audio Assault Unit
end of transmission....


c/o erik

I'd say do it, Jon.  You might remember a recent article in the Bay
Guardian that highlighted the new manager of the Troc and the revitalizing
of the local punk scene that is his mission.  I mean, sounded pretty good
and all that, but I've observed the same problems you have, as have
many others.

The Troc has a long and very interesting history.  Back in the 1970s and
early 1980s it was the center of the gay disco scene in SF.  There's a
book called "Tribal Vibes" (if I remember the name right, my copy is
floating around somewhere at Ameba) which goes into that in great detail
and has some good photos from that period.  

Since the mid-1980s it's been more of a mixture, with the longstanding
Bondage a Go Go, punk shows, bands and a fair number of rave-type events.
I remember one specifically I went to a couple of years back called
Turtle Wax.  For a while it was a pretty good venue for that, and the
sound system around the beginning of 1993 was the most awesome I've
ever heard, no exceptions.  One day most of it walked out the back
door.  That is just one of many stories in the sketchy history of
the Troc.  

The antipathy of the staff toward "ravers" is well know.  The last time
I was there was during the Billboard convention last January, when
Deconstruction were holding their showcase night.  I arrived at around
2 am and shortly thereafter the police shut it down, hours early, right
during the middle of Justin Robertson's set, as a result of an obviously
bogus "sound complaint."  I had barely heard the sound when I was outside,
as they were using the then-new Wicked system in the main room and it
wasn't cranked all the way.

So your story about shutdowns right after the final money changes hands
makes me wonder yet again about what happened that night, and maybe
you should get in touch with Deconstruction US and see what they know, Jon.

I think it's about time someone really dug into this story.  I know there
is no shortage of horror tales about attending and putting on events
at the Troc.

phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec 10 19:39:57 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA03478; Sun, 10 Dec 1995 19:39:57 -0800
Received: from aoaioxxysz.organic.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA03468; Sun, 10 Dec 1995 19:39:53 -0800
Received: from aoaioxxysz (localhost [127.0.0.1]) by aoaioxxysz.organic.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with ESMTP id TAA00418 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 10 Dec 1995 19:39:43 -0800
Message-Id: <199512110339.TAA00418@aoaioxxysz.organic.com>
To: San Francisco Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Party People, Yeeeeeeeaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaahhhhhh!
Date: Sun, 10 Dec 1995 19:39:42 -0800
From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@organic.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


This has to rate as one of the most intense and beautiful (and frustrating,
but I'll get to that in a bit) weekends in my raving life (there have been a
lot of them in the past year!). I lost my mind, found it again, lost it
again, and hopefully won't find it again for a good two or three weeks
(hopefully until well after the Gathering, which I'm looking forward to with
all of my heart). I danced until I was reduced to sitting on the floor and
nodding rhythmically, I made a happy ass out of myself on several locations,
and I generally could just not contain myself.

All I can really say about Planet Rock:

Donald & DJ Dan KICKED ASS.

Anybody who saw me after about 15 minutes into their set can attest to the
fact that I was well gone early on (I was the tall guy with the pony tail,
double nose rings, beat-up sandals, jeans, and the Deadfall Snowboards
shirt, grinning like a maniac and making lots of noise). They fucking
_rocked_ me: for two (or more) hours it was non-stop funked-up tough electro
beats, funky house, techno, and mad scratching. Did I say "mad scratching"?
That doesn't even come close to the sick shit that Donald and Dan were
pulling out of their turntables! They were evil on the transformers, rocked
the faders, and had their loops down cold. Serious technique, outta-hand
music, and tons of vibe to share with the (admittedly somewhat lame)
crowd. Superlatives fail me. It was transcendental; it was fabulous; it was
tons of fun.

The venue (as others have said) was a roller rink that the promoters had
subdivided with polypropylene into various areas: The main room, a chill
room, and the hardcore room. The visuals were pretty cool (nothing on the
F'n'F crews, though) and the laser was one of the cooler ones I've
seen. Sound was good in the main room (although they could have killed the
highs a little more), but what they did to the hardcore room was near
criminal. Half the sound system turned up twice as loud does not equal a
whole sound system, and it's time that promoters and sound people figure
that out. It's a shame, because most of the stuff I heard in there (even
with the lamentable fact that I missed Dieselboy's set) was pretty cool. The
jungle crew in SF can only go up, and I have a feeling they're going to go
very high indeed; they have too much talent not to. I didn't hear anybody
play "Six Million Ways to Die," though. ;)

I do have to bitch about the crowd. While there was a small crowd (~50) of
hardcore groovers up near the speakers going crazy, most of the people in
main room were either sitting in little clumps or wandering around
aimlessly. I don't understand how they could sit through a set like Donald &
Dan's, but they did. I kept trying to get people more interested, but I
think my antics annoyed more than they entertained. It was quite
frustrating.

Something else really frustrated me. I've watched the whole thread on
shyness with some interest because of my own problems in dealing with
strangers. Anybody who has known me for anything longer than 15 minutes will
tell you that I am incredibly obnoxious, if not annoying, and that I would
seem like the furthest thing from shy. However, I am an extremely reserved
person when I'm around people I don't know. It sucks, but that's the way I
am. I saw Wayne wandering around and I wanted to say hi (hi Wayne!), but I
could never think of anything non-lame to say. Also, there was an
excrutiatingly attractive young woman who was giving me the eye all night
and I really wanted to talk to her. I ended up _totally_ wimping out. If
anybody knows who the tall brunette in the red tank top and Adidas sweat
pants and shoes was, please let me know. I'd be forever grateful.

Anyway, when the lights came up at 6:30, it was far too early for the party
to end. DRC had just gotten warmed up and was throwing down some totally
cool hard techno, and then boom! the house lights were on and the music was
gone. Bummer, especially because the nerve I'd been storing up to talk to
the aforementioned young lady evaporated with the darkness.

Although the crowd could have been _much_ more into it, Planet Rock was a
good time. The security didn't particularly bug me and it was sorta cool
going to a party with that big rave feel to it (is that feel generated
mostly by the fact that you have to shell out $20 to get in?).

There could not have been more of a difference between Planet Rock and
Chrysalis. I didn't make it to Chrysalis until about 2:30 (my friend Derek
and I were slow to get moving that night because we were both still somewhat
spun from the night before), but the instant I stepped inside I knew it was
a party. The gallery space where the party was located was full of sweaty,
enthusiastic groovers going off bigtime to John Carel. That place was _hot_
-- I was sweating heavily even when I was just standing still. The sweaty
atmosphere worked _for_ the party for me, because it made it seem even that
much more intimate. Where Planet Rock was all coolness and suburban ravers,
Chrysalis was down-home and much more of the vibe-oriented freak scene that
makes San Francisco special for me. When Monty started bringing in the hard
funky beats, I was forced to dance despite my considerable fatigue.

All in all, it was a pretty ace weekend.

yrz,
ozy

ozymandias G desiderata      ogd@organic.com       Ravers Suck Our Sound
(415)284-6888     http://www.organic.com/Staff/ogd/       ::AOAIOXXYSZ::

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec 10 22:28:35 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id WAA12703; Sun, 10 Dec 1995 22:28:35 -0800
Received: from mail.crl.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id WAA12693; Sun, 10 Dec 1995 22:28:29 -0800
Received: from crl.com (crl11.crl.com) by mail.crl.com with SMTP id AA28265
  (5.65c/IDA-1.5 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>); Sun, 10 Dec 1995 22:26:09 -0800
From: davidmin@crl.com (David Minuk)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Shyness
Date: Mon, 11 Dec 1995 06:09:26 GMT
Message-Id: <30cbc3e6.342580363@mail.crl.com>
X-Mailer: Forte Agent .99c/16.141
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It seems there are a great many shy people in the rave scene, just as
there are outside.  Perhaps everyone exhibits characteristics of
shyness from time to time.  As someone who has had these feelings as
well, and have in many ways overcome them, I may be able to offer some
advice.

It helps to have a strategy.  Many people resolve to meet a number of
new friends at each party.  Determine what tools you have to help you
meet people.  There are certain topics which work successfully to open
a conversation at parties.  Learn about the music, this is the common
denominator that brings everyone together.

  When you don't know the other person, it is difficult to find a
connection.  Bringing an object such as a toy helps provide a focus
for conversation.  It can be something as attention grabbing as my
moon shoes (a cross between platform shoes and a moonbounce) or just a
fuzzy stuffed animal.  Bring things to share, such as small toys or
candy.  At hot, stuffy parties, spraying people with a plant mister
has been a way to make friends fast.  

An SF raves laminate is a very good way to meet people...even non
SFRavers.  People are curious as to what that thing around your neck
is.  Wearing unusual clothing can help produce introductions.  Be
creative.  

If there's a better place to meet people than a rave, I don't know
what it would be.  Peoples defenses are down and are open-minded(at
least at a good party).  I believe  barriers between people are one of
the great problems of civilization. I would like to hear any further
comments.

David


---------------------------------------------------------------------------
David Minuk(davidmin@crl.com)
WWW:  My URL is http://www.crl.com/~davidmin/



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec 10 22:46:52 1995

From: Foustus@aol.com

Subject: And the funny green light too....
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hot, sweaty bodies entwined in mind expanding excursions...

Hello everyone,

I'd like to take a few moments to share my views of Gateway System's
Chrysalis...

I dropped by @ about 1ish with an olde friend of my 92' raving days... Afta
getting in from the cold outdoors I was comforted by warmth of fellow
ravers....

The music was quite varied... From the tribal thumpings to funky trance tunes
and even a breakbeat (cira 91-3'ish) set here and there...  I think I would
of appreciated the music more if-it-if-it-if-
it-weren't-for-the-for-the-for-the-for-the-
record-record-skipping-skipping-skipping-skipping.....
       But hey, dem wood floors did look worn...
I realy enjoyed seeing all of you netravers (ie. my extened family) in the
crowds and took a few minuets off the dance floor (yikes! rarity..) and
chatted a bit.  I also fancied the notion of another sound system in the
crowd (& you know who you are) trancing out to the Gateeway DJ's sets.  It's
not crews vs. crews, but rather people enjoying people....
I also got a kick outta the funky green laser.

BTW to thoses whom I didn't happen the chance to meet I was the guy in the
green cap, black jeans and grey PUMA shirt... Not your standard raver attire
but I think we covered that in a posting before....

Anyhoot, I had a blast (even though I had to leave comparatively early than
my usual outings) and give a kwel thumbs up to a splendid tyme...

Smile'o'meter

Size:  7.5Smiles (a few people jams here and there but ample wander space)

Dancing media:  9Smiles (ahh, wood.  one of the best meduims for serious
firewalking)

Friendship factor:  9.5Smiles (Almost a mythic 10.  Serious grin sessions
agoing on...)

Vibe:  8Smiles ( Some sets were tight and one or two were a bit loose.  Also,
just when you're grooving..."pop" the record skips)

Overall:   8.5 Smiles  Strong beats, great friends, nice vibe.   Well worth
$10.

In closing....
     Quite recently there have been words said about the scene, SFRavers, and
the general 'tude of the bay area vibe....  Well, @ Chrysalis I saw a lot us
comminicating on a very kind level...  I don't remember seeing anyone really
whining or complaining. But communing and relating & experimenting ("rub that
Vicks where?") in a positive manner.  I reached out to thoses who I though
need solace weither or not they were SFRavers, Cos in the end   we   are
  people...   And to make our scene grow we need each other to understand,
relate, and dance till the wood floorboards catch aflame...

I really look foward to seeing you, my SFR family, at Mission Vortex, or
Interstate 420, or The Gathering or wherever a funky beat is playing... I
might be there.

Spins

Adam
"just sitting here watching the wheels go round and round..."
























                                                                      -Lennon

Hiya everyone!  I just wanted to say hello to those who are part of this
mailing list and ofcourse those who reads all the mails!  Anyhow I just
joined to the mailing list and so far it is really interesting.

I live in San Francisco and attending Academy of Art College majoring in
Computer Art.  Some might have seen me around at parties and also playing
records.  It's not hard to miss me<gg>  I am a really short (I mean short)
Korean guy name Nam  =). 

Although I have been using AOL and Compuserve for 5 months I didn't know
there was such a mailing list.  On Saturday evening, I helped Dj Moonpup log
onto the internet for his first time ever!!  It was sooo interesting.  He was
overwhelmed at everything from the signing on process to logging on, and etc.
 He was soo into it it was great!!  

We hung out and my brother Jin, Moonpup and I went one record each and mixed
while his 2400 baud modem (it belongs in the museum) download AOL ver 2.6 for
the mac.  Do you realize it took us 3 hours and ten minutes to download that?
 Geez!!   Anyhow we had a great time and listened to some great mixes.  I
learned a lot from listening and watching to Moonpup.  It was amazing what he
can do.  Takes a simple track and makes it into this work of art!  

Well, anyhow I'm glad I found you guys.  I am hoping to meet some wonderful
people and learn and share knowledge.  Hope you all have a Merry Christmas
and a Happy "Safe" New Year.!!!     

-dj Nam,  Jst smilin@aol.com

From: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)
Subject: Re: Shyness
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Funny how many shy people are coming out of the woodwork!  And I don't 
think it's just coincidence either.  I can be one of the most painfully 
shy people I've ever met.  Paralyzing shyness and self-consciousness 
hit me pretty hard at Wicked, which pretty much ruined it for me.  I 
would find myself just sitting there wishing I could get up the courage 
and talk to someone or go dance by myself or something, and I couldn't 
do any of it!  Really pissed me off.  So then I was painfully shy AND 
really pissed off!  Great combo-platter to set the mood for party!  
Anyway, my original point was that I didn't think it was just a 
coincidence that there seem to be so many shy people in the scene.  I 
think people like that are drawn to loving community scenes like this 
one.  One of the things that has attracted me to it is the total 
community feel it has (whether people know you or not), which can be 
very healing and inviting to people such as myself.  There's nothing 
that makes me feel more at home than being surrounded by people having 
an immensely good time, sharing their water & candy & stuff with me 
even though they've never seen me before in their lives, freely giving 
hugs, and people who just come up to you and start conversations about 
really cool stuff!  It helps me get over my shyness problem so much 
more easily than going somewhere where everybody looks at the ground 
and murmurs quietly only to people they know and act like they aren't 
willing to give you the time of day (like being on a bart train at 
commute hour!).  Much easier for me to come out of "my shell" with 
people from the first scenario than with people from the second!  So I 
guess we shouldn't be surprised to see so many shy people coming out of 
theirs here on the list!
You wrote: 
>

Dear All;

	I'm very happy, happy, happy to say that my party sump ended 
Wedesday night with the FMR, and went over the top with Chrysalis 
Saturday night. Riding a karmatic tidal wave outta bad(for me) partydom, 
yeah, & fuckin aye!!!!

	FMR's alter was beautiful, party environment by father nature
(sorry but if we can have grandmother cluases in contracts, we can have
father nature), and the circle at the end was really cool to, and not to
mention the music was of course great. 

	Though at Chrysalis, I was having a difficult time with boundry
issues relating to someone I care about, I still had a great time, though
it could have been better, just goes to show you what a little well
thought out communication can do, but i assure you it won't happen again. 
That p-hell isn't worth it for any human being, I've been there, and it 
sucks.

	The setup @ Howard Street was the best it's ever been for and 
party as far as I'm concerned. The music was great, along with the 
people who attended for the most part.

	Long live Claire & Gateway Systems, and may their parties continue to 
rock SF though the year 2000. 

	Claire, though I didn't get a change to tell you, you where 
dressed to kill Saturday night, awesome!!!!!!!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 11 10:59:32 1995

Comments: Authenticated sender is <csil@mailhost.hooked.net>
From: csil@hooked.net
To: natural@sirius.com (Natural)
Date: Mon, 11 Dec 1995 10:57:11 +0000
Subject: Re: Trocadero Complaints.
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Priority: normal
X-mailer: Pegasus Mail for Windows (v2.23)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

You know it is really sad. I have heard a lot of bad things about the 
Troc also. And I agree, a few years ago it wasn't that bad. I was 
involved in Tilt-a-Whirl for a while, I don't know if anyone 
remembers it or not. I spun a few times and went even more. It was a 
decent space, the sound was cool, and the manager seemed pretty cool 
about the whole thing. The only bad experience I had there was with 
Goa Gil, but that is a whole 'nother story...
I saw Orbital, Meat Beat Manifesto, and Ultramarine there also a few 
years ago, and aside from some moron from MTV being there it was a 
really good show. Of course that is all it was, not really any raver 
vibe there at all, but still a great night of quality music!
Now it seems that all I hear about is problems. Does it extend to the 
Gothic/Industrial events they have there also, or just House? It just 
doesn't make sense to me. In our scene, problems that occur generally 
have not a single thing to do with the people who come. We just want 
to have a good time and enjoy the good feelings and music. I mean we 
aren't troublemakers, we don't go starting fights or rioting or 
trashing venues or anything like that. That is a pretty rare thing in 
the music/concert industry. It really makes me mad! I know Goths and 
Punks who love to go to shows just see how much trouble they can 
start, and to see if they can find a way in for free. They never have 
any money at all. Which is another thing, I'm knocking anyone or 
their scene but for the most part it seems as though IMHO that 
'ravers' in comparision to Punks or Goths, etc. seem to have a much 
higher percentage of paying clientele. So when you think about 
wouldn't it make sense not to harass house events? I don't know, 
maybe I'm getting off track, but I know that there have been several 
events at the Troc. which I would have really enjoyed going to, but 
until I hear that things have changed I will stay away!
Just my 2 cents worth...

I had a friend who worked the Troc who verified what I had suspected for =
a long time:=20

At the party "United" the Troc staff and security were tired from a =
party (not rave) the night before, So they called the police on =
themselves. At first my friend did not believe me but he looked into it =
and discovered what you have been describing- total antipathy toward the =
rave. Ravers drink less at the bar is the biggest complaint but I think =
the prejudice goes further. They get a kick out of being mean to ravers.

My friend is in England otherwise I would turn him over to you and I'm =
sure he would name names.... I'm saddened by the Troc which was the =
ultimate disco club... and operated without liquor during its early =
days, has been turned into this Wax Trax unoriginal testosterone =
festival and in my opinion is the very thing which ruined the good name =
of Industrial music.

About the Troc (Trocadero Transfer),

I went to Banco de Ghaia/EBM, and the last time I was there was Meat
Beat Manafesto/Orbital/Ultramarine a long time ago.

While waiting for the show to start, It was obvious that the staff
there is used to dealing with industrial/post-punk types. Their
attitude is totally geared toward drunk, looking for trouble people. I
think they probably get confused when a crowd like the one at BdG/EBM
shows up. The poor empty bottle hunting staff tried to take my beer
bottle five times. I simple wasn't drinking fast enough for them. I'll
bet they don't sell nearly enough alchohol on raver/dance party
shows. That probably pisses them off more than anything. They hate to
see people dancing and enjoying the show, because that means they're
not drinking!

Too bad you didn't get to DJ, Jon. That would have been very nice.

-Darrel
darrele@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 11 13:14:38 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA18135; Mon, 11 Dec 1995 13:14:38 -0800
Received: from liberty.liberty.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA18122; Mon, 11 Dec 1995 13:14:30 -0800
Received: from Default (ppp411.liberty.com [206.17.67.107]) by liberty.liberty.com (8.6.10/8.6.9) with SMTP id NAA27949; Mon, 11 Dec 1995 13:14:18 -0800
Date: Mon, 11 Dec 1995 13:14:18 -0800
Message-Id: <199512112114.NAA27949@liberty.liberty.com>

X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Subject: Re: Shyness
Cc: shawna-@ix.netcom.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Date: Mon, 11 Dec 1995 11:53:30
To: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty), SFRAVES@hyperreal.com
From: Brian Darkness <liberty.liberty.com>
Subject: Re: Shyness

Dear All;

        This may sound pretty sexist, but  womyn can generally find a man
that will approach them and starting talking with them. But if your just a
werid little male raver it can be very lonely. This is just MY!!!!
experience, and it wasn't until I started offering my
services/participateing/cleaning up ...etc that people got to know me, now
of course everyone does. It kinda flipped around for me, cause now if I want
to go to a party and be antisocial, I can't.

        Ya know since I starting having a female friend around at parties
alot, I kinda miss going out just MYSELF, and being FREE to do whatever I
want, and not having to worry about the needs, & desires of another human
being. Don't get me wrong, I like my girlfriend, more so that you can image,
for many different reasons. But I came to SF, by myself, explored the scene,
and met people all by myself, and I miss that excitement and sense of
adventure that I use to experience. Going out without a plan & just letting
my night evolve, and end up with whomever like, or necessity dictated.

        So my advice to those who are shy, be careful for what you ask for
you may just get it, with a vengence. People like Gateway, & F&F, are always
looking for people who will help cleanup, give out filers, whatever, all you
have to do is hang around at the end, and help clean up, trust me you will
meet people.

        So you say you just too hopeless huh, for even that. Well, I'll tell
ya a little story about a guy I know. This guy was so hopeless it was sick,
people would say that trying to get to know him was like trying to catch
smoke, ever try,  it's kinda hard.
See,  he thought he had nothing to say, nothing to offer, he thought he was
stupid, and ulgy. That's all he could see when he looked into the mirror, in
fact that's all he knew, was all the bad people had filled him with all his
life. So he went on in life alone & very unhappy, but very slowly he ended
up surrounding himself with kind, beautiful people who had a much greater
vision that he did for himself. Little by little , and with their help, and
a wish and a desire on his part, he was slowly able to see & realize that he
had something to stay, something important, something that people(not all,
just some) were interested it, that he had something to offer, something
wonderful, loving and totally pure & unselfish.

        The more he tried, the more he started to lose the feelings of being
stupid, ugly, and undesireable. Until one day he saw that those feeling, &
thoughts that ruled his life & exsistance, weren't his at all. They belonged
with those bad people, not him. People who felt so bad about themselves,
they needed to put down everything & everyone around them so that they could
hopefully& vainly feel better about themselves.

        The more he saw that light that burned within him, the better he
felt about himself, the more he trusted himself, the more he believed in
himself, and the brighter the light burned. Until one day, and unexpectedly
so, the light burned so bright that when he looked around, he saw it in
everyone else as well, and could no longer hold the bad feelings he had for
the people who oppressed him in his life. He saw just how special, & unique
each & everyone of us is. The more he saw, the more he felt the same way
about himself, the more he felt the same way about the people around him...etc

        This wonderful process of becomeing aware took years, some very
special facillators and both internal & geographical jourenys all  over our
universe, until one day he arrived in a very special place, called
California. Where through is deeds, and his love for himself, & humanity he
became, for the first time in his life, popular.

        A lot of people know who this person is, a lot of people have been
touched by this person, you now know who this person is.

        He continues to live life on it's terms taking the good with the
bad, occasionly approaching divinity, and also sometimes falling into
darkness......this replaces happily ever after, because thats only for
fairly tales.

        Follow that internal voice that you know is your own, leaving all
the others in it's dust. Live in the present, for you have no another time
but it. Follow your dreams, because our window in the material world is
short. Love yourself now, as you would an orginal Picasso, for you are no
different that it, and others will love you. Particpate, & assert yourself
at our parties, small ones I find are better to do this at. Above all be let
positivity rule your life & be kind to yourself when you fail, or faulter,
for to err is human, to beat oneselve up is inhuman. Be willing to let
things happen, & go with the flow.


>At 11:21 PM 12/10/95 -0800, Shawna McGourty wrote:
>>Funny how many shy people are coming out of the woodwork!  And I don't 
>>think it's just coincidence either.  I can be one of the most painfully 
>>shy people I've ever met.  Paralyzing shyness and self-consciousness 
>>hit me pretty hard at Wicked, which pretty much ruined it for me.  I 
>>would find myself just sitting there wishing I could get up the courage 
>>and talk to someone or go dance by myself or something, and I couldn't 
>>do any of it!  Really pissed me off.  So then I was painfully shy AND 
>>really pissed off!  Great combo-platter to set the mood for party!  
>>Anyway, my original point was that I didn't think it was just a 
>>coincidence that there seem to be so many shy people in the scene.  I 
>>think people like that are drawn to loving community scenes like this 
>>one.  One of the things that has attracted me to it is the total 
>>community feel it has (whether people know you or not), which can be 
>>very healing and inviting to people such as myself.  There's nothing 
>>that makes me feel more at home than being surrounded by people having 
>>an immensely good time, sharing their water & candy & stuff with me 
>>even though they've never seen me before in their lives, freely giving 
>>hugs, and people who just come up to you and start conversations about 
>>really cool stuff!  It helps me get over my shyness problem so much 
>>more easily than going somewhere where everybody looks at the ground 
>>and murmurs quietly only to people they know and act like they aren't 
>>willing to give you the time of day (like being on a bart train at 
>>commute hour!).  Much easier for me to come out of "my shell" with 
>>people from the first scenario than with people from the second!  So I 
>>guess we shouldn't be surprised to see so many shy people coming out of 
>>theirs here on the list!
>>You wrote: 
>>>
>>>It seems there are a great many shy people in the rave scene, just as
>>>there are outside.  Perhaps everyone exhibits characteristics of
>>>shyness from time to time.  As someone who has had these feelings as
>>>well, and have in many ways overcome them, I may be able to offer some
>>>advice.
>>>
>>>It helps to have a strategy.  Many people resolve to meet a number of
>>>new friends at each party.  Determine what tools you have to help you
>>>meet people.  There are certain topics which work successfully to open
>>>a conversation at parties.  Learn about the music, this is the common
>>>denominator that brings everyone together.
>>>
>>>  When you don't know the other person, it is difficult to find a
>>>connection.  Bringing an object such as a toy helps provide a focus
>>>for conversation.  It can be something as attention grabbing as my
>>>moon shoes (a cross between platform shoes and a moonbounce) or just a
>>>fuzzy stuffed animal.  Bring things to share, such as small toys or
>>>candy.  At hot, stuffy parties, spraying people with a plant mister
>>>has been a way to make friends fast.  
>>>
>>>An SF raves laminate is a very good way to meet people...even non
>>>SFRavers.  People are curious as to what that thing around your neck
>>>is.  Wearing unusual clothing can help produce introductions.  Be
>>>creative.  
>>>
>>>If there's a better place to meet people than a rave, I don't know
>>>what it would be.  Peoples defenses are down and are open-minded(at
>>>least at a good party).  I believe  barriers between people are one of
>>>the great problems of civilization. I would like to hear any further
>>>comments.
>>>
>>>David
>>>
>>>
>>>-----------------------------------------------------------------------
>>----
>>>David Minuk(davidmin@crl.com)
>>>WWW:  My URL is http://www.crl.com/~davidmin/
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>
>>
>
