        The more he tried, the more he started to lose the feelings of being
stupid, ugly, and undesireable. Until one day he saw that those feeling, &
thoughts that ruled his life & exsistance, weren't his at all. They belonged
with those bad people, not him. People who felt so bad about themselves,
they needed to put down everything & everyone around them so that they could
hopefully& vainly feel better about themselves.

        The more he saw that light that burned within him, the better he
felt about himself, the more he trusted himself, the more he believed in
himself, and the brighter the light burned. Until one day, and unexpectedly
so, the light burned so bright that when he looked around, he saw it in
everyone else as well, and could no longer hold the bad feelings he had for
the people who oppressed him in his life. He saw just how special, & unique
each & everyone of us is. The more he saw, the more he felt the same way
about himself, the more he felt the same way about the people around him...etc

        This wonderful process of becomeing aware took years, some very
special facillators and both internal & geographical jourenys all  over our
universe, until one day he arrived in a very special place, called
California. Where through is deeds, and his love for himself, & humanity he
became, for the first time in his life, popular.

        A lot of people know who this person is, a lot of people have been
touched by this person, you now know who this person is.

        He continues to live life on it's terms taking the good with the
bad, occasionly approaching divinity, and also sometimes falling into
darkness......this replaces happily ever after, because thats only for
fairly tales.

        Follow that internal voice that you know is your own, leaving all
the others in it's dust. Live in the present, for you have no another time
but it. Follow your dreams, because our window in the material world is
short. Love yourself now, as you would an orginal Picasso, for you are no
different that it, and others will love you. Particpate, & assert yourself
at our parties, small ones I find are better to do this at. Above all be let
positivity rule your life & be kind to yourself when you fail, or faulter,
for to err is human, to beat oneselve up is inhuman. Be willing to let
things happen, & go with the flow.


>At 11:21 PM 12/10/95 -0800, Shawna McGourty wrote:
>>Funny how many shy people are coming out of the woodwork!  And I don't 
>>think it's just coincidence either.  I can be one of the most painfully 
>>shy people I've ever met.  Paralyzing shyness and self-consciousness 
>>hit me pretty hard at Wicked, which pretty much ruined it for me.  I 
>>would find myself just sitting there wishing I could get up the courage 
>>and talk to someone or go dance by myself or something, and I couldn't 
>>do any of it!  Really pissed me off.  So then I was painfully shy AND 
>>really pissed off!  Great combo-platter to set the mood for party!  
>>Anyway, my original point was that I didn't think it was just a 
>>coincidence that there seem to be so many shy people in the scene.  I 
>>think people like that are drawn to loving community scenes like this 
>>one.  One of the things that has attracted me to it is the total 
>>community feel it has (whether people know you or not), which can be 
>>very healing and inviting to people such as myself.  There's nothing 
>>that makes me feel more at home than being surrounded by people having 
>>an immensely good time, sharing their water & candy & stuff with me 
>>even though they've never seen me before in their lives, freely giving 
>>hugs, and people who just come up to you and start conversations about 
>>really cool stuff!  It helps me get over my shyness problem so much 
>>more easily than going somewhere where everybody looks at the ground 
>>and murmurs quietly only to people they know and act like they aren't 
>>willing to give you the time of day (like being on a bart train at 
>>commute hour!).  Much easier for me to come out of "my shell" with 
>>people from the first scenario than with people from the second!  So I 
>>guess we shouldn't be surprised to see so many shy people coming out of 
>>theirs here on the list!
>>You wrote: 
>>>
>>>It seems there are a great many shy people in the rave scene, just as
>>>there are outside.  Perhaps everyone exhibits characteristics of
>>>shyness from time to time.  As someone who has had these feelings as
>>>well, and have in many ways overcome them, I may be able to offer some
>>>advice.
>>>
>>>It helps to have a strategy.  Many people resolve to meet a number of
>>>new friends at each party.  Determine what tools you have to help you
>>>meet people.  There are certain topics which work successfully to open
>>>a conversation at parties.  Learn about the music, this is the common
>>>denominator that brings everyone together.
>>>
>>>  When you don't know the other person, it is difficult to find a
>>>connection.  Bringing an object such as a toy helps provide a focus
>>>for conversation.  It can be something as attention grabbing as my
>>>moon shoes (a cross between platform shoes and a moonbounce) or just a
>>>fuzzy stuffed animal.  Bring things to share, such as small toys or
>>>candy.  At hot, stuffy parties, spraying people with a plant mister
>>>has been a way to make friends fast.  
>>>
>>>An SF raves laminate is a very good way to meet people...even non
>>>SFRavers.  People are curious as to what that thing around your neck
>>>is.  Wearing unusual clothing can help produce introductions.  Be
>>>creative.  
>>>
>>>If there's a better place to meet people than a rave, I don't know
>>>what it would be.  Peoples defenses are down and are open-minded(at
>>>least at a good party).  I believe  barriers between people are one of
>>>the great problems of civilization. I would like to hear any further
>>>comments.
>>>
>>>David
>>>
>>>
>>>-----------------------------------------------------------------------
>>----
>>>David Minuk(davidmin@crl.com)
>>>WWW:  My URL is http://www.crl.com/~davidmin/
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>

many clubs here in SF, DV8's main room being the exception with high
velocity fans that are connected right to the outside sucking in what ever
cold air they can get.
>
>        Though I'm never one to give a cop or security an excuse to hit me,

standing up for your rights while on their properity is usually the incident
that leads to the  violence. It's their club, and though the security
required for a punk rock show is understandabilly necessarially strong &
heavy handed, for a rave, & ravers the volumne could be turned down a bit.
>
>        In their defense, they still have the best light & smoke show going
here in SF, and it's one of the very few places that one can here Gothic in
SF, as well as do Bondage & S&M. A cities underground is based on diversity,
right, one scene, Punk, Goth, Techno, a diverse and thriving underground
does not make. They are also one of the very few places that you can see
live acts

>At 12:36 PM 12/10/95 -0800, Natural wrote:
>>Dear All,
>>                I am considering writing a column for XLR8R magazine
>>regarding the Trocadero club at 4th and Bryant. Many people I know have had
>>problems with the attitude and actions of the staff and management of this
>>venue. Their attitude is, of course, their prerogative and ravers I know
>>who don't like it are voting with their feet. What I am concerned about is
>>the continued use of the Troc' as a venue for dance and underground acts
>>when it would appear that the club does not want the business of ravers and
>>clubkids. I want to bring this to the attention of record labels and
>>management companies who continue to book dance acts like the Dust
>>Brothers, Banco de Gaia, Prodigy, etc. so that the people who enjoy this
>>particular music get to see the bands and have an enjoyable, hassle-free

>>the club. Just first hand accounts please, no hearsay!
>>
>>        This is what seems to have taken place.....
>>
>>        Water and Air Conditioning, made freely available at the clubs punk
>>and bondage events, are conspicuously absent at underground events.
>>

>>hassled by security, while people in leather gear are welcomed. (I have
>>witnessed this myself)
>>
>>        Girls have apparently been harrassed by the female security.
>>
>>        The venue has been shut down for supposed 'noise complaints' by
>>police who had been at the venue for over an hour, but who didn't act until
>>moments after the management had recieved the balance of rent due. This has
>>happened on more than one occasion.

csil@hooked.net wrote:
...
>Now it seems that all I hear about is problems. Does it extend to the
>Gothic/Industrial events they have there also, or just House?

I've been to a lot of events, mostly live shows, at the Trocadero that have
been great, but they've all been of the punk/metal/industrial variety (e.g.
recently Gwar, Lunachicks).  I've never been to a ravelike event there, but
just from observing the staff I can well imagine that it might be an
uncomfortable fit.  It's probably safe to say that rave culture is wholly
alien to most of them.

On the general subject of clubs being nasty, did anyone else go to Beyond
Race on Saturday?  At the Transmission Theater.  It started out nicely
enough with a couple of hours of spinning, then a short set in an acid
jazz vein by a group I didn't know, then a bit more spinning while BR set
up.  But after they started, they got in maybe half an hour before the
management told them to knock off.  They were just starting to rip it up,
too.  No one was too happy about that, and they managed to keep on a bit
longer, but they got shut off soon.  However, the club said, the party
continues!  Just head on to the back room or next door to the Paradise
Lounge...well, in the back room someone was still spinning, so people
started congregating there, and it looked like it would be fun, but after
fifteen or twenty minutes of that, *he* had to shut down.  Not yet to be
daunted, people broke out their drums and started a jam.  Well, you can
probably guess what happened next.  Yes...everyone got kicked out and
sent next door to the Paradise.  There was still a DJ there, but by that
time, vibe was totally dead.  A real drag, on the whole.  I probably
should have headed off to Chrysalis, but I, too, was a little confused on
the map point issue.  Anyway, the Trocadero has no monopoly on screwing
up great events.

anarch@scruznet.com

Subject: non-rave -- internet first amendment rights...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 11 Dec 1995 17:17:46 -0800 (PST)

I've seen a lot of mail recently about pending legislation which will
infringe upon the first amendment rights of internet users.  A very
useful message was sent which included a lot of key phone number of
Senetors who sit on the conference committee for the legislation.

I called all their offices today (as well as my senators and representitive)
and told them that I was opposed to the legislation, and that it was
politically foolish to support the legislation.  I think it is foolish
because of the speed with which internet users can be reached with 
information *even by otherwise politically disenfranchised individuals*.

I received one interesting comment in return from one of the people who
listened to my feedback.  They said that they were getting a lot of calls
today about this issue, but they were all coming from California.

Hmmm...  Sfravers in action?  Or maybe, more political activism in CA?

I dunno.  If you are motivated to oppose the legislation, then I encourage
you to phone your Senators and your representitive.

Peace and love,

	Howard Cohen
	hoco@timefold.com
	http://www.timefold.com

Well, it would be nice to vote with our feet re: the Troc, but due to
the joyous cabaret and etc. laws in SF they are one of the few (5?) all-
ages venues that can go all night.  So, maybe some activism is in order
here (did you vote Hallinan, at least?), because the reason we don't have
alternatives isn't because there aren't people willing to put them on
or places to have them, it's the city gov't needing a bogeyman to bust
(easier than taking down real violence) and under-the-table cash to
spend (hard to grease enough palms w/out selling liquor).

Props to all the crews who make it happen despite this shit.  You know
who you are.  Maybe someday we won't have to skulk around the abandoned
decaying fringes of civilization in order to dance...naaah.  American
Konsumer Kulture (tm) is based on suppressing your urges (sex, dance,
free expression) and channeling them into revenue-producing activities
(expensive clothes, fast cars, beer, CDs).  Check out Wilhelm Reich's
_The Mass Psychology of Fascism_ for a great analysis of this, and the
military thing.  He's the only author ever deemed so dangerous that the
US gov't actually burned his books en masse.  Though he got way into 
fringe science which you may or may not believe, TMPOF is one hell of
a book, especially considering the time it was written (a lot closer to
WWII than to now).

Rant off.

// g

>========================================================================
>     CAMPAIGN TO STOP THE NET CENSORSHIP LEGISLATION IN CONGRESS
>     (INCLUDING THE COMMUNICATIONS DECENCY ACT AND THE HYDE AMDT)
>
>        Short Update: The House Conference Committee voted for a terrible
>                        bill.
>
>        What You Can Do Now: Call the Senate conferees and tell them to
>                                oppose the infringements on free speech.
>
>        CAMPAIGN TO STOP THE UNCONSTITUTIONAL NET CENSORSHIP LEGISLATION
>                           Dec 6, 1995
>
>      PLEASE WIDELY REDISTRIBUTE THIS DOCUMENT WITH THIS BANNER INTACT
>                REDISTRIBUTE ONLY UNTIL December 20, 1995
>               REPRODUCE THIS ALERT ONLY IN RELEVANT FORUMS
>
>________________________________________________________________________
>CONTENTS
>        The Latest News
>        What You Can Do Now
>        List of Participating Organizations (changed)
>
>________________________________________________________________________
>THE LATEST NEWS
>
>Today the House Conference committee voted to criminalize "indecent
>material" on electronic networks.  The Christian Coalition, which has
>pushed for such restrictions throughout the year, now smells blood and
>is closing in for the kill.  If we lose the Senate Conference Committee
>vote, we will have lost a tremendous amount of our First Amendment
>rights.  All content on the Internet will be dumbed down to the level of
>Saturday morning cartoons.
>
>Parents, educators, libraries and individuals who post anything on the
>Internet that someone, somewhere considers indecent will be subject
>to jail time and fines.   Traditional fiction and many great works of
>art will fall prey to this law.
>
>Even if the Federal government does not prosecute every violation of
>this law, the chilling effect on speech throughout the United States will
>be severe.  Intimidation is a tremendous persuader.
>
>Please call now and tell the Senate conferees to oppose the unconstitutional
>indecency restrictions in the Telecomm.
>
>For a more detailed analysis of the language that passed, check the WWW
>or Gopher sites of the ACLU, CDT, EFF, and EPIC.
>
>Three more alerts, after this one, are expected: the full House floor vote
>on the Telecomm bill, the full Senate floor vote on the Telecomm bill, and
>then the unlikely Presidential veto.
>
>________________________________________________________________________
>WHAT YOU CAN DO NOW
>
>1. All of the proposals available to the conference committee will
>   fundamentally restrict your speech on the Internet and other public
>   networks.  Look at the list below and call the Senators in your
>   state and ask them to oppose them.  If none of the members are in
>   your state, call Sen. Dole.
>
>   If we cannot convince the conference committee to make the right
>   choices at this juncture, we will have positioned the Internet
>   community as vulnerable to widespread arrests throughout the next
>   few years.
>
>   If you're at a loss for words, try one of the following:
>
>        Please oppose the unconstitutional Internet indecency restrictions,
>        such as those passed by the House conference committee Telecomm bill
>        and those proposed by Sen. J.J. Exon.   They will criminalize many
>        forms of expression, including much art, music, and literature
>        which should be protected by the First Amendment.
>   or
>        As a religious person and a parent, I oppose all the
>        unconstitutional indecency restrictions currently proposed in the
>        Telecomm bill.  I, the parent, am the best person to monitor my
>        child's access to the Internet.
>   or
>        Although there is information on the Internet that I wouldn't
>        allow my children to see, I don't agree with all the proposals in
>        the Telecomm bill that would censor indecent material on the
>        Internet.  I have parental control tools that are far more
>        effective at controlling my children's access to the Internet
>        than the legislation being proposed.
>
>   Senate members of the Conference Committee
>
>      P ST Name and Address           Phone           Fax
>      = == ========================   ==============  ==============
>      R MT Burns, Conrad R.           1-202-224-2644  1-202-224-8594
>      D HI Inouye, Daniel K.          1-202-224-3934  1-202-224-6747
>      D SC Hollings, Ernest F.        1-202-224-6121  1-202-224-4293
>      D WV Rockefeller, John D.       1-202-224-6472  n.a.
>      D NE Exon, J. J.                1-202-224-4224  1-202-224-5213
>      R AZ McCain, John               1-202-224-2235  1-602-952-8702
>      R SD Pressler, Larry            1-202-224-5842  1-202-224-1259
>      R WA Gorton, Slade              1-202-224-3441  1-202-224-9393
>      R AK Stevens, Ted               1-202-224-3004  1-202-224-1044
>      R MS Lott, Trent                1-202-224-6253  1-202-224-2262
>      D KY Ford, Wendell H.           1-202-224-4343  1-202-224-0046
>      R KS Dole, Robert               1-202-224-6521  1-202-228-1245
>
>2. Send mail to vtw@vtw.org and let us know how it went.
>
>        $ Mail vtw@vtw.org
>        Subject: phoned Senator XXX
>
>        They thanked me for my opinion and said they had received many
>        calls speaking out against net censorship.
>
>        ^D
>        Mail sent!
>
>3. If you run any sort of system that allows a welcome message for all
>   users, please add the following:
>
>       The Christian Coalition and others are lobbying for broad
>       infringements on free speech net by passing legislation that "dumb
>       down" Internet content to that which is acceptable to children.  In
>       addition, services like this one might become liable for what their
>       users say and read on the Internet.  Please call Congress now; for
>       more info URL:http://www.vtw.org/ or send mail to files@vtw.org with
>       "send alert" in the subject line. (12/6/95)
>
>   If you have a Web page that gets a lot of traffic, please add the
>   following link:
>
>        <a href="http://www.vtw.org/">
>        Stop the Christian Coalition and others from restricting your
>        online speech! (12/6/95)</a>
>
>4. This is a very tense week.  All indications are that a very very
>   bad bill will get passed.
>
>________________________________________________________________________
>LIST OF PARTICIPATING ORGANIZATIONS
>
>In order to use the net more effectively, several organizations have
>joined forces on a single Congressional net campaign to stop the
>Communications Decency Act.
>

========================================================================
     CAMPAIGN TO STOP THE NET CENSORSHIP LEGISLATION IN CONGRESS

    On Tuesday December 12, 1995, Join With Hundreds of Thousands
                  Of Your Fellow Internet Users In

                  A NATIONAL INTERNET DAY OF PROTEST

      PLEASE WIDELY REDISTRIBUTE THIS DOCUMENT WITH THIS BANNER INTACT
                REDISTRIBUTE ONLY UNTIL December 20, 1995
________________________________________________________________________
CONTENTS
        Internet Day of Protest: Tuesday December 12, 1995
        What You Must Do On Tuesday December 12, 1995
        List of Participating Organizations
        Where Can I Learn More?

________________________________________________________________________
INTERNET DAY OF PROTEST:  TUESDAY DECEMBER 12, 1995

Outrageous proposals to censor the Internet demand that the Internet
Community take swift and immediate action. We must stand up and let
Congress know that we will not tolerate their attempts to destroy this
medium! Please join hundreds of thousands of your fellow citizens in a
National Day of Protest on Tuesday December 12, 1995.

As you know, on Wednesday December 6, 1995, the House Conference
Committee on Telecommunications Reform voted to impose far reaching and
unconstitutional "indecency" restrictions on the Internet and other
interactive media, including large commercial online services (such as
America Online, Compuserve, and Prodigy) and smaller Internet Service
Providers such as Panix, the Well, Echo, and Mindvox.

These restrictions threaten the very existence of the Internet and
interactive media as a viable medium for free expression, education,
commerce.  If enacted, the Internet as we know it will never be the
same.

Libraries will not be able to put any books online that might
offend a child somewhere.  No "Catcher in the Rye" or "Ulysses" on the net.
Internet Service Providers could face criminal penalties for allowing
children to subscribe to their Internet Services, forcing many  small
companies to simply refuse to sell their services to anyone under 18. Worst
of all, everything you say and publish on the net will have to be "dumbed
down" to that which is acceptable to a child.

As Internet users, we simply must not allow this assault against the
Internet and our most basic freedoms to go unchallenged.

On Tuesday December 12, the organizations below are urging you to
join us in a NATIONAL DAY OF PROTEST. The goal is to flood key members of
the House and Senate with phone calls, faxes and email with the message
that the Internet community WILL NOT TOLERATE Congressional attempts to
destroy the Internet, limit our freedoms and trample on our rights.

Below are the phone, fax, and email address of several key members of
Congress on this issue and instructions on what you can do to join the
National Day of Protest to save the Net.

______________________________________________________________________
WHAT YOU MUST DO ON TUESDAY DECEMBER 12, 1995

1. Throughout the day Tuesday December 12, please contact as many
   members of Congress on the list below as you can. If you are only
   able to make one call, contact House Speaker Newt Gingrich. Finally,
   if the Senator or Representative from your state is on the list
   below, be sure to contact him or her also.

2. Urge each Member of Congress to "stop the madness".  Tell them that
   they are about to pass legislation that will destroy the Internet as
   an educational and commercial medium.  If you are at a loss for
   words, try the following sample communique:

   Sample phone call:

        Both the House and Senate bills designed to protect children
        from objectionable material on the Internet will actually
        destroy the Internet as an medium for education, commerce, and
        political discourse. There are other, less restrictive ways to
        address this issue.

        I urge you to oppose both measures being proposed in the
        conference committee.  This is an important election issue to
        me.

   Sample letter (fax or email):

        The Senate conferees are considering ways to protect children
        from inappropriate material on the Internet.  A vote for either
        the House or Senate proposals will result in the destruction of
        the Internet as a viable medium for free expression, education,
        commerce.  Libraries will not be able to put their entire book
        collections online.  Everyday people like me will risk massive
        fines and prison sentences for public discussions someone s
        somewhere might consider "indecent".

        There are other, less restrictive ways to protect children from
        objectionable material online. This is an important election
        issue to me.

3. If you're in San Francisco, or near enough to get there, go to
   the Rally Against Censorship from Ground Zero of the Digital Revolution:

   WHEN: Monday, December 11, 1995  12:00 - 1:00 PM
   WHERE: South Park (between 2nd and 3rd, Bryant and Brannon) San Francisco.
   SPEAKERS: To be announced
   BRING: Attention-grabbing posters, signs, and banners that demonstrate
        your committment to free speech and expression, and your feelings
        about Congress.
   FOR UPDATED INFORMATION (including rain info):
        http://www.hotwired.com/staff/digaman/


### THIS IS VERY IMPORTANT ###

4. Mail a note to protest@vtw.org to let us know you did your part.
   Although you will not receive a reply due to the number of
   anticipated responses, we'll be counting up the number of people that
   participated in the day of protest.

________________________________________________________________________
WHERE CAN I LEARN MORE?

At this moment, there are several organizations with WWW sites that now
have, or will have, information about the net censorship legislation and
the National Day Of Protest:

American Civil Liberties Union (ftp://ftp.aclu.org/aclu/)
Center for Democracy and Technology (http://www.cdt.org/)
Electronic Frontier Foundation (http://www.eff.org/)
Electronic Privacy Information Center (http://www.epic.org/)
Wired Magazine (http://www.hotwired.com/special/indecent/)
Voters Telecommunications Watch (http://www.vtw.org/)

________________________________________________________________________
LIST OF PARTICIPATING ORGANIZATIONS

In order to use the net more effectively, several organizations have
joined forces on a single Congressional net campaign to stop the
Communications Decency Act.


American Civil Liberties Union * American Communication Association *
American Council for the Arts * Arts & Technology Society * Association
of Alternative Newsweeklies * biancaTroll productions * Boston
Coalition for Freedom of Expression * Californians Against Censorship
Together * Center For Democracy And Technology * Centre for Democratic
Communications * Center for Public Representation * Citizen's Voice -
New Zealand * Cloud 9 Internet *Computer Communicators Association *
Computel Network Services * Computer Professionals for Social
Responsibility * Cross Connection * Cyber-Rights Campaign * CyberQueer
Lounge * Dorsai Embassy * Dutch Digital Citizens' Movement * ECHO
Communications Group, Inc. * Electronic Frontier Canada * Electronic
Frontier Foundation * Electronic Frontier Foundation - Austin *
Electronic Frontiers Australia * Electronic Frontiers Houston *
Electronic Frontiers New Hampshire * Electronic Privacy Information
Center * Feminists For Free Expression * First Amendment Teach-In *
Florida Coalition Against Censorship * FranceCom, Inc. Web Advertising
Services * Friendly Anti-Censorship Taskforce for Students * Hands
Off!  The Net * Inland Book Company * Inner Circle Technologies, Inc. *
Inst. for Global Communications * Internet On-Ramp, Inc. * Internet
Users Consortium * Joint Artists' and Music Promotions Political Action
Committee * The Libertarian Party * Marijuana Policy Project *
Metropolitan Data Networks Ltd. * MindVox * MN Grassroots Party *
National Bicycle Greenway * National Campaign for Freedom of Expression
* National Coalition Against Censorship * National Gay and Lesbian Task
Force * National Public Telecomputing Network * National Writers Union
* Oregon Coast RISC * Panix Public Access Internet * People for the
American Way * Republican Liberty Caucus * Rock Out Censorship *
Society for Electronic Access * The Thing International BBS Network *
The WELL * Voters Telecommunications Watch

(Note: All 'Electronic Frontier' organizations are independent entities,
 not EFF chapters or divisions.)

From: punk@inreach.inreach.com (Politikon Zoon)

X-Mailer: Quarterdeck Message Center [1.0]

ooo
> the music/concert industry. It really makes me mad! I know Goths and 
> Punks who love to go to shows just see how much trouble they can 
> start, and to see if they can find a way in for free. They never have 
> any money at all. Which is another thing, I'm knocking anyone or 
> their scene but for the most part it seems as though IMHO that 
> 'ravers' in comparision to Punks or Goths, etc. seem to have a much 
> higher percentage of paying clientele. So when you think about 
> wouldn't it make sense not to harass house events? I don't know, 

First of all I don't understand how you can say that because your crowd brings 
in more money that the owner of this place should treat you differently.  Why 
couldn't he treat you the way he wants?  If you don't like it go somewhere 
else.  I actually never been there, but I don't what all this complaining is 
getting accomplished.  If you don't like it, don't go there.  For example, 
since I don't like the crowd, atmosphere, and prices of the punk shows at 
Berkeley Square, I doubt I'll go back.  Instead of paying $10 to go to B. 
Square I'll just go to 924 Gilman.  Also, I would imagine that the rave scene 
has many more events than the punks in the first place.  Try to throw a punk 
show in most places and they'll think you're nutz.

Anways...  Just because you know a few bad seeds in a punk crowd doesn't mean 
you can generalize about everybody.  I could say that I know a few ravers that 
like to experiment with hard drugs and go to a rave.  Does this mean that all 
ravers are this way?  No?

> has many more events than the punks in the first place.  Try to throw a punk

> like to experiment with hard drugs and go to a rave.  Does this mean that all 
> ravers are this way?  No?
> 
No, no! I'm not saying that they are bad seeds, that's just the way 
they are. They are my friends and I'm not putting them down. I'm just 
trying to make a comparision, not a stereotype. Sorry for the 
confusion. I never try to put people down because of what they like 
or do, I just state how things are, with no opinions attatched. I 
know _several_ people who experiment with hard drugs, and not all 
ravers are like that, that was not what I was trying to get across. 
My point was that venue owners and managers shouldn't treat their 
clientele different depending on who they are or how much money they 
make off them. I myself will NOT go back to the Troc until things get 
better. I go out to enjoy myself, not to get harrassed and have 
shitty time because the staff sucks! 
Sorry for the misconceptions my friend!

Wayne D. Correia writes:
> How are you all doing out there after last night's many inches of rain and
> 100MPH winds? Our neighborhood here in SF was flooded and many units in my
> building were flooded but my place was spared!

good to hear that you surrived relative unscathed.

as for me, we had some leaks in the house.  nothing a few pots didn't fix
and some water in the basement (but no damage, it is just a garage  :-) )

when i woke up, the power was out.  this actually turned out to be not to
bad.  i showered and got dressed by candlelight.  as it turns out, it was
pretty kewl.  normally, i am totally rushed in the morning trying to get
out of the house.  but getting ready by candlelight, i could hardly see
anything.  it forced me to relax and chill which feels like the right way
to start the morning.  anyway, right after i get dressed, the power comes
on.  just in time to make coffee.  :-)

i hope everyone else is doing ok.

hugs
mike

>

Here in Sacramento it rained really hard as well.  I got a little water that
ran down the front door and dripped under it on to the tile.  No biggy.  I
walked to work this morning and it was crazy.  Supper high winds and crazy
rain.  I just strapped on my big rain coat, put a plastic bag on my head
(the kind you get in the produce section of the grocery store - It was tight
so I looled like some kinda bank robber) and got thrashed by the Earth
Mother.  It was pretty fun actually til my rain coat soaked through and I
could feel the water soaking through my pants on to my leg.  Took until
lunch for it to dry.  The sun's out now...go figure.

Rick

To: Czefir@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu (David Ginsberg)
Subject: Re: Shyness
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Czefir,
I spent alot of time this last year thinking about shyness and
outgoingness.  I think they're related to love and fear, which I think are
two sides of the same coin.  In any new social interaction, there is a
choice between love and fear, love being expressed in the reaching out to
connect and fear (of rejection, of not-belongong) being expressed
withdrawing.  And it often seems the longer the period before reaching out
the more awkward and difficult it becomes.  For me taking that initial leap
of faith is much easier at those times where I feel confident and like I
have something to contribute.  The funny thing is, the more I do this the
happier I get and the more I feel I can contribute so I do it more and so
on and so on and so on.  Pretty cool stuff, the psychology of love and
community!!!

I'm pretty shy also, though I've been gradually getting more outgoing.  And
now, having said that, it's time to walk my talk...I'm curious about your
name...I like the spelling and the way I imagine it's pronounced.  Do you
know what it means?  Where does it come from?  It sounds like the name of
an exotic shiek or a punjabi warrior or something, or the name of a distant
star.  Hmmm...
hugs,
David


****************************************************************************

David Ginsberg
Student of Philosophy and Cognitive Science
University of California at Berkeley
ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu
http://www.geopages.com/athens/2001

****************************************************************************

Received: by netcom17.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id UAA10779; Tue, 12 Dec 1995 20:20:13 -0800
Date: Tue, 12 Dec 1995 20:20:13 -0800 (PST)
From: kendall griggs <kgriggs@netcom.com>
Subject: Shyness is nice...("Ask")/ CHRYSALIS (12/9)
To: Shawna McGourty <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
cc: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
In-Reply-To: <199512110721.XAA09463@ix2.ix.netcom.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9512122030.A7836-0100000@netcom17>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Allright, enough references to THE SMITHS for one day.  But it's TRUE; It 
can STOP you from doing/saying all the things in life that you'd like to...

Chalk me up as yet another shy person with fits of self-consciousness.  
But it is a good idea to keep it under control.  I too, so far, have 
found the scene to be a place where you can be free and people are coming 
together at one place to share experiences.  I AGREE with Shawna here, 
that a FUZZY stuffed animal (i.e., a Koala bear) is a good icebreaker- 
you can even seek those people out and people seem to be apt to open up...

As for CHRYSALIS, it was another success on their part; BOTH chill rooms 
were BIG and PACKED.  However, ONE word comes to mind to describe last 
Saturday:  

	Can you say, "SWEATBOX?"

However, the music once again was incredible!  I also liked how the 
volume wasn't so OVERPOWERING (even through EAR PLUGS).  Now, this time, 
I took a friend to her first rave.  IF she weren't so tired from the 
commute and a Sharks game AND a Christmas party, she probably would have 
let me be there longer!  As for me, I again had a positive experience and 
had run into a few people I actually knew!  

One minor gripe is that she did not really expect to get SOMETHING in 
RETURN from sharing a water bottle...But overall it was well executed.  I 
like how there seemed to be a lot of effort in finding GOOD chill music 
as well.  KEEP the lazers!  Even though this time there was an absence of 
video projections (space constraints), the smaller place actually added 
some charm to it.  This type of situation works for me at small places 
seeing bands I like.  That's WHY I went to RANCID at The Edge, which 
reminded me of when THE OFFSPRING played there... Good job everybody...I 
can't wait for the next one...

that's my .02...

[ to SFRaves ]

 I went to Chrysalis , but I'll let others report on that excellent event!

 I do want to say my 2x$.02 about 'Nuff Respect and the jungle event
Cyberzen at The Top. Both good changes to listen to good jungle , but with
different character:

'Nuff Respect 
  A little pool hall/lounge/healthy snack bar establishment is Your Mama's
Cafe , at the corner of College and Broadway in Oakland. A nice site for
a meal and a chat as some tasty jungle music gets spun by DJ Star*Eyes  
and DJ Thad . I munched on a cashew and veggie and cheese sandwich ( quite
crunchy and good , a nice compliment to the music ).  
 No obvious place to dance , unless the pool tables get moved over. Still,
a nice lounge preliminary to the more kinetic action at The Top.

The Top/Cyberzen
  When I called The Top to ask when Cyberzen usually starts , the guy who
answered didn't know what I was talking about. When I said "the jungle music",
he recognized that - he told me it starts at about 9PM. Actually , the music
doesn't switch over from acid jazz to jungle until about 9:45PM or 10PM.
It takes awhile for a dancing crowd to get on the little dancefloor , but
the dance area gets filled up by midnight. And an enthusiastic crowd it is
too - more dance enthusiasm than vocalisation/yelling . That's probably cause
one has to concentrate to dance to jungle , more than techno ( although that
may be me ). 
  For the fog phobic/philic, there was one floor-sitting fog machine , used
sparingly . Also one strobe light , used almost continually. 
 I had a ticket for Chrysalis , so I left The Top around 12:30AM , but I
will definitely plan a Saturday night for jungle groovin' in the future!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

hmmm... i have been reading some posts on this list about shyness for a
while and here is my .o2...  i am really shy. i think this is a self
esteem/confidence issue with me.  i know parties especially under the
right circumstancEs are great for shyness, but generally i hardly ever
talk to anyone especially strangers.  i guess i figure that if we really
do not have anything mutually important to communicate, then, don't...
this is ok. i really like to dance and bliss out and listen to music and
feel the music and atmosphere instead. sometimes when i am on e i really
come out of my shell and it probably seems that i am a changed person.
something about the drug helps me tap strenghts i really have and to
temporarily put the dysfunctional tape loops on pause for a while. but i
really have the ability to do this without the drug... and this gets me
thinking that perhaps i think i use my shyness as an excuse to not take
chances and do anything which will pull me out of my ordinary way of
interacting with the world. perhaps this occurs with others?  i realize
that by being shy, there is a sort of protection(???) from self discovery
- we learn alot about ourselves from others - and when we are shy, we can
hide from this self discovery and the responsibilities it presents... so
shyness then becomes our defense from parts of ourselves we find it hard
to see or accept. make sense? maybe... 

kevin
:)

here at u.c. santa cruz we did not have finals today because the power 
was out all over campus and in most of town (except down town)..the power 
went out at about 1am tue morn and then on and off intermitantly until 
about 5am..
at about 5 or 6 in the morning i saw the flash from ....BOOMMMMMMM and 
there it was.... it must have been at least six miles away because the 
sound came about six seconds after the flash (i think that is how you 
measure the distance lightening is away from you?) that was the only 
thunder i heard all night (there might have been more) but it was preety 
spectacular!
power was restored at about 6pm to our delight
we are supposed to have finals tomorrow if we have power...i just started 
raining again (3am) so we will see!

in short will REAL nightlife return to SF?

I dunno.  Who dares make the first step?

Out,
John

At 1:00 AM 12/13/95, Kevin Keiper wrote:
>hmmm... i have been reading some posts on this list about shyness for a
>while and here is my .o2...  i am really shy. i think this is a self
>esteem/confidence issue with me.  i know parties especially under the
>right circumstancEs are great for shyness, but generally i hardly ever
>talk to anyone especially strangers.  i guess i figure that if we really
>do not have anything mutually important to communicate, then, don't...
>this is ok. i really like to dance and bliss out and listen to music and
>feel the music and atmosphere instead. sometimes when i am on e i really
>come out of my shell and it probably seems that i am a changed person.
>something about the drug helps me tap strenghts i really have and to
>temporarily put the dysfunctional tape loops on pause for a while. but i
>really have the ability to do this without the drug... and this gets me
>thinking that perhaps i think i use my shyness as an excuse to not take
>chances and do anything which will pull me out of my ordinary way of
>interacting with the world. perhaps this occurs with others?  i realize
>that by being shy, there is a sort of protection(???) from self discovery
>- we learn alot about ourselves from others - and when we are shy, we can
>hide from this self discovery and the responsibilities it presents... so
>shyness then becomes our defense from parts of ourselves we find it hard
>to see or accept. make sense? maybe...
>
>kevin
>:)
        TOTAL sense. I have realized (or, that is, am still realizing) a
lot of things about self-awareness and perception/perspectives and
self-reflection. One of the difficulties of being really introverted and/or
shy (because sometimes ppl CHOOSE not to talk to other people though
they're not shy) is that you become really entangled in your own thoughts.
THis can be good, you can learn a lot about yourself and about other
people. In fact you can dig so deep subjectively that you end up realizing
a lot of things about all of us which is universally applicable. THe thing
that i've found though, is that recently i've become really introverted and
it's not a good thing. When you get into this whole "thinking about the way
that you're thinking thing" (say that 3 x fast!) you end up kind of phasing
out people around you. You're lost in your own little world and that's not
good.  Because to understand yourself 'objectively' you need more than one
view. Your normal state of consciousness is one view of yourself (if you
choose to look inward, and there are those who don't i think), the view you
have of yourself in altered states are other views (dreams or ...whatever
:)) but also, when you REALLY communicate with someone, when you really
EMPATHIZE you begin to understand who they are and how they see the world,
you can see the world through their eyes to an extent, and when you're in
that situation you can use THAT perspective to look at yourself and all of
your flaws and all of your beauties :) So, by losing yourself in another
person you are sort of able to find yourself...woo woo how zen! :)
        :) brad :)

At 4:44 PM 12/12/95, David Ginsberg wrote:
>Czefir,
>I spent alot of time this last year thinking about shyness and
>outgoingness.  I think they're related to love and fear, which I think are
>two sides of the same coin.  In any new social interaction, there is a
>choice between love and fear, love being expressed in the reaching out to
>connect and fear (of rejection, of not-belongong) being expressed
>withdrawing.  And it often seems the longer the period before reaching out
>the more awkward and difficult it becomes.  For me taking that initial leap
>of faith is much easier at those times where I feel confident and like I
>have something to contribute.  The funny thing is, the more I do this the
>happier I get and the more I feel I can contribute so I do it more and so
>on and so on and so on.  Pretty cool stuff, the psychology of love and
>community!!!

        i just wanted to say: "well put! well put!" :)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Dec 13 11:38:03 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA18761; Wed, 13 Dec 1995 11:38:03 -0800
Received: from parcplace.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA18754; Wed, 13 Dec 1995 11:38:00 -0800
Received: from [192.159.3.151] (2heads.parcplace.com [192.159.3.151]) by parcplace.com (8.6.12/8.6.9) with SMTP id LAA06648 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 13 Dec 1995 11:32:52 -0800
X-Sender: snomura@central
Message-Id: <acf4beec00021004989d@[192.159.3.151]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 13 Dec 1995 11:41:54 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: snomura@parcplace.com (Sean Nomura)
Subject: Re: Shyness is nice...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Wow! All these shy people! Not just shy..... painfully shy and self-conscious..
Both men and women, all with wonderful, thoughtful insights about their
condition.

I'm not alone. I'm not alone. I'm not alone.

Because other people's shared experiences has brought some comfort to me, I
would like to share my own...

I remember when I was young.... I felt that my parents had little or no
interest in me.... They made me feel like I was... a burden... As a child,
I really didn't feel like I was welcomed into this world. It was from there
that I turned inward to find out who I was.

Not even feeling worthy of the food that I ate or the bed that I slept in,
and fear that my parents would one day turn me away, I became extremely
aware of their every move and every thought. Even more, I became extremely
aware of my own.... every move I made, I had to measure the ramafications
by which my actions would impact my very own existence. If I screwed up, I
would be turned away... and I would die. Feeling like I didn't belong, I
would do anything to belong. Feeling, unloved, I would do anything to be
loved, even if that meant turning away from who I really was and doing what
was necessary for my own survival.

And so, Kevin and David, I think you're both right. I attribute my shyness
to confidence, esteem, and fear. I think it is the constant weighing of the
consequences of one's personal actions. It is behavior (programmed by fear)
for the fulfillment of one's desires - the desire to be loved and accepted.
It is the product of being SELF seeking, and very often a self-fulfilling
prophecy.

Even though many of us are aware of this, why do we continue to hold on to
our defenses? I believe it is because we are comfortable hanging on to
them. And observing many people with the so-called confident behavior can
often leave much to be desired. It is often used, or rather abused, to help
someone fulfill their own narcissistic needs, and often wreaks havoc on the
lives of other people. Many of you are aware that with gained
self-confidence comes responsibility. I would like to say that confidence
is not 'bad', just like anger is not 'bad.' It's what one does with it that
makes it so. I found that in my own self, that as my confidence began to
grow, that it wasn't life that I feared after all.... it was my own self.

With shyness also comes the appearance of being humble, which is an
admirable quality... The desire to learn, and to reach out. When a person
has based his/her life on self-discovery the prospect of losing that drive
can be EXTREMELY scary.

And then why would we want to NOT be shy? Well, because shyness doesn't
feel too good now does it? I think we all have this picture in our heads
about our 'ideal' self, and not being 'comfortable within onself' certainly
does not fit the profile. Quite frankly, I think this reason is
self-seeking and not realistic. In fact, these motives will actually foster
the exact opposite of what this person really wants for himself.

One may argue that what I'm saying is just a matter of semantics. But what
I'm getting at is that a person strives to be his 'True' self. If one seeks
confidence/esteem for the gratification of his ego (ideal), then that's
what he'll get in return. A 'true' self does not worry about ego
projection, nor the consequences of his actions. He trusts in himself.
Values himself. He is spontaneous, joyful, alert and sensitive, and
extremely aware. He lives for the now, in the moment. All the most powerful
and most feared qualities lie under all of the fear-based, ego projecting,
self-seeking programming.....

Take away all of the programming... and what do you find?




Something WONDERFUL.




You.



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Dec 13 12:01:26 1995

Well, for all us shy people out there, who don't talk to anybody 
because there doesn't seem to be anything to talk about, now we have a 
subject to discuss:  shyness!  It sure has elicited a lot of discussion 
on the list, good to know I'm not alone; in fact I'd bet there's very 
few people out there who aren't shy to some degree, so I guess we're 
all in the same big boat!  We should call this list SFRAVES/SHYNESS :) 
so many people have both those in common.  And isn't it ironic that, 
while shyness results from fear of communications & situations that can 
cause isolation & aloneness, shyness is actually a bigger cause of 
isolation & aloneness!  Well I certainly don't feel isolated or alone 
(right now anyway), and I am quite grateful for that.


Peace

Shawna

	id MAA00847; Wed, 13 Dec 1995 12:11:58 -0800
Message-Id: <199512132011.MAA00847@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: FYI 1/1
Date: Wed, 13 Dec 95 12:11:57 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i found this somewhere on the internet. no idea of it's copyright
status so please remove my name from any copies you save/repost.
------- Forwarded Message
                               PLANTS- MARIJUANA

SYNONYMS:  MARIHUANA; MARIJUANA;  THC

0.0 OVERVIEW (OVER)
 0.1 LIFE SUPPORT (OV-LIFE)
This overview assumes that basic life support measures have been instituted.
 0.2 CLINICAL EFFECTS (OV-CLEF)
  0.2.3 HEENT
    A.   Marijuana  may cause reddening of the conjunctiva.  An increase in
heart rate and cardiac output may follow  marijuana  exposure.  Large doses of
THC have also caused postural hypotension.
    B.  Prolonged administration of high dose THC may result in a decreased
heart rate and signs of congestive heart failure.
  0.2.5 RESPIRATORY
    A.  Large doses of smoked  marijuana  may cause irritation and coughing.
A dose-related bronchodilator effect follows both ingestion and inhalation.
Long term smoking of  marijuana  has been associated with chronic
respiratory syndromes.
  0.2.6 NEUROLOGIC
    A.  A low level intoxication usually presents with drowsiness, euphoria,
heightened sensory awareness, feeling of well being, and alteration of time
perception.
    B.  Moderate intoxication presents with memory impairment,
depersonalization, and mood alterations.
    C.  High levels are associated with decreased motor coordination,
lethargy,
and slurred speech. Apprehensive patients may experience panic reactions.
Seizures may occur in patients with existing seizure disorders.
  0.2.7 GASTROINTESTINAL
    A.  Dry mouth, reduced bowel motility, and increased appetite have been
reported.
  0.2.9 GENITOURINARY
    A.  Urinary retention has occurred following THC use.
 0.3 LABORATORY (OV-LAB)
  A.  THC is difficult to detect in body fluids because of the low levels
found
in the plasma and the numerous metabolites formed.
   1.  An ingestion of 20 mg/THC has produced a peak plasma level of 10
nanograms/mL.
  B.  A semiquantitative EMIT homogenous enzyme immunoassay is
available for measurement of cannabinoids in urine.
  C.  An RIA method is available for high volume work with the same
specificity  as the EMIT.  GC/Mass Spec is the most specific and is used as the
reference method.
 0.4 TREATMENT OVERVIEW (OV-TRMT)
  0.4.2 ORAL/PARENTERAL EXPOSURE
    A.  EMESIS: May be indicated in recent substantial ingestion unless the
patient is or could rapidly become obtunded, comatose or convulsing.  Is most
effective if initiated within 30 minutes.  (Dose of Ipecac Syrup: ADULT: 30
mL;  CHILD 1 to 12 years: 15 mL).
    B.  ACTIVATED CHARCOAL/CATHARTIC: Administer charcoal slurry,
aqueous or mixed with saline cathartic or sorbitol.  The FDA suggests 240 mL
of diluent/30  g of charcoal.  Usual charcoal dose is 30 to 100 grams in adults
and 15 to 30 grams in children (1 to 2 g/kg in infants).
     1.  Administer one dose of a cathartic, mixed with charcoal or given
separately.  See "Treatment: Prevention of Absorption" in the main
document.
    C.  Depressive, hallucinatory or psychotic reactions should be treated by
placing the patient in a quiet area and providing them with reassurance that
no  permanent effects will occur.
     1.  Benzodiazepines are preferred drugs for treatment of extreme
agitation
(5 to 10 mg diazepam PO is usually sufficient).
  D.  HYPOTENSION: Administer IV fluids and place in Trendelenburg
position. If unresponsive to these measures, administer dopamine (2 to 5
mcg/kg/min) (first choice) or norepinephrine (0.1 to 0.2 mcg/kg/min) and
titrate as needed to desired response.
 0.5 RANGE OF TOXICITY (OV-TOX)
  A.  The estimated lethal dose of cannabis in humans is 30 mg/kg of absorbed
cannabis.
  B.  15 mg/m(2) orally of THC produced significant CNS symptoms in
patients receiving THC as an antiemetic.  5 mg/m(2) was tolerated by these
patients with  a low degree of CNS effects.
  C.  The acute oral toxicity of cannabis derivatives used as intoxicants
is low.

1.0 SUBSTANCES INCLUDED (SUBS)
 1.1 THERAPEUTIC/TOXIC CLASS (CLASS)
  A.   Marijuana  is the common name of Cannabis sativa.  There are over 200
to  300 million users worldwide.  It is used for its perception altering
characteristics.  Therapeutic uses include treatment of glaucoma and
chemotherapy induced nausea (Johnson, 1990).
  B.  Pure delta 9 THC is available by prescription under the generic name
dronabinol.  A synthetic cannabinoid, nabilone, is also available.
 1.2 SPECIFIC SUBSTANCES (SPEC)
  A.  SYNONYMS: There are hundreds of  marijuana  synonyms.  A few of
these include:
          Bhang
          Charas
          Dagga
          Ganja
          Grass
          Hashish
          Kif
          Majun
          Mary Jane
          Pot
          Weed

2.0 CLINICAL EFFECTS (CLEF)
 2.1 SUMMARY (CLEF-SUM)
  A.  A LOW LEVEL of intoxication usually presents with somnolence, mild
euphoria, heightened sensory awareness, a generally relaxed feeling of well-
being, and some alteration of time perception.
  B.  MODERATE INTOXICATION may present with short term memory
impairment, inability to accomplish tasks requiring multiple mental steps,
depersonalization, lapses of attention, and decreased social inhibition.
    1.  Mood alterations, including giddiness manifested by laughing episodes,
depression, and withdrawn behavior may also occur.
  C.  HIGH LEVELS OF INTOXICATION are associated with decreased motor
coordination, muscle strength and hand steadiness. Lethargy, sedation, poor
concentration ability, slurred speech, ataxia and an increase in reaction time
may also occur.
   1.  Apprehensive patients may experience panic reactions. Large doses may
produce skeletal muscle jerking (Nahas, 1971; Weil, 1970).
  D.  ABRUPT DISCONTINUATION of chronic  marijuana/ THC use has
resulted in a mild abstinence syndrome, consisting of agitation, apprehension
and aggressiveness, as well as tremulousness, insomnia and diaphoresis
(Mendelson et al, 1984; Nahas, 1984), and the development of common
migraine headaches
(El-Mallakh, 1987).
  E.  INGESTION: Typical manifestations following accidental ingestion of
marijuana  or hashish in children include rapid onset of drowsiness,
mydriasis, marked hypotonia, significant eyelid lag, and the finding of
granules, leaves, or resin in the mouth.
   1.  Rarely, more serious problems, such as coma and/or respiratory
obstruction may occur (Macnab et al, 1989). Stupor and respiratory depression
have been reported after ingestion of 1 to 1.5 grams of hashish or several
marijuana  butts (Bro et al, 1975; Macnab et al, 1989).
 2.3 HEENT (HENT)
   2.3.2 EYES
    A.  CONJUNTIVITIS:  Marijuana  use characteristically causes reddening of
the conjunctiva and reduces intraocular pressure (Green & McDonald, 1987).
It is noted at levels greater than 5 ng/mL (Digregorio & Sterling, 1987).
    B.  CHEMOSIS: Topical application of THC over 9 days to cats produced
chemosis and corneal opacification (Colasanti et al, 1984).
    C.  MYDRIASIS: Has been reported in children after accidental ingestion of
marijuana  or hashish (Macnab et al, 1989).
    D.  NYSTAGMUS: And photophobia have rarely been reported (Gilman et
al, 1985; Ashton, 1987).  Both vertical and horizontal nystagmus have been
reported  in pediatric poisoning (Weinberg et al, 1983).
  2.3.5 THROAT
    A.  UVULA: An edematous, often elongated uvula has been associated
with marijuana  use (Haddad, 1990).
 2.4 CARDIOVASCULAR (CARD)
  A.  HEART RATE CHANGES
   1.  TACHYCARDIA: An increase in heart rate and cardiac output may
follow marijuana  exposure--the response is dose-related (Digregorio &
Sterling, 1987).  The heart rate may increase as much as 20 to 50 beats per
minute.
   2.  BRADYCARDIA: Non-specific ST wave changes have been reported.
Prolonged  administration of high doses of THC may result in a decrease of
heart rate and signs of congestive heart failure.
   B.  BLOOD PRESSURE
   1.  HYPERTENSION: A slight elevation in blood pressure occurs commonly
and significant hypertension has been reported (Beaconsfield et al, 1972).
   2.  HYPOTENSION: Large doses of THC have also caused postural
hypotension (Ishbell et al, 1967; Thacore & Shukla, 1976; Ashton, 1987), and
severe dizziness (Mathew et al, 1992).
  C.  ANGINA: May be precipitated.  A case report suggests an association
between cannabis smoking and a fatal coronary artery thrombosis in a 32-year
old, but other drugs were not ruled out (Macinnes & Miller, 1984).
  D.  STROKE: Cerebral infarction due to heavy  marijuana  use was proposed
in two cases seen by Zachariah (1991) and one by Barnes et al (1992).  This is
not  a commonly reported effect.
  E.  CEREBRAL BLOOD FLOW
   1.  Mathew et al (1992) found that smoking high (THC 3.55%) and low (THC
1.75%) dose  marijuana  causes a significant increase in cerebral blood
flow to
both hemispheres, which peaked in 30 minutes and lasted 60 minutes.
Greater increases were noted in the frontal region and the right hemisphere.
The increase in cerebral blood flow correlated with the degree of intoxication,
THC  plasma levels, pulse rate, and blood pressure.
 2.5 RESPIRATORY (RESP)
  A.  BRONCHITIS
   1.  Large doses of smoked  marijuana  may cause irritation and coughing.
     a.  Long-term smoking of  marijuana  has been associated with chronic
respiratory symptoms such as sore throat, rhinitis, bronchitis, and
deterioration of pulmonary function suggesting airway narrowing (Tashkin
et al,  1980; Tilles et al, 1986; Wu et al, 1988; Bloom et al, 1987).
   2.  A dose-related short term bronchodilator effect follows both ingestion
and inhalation (Tashkin et al, 1976; Murray, 1985).  This effect is seen in
both
normal individuals and asthmatics (Gong et al, 1984).
   3.  TAR
    a.   Marijuana  smoke also has a high tar content and it has been
estimated
that 2 to 3  marijuana  cigarettes may carry the same risk of lung damage as a
pack of tobacco cigarettes.
    b.  In prospective studies of chronic  marijuana  smokers compared to
tobacco smokers, inhalation of  marijuana  was associated with a 4 to 5-fold
increase in blood carboxyhemoglobin level, a 3-fold increase in amount of tar
inhaled, and increased respiratory tract retention of tar (Wu et al, 1988;
Tashkin et al, 1988).
  B.  BRADYPNEA: Has been noted in children following ingestion of
cannabis resin (Pettinger et al, 1988; Bro et al, 1975).
  C.  RESPIRATORY OBSTRUCTION: Was reported in a 3-year-old boy after
ingestion  of tea made from  marijuana  (Macnab et al, 1989).
 2.6 NEUROLOGIC (NEUR)
  A.  SEIZURES:  Marijuana  use may potentiate seizures in patients with
existing seizure disorders.
  B.  SLEEP CHANGES:  Marijuana  usually facilitates sleep induction and
may slightly prolong the duration of sleep. Large doses of THC reportedly
decrease the activity and duration of rapid eye movement (REM) during
sleep.
   1.  REM rebound has occurred following withdrawal of large, but not small,
doses.
  C.  COMA: Drowsiness and stupor occurs rapidly after accidental ingestion of
marijuana  by children.
   1.  It has also been seen after deliberate intoxication of 5-month to
10-year
olds who were under the care of a babysitter.  (Schwartz et al, 1986).
   2.  Coma has been reported in children after ingestion of hashish or
marijuana  (Macnab et al, 1989; Lacroix et al, 1989).  Recovery generally
occurs
within 6 to 12 hours (Macnab et al, 1989; Pettinger et al, 1988).
  D.  EUPHORIA: A dreamy fantasy, depersonalization, increasing audio and
visual perception, and time-space distortion may be noted (Digregorio &
Sterling, 1987).
  E.  LAUGHTER: Spontaneous and inappropriate laughter often is seen
(Digregorio & Sterling, 1987).
  F.  INCOORDINATION: Muscle incoordination may be noted (Schwartz,
1985).
  G.  MEMORY LOSS: Recent (short-term) memory loss has been shown to
occur after THC exposure.  Studies have been split as to whether the
impairment continues after an exposure (Schwartz, 1991; Schwartz et al, 1989).
    1.  These amnesic or "blackout" spells occur most often with chronic
excessive smoking (Chopra & Smith, 1974).
  H.  DIZZINESS: May be seen.  In one study severe dizziness was associated
with hypotension and reduced cerebral blood velocity while moderate
dizziness was seen with reduced blood velocity but not hypotension, and
mild dizziness was not associated with either (Mathew et al, 1992).
  I.  COGNITION
   1.  SUMMARY
    a.  Whether or not  marijuana  use affects human cognition remains
controversial.  Some studies have reported some degree of cognitive
impairment from chronic  marijuana  use (Block & Ghoneim, 1993; Schwartz
et al, 1989; Page  et al, 1988; Soueif, 1976; Soueif, 1975; Entin &
Goldzung, 1973),
while others have found that impairments were absent or negligible (Block &
Ghoneim, 1993; Carlin & Trupin, 1977; Weckowicz & Janssen, 1973; Bowman
& Pihl, 1973).
    b.  Cognitive impairments may depend on the frequency of chronic use
(Block  & Ghoneim, 1993).
 2.7 GASTROINTESTINAL (GAST)
  A.  DRY MOUTH: And throat have been noted (Digregorio & Sterling, 1987).
  B.  APPETITE: Increased appetite, especially for sweets, has been reported
(Abel, 1982).
  C.  CONSTIPATION: Reduced bowel motility has been reported (Ishell et al,
1967).
  2.9 GENITOURINARY (GENT)
  A.  URINARY RETENTION: Has occurred following THC use (Burton,
1979).
  B.  FERTILITY: Chronic use may decrease sperm count and fertility (Margolis
&  Popkin, 1980).
  C.  TESTOSTERONE LEVELS: Decrease with chronic use (Digregorio &
Sterling, 1987).
  D.  MENSTRUATION: Abnormal menstruation and decreased ovulation
may be seen with chronic use (Digregorio & Sterling, 1987).
  E.  GYNECOMASTIA: Has been reported (Johnson, 1990).
 2.13 TEMPERATURE REGULATION (TEMP)
  A.  HYPOTHERMIA: Was noted in children who accidentally ingested
cannabis resin (Pettinger et al, 1988; Bro et al, 1975).
  B.  HYPERTHERMIA: Was seen in a 24-year-old chronic user who smoked
one cigarette and immediately jogged in 84 degrees F weather.  He presented
with an  agitated delirium, rectal temperature of 41.7 degrees C.  Cooling
therapy reduced his rectal temperature to 38.5 degrees C within 80 minutes
(Walter & Benowitz, 1990).
 2.17 ENDOCRINE (ENDO)
  A.  HORMONE CHANGES: The use of  marijuana  cigarettes and oral THC
has reportedly lowered testosterone (Kolodny et al, 1974), luteinizing
hormone, growth hormone and follicle stimulating hormones in humans,
however, these levels remain within the normal range (MayKut, 1985).
   B.  T-CELLS: A reduced T-cell function has been reported (Aaronson &
Dunn, 1974).
 2.18 PSYCHIATRIC (PSYCH)
  A.  SCHIZOPHRENIA
   1.   Marijuana  use has exacerbated existing schizophrenia. It is unknown
whether  marijuana  use can cause mental illness in otherwise normal,
healthy people without predisposition to schizophrenia.  Flashback
phenomena have been reported, but occur rarely (Ghodse, 1986).
   2.  Andreasson et al (1987) reported the relative risk for schizophrenia
among high consumers of cannabis (>50 occasions) was 6 compared to non-
users in  a 15-year follow-up study in a cohort of 45,570.
  B.  AMOTIVATIONAL SYNDROME: Has been reported, especially in teens.
Behavior  changes include mood changes, abuse behavior, withdrawal from
family and friends, apathy, and underachievement (Schwartz, 1985; Toohey et
al, 1982; Hendin et al, 1981; Creason & Goldman, 1981).
   1.  Subsequent studies using a broader user base as the study group have
not
been able to duplicate the amotivational syndrome (Beaubrun & Knight, 1975;
Murray, 1985; Relman, 1982).
  C.  PSYCHOSIS
   1.  Various types of psychoses have been suggested to result from acute and
chronic  marijuana  use (Solomons et al, 1990; Binitie, 1975; Kunkel,
1985); it
is unclear whether cannabis psychosis actually exists.
    2.  Cannabis may produce acute organic reactions or psychotic reactions in
clear consciousness (Thornicroft, 1990; Rottanburg et al, 1982).
 2.19 PREGNANCY/BREAST MILK (PREG)
  2.19.1 TERATOGENICITY
    A.  SPERMATOGENESIS:  Marijuana  decreases spermatogenesis, sperm
motility,  and increases abnormal forms of sperm (Nahas, 1984).
    B.  CONGENITAL ANOMALIES: There is a potential for cogenital
anomalies in offspring of women who smoke throughout pregnancy (Oazi et
al, 1985; O'Connell & Fried, 1984).
    C.  ANIMAL STUDIES: Suggest that cannabinoids can be embryocidal, affect
gestational length and labor, induce maturational delays, and affect long term
neuroendocrine function and adult sexual behaviors (Dalterio, 1986).
  2.19.2 EFFECTS IN PREGNANCY
    A.  In a prospective study of 3,857 pregnancies in which 4.1% of the
mothers
used  marijuana  occasionally and 5.4% frequently, among white (but not
non-white) mothers, it was found that:
     1.  There was a higher incidence of delivery of low birth weight and
small
for gestational age infants (Pinkert, 1985).
     2.  A high incidence of preterm delivery occurred among mothers with
frequent  marijuana  use (Hatch & Bracken, 1986; Linn et al, 1983).
    B.  In a controlled prospective study of 202 pregnant women with positive
urine assays for  marijuana,  decreased birth weight and length were
observed, compared to non-users.  No associattion with increased congenital
anomaties was  found (Zuckerman et al, 1989).
     1.  Witter & Niebyl (1990) found no association between  marijuana  and
either prematurity or congenital anomalies.
    C.  POSTNATAL NEUROBEHAVIORAL DEVELOPMENT: 48 months after
prenatal exposure to  marijuana,  children scored lower in verbal skills and
memory (after controlling for confounding variables) (Fried & Watkinson,
1990).
    D.  In a rabbit study,  marijuana  was found to be embryotoxic but not a
teratogen (Rosenkrantz et al, 1986).
 2.20 CARCINOGENICITY (CARC)
  A.  BRONCHOGENIC CARCINOMA: The polyaromatic hydrocarbons may
produce increased risk of lung and bronchial cancer (Anon, 1980; Relman,
1982; Ferguson  et al, 1989).
  B.  MOUTH CANCER:  Marijuana  smoking has been implicated as a
possible cause  of mouth cancer (Caplan, 1991).
 2.21 IMMUNOLOGIC (IMMU)
  A.  LYMPHOCYTES: Abnormal T-lymphocyte function has been associated
with the chronic use of  marijuana  although increased susceptibility to
infection has not been shown.

3.0 LABORATORY (LAB)
 3.1 METHODS (METH)
   A.   DETECTION  DIFFICULTIES: THC is difficult to detect in body fluids
because of the low levels found in plasma and the numerous metabolites
formed.  The small amount excreted in the urine makes it difficult to detect.
  B.   DETECTION  METHODS
   1.  MASS SPECTROMETRY with high-pressure gas or liquid
chromatography may be  available in special laboratories for the  detection
and quanitation of cannabinol.
   2.  An IMMUNOREACTIVE METHOD and homogenous enzyme
immunoassay may also be available but are less specific since they identify
both THC and other cannabinoids simultaneously (Nahas, 1979).
   3.  A SEMIQUANTITATIVE EMIT(R) homogeneous enzyme immunoassay
is available for measurement of cannabinoids in urine.
    a.  The assay detects major urinary metabolites of delta(9)-
tetrahydrocannabinol, with a  detection  limit (sensitivity) of 50 ng/mL for 11-
nor-delta(9)-tetrahydrocannabinol-9-carboxylic acid.
    b.  Also available is a qualitative EMIT urine assay, which has a
detection
limit of 200 ng/mL for 11-nor-delta(9)-carboxylic acid.
    c.  Two systems are available, an EMIT-st (single test) and EMIT (d.a.u)
drugs of abuse in urine.  The first has a sensitivity of 100 nanograms/mL, the
second 20 ng/mL (Digregorio & Sterling, 1987).
  C.  LABORATORY-SYMPTOM CORRELATION: These urine tests do not
correlate with symptoms or degree of exposure.  A positive result indicates
only the likelihood of prior use or the possibility of exposure to sidestream
smoke.
   1.  Following a single cigarette, THC metabolites are detectable for
several
days.  In casual users cannabinoids may be excreted for up to 2 weeks, and
greater than 4 weeks in heavy users (MMWR, 1983).
  D.  ADULTERANT-LABORATORY INTERFERENCE
   1.  Urinary levels fluctuate from day to day.  Adulterants may cause false-
negatives (acidic or alkaline adulteration or extreme dilution of the urine),
therefore urine pH and specific gravity should also be assessed (Schwartz &
Hawks, 1985).
   2.  Ingestion of 3000 mg of ascorbic acid, 1560 mg of golden seal root,
and 750
mL of cranberry juice did not interfere with EMIT testing of urine for
cannabinoids. Levels were reduced but still detectable (Schwartz & Bogema,
1988).
   3.  The addition of Visine (R) eye drops in concentrations of 20 to 100
mL per
liter of urine resulted in false negative urine assays for cannabinoids using
the EMIT and TDx assays.  This effect was more evident when glass specimen
containers were used.
    a.  Studies with various components of Visine (R) showed the
benzalkonium chloride to be primarily responsible, although the borate
buffer had some effect (Pearson et al, 1989).
   4.  False negative results were seen in cannabinoid EMIT assays with the
adulterants sodium hypochlorite, Joy (R) liquid dish detergent, and sodium
chloride.  The amount of sodium chloride needed to produce this effect
(greater  than 50 g/L) would preclude its practical use.
    a.  When the same adulterants were tested with an RIA assay or the Abbott
TDx assay, no false negatives were seen, but false positives occurred with the
Joy (R) detergent (Warner, 1989).
 3.2 MONITORING PARAMETERS/LEVELS (MONIT)
  3.2.1 SERUM/PLASMA/BLOOD
    A.  Five mg of smoked THC has produced a maximum plasma level of 100
nanograms per mL.  Ingestion of 20 mg of THC has produced a peak plasma
level of 10 nanograms per mL (Nahas, 1979).
    B.  It was determined that plasma levels of greater than 10 nanograms per
mL THC were necessary to prevent nausea and vomiting in patients
receiving THC plus chemotherapy agents (Chang et al, 1979).
  3.2.2 URINE
    A.  DURATION OF  DETECTION
     1.  Depending upon the assay, chronic cannabis users who have stopped
using  marijuana  can continue to have positive urine results for:
      a.  An average of 16 days (up to 46 days) before the first negative
and up to
77 days (average 27 days) before it was less than the cut off of 20 ng/mL
for 10
consecutive days (Ellis et al, 1985).
     2.  A study of 13 chronic  marijuana  users demonstrated positive EMIT
urine assays for 3 to 25 days after cessation of smoking.  The excretion
half-life
for the delta-THC-7-oic acid metabolite ranged from 0.8 to 9.8 days (Johansson
& Halldin, 1989).
    B.  LEVELS AFTER PASSIVE INHALATION
     1.  A study by Law et al (1984) demonstrated that passive inhalation of
marijuana  smoke may result in urinary (not blood) levels of THC
metabolites, but should rarely exceed 50 ng/mL.
     2.  Other studies have shown similar results (Cone & Johnson, 1986; Mason
et al, 1983; Perez-Reyes et al, 1983).
     3.  Passive inhalation of smoke may produce detectable levels of the
metabolites in the urine, but generally only under conditions in which the
marijuana  smoke is so concentrated in the atmosphere as to be irritating and
noxious (Cone et al, 1987).
     4.  Sidestream smoke from 4 to 16  marijuana  cigarettes for 1
hour/day for
6 days produced positive urine assays in 5 volunteers (Cone et al, 1986).
  3.2.3 OTHER
    A.  SALIVARY LEVELS
     1.  Positive salivary levels of THC suggest  marijuana  smoking within
a 12
hour period (Verebey et al, 1986).
     2.  One study indicated that salivary THC levels, as determined by
GC-mass
spectrometry, correlated well with a subjective index of intoxication and with
heart rate (Menkes et al, 1991).
