------- Forwarded Message

 4.0 CASE REPORTS (REPS)
 A.  INGESTION
  1.  Following the ingestion of cookies which were found to contain
marijuana,  three children presented with ataxic gait, generalized pallor,
bilateral conjunctival hyperemia, fine motor tremor, and stupor.
   a.  All three children recovered uneventfully within a six hour period
(Weinberg et al, 1983).
  2.  Inappropriate smiling and crying, tachycardia, and nystagmus has also
been noted in children following the ingestion of  marijuana  (Weinberg et al,
1983).   3.  A 2.5-year-old girl ingested some cannabis resin. Drowsiness
occurred within one hour and she remained stuporous for 12 hours.  The
respiratory rate decreased gradually to 15/minute and hypothermia (34.5
degrees C) was noted.  At 18 hours she was alert and oriented (Pettinger et al,
1988).
  4.  A 4-year-old girl ingested 1.5 grams of cannabis resin. She was found in
stupor, with alternating excitation and laughter.  She was hypothermic (32.4
degrees C), with a respiratory rate of 12/minute.  She recovered during the
following day (Bro et al, 1975).
  5.  A 17-month old child ingested hashish cookies and developed drowsiness
and upset stomach, progressing to coma within 5 hours.  He was hypotonic
and responded only to deep pain, with no focal neurologic signs.
   a.  HEENT findings included conjunctivitis, eyelid lag, and mydriasis.  He
recovered over 8 hours (Macnab et al, 1989).
   6.  A 2.5-year-old child ingested several  marijuana  butts and was found
comatose, hypotonic, and had dilated pupils. He aroused over 7 hours
(Macnab et al, 1989).

5.0 TREATMENT (TRMT)
 5.1 LIFE SUPPORT (LIFE)
Support respiratory and cardiovascular function.
 5.3 ORAL/PARENTERAL EXPOSURE (ORAL-EXP)
  5.3.1 PREVENTION OF ABSORPTION
    A.  EMESIS
     1.  INDICATIONS/CAUTIONS
      a.  Measures to decrease absorption may be useful.  The decision to
induce
or not to induce emesis in ingestion is often controversial, is not automatic,
and must be carefully considered.
      b.  Emesis may be indicated in substantial recent ingestions.
Contraindications to emesis induction include: signs of oral, pharyngeal, or
esophageal irritation; a depressed gag reflex; or central nervous system
excitation or depression.  If these are present or likely, EMESIS SHOULD NOT
BE  INDUCED.
      c.  Emesis is most effective if initiated within 30 minutes of
ingestion.
2.  DOSE OF IPECAC SYRUP
      a.  ADULT OR CHILD OVER 90 TO 100 POUNDS (40 to 45 kilograms): 30
milliliters
      b.  CHILD 1 TO 12 YEARS: 15 milliliters
      c.  CHILD 6 TO 12 MONTHS (consider administration in a health care
facility): 5 to 10 milliliters.
      d.  FLUIDS: After the dose is given, encourage clear fluids, 6 to 8
ounces in
adults and 4 to 6 ounces in a child.
      e.  REPEAT DOSES: The dose may be repeated once if emesis does not
occur within 30 minutes.
     3.  EMESIS FAILURE
      a.  If emesis is unsuccessful following 2 doses of ipecac, the
decision to
lavage or otherwise attempt to decontaminate the gut should be made on an
individual basis.  Two doses of ipecac pose little inherent toxicity.
     4.  Refer to the IPECAC/TREATMENT management in POISINDEX or
MEDITEXT portion of TOMES or TOMES PLUS for further information on
administration and adverse reactions.
    B.  ACTIVATED CHARCOAL/CATHARTIC
     1.  CHARCOAL ADMINISTRATION
      a.  Administer charcoal as slurry; charcoal slurry may be aqueous, or
mixture of charcoal with saline cathartic or sorbitol.
     2.  CHARCOAL DOSE
      a.  The FDA suggests a minimum of 240 milliliters of diluent per 30
grams
charcoal.  Optimum dose of charcoal is not established; usual dose is 30 to 100
grams in adults and 15 to 30 grams in children; some suggest using 1 to 2
grams per kilogram as a rough guideline, particularly in infants (FDA, 1985).
     3.  CHARCOAL ADMINISTRATION/ADVERSE EFFECTS
      a.  Refer to the ACTIVATED CHARCOAL/TREATMENT management for
further information on administration and adverse reactions.
     4.  CATHARTIC CONTRAINDICATIONS
      a.  Cathartics should not be used in patients who have an ileus.  Saline
cathartics should not be used in patients with impaired renal function
(Gilman et al, 1990).
     5.  CATHARTIC ADMINISTRATION/CAUTIONS
      a.  Administer in a health care facility, especially in children.
      b.  Monitoring of fluids and electrolytes may be necessary in children.
      c.  The safety of more than one dose of a cathartic has not been
established.
Hypermagnesemia has been reported after repeated administration of
magnesium containing cathartics in overdose patients with normal renal
function  (Smilkstein et al, 1988).
      d.  Repeated cathartic dosing should be done with extreme caution, if
at all.
      e.  Administration of cathartics should be stopped when a charcoal stool
appears.
     6.  CATHARTIC ADMINISTRATION
      a.  Administer ONE DOSE of a saline cathartic or sorbitol, mixed with
charcoal or administered separately.
      b.  SALINE CATHARTIC/ADULT DOSE: 20 to 30 grams per dose of
magnesium sulfate or sodium sulfate, OR magnesium citrate 4 milliliters per
kilogram per dose up to 300 milliliters per dose, administered orally
(Minocha et al, 1985).
      c.  SALINE CATHARTIC/PEDIATRIC DOSE: 250 milligrams per kilogram
per dose  of magnesium or sodium sulfate OR magnesium citrate 4 milliliters
per kilogram per dose up to 300 milliliters per dose, administered orally
(Minocha et al, 1985).
      d.  SALINE CATHARTIC ADMINISTRATION/ADVERSE EFFECTS: Refer
to the LAXATIVE-SALINE or MAGNESIUM management for further
information on administration and adverse effects.
      e.  SORBITOL/ADULT DOSE: 1 to 2 grams per kilogram per dose to a
maximum of 150 grams per dose, administered orally (Minocha et al, 1985).
      f.  SORBITOL/PEDIATRIC DOSE: 1 to 1.5 grams per kilogram per dose as a
35  percent solution to a maximum of 50 grams per dose, administered orally
to children over 1 year of age (Minocha et al, 1985).
      g.  SORBITOL ADMINISTRATION/ADVERSE EFFECTS: Refer to the
SORBITOL management for further information on administration and
adverse effects.
  5.3.2 TREATMENT
    A.  SUPPORTIVE CARE
     1.  Treatment of the rare acute overdose should be supportive as in a
sedative-hypnotic type overdose with support of respiration, blood pressure
and other functions as necessary.
    B.  PSYCHIATRIC CARE
     1.  Treatment of the depressive, hallucinatory or psychotic reactions
is as
listed below.
     2.  The patient should be taken to a quiet area and reassured in a
quiet but
positive way that the drug will have no permanent effects and will wear off
after several hours.
     3.  Benzodiazepines are the preferred drugs for treatment of extreme
agitation, panic or disorientation.  5 to 10 milligrams diazepam orally is
usually sufficient.
     4.  The patient should always be handled in a non-threatening manner.
Hospitalization or psychiatric referral are seldom necessary.
    C.  HYPOTENSION
     1.  Patients suffering from postural hypotension should be placed in the
Trendelenberg position until the blood pressure stabilizes.  Administration of
intravenous fluids is rarely necessary in this situation.

6.0 RANGE OF TOXICITY (TOX)
 6.1 THERAPEUTIC DOSE (THER)
  6.1.1 ADULT
    A.  ANTIEMETIC IN CHEMOTHERAPY
     1.  Dronabinol: 5 milligrams/square meter 1 to 3 hours prior to
chemotherapy, to a maximum of 4 to 6 doses/day.  The dose may be increased
by 2.5 milligrams/square meter/dose to a maximum of 15 milligrams/square
meter/dose (Prod Info, 1989).
     2.  Nabilone: 1 to 2 milligrams 1 to 3 hours prior to chemotherapy, to a
maximum of 6 milligrams/day (Prod Info, 1989a).
 6.2 MINIMUM LETHAL EXPOSURE (MIN)
  A.  The lethal dose of cannabis in humans is uncertain.  One ESTIMATE by
Nahas (1971) is 30 milligrams/kilogram of absorbed cannabis, but the lethal
dose in humans is really unknown (Hollister, 1988).
  B.  The acute lethal intravenous dose of THC is estimated to be 1000 to 2000
milligrams (Prod Info, 1985).
 6.3 MAXIMUM TOLERATED EXPOSURE (MAX)
  A.  Fifteen milligrams/square meter orally of THC produced significant CNS
symptoms in patients receiving THC as an antiemetic.
  B.  5 milligrams/square meter was tolerated by these patients with a low
degree of CNS effects (Lucas & Laszlo, 1980).
  C.  Doses of over 1 gram/kilogram orally have been survived by monkeys.
6.4 TOXIC SERUM/PLASMA/BLOOD CONCENTRATIONS (CONC)
  A.  PASSIVE INHALATION
   1.  Some have argued that significant levels of THC could be passively
inhaled.  A recent controlled exposure study using the EMIT analysis method
failed to demonstrate any urine levels above 50 nanograms/milliliter and
only 2 of 80 had levels above 20 nanograms/milliliter (Perez-Reyes et al,
1983).
    a.  The onset of effects occurs within 6 to 12 minutes and continues
for 172
to 240 minutes (Nahas 1979, Ohlsson et al, 1980, Lemberger et al, 1972).
  B.  There is a non-linear relationship between plasma THC levels and degree
of intoxication (Agurell et al, 1986).
  C.  Roughly, absorption of less than 50 micrograms/kilogram of THC by
smoking  will result in a "low dose" effect, and absorption of greater than 250
micrograms/kilogram will produce "high dose" effects.  Between these values
the  dose-effect is variable (Ishbell et al, 1967).
  D.  Conjunctival reddenning was associated with plasma THC levels greater
than 5 nanograms/milliliter (Hollister et al, 1981).
  E.  Heart rate is maximal at plasma levels of about 45 nanograms/milliliter
(Hollister et al, 1981).

7.0 AVAILABLE FORMS/SOURCES (FORM)
 A.  DEFINITIONS
  1.  The term sinsemilla  marijuana  usually refers to the seedless flowering
tops from the female plant Cannabis sativa (Selden et al, 1990).
  2.  But  marijuana  is also frequently used to refer to other Cannabis
products
such as Hashish, Bhang, and Hashish oil, which are more concentrated forms
of the active alkaloids of this plant.  Hash oil contains 30 to 50% THC (Nahas,
1984).
   3.  Cannabis indica and C.  ruderalis are usually considered synonymous
with C.  sativa.
 B.  CONCENTRATION OF ACTIVE INGREDIENTS
  1.  US Products: The concentration of US-grown  marijuana  is 1 to 8%
(Kunkel, 1985).
  2.  US Sinsemilla (seedless): 5% THC (Kunkel, 1985)
  3.  Colombian  Marijuana:  3.7% THC (Kunkel, 1985)
  4.  Nigerian or Ghanain  Marijuana:  2 to 4% THC (Pitts et al, 1990)
  5.  Thailand: 6.7 to 8% THC (Pitts et al, 1990)
  6.  South Africa: 2.2 to 4.6% THC (Pitts et al, 1990)
 C.  CONSUMPTION FORMS
  1.  The usual form in which this drug is consumed is as cigarettes
referred to
as reefers, joints, or numbers.  Marijuana  contains 1 to 3% THC (Nahas,
1984).     a.  A  marijuana  cigarette contains 2% or 20 milligrams of active
ingredient.  Concentration of THC varies greatly, depending on the plant
material (Digregorio & Sterling, 1987).
  2.  Hashish, which is usually 5 to 10 times more potent than the flowering
tops, is a light brown to dark black resinous material which is usually smoked
in a pipe. Hashish contains 3 to 6% THC (Nahas, 1984).
   a.  It is obtained by reported extraction of  marijuana  with a non-polar
solvent (Selden et al, 1990).
  3.  Although the most common method of abuse is via inhalation, both the
flowering tops and the various forms of Hashish have been included in a
number of oral forms from brownies to candy.
  4.  Although much less common, IV use of the oil has also been noted with
a high associated mortality.
  5.   Marijuana  purported to be "super grass" or products sold as the active
ingredient of  marijuana  THC frequently turn out to contain the drug
phencyclidine, a very potent and dangerous drug.
 D.  SYNTHETICS
  1.  Synthetic delta-9 THC (dronabinol) is available from Roxane under the
trade name Marinol(R) for use as an antiemetic (Anderson & McGuire, 1981;
Poster et al, 1981) during cancer chemotherapy (Lemberger, 1980).
  2.  It comes in round, amber, soft gelatin capsules filled with sesame
oil in
which either 2.5, 5, or 10 mg of THC is dissolved.
  3.  The synthetic cannabinoid, nabilone, is available from Lilly under the
trade name Cesamet(R) in 1 mg capsules (Digregorio & Sterling, 1987).
 E.  BIOSYNTHESIS: There is still work being done on the biosynthesis of the
cannabinoids found in C.  sativa.  The maximum levels of cannabinoid in the
primary leaves of seedings occurred at 120 to 122 hours.
  1.  The primary cannabinoid was cannabichromenes whereas the primary
one in older plants was delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC).  THC became
dominant in the seedling at 144 to 146 hours (Vogelmann et al, 1988).
 F.  USES
   1.   Marijuana  cigarettes are being supplied by the National Institute on
Drug Abuse.  They are blended to produce a final THC content between 1 and
1.5%  and weigh about 900 mg each.
  2.  One case study has implied that smoking  marijuana  may have a
protective  effect against ulcerative colitis (Baron et al, 1990).
 G.  SOURCES
  1.  The plant may be grown in most tropical and temperate regions of the
world.  It is resistant to fire and chemicals.
  2.  Children may be exposed via milk from dairy animals who heavily feed
on cannabis (Ahmad & Ahmad, 1990).

8.0 KINETICS (KINET)
 8.1 ABSORPTION (ABSR)
  A.  INHALATION/SMOKING
   1.  ABSORPTION: After smoking, 18 to 50% of the available THC is absorbed
(Digregorio & Sterling, 1987).  Heavy or habitual users had a systemic
availability of 23% compared with 10% in light users (Lindgren et al, 1981).
   2.  ONSET/DURATION
    a.  ONSET of effects occurs within 6 to 12 minutes and continues for
172 to
240 minutes (Nahas, 1979; Ohlsson et al, 1980; Lemberger et al, 1972).
    b.  DURATION: 2 to 3 hours (Lemberger et al, 1972)
   3.  PEAK PLASMA LEVELS: 5 to 12 minutes (Digregorio & Sterling, 1987),
but peak clinical effects may be 20 to 30 minutes later, after distribution
into
brain and other tissues (Selden et al, 1990).
   4.  PEAK PLASMA CONCENTRATION: 20 to 50 nanograms per milliliter
(Digregorio  & Sterling, 1987)
  B.  INGESTION
   1.  ABSORPTION: Following ingestion, only 5 to 20% of THC is bioavailable
(Agurell et al, 1986).  Absorption is increased by fatty foods or a lipid
vehicle
(Hollister, 1976).
   2.  ONSET: The onset of effects begins within 30 to 60 minutes and persists
for 4 to 6 hours (Digregorio & Sterling, 1987; Hollister et al, 1984;
Ohlsson et al,
1980; Perez-Reyes et al, 1973).
   3.  PEAK PLASMA LEVELS: 2 to 3 hours after THC (Johnson, 1990)
 8.2 DISTRIBUTION (DIST)
  8.2.1 DISTRIBUTION SITES
    A.  PROTEIN BINDING: THC is 97 to 99% protein bound in man (Hunt and
Jones,  1980).
    B.  THC is lipid soluble and is assumed to partition into the body fat,
heart,
salivary glands, liver, brain, and kidney of humans (King & Forney, 1967).
Lung has the highest concentration while brain has the lowest (Agurell et al,
1970; Klausner & Dingell, 1971).
  8.2.2 DISTRIBUTION KINETICS
    A.  VOLUME OF DISTRIBUTION
      1.  The volume of distribution upon initial exposure to THC is 2.55
liters
per 70 kg but increases substantially with chronic use.
     2.  The steady state volume of distribution of THC is over 100 times
larger
than its initial volume of distribution (Hunt and Jones, 1980).
     3.  The volume of distribution was estimated to be about 10 liters/kg
(Agurell et al, 1986).  Because of the high lipid solubility, delta-9-THC
has an
apparent volume of distribution of 500 liters (Busto et al, 1989).
 8.3 METABOLISM (METAB)
  8.3.1 METABOLISM SITES AND KINETICS
    A.  Following oral administration, THC undergoes substantial first-pass
metabolism, with 10 to 20% absorbed (Digregorio & Sterling, 1987).  Liver
metabolism is by microsomal hydroxylation and non-microsomal oxidation
(Wall & Perez-Reyes, 1981).
  8.3.2 METABOLITES
    A.  THC is metabolized primarily to 11-hydroxy-delta-9-THC. This
metabolite  is present in higher concentrations following ingestion.  Chronic
use increases  the ability to form this metabolite.  THC metabolism appears to
be decreased in  patients with severe hepatic dysfunction.
    B.  11-hydroxy THC is present in amounts of about 10% that of the parent
drug THC after smoking.  After oral administration this metabolite is present
in equal amounts as THC (Agurell et al, 1986).  This is the most abundant
metabolite.
    C.  11-hydroxy-delta-9-THC is pharmacologically active, but is further
metabolized to 11-nor-delta-9-THC carboxylic acid, which is not active (Jaffe,
1985).
    D.  Other metabolites include (Agurell et al, 1986):
        1.  6B-hydroxy THC
        2.  6 alpha-hydroxy THC
        3.  2"-hydroxy THC
        4.  THC-6-one
        5.  6 a,7-dihydroxy THC
        6.  6 b,7-dihydroxy THC
        7.  2",7-dihydroxy THC
 8.4 EXCRETION (EXCR)
  8.4.1 KIDNEY
    A.  A negligible amount of unchanged THC and 11-hydroxy-THC are
excreted in  the urine.
    B.  Within the first 72 hours following ingestion of THC approximately 10
to 15% of a dose is excreted in the urine as acidic metabolites and conjugates
(Busto et al, 1989).
    C.  Johansson et al (1990) found that 8 to 14% of an oral dose of
radiolabeled
marijuana  was found in the urine of both naive and chronic users. About 5%
of the dose was found in the urine after inhalation by naive users, about 2%
in chronic users.
  8.4.2 FECES
    A.  Within the first 72 hours following ingestion of THC, approximately
35%  of the dose is excreted in the feces as unconjugated metabolite (Agurell
et al,  1986).
  8.4.3 BILE
    A.  Biliary excretion via the feces is a major route of metabolism.
 8.5 ELIMINATION HALF-LIFE (ELIM)
  8.5.1 PARENT COMPOUND
    A.  The high lipid solubility results in an initial short plasma
half-life,  but
this adipose storage produces a biologic half-life of 25 to 30 hours
(Digregorio
& Sterling, 1987).
    B.  CHRONIC USERS: The plasma half-life in chronic users was 4 days in a
volunteer study (Johansson et al, 1988; Johansson et al, 1989).  THC was
detectable in plasma for up to 15 days.
     1.  Previous studies demonstrating shorter half-lives (25 to 36 hours)
measured levels for up to 72 hours and may not have accurately reflected the
terminal elimination phase (Wall et al, 1983).
    C.  ELIMINATION: About 50% of an initial dose is thought to be eliminated
in the first 72 hours (Ahmad & Ahmad, 1990) and 80 to 90 percent in 5 days
(Hawks,  1982; Hunt & Jones, 1980).
     1.  The average urinary excretion half-life in one study using
radiolabeled
marijuana  was 18.2 hours (Johansson et al, 1990).
    D.  Nabilone: 2 hours; 35 hours for total metabolites (Prod Info, 1989a)
  8.5.2 METABOLITE
    A.  A study of 13 chronic  marijuana  users demonstrated positive EMIT
urine assays for 3 to 25 days after cessation of smoking.  The excretion
half-life
for the delta-THC-7-oic acid metabolite ranged from 0.8 to 9.8 days (Johansson
& Halldin, 1989).

9.0 PHARMACOLOGY/TOXICOLOGY (PHAR)
 9.1 PHARMACOLOGIC MECHANISM (PHAR-MECH)
  A.   Marijuana  contains other cannabinoids, such as cannabinol (CBN) and
cannabidiol (CBD).  These compounds do not have psychotommetic effects,
but may  explain some of the therapeutic effects of this plant.  CBD has
anticonvulsant-activity (Agurell et al, 1986; Evans, 1991).
  B.  Cannabis sativa is known to contain the dihydrostilbene canniprene
which is an anti inflammatory with activity as lipoxygenase and
cyclooxygenase inhibitors (El Sohly et al, 1990).
  C.  Smoking  marijuana  (0.9 to 1.5% THC) reduced intraocular pressure after
30 to 40 minutes up to 45% (Hepler & Frank, 1971).
  D.   Marijuana  contains at least 61 cannabinoid compounds (d-9-THC being
the  primary one) and over 300 other substances (Selden et al, 1990).
  E.  d-9-THC is known to act at a number of sites. Dopaminergic, cholinergic,
noradrenergic, serotonergic, and GABA sites are affected, as are a number of
neuropeptides (Domino, 1981; Hollister, 1976; Jones, 1987; Leader et al, 1981;
Nahas, 1986).
 9.2 TOXICOLOGIC MECHANISM (TOX-MECH)
  A.  The resin from the cannabis plant contains a number of
pharmacologically active alkaloids but delta 9-tetrahydrocannabinol (9-THC)
is thought to be the most active isomer.

10.0 ANIMAL POISONING (ANIMAL)
 10.1 CLINICAL EFFECTS (AN-CLEF)
  10.1.2 CAT
    A.  Some animals have been exposed via pet owners who blow smoke into
the dog or cat's nostrils.  The animals are reported to get "glassy eyed,"
ataxic,
or uncoordinated (Swartz, 1985; Swartz, 1989).
  10.1.4 DOG
    A.  Canine Atopy: Evans (1989) reported a case of allergic inhalant
dermatitis in a black labrador retriever to  marijuana.   Symptoms included
pedal and facial pruritus, and bilateral ocular discharge.
    B.  Other effects include tachycardia, hypotension, ataxia, stupor,
behavioral
change, muscle weakness, hypothermia, vomiting, and conjunctival
infection (Dumonceaux & Beasley, 1990).
  10.1.13 OTHER SMALL ANIMALS
    A.  Ferret: Ataxia proceeding to coma was seen after a ferret ingested
marijuana.   The animal was sacrificed before the truth was known (Smith,
1988).
 10.2 TREATMENT (AN-TRMT)
  10.2.3 TREATMENT
    A.  Canine Atopy: Although corticosteroids and antihistamines
(systemically  and topically) were useful in this case, long term relief
was only
obtained by hyposensitization therapy (Evans, 1989).
    B.  For ingestions, emesis (if less than 1 hour), activated charcoal, and
supportive care (Dumonceaux & Beasley, 1990)

------- End of Forwarded Message

Sean Wrote:

> I'm getting at is that a person strives to be his 'True' self. If one seeks
> confidence/esteem for the gratification of his ego (ideal), then that's
> what he'll get in return. A 'true' self does not worry about ego
> projection, nor the consequences of his actions. He trusts in himself.
> Values himself. He is spontaneous, joyful, alert and sensitive, and
> extremely aware. He lives for the now, in the moment. All the most powerful
> and most feared qualities lie under all of the fear-based, ego projecting,
> self-seeking programming.....

I think I have now reached that point in my life...I know pretty much who 
I am and the kind of person I am, and I am still introverted on 
occasion.  However, I still look at my best friend, who has an 
extroverted nature about her, and has newly joined the rave scene.  I 
look at her with good natured envy as her wonderful demeanor draws people 
to her.  I wish I could be that dynamic!  But I think again and realize 
that I wouldn't be Amy if I did, and I still have plenty of friends.  And 
I smile. :)

love,
Amy

At 1:53 PM 12/13/95, ecto wrote:
>At 1:00 AM 12/13/95, Kevin Keiper wrote:
>>hmmm... i have been reading some posts on this list about shyness for a
>>while and here is my .o2...  i am really shy. i think this is a self
>>esteem/confidence issue with me.  i know parties especially under the
>>right circumstancEs are great for shyness, but generally i hardly ever
>>talk to anyone especially strangers.  i guess i figure that if we really
>>do not have anything mutually important to communicate, then, don't...
>>this is ok. i really like to dance and bliss out and listen to music and
>>feel the music and atmosphere instead. sometimes when i am on e i really
>>come out of my shell and it probably seems that i am a changed person.
>>something about the drug helps me tap strenghts i really have and to
>>temporarily put the dysfunctional tape loops on pause for a while. but i
>>really have the ability to do this without the drug... and this gets me
>>thinking that perhaps i think i use my shyness as an excuse to not take
>>chances and do anything which will pull me out of my ordinary way of
>>interacting with the world. perhaps this occurs with others?  i realize
>>that by being shy, there is a sort of protection(???) from self discovery
>>- we learn alot about ourselves from others - and when we are shy, we can
>>hide from this self discovery and the responsibilities it presents... so
>>shyness then becomes our defense from parts of ourselves we find it hard
>>to see or accept. make sense? maybe...
>>
>>kevin
>>:)
>        TOTAL sense. I have realized (or, that is, am still realizing) a
>lot of things about self-awareness and perception/perspectives and
>self-reflection. One of the difficulties of being really introverted and/or
>shy (because sometimes ppl CHOOSE not to talk to other people though
>they're not shy) is that you become really entangled in your own thoughts.
>THis can be good, you can learn a lot about yourself and about other
>people. In fact you can dig so deep subjectively that you end up realizing
>a lot of things about all of us which is universally applicable. THe thing
>that i've found though, is that recently i've become really introverted and
>it's not a good thing. When you get into this whole "thinking about the way
>that you're thinking thing" (say that 3 x fast!) you end up kind of phasing
>out people around you. You're lost in your own little world and that's not
>good.  Because to understand yourself 'objectively' you need more than one
>view. Your normal state of consciousness is one view of yourself (if you
>choose to look inward, and there are those who don't i think), the view you
>have of yourself in altered states are other views (dreams or ...whatever
>:)) but also, when you REALLY communicate with someone, when you really
>EMPATHIZE you begin to understand who they are and how they see the world,
>you can see the world through their eyes to an extent, and when you're in
>that situation you can use THAT perspective to look at yourself and all of
>your flaws and all of your beauties :) So, by losing yourself in another
>person you are sort of able to find yourself...woo woo how zen! :)
>        :) brad :)
>

And now it's my turn...with heartfelt irony, I'd like to say: "ditto what
Brad said!"

hugs,
David

Amy, as for your reply, I think you're wonderful.

I'd like to tell you where I am coming from when I speak of 'true' self.
The search for, or rather the attainment of 'true' self is a lifelong
process. Being of Asian descent (Japanese), and having studied and
practiced Eastern philosphy for all of my life, I have come to appreciate
some of the teachings that have been handed down to me.

Of the 7.5 billion people that inhabit the earth, there are supposedly but
6 people who have achieved, and live within the 'enlightenment' of true
self. They live in a state of 'higher' consciousness... pure awareness. In
the teachings of Buddha, all of man's turmoil is a product of his
attachments, whether its his earthy possessions, his image, his spouse, his
children, etc.

'Extraversion' is a characteristic, or personality tendency. I can surely
appreciate that your friend's extraversion draws people to her. We do live
in a society that rewards extraversion. True self, however, does not define
a person by introversion or extraversion. It only lovingly ACCEPTS what IS.
Not by ideals, or even by preferences, but accepts reality. These 6 people
that I speak of live in a realm of unconditional acceptance of REALITY. As
humorous as this may sound.... Popeye the sailor was a great role model of
this unconditional acceptance of himself.... "I am what I am."

With that, I'd like to share a little anectdote that relates to the martial
arts.

When you first start practicing an art, your belt is white. White signifies
innocence. Innocence, just as a newborn. A child... happy, joyful... pure
awareness, no prejedice or preferences... lovingly accepts the world around
it.

And then you strive, work, discipline yourself... success, achievement. The
belt is black... status is attained.... and innocence is lost.

As time passes the blackness begins to fade. The fight continues on... the
rest of your life is a process to make that black belt fade into white....
fighting to regain your innocence.


Brad> excellent insights...!

My roommate told me probably the best story about a storm that I've ever
heard last night.  Apparently, some of her friends in Denmark were caught in
a big storm and their server went down.  Now, it's one thing if the power
went down and they couldn't use it, but I think it's a sign from God when it
got struck by lightning.

TTFN,
Jake

The barometric pressure is wreaking havoc on my ears right now :(

Subject: Re: Shyness is nice...

>Wow! All these shy people! Not just shy..... painfully shy and self-conscious..
>Both men and women, all with wonderful, thoughtful insights about their
>condition.
>
>I'm not alone. I'm not alone. I'm not alone.

You're not alone. You're not alone. You're not alone. :)

>With shyness also comes the appearance of being humble, which is an
>admirable quality... The desire to learn, and to reach out. When a person
>has based his/her life on self-discovery the prospect of losing that drive
>can be EXTREMELY scary.

I find shyness very endearing, and while I'd like to be a little more
self-confident and that sort of thing, I think I can do that without losing
my shyness-- because it _is_ part of my personality and if I lost it, I'd
be a very different person and I don't think I'd like that at all.

Don't lose it.

-mike.

	hey mike! we meet again.
	at first, when i came into the scene, i was really shy and didnt 
know what to do with myself, being caushious and all that. then slowly i 
began to realize how open ya can be among all these people who seem to be 
looking for something similar, if not the same, we just all call it 
different names.  more often than not, i get a totally friendly response 
when i go up to meet a total stranger :)

spirituality, out there on this list. we met via the sfr laminate and fnf

David,
First off, I'm really sorry about your ant problem and no lights.  I hope
everything turned out alright.  Although I didn't have a problem with power,
my house was also bombarded with ants, esp. in the trash compactor that
hasn't been emptied in months.  It looked like the ants had made a nest in
there and decided today would be a good day to come out...AAARRRHHH!!! 

Next, I totally agree with your whole thing about shyness and outgoingness
being related to fear and love.  The fear of rejection faces me and I'm sure
a lot of people every day.  As much as I like to be different from everyone
else there is still a little part of me that wants to conform, to fit in.  So
sometimes that fear of not fitting in causes me to seperate myself from all
who might reject me.  

In a message dated 95-12-12 19:45:03 EST, you write:

>I'm curious about your name...I like the spelling and the way I imagine it's
pronounced. > Do youknow what it means?  Where does it come from?  It sounds
like the name of
>an exotic shiek or a punjabi warrior or something, or the name of a distant
>star.  Hmmm...

As for my name, my real name is Megan.  Not quite exotic enough for my
liking, though.  On AOL, in case you don't know, you have to have a screen
name NO ONE else has.  My favorite name for a while has been Zephyr, it means
something about wind...?...so on AOL instead of using boring old MEGAN I
wanted to use the name ZEPHYR but evidently quite a few other people had used
it also, so instead of having Zephyr with some random number in back of it I
decided to try alternate spellings of the same name.  Even that took a while
to find a spelling no one had used.  I finally ended up with CZEFIR which I
have grown to like even more than ZEPHYR.  I consider it to be pronounced
exactly the same as Zephyr :  ze-f-ir,  but if you have some other cool way
of pronouncing it I would like to know.  So that's the scoop on my name.

    Love,
       Czefir aka Megan

>        hey mike! we meet again.
>        at first, when i came into the scene, i was really shy and didnt
...
>laminate. (boy, the latter sure does teh trick as well)
>        evolve :) tom

I've seen the FnF laminates... those are basically "tickets" right? Or do
you get them someplace else for other reasons? Also, I got a couple
addresses of the "sfr laminate guys" from the list, but one of the
addresses had some kind of "Host Unknown" mail delivery problem and the
other one just hasn't responded yet... where did you get yours?

Yeah I really like the open atmosphere of this scene... Although I have
noticed a lot of animosity/arrogance toward other scenes: i.e. goths and
punks and that sort of thing. Well, as a former gothboy myself lemme be the
first to say that the vibe among my goth friends and I was just as good as
any rave's. Yes, they (we?) do tend to express themselves in dark and scary
kind of ways, but my friends and I were really into it for fun and got a
lot of really positive things out of it...

I guess the main reason I distanced myself frum that group wasn't because I
dislike them or disapprove of them (Anyone going to Death Guild in the city
this saturday make sure to say hi to me :) but because there really is an
added element of openness at raves that really appeals to me. It's tough
meeting new people when you're a shy death rocker.

Oh yeah, plus I like the music ;)

I'll probably see you at the gathering, Tom.

-mikey.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Dec 14 16:32:48 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA00258; Thu, 14 Dec 1995 16:32:48 -0800
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id QAA00253; Thu, 14 Dec 1995 16:32:43 -0800
Received: from [128.32.205.139] (unit2-1mac19.ResHall.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.205.139]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id QAA10656; Thu, 14 Dec 1995 16:32:38 -0800
Message-Id: <v02120d04acf6715d7ad8@[128.32.205.139]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora 2.1.2
Date: Thu, 14 Dec 1995 16:32:37 -0800
To: Czefir@aol.com
From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Michal Migurski)
Subject: Re: My name
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>exactly the same as Zephyr :  ze-f-ir,  but if you have some other cool way
>of pronouncing it I would like to know.  So that's the scoop on my name.
>
>    Love,
>       Czefir aka Megan

well, for a while I thought it was polish... the c-z combination is very
common in Polish (but not in any other language, I think). It's pronounced
sort of like an english "ch" but it sounds a bit harder: try saying "ch"
except curl your toungue backwards so it touches the roof of your mouth
right behind your teeth. Also, roll the "r." So, czefir would be pronounced
something like "chefir."

-mikey.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Dec 14 17:19:28 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu (David Ginsberg)
Subject: Re: My name
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Czefir (Megan),
>
>As for my name, my real name is Megan.  Not quite exotic enough for my
>liking, though.  On AOL, in case you don't know, you have to have a screen
>name NO ONE else has.  My favorite name for a while has been Zephyr, it means
>something about wind...?...so on AOL instead of using boring old MEGAN I
>wanted to use the name ZEPHYR but evidently quite a few other people had used
>it also, so instead of having Zephyr with some random number in back of it I
>decided to try alternate spellings of the same name.  Even that took a while
>to find a spelling no one had used.  I finally ended up with CZEFIR which I
>have grown to like even more than ZEPHYR.  I consider it to be pronounced
>exactly the same as Zephyr :  ze-f-ir,  but if you have some other cool way
>of pronouncing it I would like to know.  So that's the scoop on my name.
>
>    Love,
>       Czefir aka Megan

I imagined it being pronounced much like zephyr, but with a 's' sound in
front of the 'z' sound and the accent on the 'ir' - pronounced 'eer.'  So
it would be proncounced 'sz-feer.'  I don't know how to make this actually
phonetic...hopefully it comes across.  If not, then I'll be happy to
pronounce my imagined pronunciation for you at the next F&F or FMR or
whatever party I end up at next (maybe this week-end if I'm real good!!!).


Love,

David


****************************************************************************

David Ginsberg
Student of Philosophy and Cognitive Science
The Evergreen State College & University of California, Berkeley
ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu
http://www.geopages.com/athens/2001

Well, I didn't go out to get flyers again this week (got a few over the
weekend though), but it seems like everyone's planning to go to the
Gathering anyway.  If you want to save $$ for holiday gifts, try out
Club Freaky or the Mission Vortex on Saturday.  On Friday, A Single Red
Light got good reviews last time, and the Top seems to have returned
as a scene spot, for both Friday and Saturday.

Next week the calendar will be out early again, so please send updates
by Tuesday.


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
                                       
    http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/sfrcal.html

Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Friday, December 15th - _A Single Red Light _

   Martin, Ethan, Jeffery. 415.522.3994 415.905.9629

   Sabbah. 510.428.1961 415.435.7981

   [12/27 - Joshua & Ryan Tapia]

   415.241.8815. Afterparty at 201 Howard.

   and Jazz Picks. Live music with Josh Jones and Guests the Up&Down Club
   1151 Folsom

   live acid jazz. 10pm-2am @ Eleven, 374 11th St.

   the EndUp, 6th & Harrison, SF. free before midnight w/invite.
   415.703.7105

   Black Diamond - Felix the Dogge, Thomas + guests - in the lounge.
   10-4. 415.512.5713
   
   cosmic lounge - space jazz, galactic grooves, jungle. DJs Caspar,
   Paul, Seth + special guests. cafe mars, 798 Brannan @ 7th. 10pm-2am.
   No cover.

   guests. 21+, free before 11, $2 after. The Top, 424 Haight.
   415.267.7614

   Fulton Bar, 1243 Fulton Mall, Fresno. 209.488.5332

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@netcom.com
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Saturday morning - "The Uncle Noah TV Show" 6-9am, KDVS 90.3,
       Davis.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

[This purports to be a letter from Don Wildmon, head of the American
 Family Association.  It's not yet validated, but if it is a joke,
 the jokers sure got the patter right.]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Dear Friends:

Once again, it is time for us to stand up and tell the liberal
entertainment industry that America will not tolerate the continual
erosion of the minds of our young people with obscene pornography
disguised as "family entertainment".

The Walt Disney Company, one of America's leading distributors of lucrative,
mind-rotting garbage aimed at children--THE LION KING, ALADDIN--is at it
again.  TOY STORY, the company's big Christmas release, is positively the
most disgusting example of Hollywood's use of pornography to line its
coffers since ABC-TV's NYPD BLUE.

Some of the following descriptions may be offensive, so please keep this
out of the hands of your children:

In TOY STORY, rated G by the ultraliberal MPAA, the main characters,
"Woody"--note sexual reference--and "Buzz"--note drug reference--are
owned by a child in a single-parent household in which the father is
noticeably absent.  "Woody" and "Buzz" have equally disturbing toy
friends, including a sex-obsessed talking potato, a sex-obsessed Bo Peep
doll who cannot keep her hands (or lips) off "Woody," and an Etch-a-Sketch
whose "knobs" must be "adjusted" to produce results.

(For a complete report on TOY STORY, see the December issue of the AFA
Journal, available from the American Family Association, P.O. Drawer
2440, Tupelo, MS  38803.)

This is obviously material not acceptable for children, yet Disney has aimed
this wallow in the gutter squarely at the hearts and minds of our youth.  We
MUST tell them that we will NOT allow them to continue this mind pollution.
I URGE you to make copies of this letter and DISTRIBUTE it to your friends
and neighbors and boycott TOY STORY and all of its tie-in products
IMMEDIATELY.

And PLEASE write or call the creators and distributors of this filth and
let them know that you are FED UP with their reckless and immoral
actions.  AFA efforts like this are keeping pornography off store shelves,
off television sets, and out of the theaters and video stores of America,
but we MUST NOT LET UP.  As long as Hollywood does not get the message
and WAKE UP, we must continue to tell them how America feels.

Write to:    Chrm. Michael Eisner
             The Walt Disney Co.
             500 S. Buena Vista Street
             Burbank, CA  91521

Or phone:    818-560-1000

Hollywood IS listening.  We ARE winning battle after battle.  And with
your help, we will win the war.  Boycott TOY STORY.  Tell your friends
and neighbors.  The children of America thank you, and I thank you.

God bless,

Don

Subject: mission vortex, PLUR, and new growth
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

fellow ravers, 

i write you today to tell you about the healing and celebratory event that
mission vortex will be putting on this saturday, starting at around 7:30. if
you've been assiduously reading all the sfraves messages over the past few
months and you have an especially keen memory, you might remember that
mission vortex threw a healing rave a month or two ago, and that i wrote you
all about the wonderful time i had there. now it's happening again. 

mission vortex is an experience designed to bring people together for a
common purpose: healing, regeneration, renewal, celebration - whatever you
choose to call it. to this end, we have brought many different kinds of
healers into our project - body workers, vibrational healers, local shamans,
musicians, visual artists, and other people who are working to bring fullness
into their lives, and share it with others. 

essentially, we can't know what the event is going to be like until it
actually starts to happen. all we can do, as the volunteers who are helping
make it work, is put our energy into the preparations before the event and
then bring all peace, love, untiy and respect we have within us to the actual
event.

we are hoping for an alcohol-free, smoke-free environment, but i'm not sure
whether or how we're going to enforce this. i should tell you now that i am
not the organizer or promoter of this event. this is a grass-roots
collective, and we operate in a democratic, non-hierarchical fashion. i'm
just the person in the group who is the most closely linked to sfraves, which
is why i have the responsibility of writing this letter to you. 

there will be a $15 cover, the proceeds of which will go towards a fund
established for the creation of a healing center in hawaii.  if you have
questions about this, you can call dino at 510.428.1961. 

if you're interested in helping future mission vortex events succeed, i would
suggest calling dino, leaving you name and number with him, or on his
machine, and telling him how you'd like to help. 

if you would like to come join us on saturday, the voicemail number to call
is: (415) 435 7981. the healing ritual will begin at 7:30, after which, the
dancing will begin, at around 10:00. 

music-lovers, this will not be a night of hard techno, jungle, or house. the
 dj in the main dance area is Cheb i Sabbah, who many of you may already
know. he spins ethnotrance & etc. we'll also have an unknown [not "Unknown"]
cdj spinning ambient in the chill-out room. his name is david and he's quite
good. 

i hope to see some of you there. i don't know what i'll be wearing and i
don't have a sfraves laminate (woe is me), so i don't know how i'd find you,
but my name is shalom and if we do happen to meet - lovely. 

come join us, whether you're shy, gregarious, or somewhere in between. 

shalom
or 
dissssssssssssolve, 
whichever i happen to be at the moment.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Eric Hill <ehill@best.com>
Subject: Re: Electro
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A couple of people have asked:

>>What classifies electro?  

It's radness. Rhythm and sound. It's where techno and hip-hop come from.
It's being rediscovered as a influential-but-previously-ignored style. Pure
dancing music. It's humorous sometimes. They play it at MaD Mondays
sometimes. Come Tuesday to the Bahia and hear for yourself.

eh

On Wed, 13 Dec 1995, Dimitri K Gortinsky wrote:
> at about 5 or 6 in the morning i saw the flash from ....BOOMMMMMMM and 
> there it was.... it must have been at least six miles away because the 
> sound came about six seconds after the flash (i think that is how you 
> measure the distance lightening is away from you?) that was the only 
> thunder i heard all night (there might have been more) but it was preety 
> spectacular!
> power was restored at about 6pm to our delight

I live in San Jose and I heard this boom...I awoke to my apartment 
shaking...at first I thought it to be an earthquake!  This was by far the 
loudest thunder I have ever heard!  I couldn't go back to sleep for a 
while after that cause my heart was a beatin.  All the car alarms started 
going off too.

Very trippy!

Hi everyone, I've been following this list from my work account for a few
weeks now and I think it's time for me to come out of the woodwork.  My
name is Rob and I've been out of the rave scene for a couple years but I
kinda want to see what its like now.  I used to be into raving in So Cal.
while I was in college but I didn't like the way that everyone was too into
Xing or whatever.  So I'm back home now and I miss going out and dancing
and having a little fun(a cool thing about being in school-9to5's suck).
So by luck I find you all.

Gathering is as good a place as any to get back into it.  But first can I
ask some questions?(Let me know if these ???'s are things that shouldn't be
asked)

I don't think this got out since my usual mail headers went down with my
old hard drive. But if it did I've augmented the thoughts anyway.

One possible thing to do pre-Gathering is to stop at the *Rockridge* BART,
which is actually in North Oakland. Within a short walking distance you
have Zachary's pizza to the North, a burger shop, a coule of nice Japanese
restaurants, and Dryers Ice cream. To the south along College you get
Cactus Taqueria, College Ave Burrito, Olivetto, Edible Complex, Diesel
Books, Gaucho's Rotisserie, Saturn Records (real records), and Pegasus
Books. If you've never been to Zachary's pizza it's the best deep dish
Chicago pizza, bar none, in the Bay Area

Finally, you can top it all off with a 10 to 15 minute hike down to Your
Momma's House cafe, where honest to gosh sfravers actually spin music on
Saturday nights. I don't know if stareyes is in town to do her set, but
I'll be on doing my disco acid house thang from 11-1 at the very least
before I boogie on over to the Gathering.

Latez.
							--Chesapeake

>>{}  Yea, we do these silent raves all the time.  We call them Boom Box

>>{}  but we cannot get a cooperating radio station,  so we operate a low power
>>{}  pirate transmitter,  and purposly keep the range as confined as possible.

>I actully checked out the posibilities of doing this some years ago when I
>was a DJ at the now ledgendary (or infamous) Ziggurat and The Front.
>
>It's not actully a pirate transmitter.  Anyone can transmit on FM
>frequencies within a certain power restriction.  From memory it's 100
>miliwatts - but this may have changed.  Those on the list who are in touch
>with Elec-eng students will be able to easily find out the ins and outs of
>the situation, plus probably find people more than willing to help on the
>technical side.
>

>is (at least at the moment) freedom to gather.  It's just the sound volume
>that means Mr Police can act.  I'd love to see the faces of our friendly
>constabulary when faced with a non-volume rave.  If someone wants to go one
>step further, get a silenced generator and do the lighting as well - not too

------------------------------------------------------------------------

It's coming up on 4 years that sfraves has been in operation,
four years since the whoopy ball (where I first "felt the vibe")
four years from my first FMR (when I truly became a raver)

I've seen the Scene go through it's gyrations it's ups and it's downs.
It's ins and it's outs, as far as old timer's go. I'm not really an
"old timer" though, many of the true old timer's are not on this list, though
some of them are (and you know who you are :)

I guess for me, the "Rave" scene has been something that has brought 
incredible happiness to me (it has also brought some incredible sadness
to some).  When I look back in my life, I realize that I was always
a raver, really!, when I was 16 years old in Baltimore, we would take
Acid and listen to Curved Air, Pink Floyd, Gong, Yes (still remember
classics like Close to the Edge) and dance and dance and dance.
(For some of you folks who don't know me, I'm going to be 39 in 24 days)
In the 80s when I was a video artist, I used to fantisize about all night
dance parties with computer controlled video and lights, that would
be synchronized to the music, which would be DANCE MUSIC.  I always
found dancing hard and long to be the best way to beat back the blues,
rally spirit, and bring about direct change in one's life.  Being a
member of an "underground" video art collective called Subterranean
Video (operating out of Boston), we were dedicated to "breaking new 
ground in Television", looking at the screen as a canvas, trying to
break the spell of a decade that was dominated by an Actor acting as 
a President. Much of our early work of deconstruction of the TV image and 
the "psychedelic" splash of the Sandin IP (Image Processor), I see echoed
in just about every major Visual production that exist at parties today.
When I went to my first Toon Town, I realized that other folks had
those fantasies as well, and that I was not alone.  When I went to
the Whoopy Ball and the FMR it was like a homecoming,  I immediately
recognized the Energy.  People were taking back their freedom of expression
and their freedom of consciousness, what was totally styfiled in the
80s was welling up again.  When I went to my first FMR at Grey Whale Cove,
I was amazed that people were assembling at this remote location in the
middle of the night, forsaking late night TV and even sleep or sex to
be at this spot, dodging, even calmly ignoring the Highway Patrol who
was up on US 1 trying to trick people into going home with threats of towing
(which never happened :), and down on the Beach, a sound system, playing
joyous, loud, happy and defiant music, (and the police powerless to stop it:)
I was hooked immediately; what an apt form of non-violent protest for the
coming police state.  Here were a group of people all races, ages, 
nationalities, who were loosing sleep, even though many had to go to work 
or school in the morning, to be together, to do this "thing", to participate
in a group gesture of love, joy and power, to take back the wild and public
places, to revel at the Full Moon as so many of our ancestors did.

Things change and ebb and flow, the Bush babies are gone and we are replaced
by a more "hip" president (who doesn't know how to smoke pot correctly:)
It seems like the coming police state has abated, (but those of us who work
in cyberspace know full well it is just as present as ever, though it's
face has succeeded in being "Kinder and Gentler" to the public).

And what has happened to raving? That wonderful flower of youthful defiance?
Do the people who go to FMRs create it as their own? Are they participating
in a celebration, or is it just about how many Es/Balloons/beers/hits/lines
you can take while littering the beach with cigarette butts.

I'm not so sure I could face the Santa Cruz sherriff like I did that
warm summer night so long ago and tell him that all we want to do is dance
and enjoy this beautiful beach and this beautiful summer night and that
we'll leave the beach cleaner then we found it.  All things ebb and flow
and maybe it's just human nature, nay maybe just Nature it'self for
creatures, Energy, movements to blossom, bloom, mature, wither, die
and be reborn again.  It seems like our Scene has past it's prime.
Now I'm sure some of you out there will say, stop whining about how it
used to be, I wasn't there and things are great for me right now!
This may be true but try to think about it this way...

Suppose you grew up next to a beautiful brook that bubbled out of the
ground at the bottom of a mountain, when you were little, you could drink 
from it's source, about a mile down there was a pond, with all kinds of
frogs, and little fish, you used to go play with the turtles, and polywogs,
and duck the dragon-flies.  As you got older and were in high school, they
began to drill out the mountain to put some type of factory there,
the brook remains, but the pond starts to get over grown and to smell funny,
the water is slimy and you wouldn't think of drinking from the brook or
swimming in the pond (your too old for that anyway). Now your 27 and come 
home to visit your folks (who still live the next town over) you go back
to the old neighborhood and look in on where you spent your early years,
the brook is now a "waterway" cement walls on both sides, with a chain-link
fence to keep out the kids, the water level is high due to the rain
that the area has been having so the current is swift, but the water is grey.
There is not doubt in your mind that to drink even a sip could put you
in the hospital. The pond with the turtles and the dragon-flies is nowher
to be found but there is a new Mc Donald's approximately where you think 
it used to be.   Are you being silly to lament the polluting of your
brook?  Are we being silly to speak out about the pollution of the Scene?
Are we being silly to speak out against the pollution of our World?
Maybe if we speak out and say hey! Wait a minute, stop that! or Find 
another Way!  We might be able to save our Brook, Our Scene, Our Planet

I hope so.

For me, it becomes increasingly hard to go out these days.  A Scene that
used to include every race, every sexual preference, every type of
House music (Because there IS only one House Music which is Our House Music)
has once again become factionalized into Straight, Gay(Garage), 
Gangsta(black/hispanic), White(techno/trance), Wicked, Goodness, etc.

I remember meeting a guy at a ToonTown years ago, he was a real buff
"white guy" and we shared a speaker together one night, deep into the
vibe of a raging Techno track, which was ALL that mattered at the time,
later that evening we talked briefly, I detected an accent from my past,
when I asked him, sure enough, he was from Brooklyn (I live there as well
grades 1 - 9), I said wow! so am I, he asked me what part, I said "Bedford
Stuyasant, how bout you?" He said "Bensenhurst", for a moment we both looked
at each other with a sort of strange glint in our eyes, we both knew
the ramifications of our respective turf, (mortal enemies). then he smiled
and said "Aren't you glad we don't have to put up with that shit anymore?"
I said "Yes my brutha, I am" We gave each other a "manly hug" and continued
to party.  Where are the parties that reach out and break down those kind 
of barriers?  What has happened to our Scene is that we have become way too
self-righteous, too selective, too exclusive and way too willing to blame
the Other.  On the eve of the Gathering I want to ask everyone out there
who is going out to really look into your heart, FEEL THE MUSIC!! Whether
HARDCORE or HOUSE, the power is there IN THE MUSIC, NOT THE DRUGS, THE
MUSIC!!, in the music is the power to save the Scene. Also extend your Family
DON'T JUST MEET PEOPLE WITH SFR Laminants, meet people without LAMINANTS,
meet people who are scary to you, spread the vibe, you won't be disappointed.


I will be at the Gathering, Luv Phasers armed to Kill (with kindness :)
I WON'T be wearing my SFR LAMINANT (but I will carry it:) You will just have
to find me without it (I bet a lot of big black guys will be getting
hugs from strangers, this is good, the bruthas could sure use em')


I'll see you all first bass bin on the left :)

		

				G


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NEXUS SYSTEMS/CYBERTRIBE-5 : Voice:(415)965-2384 
Editor/Instigator/Catalyst : Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>

	              RAVE: For a better tomorrow

		--PGP Public key available upon request--
     "If I can't trance, I don't want to be part of your revolution"
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

recommend there.

used before.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec 17 13:03:02 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA00263; Sun, 17 Dec 1995 13:03:02 -0800
Received: from nixon.ind.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA00250; Sun, 17 Dec 1995 13:02:58 -0800
Received: (from lmnt@localhost) by nixon.ind.net (8.6.11/8.6.9) id RAA02530; Sun, 17 Dec 1995 17:13:26 -0500
Date: Sun, 17 Dec 1995 17:13:26 -0500 (EST)
From: e colmar <lmnt@nixon.ind.net>
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Mission Vortex review (long)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.951217171119.2524A-100000@nixon.ind.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

	i had a brief experience with Mission Vortex that i'd like to 
share with you all, i'm not sure if the subject line should read "not 
rave related" or not???
	Jana and i arrived at around 9:00, and were greeted with sage and 
face painting.  We looked around...  everyone lying on the ground 
massaging each other...  sorta.  We were sort of amazed that people 
actually were doing this on their own free will, and marveled at how 
great it was...  but then this uncomfortable feeling came over us, as we 
examined the situation further...  there were clusters of people maybe 5 
or 6 of them, each cluster focusing on one person.  And there was this 
other person walking around giving instructions.?.?.?  telling them to 
switch people, slow down, breathe, etc...
	We started to feel like we were doing something wrong by NOT 
participating, we were still sitting off in the corner.  This just added 
to the uncomfortableness of the situation.  There was only someone 
playing bells at this point so i couldn't just trance out.  We were 
watching, and for that we were being watched...i'm finding it hard to 
describe my feelings about this portion of the event, so i'll just go on...
	Eventually ~10 min.  someone came up to us and did a great job 
making us feel like we should join one of the groups...  So, we did, 
reluctantly...  we got led over to these people kneeling around this 
other person, seemingly massaging them, i personally did not witness any 
massaging at all, i guess it was more like cellular holding, or maybe 
pressure therapy???...  Suddenly the guy walking around the outside 
says...  "with this many people in the group, it's easy to lift them off 
the ground."  nobody in our group really responded, but i heard one of 
them ask "are we supposed to lift her off the ground now?"  and then the 
leader guy says louder, "it's EASY to lift them off the ground"  and they 
all responded, lifting her off the ground.  it was all really schoolish.
	then the music started.  quietly.  trance/acid at about 135 bpm!  
people start clapping, and suddenly the whole dance floor erupts, and 
everyone (except the 5 ravers sitting on the floor staring in amazement) 
starts dancing around cheering and clapping...  it really reminded me of 
a high school dance.  The DJ "DJ cheb i sabbah" had a strange mixing 
style that i had never seen before.  He inserted periods of silence in 
between the songs,  it seemed to kill the dance floor every time 
though...  =(
	He spun for ~15 minutes, and then one of the Leader type people 
got everyone into a circle.  said a little bit of cool stuff about energy 
and love, nothing special, then started the group doing things again...  
"run in to the middle"  "do it again"  "now do it backwards"  "feel the 
energy"  "touch some one's ankle, but don't let anyone touch yours"
	i looked at Jana and said "My bag is right next to me, we could 
escape right now!"  The next moment we were outside (with the rest of the 
ravers)...  and someone said on our way out "they're running out the door".

	i felt bad, again because i felt like i was doing something wrong 
by not participating.  One of the reasons i LOVE the rave scene so much 
is because of the quality of the ritual, and the personal-ness, each 
person has thier OWN ritual to bring into the bigger ritual...  I guess 
Mission Vortex just wasn't my taste...

	...but we did leave early ~11:00  so it may have changed.?.?.?


e

<delete>

Oh Kewl i get to give the first review! Ok, if you saw me, you were either
pissed cause i wouldn't let you in on the guest list, or because I was behind
the counter eating and not serving water! The music was slamming, the VIBE
WAS AWSOME!!! It was a really good party. I was the dude at the end who stood
up on the table and took pictures behind Doc, I had a toon town shirt on, and
blue jeans, I had brown hair(Still do) in a pony tail. I forgot my laminate,
anyway, I took like 30 pix, and I'll see if they will put them up on the web
site. I heard there was bunk E going around that was giving people rash's and
stuff, (Whoever was dealing bunk E....What goes around comes around)! That's
not cool. So If you saw me tell me, because I would like to put a face to the
name's here! The Party was killer!!!!!!!!!!!
Jonathan
Peace, Love, and diversity:)

I wanted to say I had an excellent time at the Gathering.
The set-up was great, the music was incredible...There's a 
lot more I could say, but i'm still really exhausted...It 
was nice to have a chance to go dancing, especially since 
i finished my finals on friday  =)

the worst parent in the world.  i'm hoping that someone has taken
him to their home and that we will be reunited at another party.
if you happen to know someone who found an elmo doll, please let me
know.  he has a rave hat with 'happy' and 'smile' stickers along
the edge of his hat...anyways, thanks for the help...

still recovering....

Hello.

There are thoese who could say....Pricey...
There sre thoese who could say....Commerical....

There are thousands of reasions not to of liked The Gathering.

But I'd have to say I had one of the most wonderful experiances this year @
an event... Just the sight of seeing you, my virtual familiy kept me smiling
all night.  The vibe was high and it was you, the people, that helped keep it
alive. And who was taking pictures??? I was dancing and *FLASH* I was stunned
for about a few seconds....

Allthough not everything was peaches and cream...
-The continual shortage of H2O
-A guest list (?) for a rave...
-The unfortunate confiscations of certian substances and medias to use thoses
substances.  

I hesitate to include price into that factor, due to the fact that that
warehouse was waaaaay messy in the morning.  As well as the fact (hopefully)
a certian proceeds go to helping out thoses more unfortunate than ourselves.
 

And in the end, isn't that what it's all about?  Helping each other?

A big Hello to:
Vince, Wayne, Amy, Austin, Rikki (and company)... Umm, Eric, Wendy, Rick,
Mike (although I didn't see you) and the plethora of others I danced with,
Hugged, shared vibes with ect. 

BTW: I was guy dancing about with the black cap, funny redlight / bluelight
glasses, black shirt, white teeshirt, black jeans and white, dirty, shoez.

And allthough The Gathering was nice I still think the smaller venues are
what makes it for me.

C-ya neXt weekend,

Spins

Adam

"love happens"

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec 17 20:10:08 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id UAA00440; Sun, 17 Dec 1995 20:10:08 -0800

From: Jondabomb@aol.com
Received: by emout04.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id XAA26655 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sun, 17 Dec 1995 23:09:33 -0500

Subject: Don't flame(Gathering)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok, I'm not trying to start something here, but check it out....It ends
happily. I want to know why some people would have the nerve to bring a piece
of shit toy, that obody would enjoy. Now I understand you saved 5 dollars
but....It's not about the money, its about the kids in need, and helping
others out, No love for the fools who brought, matchbox cars that were
missing windows and wheels, and g.I. Joe dolls with no arms, some people make
me sick!:( But there is some glimmer of hope, one girl brought in a huge Lion
and that was cool, but she said to me, "I better get a big discount for
shlepping it here," that bummed me out she said that.... To sum this up, The
scene is about love, and breaking the boundaries, and being yourself. To many
people are full of shit , and it makes me sad that people are that way. If
this doesn't make any sense, read A Catcher in the Rye by J.D. Salinger.
There are way to many phonies in this world. On a positive note, I didn't get
one bad look, or bad vibe from anyone, I made many new friends and hopefully
you did too! I am not looking to be flamed here!
Just my 5 bucks worth.
Jonathan

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

What a monster space.  PLenty of room for everyone. Yes the water 
shortage was kinda bad but liquids were available in some form or another 
I suppose.

in search of the pocket of vibe.  That was all I could think of was "Find 
the vibe...find the vibe"  I got a high number of occurances in the 
techno room and less in the house room but maybe because the house room 
was so packed with standers and sitters or maybe because I just don't 
know what I'm doing and I couldn't get where I wanted to go.

It sure does get confusing.

the trash factor was almost funny.  Trying to walk without kicking stuff 
into peoples faces (especially the ones who like to lay down right smack 
in the middle of the dancefloor) or trip on an empty water bottle.  WHat 
a mess.  WHen I see that I just wonder why I come to these events.  
There's always a trash factor, and I do love the vibe.. so where does 
that leave me I just don't know.  

meanwhile, we must dance.




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Dec 17 22:22:05 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id WAA08642; Sun, 17 Dec 1995 22:22:05 -0800
Received: from orion.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id WAA08637; Sun, 17 Dec 1995 22:22:01 -0800
Received: (from dislex@localhost) by orion.sfsu.edu (8.7.1/8.7.1) id WAA27038; Sun, 17 Dec 1995 22:21:56 -0800 (PST)
Date: Sun, 17 Dec 1995 22:21:56 -0800 (PST)
From: MIKE BOLGER <dislex@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: dislex@orion
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: 666
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.951217213059.22591A-100000@orion>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Started my day off at Great Expecations Bookstore to get Timithy Leary to 
sign my copy of Grand Royal #2. Leary looked a bit more baffled than 
usual as he scanned that Mark Riebling article which exposed his long 
standing affliation with the CIA, it looked as though it was the first 
time anyone had brought that article to his attention. He asked who 
were the people resposible for the publication and I answered that it was 
the Beastie Boy's fanzie...but I don't think regestered much either. 
Regardless though, I got the man's signature which was as good an omen 
as any to kick off the weekend.

Sun, Ryann, and I didn't get to Oakland till about midnight. Spent a 
while freezing in line, let a stranger next to me borrow my sweat jacket, 
and watched as packs of bubble-gum ravers bum rushed their way past us. 
Tried to bare no hard grudges. 

During this time had one of those moments where, even though you don't 
want to go off making snap judgements or blankent generalizations, but... 
to be quite honest, you feel a lot of bad karma being tossed around, much 
like when someone decides to share their racism with you. It makes you 
think, "Are these the people that I really want to party with ?" Because 
if this is one of the situations where You Are Who You Fuck, then you've 
just become that 30 year old dude from Dazed and Confused and I don't know 
if I really want to be that guy...

What impressed me then, and throughout the night, was that the Gathering 
had all the basic elements to be a really sketchy scene, but wasn't. ((at 
least from where I was standing. I don't know how many acts of violance 
there were so I could be wrong)) I attribute a lot of that on Faith, 
Faith and Integrity. Integrity that you can see in the form of photo 
flyers, 5 min voice messages, and people saying Thank You.

In terms of raving and San Francisco, it's taken me quite a while to find 
my dance. e is an invaluable learning tool in that process, but something 
I didn't want to become dependant on ((in general and last night in 
particular)). Triping & Trancing are great to have your visions, but, at 
least for me, it's also really easy to fall into a single track mentality 
: introverted : obsession with 1 : person : DJ : thing. Shrooms kind of 
help me break that paradigm by not only opening the universe up around 
you, but also by puting a twist on things and giving you the oppurtunity 
to see the people behind you who your dance might be influeincing and the 
other distant personalities from which to draw strength from.

We're all shaped by experiences. I think sometimes all psychodelics do is 
increase the significance of those infante moments that normally you 
wouldn't concesiouslly register. In more of an abstract level I though a 
lot about recharging karma batteries, learnig how to project & pogo at 
the same time, and a few other concepts that I really couldn't interpert 
to you in a sentance. 

Specifically though, I resolved last night to ((try)) and bow more 
often in the future to show respect to my elders : peers. Buddist Boy 
Scout Merit Badge.

Hope you and yours got something out of the evening as well. 

Enjoy the corporate holidays.

later.

Bolger


end note : On the trek home, Sun sported our morning breakfast at a 
local coffee dive. He paid for the meal with a ten dollar bill and 
recieved exactlly 3:03 back in change...the signifacance of which 
wasn't lost to either of us.

[ To SFRaves mailist ]

 I'm getting somewhat overwhelmed with work and the joy of meeting lost-
seperated friends and the self-imposed responsibilities of the holiday
season ... not much mental time to devote to replying to some of the 
great and interesting topics that have been here on SFRaves lately -
especially the "shyness posts" and Geoff White's recent post of the past
and present of his personal rave history. 

 I'd just like to say that I'm glad to seem something in SFRaves in addition 
to just "where's the good raves?/that raves was great!/that raves sucked!".

 I didn't go to anything this weekend , so I appreciate any posts about
this weekend's raves - I have nothing against rave reviews on SFRaves!

 May God and/or the Gods or "Powers" or Angels or whatever benevolent you
beleive in take special care of every one of you in this season. ( Of 
course , if you get drunker than a fish in a vat of vodka and then go
driving in the fog , you're asking your guardian angels for more than
what's in their job description! ).

 Happy and Joyous and Safe and Lucky Holy Days To You!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

> I have just two questions. 
> 
> 1) Just how much money did The Gathering make (net)?

I don't know the exact answer to this question but I'm sure
the answer lies some where in the low end of 5 figures, my guess.


> 2) How much of that profit is going to charity?
> 
>                                           Black Adder


Why is this important at all? how much of your income do you donate to
charity?  Martin is a party promoter, he also has a clothing company.
He lives by doing these two things.  He, like me, is dedicated to
trying to spread a message to a large number of people, this takes
money. For me, I took a bunch of money that I made (actually MOST of
the money I still make) and drop it into the black Hole of PacBell to
pay for my T1 connection, so that certain "points of view" can, and
always will have a home on the net.  Martin threw an Excellent party! I
saw straight up vato's totally blown away by the Vibe,  There is no
doubt in my mind that some lives were saved last night, maybe not at
that moment but down the line.  The  desired effect that we all wish
massives of that size could attain was achieved.  Now all of those
"newbie" ravers who haven't realized that $25 is a high price to pay
for a party will have a reference point the next time they pay it at
Cool World.

I hope Martin make a fucking mint at the party because I know from his actions
that the money will go to good use.  


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 18 00:48:46 1995

From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <199512180850.AAA20437@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: The Gathering
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

When I asked Martin a week ago was this party going to be worth it.
He said "I Gurantee ya man, you will leave your head in the place".
He totally made good on his promise.
This was a critical point for me because I really didn't think that you could
have large parties with that kind of Vibe and the resultant aftershocks in SF
any more.  Silly me :)  I was totally blown away by the energy in both the
Dedication Room and the Inspiration Room. There were a lot of Bruthas and
Cholos in the place which made me feel good because they were totally grooving.
Jeno came on, locked the door and immediately set about the business of
smashing heads (ego).  When it started happening I saw several people heading 
out of the room with the chareteristic frantic look on their face.  I recognized
the distant yet familiar feeling as my brain wave activity changed and I slid
into Trance State, deep and hard, it indeed had been a long time and frankly I
didn't believe that Jeno was going to rise to the occasion but he did, with
a vengance.  After Jeno "beat down" all the Ego in the room Markie came in with
some totally sick British Acid House that truly brought the freak out in just
about everyone.  Jeno beats your mind to a pulp, Markie injects the appropriate
recombinate DNA sequence to perform the appropriate genetic mutations, then
all that was left was for Doc to rebuild your psyche in the image of House :)

But seriously I had some amazing experiences.  A lot of really trippy stuff.

I'm still integrating it so I can't really talk about it. but hopefully
over the next few days I will be able to.


				G

At 6:10 PM 12/17/95, Foustus@aol.com wrote:

>But I'd have to say I had one of the most wonderful experiances this year @
>an event... Just the sight of seeing you, my virtual familiy kept me smiling
>all night.  The vibe was high and it was you, the people, that helped keep it
>alive. And who was taking pictures??? I was dancing and *FLASH* I was stunned
>for about a few seconds....

Coulda been the Dataflashes that they tended to either have off or at full,
disorienting, intensity. =)

>-A guest list (?) for a rave...

There's always a guest list for almost any party, and they can never find
your name. =)

I thought the Gathering was spectacular. A little large for my taste, but
given the conditions, a great event, and certainly a great vibe for the
number of people there. It absolutely seemed like LA c.1992 in there while
Tony was spinning - albeit with better music.

Ethan did a tremendous job of filling up the techno room, which had much
more energy and vibe than the house room for the first few hours. I didn't
catch all the DJ's, but Tony and Jeno were in top form, Spun brought back
the acid house, and Terry Mullen amazed everyone with his manual dexterity.
(Imagine DJ Dan growing up in the midwest, listening to Chicago acid tracks
and Detroit techno)

All in all a great party, and worth it if only to see Martin gyrating madly
in a Santa costume behind Jeno...

Joe

> > I have just two questions. 
> > 
> > 1) Just how much money did The Gathering make (net)?

> I don't know the exact answer to this question but I'm sure
> the answer lies some where in the low end of 5 figures, my guess.
> 
> 
> > 2) How much of that profit is going to charity?
> > 
> >                                           Black Adder
> 
> 
> Why is this important at all? how much of your income do you donate to
> charity?  Martin is a party promoter, he also has a clothing company.
> He lives by doing these two things.  He, like me, is dedicated to
> trying to spread a message to a large number of people, this takes
> money. For me, I took a bunch of money that I made (actually MOST of
> the money I still make) and drop it into the black Hole of PacBell to
> pay for my T1 connection, so that certain "points of view" can, and
