It is VERY important when the name of charity is being used as a 
marketing tool, to make people feel like they are doing something great 
by handing over their cash.

How much I donate to charity is not an issue, because I am not using 
charity as a tool to make my money.

As far as the message is concerned, what is that message? Unity? Tell 
that to the guy whose ass is on the curb cause he can't afford the cost 
of admission to your idea of unity. Understand that I have no problem 
with people making a profit. But it was totally unecessary to charge $25 
for this event. There comes a point when making a profit turns into 
taking advantage of. 

I am sure that a lot of people had a good time, which we will all be 
hearing about soon. Good for them. I am happy that people enjoyed 
themselves. Maybe someday they will learn that it is unecessary to make 
someone rich in order to have a good time. Maybe someday they will learn that 
unity is not something reserved for those who can afford the price of 
admission. I have seen this happen in small doses. And it is such a 
beautiful thing. Large, high profit-driven parties *PALE* in comparison.

> I hope Martin make a fucking mint at the party because I know from his actions
> that the money will go to good use.  

Geoff somehow I am less than amazed by this. Got to make a buck somehow, eh?

If Martin is doing great things for the community other than taking their 
money, please, please let me know what. I have a very negative opinion of 
the motives behind the gathering, and would very much like to find out 
that I have been wrong. I don't particularly enjoy thinking bad things about 
people, belive it or not. Anyone?

                                           Black Adder

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 18 09:50:27 1995

From: Peter Fogel <peterf@netcom.com>
Subject: gathering :)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Well I couldn't ask for a better way to spend my birthday.  Though 
whatever significance my birthday has, was mostly lost or found depending 
on how I look at it as I danced away and merged with the enormous energy 
and love that filled the party.

All in all, angela and I (her first massive) had a wonderful time.  We 
did have our moments of feeling overwhelmed, but were able to ride 
through those to feeling extactic joy, and spiritual sensations of 
connectedness that I don't think I can put into words.

We spent the beginning of our time in the big room listening to tony.  
Decided to check out the techno room, after markie started playing some 
diva sounding stuff.  I was reluctant to go to the techno room, because 
that music tires me out, as it usually makes me dance fast and hard.
Upon entering the room, we felt like we were hit with this fresh bright 
energy, and realized Lee was right in saying the vibe was better in there.

We had the most fun dancing in there as we danced our asses off (had to 
take a couple of rests).  We liked the brighter lighting which I felt 
brought people together more, where in the other room the dark enviroment 
separated people a little more.

I usually prefer housyer stuff, but that fast techno stuff really got 
me.  I felt like it locked me in to this groove, that I was able to go 
crazy in.  When I say crazy its a good kind of crazy that feels great, 
outta my mind, feeling and giving the energy that is in me and beyond "me".

Well I almost didn't make this party, as I was feeling tired from having 
moved earlier in the day, and didn't know if I had enough energy to have 
a great time.  I found out I didn't need that much energy as I got plenty 
of energy from the great music coming from wonderful sound systems, and 
the combined energy radiating from everyone.  Thank you all some much for 
sharing that energy.

:)
peter

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 18 11:04:19 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA00232; Mon, 18 Dec 1995 11:04:19 -0800
Received: from ix6.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id LAA00221; Mon, 18 Dec 1995 11:04:15 -0800
Received: from  by ix6.ix.netcom.com (8.6.12/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id LAA07843; Mon, 18 Dec 1995 11:03:41 -0800
Date: Mon, 18 Dec 1995 11:03:41 -0800
Message-Id: <199512181903.LAA07843@ix6.ix.netcom.com>
From: sequoia1@ix.netcom.com (Chris Chervin )
Subject: Why $25 and not $20
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all,

At last years gathering it was $20.  That was at the civic center.  I 
don't know the cost of the space and the crew and everything else 
involved but as far as I can tell it couldn't have been any different 
from last years.  So why $25?  If you bring a toy you pay normal price 
but if you don't than you pay extra.  Shouldn't it have been $15 with a 
toy and $20 without?  OR ever $15 with a toy and $25 without?

I feel like a great idea was thunked up (toys for children) but who is 
going to bear the costs?  Obvioulsly just asking people to bring toys 
won't work.  Reducing the cost is a good solution.  I know it worked 
with me and all my friends.  But what of the ramifications.  IF Martin 
made the cost $15 with a toy would he risk losing his shirt (And why 
should he).  If the whole toy idea was not thought up than would the 
party have still been $25 or would it have been $20?  Truly $25 seems 
steep for a one-night party to me.   But it was legal.  That alone must 
cost money and effort.  I just can't help feeling like those people who 
paid $25 were doing it so the rest of us would bring a toy.  

Regardless of all that the party was GREAT!  I knew it would be and 
thats why I paid my $20.  Once a year I will do this.  Also, I don't 
want to sound like I'm moaning and groaning about this because  truly 
regardless of the price issue I think the toy idea is beautiful and 
should be contiuned with canned food and other dealies.

love chris

Subject: Gathering (short)

A few things about this event;
 Several thousand people of several backgrounds and not one fight did I
see.  I cant say that about any club I've been to on a packed/crazy night
(Spundae last labor day!!, saw several swollen eyes,at 1015 I almost got
jacked for falling asleep on a couch! )

I've been to several big parties put on by Martin and Co. (Basics, Vision)
and even though they are large like this one, somehow there's not the
cheezee commercial feel that are at most massives (and this one was
MASSIVE)  It was nice to see a broad spectrum of people which seems to be
gettin rare and what Geoff White said about techno/ house and divisions has
been on my mind for a while and scares the fuck out of me.  Are we all just
going to divide ourselves (our scene)  into musical/racial tribes?(some say
it's too late) I guess it's just natural evolution that electronic/dance
music will branch off into so many forms lets just not forget where it came
from and what it's all about.  Maybee it takes huge parties like the
Gathering to bring all "types" together even if it's only once a year.
Overall the vibe was strong, Doc Martin made me remember the meaning of
House  I got there ealy enough to hear Stevie put down some exteeeemly hard
jungle.  The music was swimming thru my brain till late sun
night,increadible space too.  Hope we all make it to the 5 year Gathering.

SEEYA,
Mark

        "Why $25 and not $20" (Dec 18, 11:03am)
References: <199512181903.LAA07843@ix6.ix.netcom.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: sequoia1@ix.netcom.com (Chris Chervin ), sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Why $25 and not $20
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Of course, I'm only kibitzing (because I flaked out and didn't go to
the Gathering as a result of lack of stamina, I could just tell at
11 pm I wouldn't last the night after a very tough work week), but
all I can say about the $20-vs-$25 thing is that in comparison to
other events in the same price range, Martin has always delivered 
a much better value.  I mean, just look at the latest monstrosity
being promoted by Cool World for the Kaiser on New Year's Eve.
(Since that night and that place were the locale of some of my
most cosmic Grateful Dead shows, this one particularly sticks in
my throat.)  

I'm not going to go into the ins and outs of event pricing, since it
is far more complicated than anyone has hinted so far, but let me
boil it down to this: the same people who take home the profits for
these big events also put serious hard out-of-pocket money on the line,
and it is very possible to lose it, quick and large.  I say this with
some regret as a reformed concert promoter :)

We can quibble about the details, but frankly, looking at the very
happy reports coming in from y'all about the Gathering, even from
the many who don't particularly care for the mega-event scene, I'd
have to say that from SF on up north to at least Seattle, Martin's
events are some of the very few that sustain any of the *real* rave vibe
(I've heard very good things about Futur and Area 51 in that regard, as
well).  

I wouldn't do things the way he is doing them, but then I'm not putting
months of effort and big sums of my money on the line either.  

In general, I think the customer has the right to judge the quality of
the event, each on our own terms, according to the price, ambience,
music, lighting, security and general space.  But I think it's important
as well to be fair and consider the perspective of party organizers as
well.

We are still a very long way from the mega-commercial arena events in
Europe, where they are turning DJs into demigods and using all the
tricks of arena rock shows to bludgeon the masses into submission.

As Andrew Rawnsley so clearly notes in the new XLR8R, based on his
view of things just back from the UK, I think the moment has arrived
where our scene, once a rebellion against the stale, money-mad, 
artistry-deadening cattle calls of the rock arena music world, has now
gotten so stale and business oriented that we will have to rebel once
again, from within this time.  I suspect in that context events like
the Gathering will help remind us how it doesn't have to be limos,
fireworks and contrived mayhem to keep the masses entertained.  House
*and techno* are based on a more personal sense of communication that
does not scale up well without losing its soul.  

My kibitzing $0.02 for the first day of Hanukkah, a week before Christmas
and, most notably, three days before the ending of the solar year and
the start of another . . .

phred

At 11:31 AM, jjjJJJOOOOOOOOOOOOHHHhhhnnnnnn...... wrote:

>Does anyone know where to get orange (the brighter the better)
>jumpsuits/mechanics outfits anywhere in the bay area?

You might want to try Industrial Safety Supply in Emeryville, or Hawkins
Traffic Safety Supply in Berkeley.  They're both in the Yellow Pages, under
'Safety' and 'Traffic Safety' respectively.  I don't know if either has
orange _jumpsuits_, but when our lab needed snazzy reflective coverings for
some HazMat barrels (I know I know, boo! hiss!!) I remember almost
everything in those places was some shade of Day-Glo Orange=81 8)  Good luck=
!

manuel

At 10:38 AM 12/18/95, blkadder@value.net wrote:

>It is VERY important when the name of charity is being used as a
>marketing tool, to make people feel like they are doing something great
>by handing over their cash.
>

I don't know if he promised that any of the proceeds were going to charity,
merely the toys.


>If Martin is doing great things for the community other than taking their
>money, please, please let me know what. I have a very negative opinion of
>the motives behind the gathering, and would very much like to find out
>that I have been wrong. I don't particularly enjoy thinking bad things about
>people, belive it or not. Anyone?
>
>                                           Black Adder

Why don't you call Martin and ask him - Communion 415 284-0180 - if you
care that much about it. Martin has done more than any other major promoter
to try and keep big parties true to the spirit of raving. Yeah, they're on
the more massive tip, but that's a known factor. If you don't want to go,
don't go. He's done more than anyone else I can think of to get city
governments to understand exactly what raving is about and has been
successful in having legal events which even earn kudos from most local
agencies involved without much hassle evident to the partygoers. He's
playing the game, sure, but he's playing it _well_. And if you talk to him
for awhile about where he's been and where he's going you'll see he's not
out to make a fast buck.

There are many others better deserving of this sort of criticism.

Joe

The Gathering
============

Martin,  you did it this time....  You pulled off one of the most amazing rave
events I've ever had the honor of attending.    Everything about it was
RIGHT ON...    A BIG venue,  plenty of room,  pumpin sound,  cool
(temperature wise).   Don't know how many attended,   but it was thousands.

I was able to talk Nate into stopping my "Your Mama's" cafe in Berkeley
(Actually Oakland).   I arrive kind of early,  ordered some food,  and hung
out,  listening to some Jungle.   Very nice place.   For those looking for
me,  I
WAS there,  but Nate had "Ants in his pants",  got bored and insisted that we
leave the cafe NOW and head out to the site.    Sorry I missed those that
wanted to meet me.

We  arrive around 9 pm.   Already,  the security was in place,  so we hung
around and chilled out in front.    The venue was behind this huge Home
improvement center called "Home Base".   A HUGE warehouse.

When we were eventually let in,   after the usual security searches,  one sees
a split...   One way leads to "Inspiration",  the main room (Mostly house),
the
other way leads to "Dedication",   the (Other than house) room.    In
dedication, they were spinning Jungle,  and in "Inspiration" was pumpin
house with an incredible sound system.

They were also just setting up,  with the lights on,   so I cased the joint,
greeting the many friends that were there.    The spaces were amazing,   the
chill room wasn't that good,   few pillows or comfortable places to flop on,
but the space was perfect.   Visuals were mostly projections,  and some
video,  but (sigh!) NO LASERS!!    That's what I'm missing in raves here in
SF.
Good visual effects.   In Australia,  the lasers are amazing.

Ethan went on in "Dedication" room,  and I was right there (as well as all the
SFRavers).   As usual,  his trance sets were totally brilliant,   a little
faster
than he normally plays,   but really good acid trance.   As usual,  I WENT
OFF!  and in no time,  went ballistic,  bouncing off the walls,  floor,  other
people,  whatever.

I had absolutely no idea how long Ethan was playing,   at that point,  I didn't
care,  because the next DJ mixed in so subtly,  that I didn't notice the
change.
For a very long time,  I was lost out in that maze of happy people.
My face is still hurting from all that smiling....

I spent MOST of my time in Dedication room,   then later on,  Tony started
slowing things down,   but all night was excellent trance and house.

They closed down Dedication room around 6:30,   but by that time,  I was in
the main room,  getting it on...   Then,  the lights started coming on,   music
stopped.   Then the last song was played.    After that,   things went
silent for
a few minutes,   then the music started once again for just one more song.

At the end,  Martin thanked everyone,  and we left...

Crunchman

> >people, belive it or not. Anyone?

> 
> Why don't you call Martin and ask him - Communion 415 284-0180 - if you
> care that much about it. Martin has done more than any other major promoter
> to try and keep big parties true to the spirit of raving. Yeah, they're on
> the more massive tip, but that's a known factor. If you don't want to go,
> don't go. He's done more than anyone else I can think of to get city
> governments to understand exactly what raving is about and has been
> successful in having legal events which even earn kudos from most local
> agencies involved without much hassle evident to the partygoers. He's
> playing the game, sure, but he's playing it _well_. And if you talk to him
> for awhile about where he's been and where he's going you'll see he's not
> out to make a fast buck.

Thanks for the number, I just might do that. 

As far as the "spirit of raving" I am sure we all have different opinions 
on what that is. Personally I don't think that a $25 admission holds to 
the "spirit of raving" unless of course hard costs necessitated that kind 
of charge, which I find highly doubtful. I was under the impression that 
part of the "spirit of raving" included Unity. Unity of whom? Those that 
can afford $25 for a party? Is that Unity? Again, I do not expect people 
to martyr themselves to the cause, going broke for the enjoyment of 
others. Do the math. That ain't happenin here, by a LONG, LONG shot.


 > 
> There are many others better deserving of this sort of criticism.
> 
> Joe

By all means, point them out.

                                           Black Adder

HI kids,

I'm not going to add to the Gathering price flame wars !!
I thought it was a good event. And YES it did not have the feel of a "Cool
World", it was a *rave*, just a big one :)

The reason for this post is, I think it would be a good idea to have Martin
subscribe to SFRaves (if he isn't already), he will probably like to hear
what we have to say, and I know we would really like to hear from him. I
don't mean fighting off flame attacks, but info about his events, ideas to
make them better, etc.. I know several promoters and DJ's are here, and
make very good use of this medium.

Just my .03 (.02 if you email a toy :) )

Vince

to him. If someone here knows Martin, maybe you could mention it to him.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 18 15:02:15 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA22361; Mon, 18 Dec 1995 15:02:15 -0800
Received: from alpha.xerox.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id PAA22355; Mon, 18 Dec 1995 15:02:12 -0800
Received: from godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com ([13.242.128.10]) by alpha.xerox.com with SMTP id <14654(8)>; Mon, 18 Dec 1995 15:01:33 PST
Received: from beluga.adoc.xerox.com ([13.242.128.26]) by godzilla.ADOC.xerox.com with SMTP id <2201>; Mon, 18 Dec 1995 15:00:01 -0800
Received: from cc:Mail SMTPLINK 2.1 by beluga.adoc.xerox.com
	id AA819328759; Mon, 18 Dec 95 15:18:54 PST
Date: Mon, 18 Dec 1995 15:18:54 PST
From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>
Message-Id: <9511188193.AA819328759@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>
To: blkadder@value.net
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: The Gathering, Profit and Delivering
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     Like others, I too was reluctant to go to a massive and hemmed and 
     hawed until the evening of the party.  I knew lots of "retired" ravers 
     were coming out to this event as well as other friends of mine so I 
     got psyched into going.  Sometimes you can feel the vibe building and 
     for this one, several hours before the event--even by myself at home 
     with no electricity or music :( --I could feel the pull.
     
     Yes, $25 is a lot of money but when you look at the dj line-up and are 
     familiar with the parties Martin gives, what he promotes, and his 
     _intentions_, you either pay up or pass on it.  For me, Martin is 
     always able to deliver 1) good music/dj line-up, 2) a diverse mix of 
     people, 3) a positive vibe (and introduction/experience to any 
     newbie), and 4) a concern for people in the community he's hosting the 
     party in as well as for those who have no transportation.  Aside from 
     the Food not Bombs donations at some parties, what raves have you gone 
     to that gives a discount if you provide something (in this case a toy 
     to a charity)?  And what rave promoters make arrangements for buses to 
     take people to and from a rave or for that matter, picks a location 
     near public transportation?  To me a good promoter considers his 
     audience and delivers what they want.
     
     Sure there are kinks w/Martin (from what I hear) but who doesn't have 
     some quirk about them...after all, we are human.  And what's wrong 
     with profit?  Again, if one's intention is good and not motivated by 
     the wrong reasons, then what's wrong with earning their keep?
     
     Other reasons mentioned in previous posts bring up good points about 
     working w/police, city governments and the permit process help bring 
     raving into a positive light.  Something I'd personally like to see 
     more of if we want to gain legitimacy and have less hassles w/r/t 
     venues and law enforcement.
     
     Well, onto my review of the Gathering:  It kicked!  This time for me, 
     it wasn't the music that made me go off but the vibe/psychic energy 
     and the people.  I arrived around 11:30 pm and though the line was 
     long, we were quickly searched and entered with no problem.  I'd say 
     we got in in less than 30 minutes.  Lots of positive vibe, cheery 
     faces, and wonderful builds of music w/the dj's.  I also had an 
     incredible psychic connection w/a friend that can't be described by 
     words.  I know our crown chakras were beaming lots of light by the 
     energy we felt around us and the reactions people gave us...and this 
     wasn't because we were sucking face or anything like that.  It was 
     pure love and it felt wonderful! 
     
     Also, for a woman, having long lines and no toilet paper in the johns 
     by the morning is a real pain.  Having neglected to bring a pack of 
     tissues, I wondered if I'd have the same dilemma.  Not so :)  There 
     were plenty of porta potties strategically placed around the building 
     and all the ones I visited had plenty of paper.  Sorry if this offends 
     anyone, it's just a personal peeve I have w/most venues.   
     
     I felt alot of planning went into this party to make it successful and 
     the love promoted by Martin and his crew extended beyond the core and 
     illuminated/inflamed all who were willing to receive.  I'm glad I went 
     and sorry I didn't get a chance to meet any new sfravers, but I'm sure 
     there'll be another time.
     
     Lotsa luv,
     Diane

How much for Lyons?
How much for "Off Duty Officers"
How much for permits?
How much for set-up crews?

How much for portapotties?
How much for clean up and trash removal?
How much for flyer production?
How much for promotion?
How much for the electrician?
How much to bring the building to "code"?
How much for the SF gathering bus rental both too and from?
How much for a 5 million dollar insurance policy?


Remember Martin throws legal straight up parties, he doesn't cut corners
on safety.  He stands openly before the Man and will get nailed if something
happens.


> >

> problem with people making a living. But $25? Please that isn't breaking

No it is not breaking even, nor should it be, Martin is a business man,
if he breaksd even, he may not be able to throw another party in a while.
If he make a good profit then he can throw a better party the next time.
I make a reasonable amount of money doing what I do, I don't
write software that kills people and i feel that my work is going toward part
of the solution as opposed to being part of the problem.


> Why does this bother me? It directly 
> conflicts with my own personal beliefs regarding "the spirit of raving." I 
> will never apologize for, nor censure myself from voicing my beliefs for 
> you, or anyone else.     
>  
>                                            Black Adder
It is fine for you to have your beliefs but make sure when you speak
"facts" that you get them straight.  As far as the spirit of raving is 
concerned, that can occure at a $50 party or at a free party, it's what
the participants bring with them not what they pay that creates this spirit.

I don't understand why someone will pay $20 for a hit of E, $10 for a 2 
hour movie, $25 for a lift ticket, but can't pay $25 to a person
who is trying to do the right thing.

	Let's actually see some math. The only numbers I've seen in this flamewar
are:
$25/head
5000 heads
$5k for the cops.

	Let's see:
how much for the space
how much time martin put into it
how much for the permits
how much for the sound system, equipment
how much for the djs
how much for other random employees

	Let me throw out some WAGs as to the numbers above:
space: $10k
time: 200 hours: $20k
permits: $10k
soundsystem: $6k 
djs: $10k
other random employees: $10k

Total cost: $71k
Total income $125k

	Therefore a total profit, according to my WAG (which is way
off, I am sure) of $56k. About 50% return. Significant,
yes. Monstrous, no. Does anyone have better numbers that they can
throw at the problem?

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Dec 18 16:09:59 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id QAA27335; Mon, 18 Dec 1995 16:09:59 -0800
Received: from gw3.pacbell.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id QAA27328; Mon, 18 Dec 1995 16:09:56 -0800
Received: from srv.PacBell.COM (mother.srv.PacBell.COM) by gw3.pacbell.com (5.x/PacBell-10/18/95)
	id AA11696; Mon, 18 Dec 1995 16:09:48 -0800
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/Mother-7/26/95)
	id AA10877; Mon, 18 Dec 95 16:09:47 PST
Received: by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA14375; Mon, 18 Dec 95 16:09:46 PST
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9512190009.AA14375@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: More Gathering Blathering
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 18 Dec 95 16:09:45 PST
Cc: martin@communion.com
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Space:  You really couldn't ask for anything better.  Plenty
of room, fresh air, nice decorations, easy to get to, safe
neighborhood.  The two dance rooms were sonically isolated from each
other and the traffic between them was smooth.  A small chill-out
tent thing with a pyramid provided a nice meditative focal stop where
I took the opportunity to sit down in a puddle of water.  I liked the
way the porto-potties where scattered around, as well as the speaker
stacks in the Inspiration (house) room.  Not only did i get to dance
while waiting to pee, but one booth I entered during Markie's set 
acted as resonance chamber and, well, it shook my world.  Apologies to
the person who entered the stall after me.

Vibe: Overall, very good.  I felt there were times that the energy 
in the house room dipped with a percentage of people sitting on
the floor or not dancing.  But the Dedication (techno) room seemed to
always be going off.  I split my time pretty evenly between the two and
can't think of a moment where I wasn't having a shitload of fun.
Everyone everywhere was friendly, I got tons of smiles, some
handshakes, and happy talk from many "strangers".  There seemed to be
plenty of diversity, and lot's of respect.  And Geoff, you were like a
vibe bomb. You sent me one luv phaser blast from across the dance floor
that almost knocked me off my feet!

Music: I didn't get there until 1:30, so i missed the early sets.
The one set that really stood out from the pack for me was Josh's, 
who finished up the techno room; wow, b4 this I had only heard him 
spin house. Jeno and Markie didn't quite hold me in their grip
like they usually do, but I think part of that was my preferance
for the punchier Wicked sound system (and better vibe) in the
techno room.  So everytime one of my favorite DJ's would play a song I 
didn't care for (like that lame-o Eurythmics "Sweet Dreams" of Jeno's)
I'd find myself wondering what was going on next door.  But every DJ
I heard that night moved me, and by the end I was exhasted.  Sorry to 
have missed Terry Mullen though  Jungle bass on the Wicked system must 
have been awesome.

Money: I saw this as a $20 party where you were penalized $5 if you
couldn't find a toy to give.  It was a top quality party in every
respect, really two parties for the price of one.  If our scene is
going to survive and remain a positive communal force, we need big
parties that can bring some of the underground vibe to a larger
'house'.  I *hope* Martin made money.  This issue came up a while back
on this list over one of his Freedom parties.  Martin came onto SFRaves
and gave us a complete financial breakdown.  The bottom line is that
he ain't getting rich doing this.  Not that I would really care all
that much.  Not many people could do what he has done.  Thanks Martin,
and to everyone who was there to make it happen!


Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

> > > Martin was trying to put on a special event, not a free event.
> > > He makes his living throwing parties, I make my living writing software
> > > which I don't give away.  Sometimes I give away my time and energy but
> > > not always, why do people think that every party should be free?
> > 
> > You convieniently deleted my statement regarding me *NOT* having a 
> > problem with people making a living. But $25? Please that isn't breaking 
> > even, it is making a small fortune.
> 
> No it is not breaking even, nor should it be, Martin is a business man,
> if he breaksd even, he may not be able to throw another party in a while.
> If he make a good profit then he can throw a better party the next time.
> I make a reasonable amount of money doing what I do, I don't
> write software that kills people and i feel that my work is going toward part
> of the solution as opposed to being part of the problem.

Last year the party was $20, now it's $25. Guess no money was made last 
year, or the year before, or the year before that, to necessitate the  
additional cost.

> > Why does this bother me? It directly 
> > conflicts with my own personal beliefs regarding "the spirit of raving." I 
> > will never apologize for, nor censure myself from voicing my beliefs for 
> > you, or anyone else.     
> >  
> >                                            Black Adder
> It is fine for you to have your beliefs but make sure when you speak
> "facts" that you get them straight.  As far as the spirit of raving is 
> concerned, that can occure at a $50 party or at a free party, it's what
> the participants bring with them not what they pay that creates this spirit.

Actually I believe we were talking about perceptions, at least I was. The 
"facts" used to base these perceptions were the ones I have available to 
me. Bring some facts to the table Geoff, tell me why I am wrong. As I 
have said before I don't automatically wish to believe that someone is an 
ass. So if I am wrong give me some FACTS rather than attempting to make 
me justify myself as a person to you. 

You are right on about the participants making the party. It is just a 
shame that a promoter choose to price an event so the participants are 
not a truly representitive of all the beautiful people out there, but 
just those with plenty-o-cash. 
 
> I don't understand why someone will pay $20 for a hit of E, $10 for a 2 
> hour movie, $25 for a lift ticket, but can't pay $25 to a person
> who is trying to do the right thing.

All good questions. Show me someone who is trying to do the "right thing" 
for the "right reasons." If Martin is that person, tell me why. 


                                               Black Adder

Firstly and foremostly- respect to the Santa Cruz and Sacramento
possies for taking the time to understand my accent.
 ;=)

This was my first time this side of the pond, and for sure not the
last. Sounds were great, but couldn't quite get in to the house room.

People were excellent,well sound. Approachable friendly and having a
whooping great time, I was starting to think this area had NO NIGHTLIFE
(I live on the peninsula), Gathering people- you restored my faith in
this place.

 As someone pointed out earlier Euro all nighters are expensive
($45-$60+) depending on the names and having anything up to 10,000+
people (Do that math then !).

The point of this is if you think $25 is too much, then don't go! but
dont end up wondering next year why there is no more all nighters like
Sat. A good scene costs, but it needn't be outrageously priced.

I appreciate that some people (normally students) dont have money so
bring in discounted prices for students- it is pretty normal every
where else.

Keep on Smiling ;=)

___________________________ Forward Header __________________________________
Subject: Re: Martin
Date:    12/18/95 4:49 PM

     Diane,
     ...(personal stuff deleted)
     re: Martin, I'll pass this info on to him. [ed.] I helped out a little 
     preparing for the party on Saturday. Let me pass on some thoughts:
     
     1) Very few people would've had the sheer chutzpah to put on a party 
     of this size at this location. It could've been a financial disaster, 
     particularly with the weather we've seen recently. In April 1994 
     Martin had an outdoor party in Livermore which had a very high-level 
     of investment and organizing, but it pulled a very meagre crowd. How 
     many SFRavers were sympathetic to his situation then ?
     
     2) He was trying to get that space for the last 2 months. Countless 
     meetings with the property owners, City Manager, Police Department, 
     Fire Department, and much handholding was required before it worked 
     out. Business license, insurance etc. also had to be purchased, and 
     all of this had to be paid for up-front, before the event.
     
     3) The high police presence was mandated by the Oakland Police 
     department, and it was _very_ expensive. That's why there were lots of 
     cops there. But they were involved with this party from the beginning 
     and felt it was being run professionally. I would wager that Martin 
     will be able to throw another party in Oakland, because he has the 
     respect of the City Manager, Fire Department and Police Department. 
     Now, I wonder if the same could be said of the people behind Cool World 
     ?
     
     4) While I was helping out at the space on Saturday, the catch-phrase 
     for the production crew was "Safety First". Nothing was left to 
     chance. _No-one_ was allowed to take a risk that would compromise 
     crowd safety or could allow a vigilant fire marshall to shut the party 
     down. Any rules mandated by the Fire Department and Police Department 
     were followed to the letter. For instance, the sound could've been 
     better in the techno room if the speaker stacks had been positioned 
     differently. But the Fire Department guidelines were that the stacks 
     were to be placed such and such apart, with little room for partygoers 
     to get behind the stacks. Those conditions were met. Security guards 
     were posted at those locations to make sure no-one got in there. 
     Another example, the vertical poles which crossed the floor in the 
     House room had to be marked out or illuminated in some way to a height 
     of 10 feet. They were, without exception. Another example: Smoking was 
     not allowed inside the location, and was allowed only outside in 
     certain areas. Lyons security enforced this patiently and courteously. 
     Another example: The Police Department said : No Alcohol. So everyone 
     was searched, and no-one, including DJ's (from one of whom it was 
     confiscated) was allowed to bring alcohol into the space.
     
     5) I picked up the lights from the rental agency in SF and while 
     there, I asked what other business this lighting company did. The guy 
     who was working there and helping me said "We do mostly corporate 
     events. We used to do a lot more raves, but not any more. Very few 
     parties still put the level of production into their events that 
     Martin does".
     
     6) Anyone I spoke to on Saturday night, including the Police 
     department, were very pleased with the party. $25 is a lot of money, 
     but a) the party was very well-organized to a high professional 
     standard. b) it did not get busted because nothing was left to chance. 
     Would SFRavers rather go to a party that cost $15 but the organizers 
     are so foolish or knavish or disorganized that they don't even pay for 
     the right permits ? Or allow the Fire department to shut them down 
     because they block fire exits and don't have assured firelanes through 
     the parking lot ?
     
     7) Martin is currently setting up a web-site, through v-site.net. As 
     of last week, his e-mail address is martin@choice.communion.com. I'm 
     sure he would welcome constructive comments, because he believes that 
     only by being professional and guaranteeing people a good, bust-free 
     time will this scene prosper. And if anyone has suggestions as to how 
     to make the experience more fun or safer, I'm sure he'd be glad to 
     hear.
     
     Lastly, I left the party at 5am (v. tired). I heard before I left (but 
     haven't confirmed) that bottled water had run out. I believe that 
     there was still a water source from mains taps, but we should all be 
     aware of how a constant drain on a mains water source can cause a 
     steep water pressure drop, which can be followed by the mains water 
     supply failing.
     
     So if this did in fact occur.. It is something that just should not happen, 
     period. No excuses are good enough. We all know the risks of 
     heat-exhaustion in the scene. This has happened at his parties in the past 
     when bigger crowds than expected turnout, and I've brought it up more than 
     once with Martin myself. He feels the same as I on this, that organizers 
     have a high-level of responsibility for partygoers in this area. I shall 
     personally endeavor to make sure it will not recur.

Hello all of you out there in e-mail land! Boy, I just finished 
finals...unfortunatly I couldnt make the gathereing...but I am really 
glad to hear that so many people had a great time. I have been reading 
all of the posts regarding the $25 dollar price on the party, i just 
wanted to throw out my 2 cents here, and a few neat ideas to play with 
and maybe we can build a stronger family foundation. Because the more we 
take care of eachother...the stronger our foundation and solidarity 
becomes, then when the  media/money/superstar dj  ->evil trys to 
break into what we have going here we will be able to get through.
	enough with my philosophical drive...
	
	Yes, i think that $25 is alot of money to pay for a one night 
party...but then it sounds like it was a great party, and a quality 
party. This is what I think is most important. I dont know firsthand, but 
it sounds like Martin has a reputation for well thought out and quality 
parties. This skill and level of caring is something that can not be 
bought. A sweet ambience and vibe is priceless and must be cultured 
through careful planning and caring. 
	Also, I have  some experience with throwing parties, smaller 
ones, but I have had to deal with insurance policies, city councils, nazi 
neighborhood organizations. It is not fun and it is very frustrating at 
times. Obviously Martins time should be included in the breakdown for the 
party. 

	Not to go over old ground continuously, I would like to throw out 
some suggestions, What bothers me the most is the fact that some people 
may not be able to go because the price is too much. Someone that may be 
the butterfly to cause a vibe storm in the crowd! I would like to 
brainstorm on ways to get around this... The promoter MUST be able to 
make money to live on as well as to invest in the future of the 
scene...but how can this be reconciled with the idea that there are some 
people that may not have enough money to get in...but are just as 
essential to the vibe and community...

	-how about promises to help clean up in return for a discount...
	-how3 about discounts for KICK-ASS costumes!!
	-how about setup crews...if you REALLY want to come to this party 
and cant afford it show up early and help set the party up...even if you 
think thsat they might get in the way givve a wall to paint with glow in 
the dark paints...anything!

	Peace and love in your hearts...and MERRY uhh whoops...
		!!! HAPPY HOLIDAYS!!!!
-Hierophant

BY YOUR COMMAND;

        This was ****MY***** experience at the Gathering, just the facts;

        Got into a SHORT line:
        (12:50AM)

        Entered a building with over 7000 people in it, according to
Martin's security.
        (1:00AM)

        Paid $50.00 for my friend & I.
        (1:01AM)

        Run into 3 separtate groups of friends with in minutes.
        (1:05AM)

        Became totally overwhelmed by the Rock Concert Like Number of People.
        (1:15AM)

        Went outside:
        (1:25AM)

        Decided to leave, after mutally deciding that we did not want to
risk getting              separtated due to the large numbers.
        (1:35AM)

        On the way out I was accidentally elbowed in the groin by two
children running 
        through the crowd. *~ <
        (1:45AM)

        I got up off the ground after making violent retching noises *~  |.
        (1:55AM)

        Was throughly taken care of by my girlfreind on the way back to Kevin's.
        (2:05AM) = >

        So when's Friend's Family, Chryilsis, Frequency 8, FMR, Cyberlab, or
New Moon going to have another party?

From: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)
Subject: my own review
To: SFRAVES@HYPERREAL.COM
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Hey!

Well in spite of the price, I had a GREAT time!!  Everything was 
killer, great space, not so hot & stuff that I couldn't breath, good 
bathroom access, some killer DJs, and the vibe was great!  Everybody 
was in great spirits, very friendly.  More than once I would run into 
somebody I'd never met before, and within seconds my hand would be 
grabbed and I'd be dragged off to the chill-room to hang out with them! 
(hi, you're shawna? I'm so & so!  come hang out with us!) I love 
massive amounts of friendly people (meaning the percentage of friendly 
people compared to the total number of people), it makes all the 
difference in the world to me.  I got to meet lots of sfravers finally 
(& I finally got my laminte!) which was very cool, one of them even 
recognized me from my description (Hi Marty!), I didn't see a single 
fight or "potentially negative" situation.  Ethan was much fun to watch 
dj, he really got me going!  Anybody hear Spun's intro with Cheech & 
Chong?  Fuckin wacky!  That really tripped everybody out who saw what 
it was that was playing! Stayed till 7:30, only missed that very last 
song that was played after the silent moment.  Never really spent too 
much time in one spot for any real length of time, it was a very 
migratory evening all in all.  Liked the chill-room (with the exception 
of the spilled water, & could've used more pillows!) and the exploded 
feather pillow was a cool toy, lots of nifty people to hang out with in 
there.  I've got to remember to bring more stuff to give next time, so 
many people offered me water, candy, fruit, groovy little nifties, etc, 
and I had nothing to give them!  I left my bag of apples & jolly 
ranchers in the car by accident :(   Oh well, I'll make up for it next 
time! 

I'm so glad that an event this huge was pulled off so successfully, 
thank you to all the people who worked so hard & for so long to make 
the incredible show happen, and thank you to all the wonderful people 
who showed up & made the incredible vibe happen!

Love 
shawna

Dear Black Adder,

	I like Martin, and I've enjoyed the Gatherings I've been to, 
although unfortunately I wasn't at this one. 
	Sometimes I think you're too cynical.  But not this time.  I 
think you're right to ask for an accounting of where the money went.  
Power corrupts, and it's people like you who will hopefully keep the 
promoters in our scene true to the spirit of the rave community. 
	I don't think it's too much to ask how much of the money from a 
party is going to charity, if a party is billed as benefiting charity.  I 
don't even think it's too much to ask for a complete breakdown of 
expenses, specific enough to be verifiable for anyone inclined to check.
	After all, if these are "our" parties collectively, and not just 
the promoters', shouldn't we take all take an interest in the "bottom 
line"?  I think such a move would go some ways toward ending the 
"producer-consumer relationship" that prevents us coming together more 
closely as a community, and so I join with Black Adder and others in 
asking all promoters who care about the scene to show that you trust and 
respect us, and open your books.

On Mon, 18 Dec 1995 blkadder@value.net wrote:

From: Kyung Rok Lee <krok@uclink2.berkeley.edu>
Subject: the Gathering
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

A couple of thoughts about the Gathering:  GOOD and bad.  

The GOOD:  The music that entered my ears that night was VERY GOOD to 
EXCELLENT.  The highlight for me was a 45-minute stretch of Doran's set 
that really lifted people off their feet (i had spent the previous time 
pleasantly rocking out to Spun's funky breaks).  Please, let's get him 
out here more often.  I spent most of my time in the harder room, which 
I found to have a somewhat older crowd and a somewhat tighter vibe (there 
is a correlation here, but not one of direct causality).  Well, soon after 
Doran's set, I got _elevated and then lost my objectivity, which was fine 
with me ;).  Surpisingly good vibe at this party.  

The Bad:  Ok, you can kinda come to expect a lot of random acts at a 
party that brings together so many random people.  If things go right, 
these random acts will be ones of kindness and good will.  Unfortunately,
there are other types of random acts.  Although I don't believe in kharma,
I hope that all those people who were cutting in line will have to go to 
the DMV sometime soon and have to wait really long, and then get bumped to
the end of the line for some random reason ;).  I do what I can to hold
these selfish people accountable by looking at them in the eyes -- 
unfortunately, I don't have 100 eyes.  Actually, I could have used an extra
pair of eyes to keep my eyes on my backpack as well as that of a friend.  
They were stolen midway into the night, but we are both strong enough (and, 
perhaps, jaded enough) to just forget about it, and go on having a good 
time.  Yeah, I took my chances by not checking it in, but as many of you 
know, there are things in backbacks that we ocassionally need to call upon, 
toke upon, eat, drink, and keep you warm outside.

So in closing, if there were any trippers out there who were so high that 
they accidentily walked off with a black Trager and a black Jansport 
backpack thinking that they were magical turtle shells capable of turning 
one into a ninja turtle... yeah, right ;).

Stay positive - Rok.

BY YOUR COMMAND;

        First, a excerpt & reprint from the holiday issue of XLR8R on MDMA-3:

       " MDMA-3(4-Methylenedioxymethamphetamine)

                Commonly known as "Ecstasy", the ***psychedelic**, known for
the way it dissolves the boundaries between people, needs no introduction in
the rave world. Legal since 1985, MDMA was tried by millions either on the
advice of psychologists or by enthusiastic partiers in Texas(God Bless Their
Little Souls) & elsewhere who discovered it to be a safe & legal alternative
to alcohol & cocaine."

        ?, I feel kinda uninformed I never knew MDMA was in the drug class
of the psychedelics, nor that it was legal until 1985, dat sucks. ?, or is
this a misprint.
Clarity from other factual verifiable sources would be appreciated, thanks.

        Ok, & next, hypothetically speaking, lets talk about the price of
MDMA, which I hear through the grape vine is going at the rate of $20/each
for those little 100mg powdered caps. Also, I hear that the powder in those
caps costs anywhere from $1600/oz to $3000/oz depending on who ya know, and
how good it is. But most average ravers need at least two for a average
night of fun(C+, B-, lets say to rate or scale them), that's at least
$40/night.  

        So the average dealer nets outta of an .oz about ((28.4 grams in a
.oz / 100mg/cap) * $20.00) = $5680.00. Of course, this person takes a lot of
risk, and in business, the size or amount of your profit should be directly
proportional to the level of risk you take on your initial investment,
right; haven't  lost anyone yet have I. Also, & note we haven' taken into
account those nice dealers that like to walk on their powder with Kitty
Tranquillizers, Speed, or something healthly like Vitumin B if they have a
conscious. Or the ones that sell caps filled with less than 100mg, or more
for than matter.

        Know suppose, & hypothetically speaking, you had a person that had a
superior MDMA product, a product so good the average raver could get off
initially on half a hit, or $10 worth of this MDMA. Were talking
Florida/East Coast MDMA for those of you I'm told are in the know. But this
product at $20/hit didn't have much of a profit magin in quanity, actually
much less than the powder. How would you feel if this person decided to sell
them at $25/hit. Also, & considering the info supplied through the grape
vine, that I hear in New York, good MDMA goes for $40/hit, Philadelphia $30
- $40/hit, Gainesville, FL. $30/hit.

        You would proablly thing that this person was a total scum bag, even
though the MDMA was better than anything you've ever had. So the ? I'm tring
to get answered is how much profit is appropreiate for a given amount of risk?

        Ok, and a slight change in topic. First, I would like to say I know
Martin of Communion personally, like him a lot, have worked for him as a
massage therapist, think & know what a HARD WORKING person he is. Would
proabily do anything for him that he asked me to, within reason. Because I
see an honest representation of who and what he is about. I prasied Vision,
a kick ass party at the Sound Factory for $11.00 if you got there early, and
was worth $20, I think even if you got there after 11PM. Some nameless
people, if you remember, complained about the price of admission to Vision,
which as a party, gave you more by far, than the Gathering, yet these same
nameless people praised the Gathering, please explain this sudden change of
heart.

        So you have a party for $25.00, it's very if not too expensive, this
I agree on,  this is why I'm asking this ?, and comparing to different forms
of bussiness, and comparing the actual response of people who attended a $25
party, to the projected responses to a hypothetical local increase in the
price of MDMA, a long with an increase in overall total quality of the MDMA.

        So I would be interested in hearing your links and responses to this
hypothetical situation, please do tell.

At 6:43 PM 12/18/95, ecto wrote:
>At 6:24 PM 12/17/95, Jondabomb@aol.com wrote:
>>Oh Kewl i get to give the first review! Ok, if you saw me, you were either
>>pissed cause i wouldn't let you in on the guest list, or because I was behind
>>the counter eating and not serving water! The music was slamming, the VIBE
>>WAS AWSOME!!! It was a really good party. I was the dude at the end who stood
>>up on the table and took pictures behind Doc, I had a toon town shirt on, and
>>blue jeans, I had brown hair(Still do) in a pony tail. I forgot my laminate,
>>anyway, I took like 30 pix, and I'll see if they will put them up on the web
>>site. I heard there was bunk E going around that was giving people rash's and
>>stuff,
>        That was probably Niacin, which is also white and can come in a
>pill, it causes your capillaries to rise to the surface of your skin
>(blushing sort of look) and you get really hot and somewhat itchy. Believe
>it or not, some ppl like to take it WITH e. (!) To each their own i guess
>:)
>        and yeah, i totally think that what comes around goes around ;)
>        brad

I bought four capsules of that stuff for my friend and I, and when it
started to kick in I felt like my head was right under a heat lamp. First
in my head, then it spread down to my arms, then my legs. My skin flet
splotchy or prickly like goosebumps but I was *burning up*! Then I felt
like I was going to pass out, so I sat down for a few minutes. It scared
the hell out of me! I splashed water on my face to try to cool myself down
and it all went away. Elapsed time was 15 minutes to 30 minutes in all.

I have E quite a few times, but nothing has ever made me feel like that did
and nothing ever came on in a way that I thought I would pass out. Ever.

So I went back to the guy selling it and told him it was shit. He denied
anyone else had complained, but I got him to buy back the other two hits we
didn't take. I should have told him to give us back the rest of the $$$
too, but I was still kinda shaken and didn't think of it at the time.

The only reason that I even bought from him at all was that I had seen him
selling at Wicked party at King Street earlier this month. While I was
standing next to him by the stairs on the right side of the room, he
actually got shaken down by the security but he 'palmed' the drugs from his
front pocket and put it in his back pocket after they searched there and
when they looked in his front pockets all they found were gobs and gobs of
$20 bills. They were really mad that they couldn't find any of his drugs
and We talked a little about it and we were both quite amused by the whole
thing.

Next time I see him I am going to tell him to give me back the rest of the
$$$ we spent on his crap.

I thought that the Gathering was an amazing party.  The security was 
cool, the cops were even decent.  The space was *huge*.  The people were 
nice, had a lot of people come up and talk to me without me talking to 
them first.  The music was slamming, those walls of speakers were 
ridiculous.  The energy and the vibe was so right on, even with a very 
large, very diverse group of people.  I just kept thinking that this 
could never happen (on this scale) in L.A.(where I moved here from:().  
At one point my boyfriend and I were trying to figure out(from the price 
and the amount of people there) how much the party was raking in.  We 
came to a pretty large sum and said GOOD, they deserve it.  The Gathering 
was worth saving up for. This is all IMHO.

*Cheers*  Looking forward to the next happening that even comes close to 
the Gathering,

Cami

Subject: Re: Don't flame(Gathering)

At 6:31 PM 12/18/95, Starchild wrote:
>Dear Black Adder,
>
>        I like Martin, and I've enjoyed the Gatherings I've been to,
>although unfortunately I wasn't at this one.
>        Sometimes I think you're too cynical.  But not this time.  I
>think you're right to ask for an accounting of where the money went.
>Power corrupts, and it's people like you who will hopefully keep the
>promoters in our scene true to the spirit of the rave community.
>        I don't think it's too much to ask how much of the money from a
>party is going to charity, if a party is billed as benefiting charity.  I
>don't even think it's too much to ask for a complete breakdown of
>expenses, specific enough to be verifiable for anyone inclined to check.
>        After all, if these are "our" parties collectively, and not just
>the promoters', shouldn't we take all take an interest in the "bottom
>line"?  I think such a move would go some ways toward ending the
>"producer-consumer relationship" that prevents us coming together more
>closely as a community, and so I join with Black Adder and others in
>asking all promoters who care about the scene to show that you trust and
>respect us, and open your books.

I have a problem with this. This was a for-profit venture. The only talk of
charity was the toys donation, nothing was ever mentioned of money being
donated. What we did know was that it would be a massive, it had an
all-star lineup, and as far as massives go, The Gathering is different in
that it is all above-board and there was a way higher chance of this party
having a much, much better vibe that most of us find as massives. And it
was true, this party was unlike any large party I have ever gone to. There
was a vibe there that I have never found at a party that size. That
definitely differentiates it from any other $20/$25 party of any size that
I have gone to in recent memory.

If I put the tens of thousands of dollars on the line for this party, I
would hope and expect to make a good profit off of it. I am an
entreprenuer, so I understand the concept of risks and rewards relating to
business ventures. This was a business venture. Martin (and his company)
deserve to be potentially (and actually) rewarded for risking their $$$ to
put this party on. Martin was not the only person to profit from the party.
Other people working this party were paid for their time (lights, lasers,
sound, DJs, etc.) yet I don't hear their name being taken in vain. It seems
the only 'evil' that ever gets talked about in our scene (and yes, I have
done it before too, but lately I have been trying to walk a mile in the
shoes of those I used to critisize, and it's changing my attitude
immensely) are the promoters, but when it comes to a party, large or small,
money losing or incredibly profitable, everybody has their hand out for
$$$, and the promoter is the one paying everybody for everything.

I will not critisize a party in the future re: $$$ as long as the party is
delivered as expected and that the paying party-goers got a good value for
their $$$. Of course, this is a lot different than a story where people
drop their $20 and don't get anything for it (i.e. a 100% party-stopper
like the Kundalini bust last month that forced everybody out in the street
at 1:30am).

The Gathering cost $20 + toy or $25, but everybody that I talked to that
dropped their cash + toy or cash felt like they got what they paid for.

This leads me to believe that Martin and company deserve whatever $$$ they
took home after the bills were paid. Yes it was capitalistic, but damn, he
also delivered the goods!

-wdc

On Mon, 18 Dec 1995, Geoff White wrote:

> It is fine for you to have your beliefs but make sure when you speak
> "facts" that you get them straight.  As far as the spirit of raving is 
> concerned, that can occure at a $50 party or at a free party, it's what
> the participants bring with them not what they pay that creates this spirit.
> 
> I don't understand why someone will pay $20 for a hit of E, $10 for a 2 
> hour movie, $25 for a lift ticket, but can't pay $25 to a person
> who is trying to do the right thing.

YEAH!!!!!! :) :) :)
I'm sitting here in Nevada kicking at the computer table, just wishin' 
that I could have been there, only to read these gripey why-so-much reviews.
I would gladly have paid *way* more than that, and would have if you 
include gas, lodging, etc. 

SF has the best vibe (aside from Burning Man ;) and you guys don't even 
appreciate it!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

In the words of Richard Bach... "Anyone you want to keep in your life, 
*never* take them for granted."

We did that in Reno, and now we have a party about every two or three months.

If you take our scene for granted, it *will* DISAPPEAR.

					lv, Alex


viva | Alexandra Crocket  | "Reality is anything 
plur | alex_c@scs.unr.edu |  you can get away with"

Subject: Re: Don't flame(Gathering)
Cc: Jondabomb@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I know this issue is getting stretched out, but two things:

Could everyone PLEASE refrain from re-quoting entire posts when you reply?
There is *no need for it*.  Yes, it is easy to do with some mail programs.
I am going to say this straight out: it is impolite and annoying and
causes me not to value the response as highly as I might.  'Nuff said.

Second, this to Black Adder.  If you're so sure Martin and his team made
off with buckets of gold from the Gathering, why don't you propose a
quick budget to show how that is the case?  Space, security, permits,
advertising, DJs, sound, lights, porta-potties, etc.  Add it up and
tell me what you think.

Then let's see if it's close to reality.  Martin has previously posted
some info about his budgets, if I recall correctly, which to me is just
amazing.  This is like your local corner market or music store or
restaurant putting their financials in the window.  There are good 
reasons not to do so.

Nevertheless, the broad outlines of the cost structure for a party of
this size can be guessed.  I think many people would be surprised a
t the cost of three items in particular: space, security and advertising.
Each one can easily amount to $5,000 or more just for a one-off event.
At even $25 a head, that represents 200 people in the door paying full
rate just to pay each of those costs (I don't know the specifics of
this particular Gathering, but I bet I'm not far off).  There are lots
more costs, and you have crew and yourself to repay as well.  Assuming
100 to 200 hours of work to pull off a party (including the schmooze
time you have to put in to spread the word), even if you pay yourself
diddly that starts to add up.  In the meantime your rent has to be
paid, gas for the car or bus fare, the phone (yow!) and advance payments
or deposits for much of the party's needs, all before much if any money
comes in.

Lonnie has talked some about the general costs of putting on his larger
parties in Baltimore on dc-raves and ne-raves.  $30 to $40K is not an
absurd amount at all for a 2000 person event.  It's only because nearly
everything except the space is donated that we can do F&F for $5.
With these kinds of numbers, the margin between making some and losing
a lot -- let's say 1800 vs. 2500 admissions -- is not all that great,
and any number of factors can head you down the tubes financially,
including weather, other events, the phase of the moon, etc.  Of coursem,
when you pack the joint you can make some serious dough, as the Cool
World approach shows.  I'll have more to say about that in my next missive.

Anyway, take it from a (retired) Concert Executive: it's just as much a
gamble as the derivatives market :-)

phred

Yeah, so money was made.  Ok, but did you have a good time?  I did. Allthough
I'll only do Massives once or twice a year (mainly to keep from going poor,
and the loss of intimacy from the smaller venues)...

There are Underground ravers, Reneagade ravers, Klub kids, Bubblegum ravers
(love that term Larry),  Massive Ravers.  So who cares, I pay money to see
movies, buy records, CD's ect.. I support my community.  Hell, I even pay
money to events that I can get in for free.  Why, because firstly, I always
believed (and still do) that the best high is to help out your scene, your
community.  I help out who I can and have as much fun as I can as well...
I even bought a $10 toy just for the Gathering.  So am I a fool? Some will
say Yes. Some will say hell yea...  But in my heart I did a service and it is
that feeling that makes me sleep well at night.

Oh well, make of this what you will... Calculate your costs and revinues to
the prices associated with throwing this paticular rave... Just remind me to
sign off for a week after Cool World on New Years....

Um, in case it hasn't been obvious, I'd like to point out that the
reviews here have been at least 10 to one in praise of the Gathering.
This tendancy to label SFRavers as a bunch of whiners is way off the
mark.  Over the years, the people on this list have been some of the
biggest supporters and contributers to the SF scene.  There will always
be some who look for the negative, and this isn't always bad either.

Anyway, since it is public record, and Martin isn't here to defend
himself, I thought this 1.5 year old post from him might be of some
interest.  Please bear in mind that things may have changed since then
and that there were a lot of logistical differences between last
weekend's Gathering, and the 1994 July 4th Freedom Party.

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Date: Thu, 7 Jul 1994 08:22:27 -0700
Message-Id: <199407071522.IAA19506@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
From: choices@netcom.com (communion)
X-Sender: choices@netcom.com (Unverified)
Sender: sfraves-owner@techno.Stanford.EDU             


Hi all,

Thank you Ethan for pulling the needed response from me and for
your kind and inspiring words.  It is nice to communicate with 900? people
@ 0nce and hear your comments, criticisims etc.  Most of you seemed to
enjoy Freedom as did most of the people not on the net. That makes me happy
to say the least.  Still i have heard that it was to far to travel from
some people.  One thing i believe is we have to learn to travel great
distances. Not only in the way of miles to a party or festival as the House
Movement ( your comments taken into consideration ethan ) expands within
america, but also in the distance we have to travel into the depths of
depths of our inner selves.  This is nessacary to in order to love and
accept ourselves first, the world will follow in due course.  This is
something i struggle with on a daily basis, somedays a lot, some a little. 

I have put parties on for three years now, i have done them for
lots of different reasons over the years.....  For the love and happiness
that is created at them; for the boost to my ego; to satisfy my drive to be
the best at whatever i do; to create an enviornment where people are more
suseptable to achieve a higher state of consciousness; to bring people
together; for the money that can sometimes be made:  These are just some of
the reasons, but for the most part as i sit here now, reflecting, the main
reasons.  I think you would agree there are both good and bad reasons in
there.  You see, i am just a human being, i am no better or worse than any
of you.  I am just doing the best i can to make sense of whats going on
around me.  I see right, i see wrong, i see change.
On the subject of $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$, ken,

Freedom rave 94'

Space                   12,000
sound                    4,000
Security                 5,200
dj's                     5,500
promo                      900
laser                    1,000
visuals                  2,000
helpers                  1,500
cash and door people     1,800
clean up                   250
toilets                    750
lighting,                  700  ( to light certin areas )
insurance                  400
lighting, strobes etc      550
bus                        500
trucks                     250
misc                     2,000??
			________
Total                   39,100

these figures are off the top of my head, and are kinda rough, ok?
i hope this answers some questions, even though i know there will always be
questions, but that is good.
peace and love  martin





From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Dec 19 08:30:00 1995

From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: Well I loved it! :)
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

Precedence: bulk


The Gathering was worth the money....I walked around and saw all the work 
that had gone into decorating, and there was a really good vibe, and best 
of all the music was incredible.  The Dedication room took me hostige and 
I couldn't come out all night - I even missed Tony's set, which is a 
first for me.  Ethan, Doran, and Jon Williams' sets stand out in my mind.
I had heard about water running out, but I guess I was lucky.  Every time 
I needed a refill, it was available.

All these flame wars don't mean much to me - I had fun and got my money's 
worth.  End. Finis. Martin needs a large sum of money to even get 
something of that magnitude off the ground, so it's not like the profits 
are being "wasted".  Most of it probably goes into the next party.  Kudos 
to Martin and the rest who put it on.  :)

love,
Amy

On Mon, 18 Dec 1995, Starchild wrote:

> 
> Dear Black Adder,
> 
> 	I like Martin, and I've enjoyed the Gatherings I've been to, 
> although unfortunately I wasn't at this one. 
> 	Sometimes I think you're too cynical.  But not this time.  I 
> think you're right to ask for an accounting of where the money went.  
> Power corrupts, and it's people like you who will hopefully keep the 
> promoters in our scene true to the spirit of the rave community. 
> 	I don't think it's too much to ask how much of the money from a 
> party is going to charity, if a party is billed as benefiting charity.  I 
> don't even think it's too much to ask for a complete breakdown of 
> expenses, specific enough to be verifiable for anyone inclined to check.
> 	After all, if these are "our" parties collectively, and not just 
> the promoters', shouldn't we take all take an interest in the "bottom 
> line"?  I think such a move would go some ways toward ending the 
> "producer-consumer relationship" that prevents us coming together more 
> closely as a community, and so I join with Black Adder and others in 
> asking all promoters who care about the scene to show that you trust and 
> respect us, and open your books.

You're right, I am too cynical some times. We all have our crosses to bear.
Thank you for defining my point of view and desire, in a much less 
confrontational manner. 

                                               Black Adder

MAD.... A tasty little groove last night.

The venue is a bar/catina which was a nice size for the number of people 
that showed up (50-75.) Free water. Nice crowd. The sound system was a 
little overdriven. But oh what it was driving.... NICE NICE change of 
pace. Music was great. Electro and some Detroit? stuff from Jon Santos, 
and some nice techno courtesy of Joe Rice(forgive if I am not up on my 
styles.) Not at all what I was expecting... Good stuff guys.... Well 
worth the $1 cover over and over.

                                              Black Adder

At 7:59 PM 12/18/95, Wayne D. Correia wrote:

>I bought four capsules of that stuff for my friend and I, and when it
>started to kick in I felt like my head was right under a heat lamp. First
>in my head, then it spread down to my arms, then my legs. My skin flet
>splotchy or prickly like goosebumps but I was *burning up*! Then I felt
>like I was going to pass out, so I sat down for a few minutes. It scared
>the hell out of me! I splashed water on my face to try to cool myself down
>and it all went away. Elapsed time was 15 minutes to 30 minutes in all.
        Yep, that's niacin! No mistaking that :( Last new years this girl
came up to me and offered a 'vitamin' randomly to me. Now, you can take
things one of two ways: paranoia or pronoia. So, thinking that raves were a
place where one COULD take candy from strangers i took half of it and had
the same reaction. Later i went up to her and politely told her what it was
and that it potentially could ruin someone's night, so make sure to keep
that in mind! THere are a lot of strange people out there who have their
own ideas about 'contributing to the vibe' some of which i just don't get.
Now, if someone is SELLING this stuff, especially as something that it's
not, then i have a problem with that.
        I think that this type of thing is perpetuted by people who 'just
don't get it' about raves. THey bring their ideas of capitalist exchange
and all that in from 'the real world' thinking that it's applicable. Now,
we do live within a capitalist society but, hopefully, profit motivation
and the value of money in general is going to be seen as a really
unimportant compared to a larger understanding about happiness and power
and how we all relate. I still don't  understand it when i hear about E
dealers fighting for territory, or selling shit for profit. I mean, have
they DONE the stuff (not to imply that i HAVE ;).
        well for those who 'get it' be happy, and realize that it's your
obligation to politely inform others about your realizations in the most
empathetic and pursuasive way.
        To jump topics for a bit, a friend of mine just mailed me a copy of
the "Feel" zine that, coincidentally, Martin O'Brien is partially
responsible for and, well, i dunno how you could go all out and dis someone
who is involved with something as cool and positive as this. I mean, like
Dianne said, we're all human but this zine is definitely not the product of
greed in my eyes :)
        peace,
                brad

========================/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\======================

              >> ecto@magnet.ca >> http://www.magnet.ca/~ecto >>

Ok, thanks to y'alls help I found a place to get orange coveralls (they 
can even stick yer name on it for you!).

A few people asked me to post info I got, so here it is:

Wear Guard Clothing:
(800) 672 4070 - Customer service - for general info on products
(800) 388 3300 - to order

long sleeve heavy duty twill coveralls are item #316 and cost $37.99
(i dunno if this is expensive, but i was getting it as a gift, and this 
was the only place i found that had them)
short sleeve coveralls are item #1305, and i don't know how much they cost

for an extra $3.95 the can put yer name on it in either script or block 
style letters, in a variety of colors...

obrave:
check out dieselboy's new tape...totally awesome, jungle/breaks kinda 
stuff. a little on the mellow side, but you don't get music like this out 
here at all!!

also, anyone been to the TOP on saturdays? i hear it's some sort of 
jungle night that's really starting to take off....any info?

-John

On Mon, 18 Dec 1995, Brian Darkness wrote:

>         Ok, and a slight change in topic. First, I would like to say I know
> Martin of Communion personally, like him a lot, have worked for him as a
> massage therapist, think & know what a HARD WORKING person he is. Would
> proabily do anything for him that he asked me to, within reason. Because I
> see an honest representation of who and what he is about. I prasied Vision,
> a kick ass party at the Sound Factory for $11.00 if you got there early, and
> was worth $20, I think even if you got there after 11PM. Some nameless
> people, if you remember, complained about the price of admission to Vision,
> which as a party, gave you more by far, than the Gathering, yet these same
> nameless people praised the Gathering, please explain this sudden change of
> heart.

I don't see you can say "... Vision, which as a party, gave you more by
far, than the Gathering..." That is just rediculous. There was no
comparison at all.  Vision was a decent party, but raves like the
Gathering just don't come around that often, period.  $25 IS alot of
money, and normally I would never pay that, but as most everyone I've seen
post seems to agree, it was money *very* well spent. 

Andy


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Dec 19 12:36:45 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA28130; Tue, 19 Dec 1995 12:36:45 -0800
Received: from thestranger.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA28076; Tue, 19 Dec 1995 12:36:35 -0800
Received: from [199.238.224.10] by thestranger.com
 with SMTP (MailShare 1.0fc6); Tue, 19 Dec 1995 12:37:01 -0800
Message-Id: <v02140509acfcaf55e909@[199.238.224.10]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 19 Dec 1995 12:34:07 -0700
To: nw-raves@hyperreal.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com, z2013@speakeasy.org
From: tigger@thestranger.com (Glenn)
Subject: Transmissions From Quantum Time: A message for the new year/era
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Life, and all that it has to offer can sometimes be overwhelming.  The
deluge of information, events, experiences, desires and needs can sometimes
lead one to withdraw, to be reactionary instead of responsive.  In an
overwhelmed state, we find it easier to lash out than to reach out.
Sometimes seeming to define one's world through the filters of criticism
and cynicism (for one's self as well as others) instead encouragement and
praise (again, for one's self as well as others).   And through this flood,
it is sometimes forgotten that we, within ourselves have the power and
means to transcend the deluge, to shape our own world, to be able to
channel that unrelenting force into constructive avenues that can nurture
the world around us instead of destroy it.  Little do we realize that at
times, the first to bear the brunt of the destructive energy that we
sometimes harness, are our own souls.

It is through dance that I have found transcendance.  Music has taught me
how to fly using wings I never knew I had. Lifting me above the seemingly
relentless tides of time and change.  It is through music and dance that my
soul is free to soar amongst the heavens and inner dimensions, allowing a
clearer view into the nature of the world that I am creating around me
(allowing a clearer view of us). It is there that I am able to discern the
path to consciousness, that seemingly elusive inner light which is often
dimmed by the trials we face on a daily basis.  For now, the light is there
for me, the path illuminated.  I shall follow it again.

We stand at the threshold of a new era.  A new range of dimensions and
possibilities.  I invite you all to take my hand and join me as we move
forward to dance brothers and sisters, dance.

Peace, Love and Happy Holidays to you all!

Love

Tigger

Mime-Version: 1.0

To: solo@IslandNet.com (solo), sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)

X-Mailer: <Windows Eudora Version 2.0.2>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Thank you all once again for the wonderful messages of love and support you
sent for my friend Alex.  Some of you asked to be informed of how he is
doing, so here goes.  He pulled through the surgery ok, but while in it, his
lung collapsed.  He has recovered from the surgery and the collaps fairly
well.  I went and visited him yesterday, and although he is weak, he may be
allowed to return home on Wednesday :) :)  I brought some bongo drums, my
didjerido, and a Tibetan bowl to the hospital and we struck up a little jam
session.  (he's a drummer)  It was incredibly beautiful to see him playing
the drums again.  He played very simply and lighly for about ten minutes,
and almost everyone in the room joined in by tapping thier feet or knocking
out a rhythm on the arms of the chairs.  He looked more at peace during that
session than he's been since he entered the hospial.  It was a very
spiritual experience.  I also gave him copies of all of your posts so he can
read them himself.  He is really grateful to all of you, and so am I.  Thank
you once again for your time and energy.

Love,

Rick
