Thank you all once again for the wonderful messages of love and support you
sent for my friend Alex.  Some of you asked to be informed of how he is
doing, so here goes.  He pulled through the surgery ok, but while in it, his
lung collapsed.  He has recovered from the surgery and the collaps fairly
well.  I went and visited him yesterday, and although he is weak, he may be
allowed to return home on Wednesday :) :)  I brought some bongo drums, my
didjerido, and a Tibetan bowl to the hospital and we struck up a little jam
session.  (he's a drummer)  It was incredibly beautiful to see him playing
the drums again.  He played very simply and lighly for about ten minutes,
and almost everyone in the room joined in by tapping thier feet or knocking
out a rhythm on the arms of the chairs.  He looked more at peace during that
session than he's been since he entered the hospial.  It was a very
spiritual experience.  I also gave him copies of all of your posts so he can
read them himself.  He is really grateful to all of you, and so am I.  Thank
you once again for your time and energy.

Love,

Rick

Subject: Bogus ppl in our midst
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

After reading the posts about the Gathering, and pondering some of the
questionable behavior i.e. in ecto's post:

>        I think that this type of thing is perpetuted by people who 'just
>don't get it' about raves. THey bring their ideas of capitalist exchange
>and all that in from 'the real world' thinking that it's applicable. Now,
>we do live within a capitalist society but, hopefully, profit motivation
>and the value of money in general is going to be seen as a really
>unimportant compared to a larger understanding about happiness and power
>and how we all relate. I still don't  understand it when i hear about E
>dealers fighting for territory, or selling shit for profit.

And about backpacks and jackets getting stolen. I think that I'd have to
agree. These people just don't get it. I think the difficult thing is that
ravers want to keep an open venue.... accept and love each other regardless
of race, creed, or religion. So what CAN we do about it? Keeping out the
'undesireables' is out of the ravers' creed of unconditional acceptance, is
it not?

I'd like to, if I may, take a different approach to these dealings. Having
a place where you can go and not have to worry about your possessions, your
body, your emotions, or being judged, or cheated is extremely idealistic. I
believe that a good rave with the right people and the proper vibe comes as
close to this type of an atmosphere as one can hope to find. I do however,
believe that humanity has quite a long way to go before this type of
atomsphere could be unequivocally achieved.

Wonderfully idealistic?      Yes...

Something to strive for?     Definitely...

Realistic?     Sadly...      No...

I would like to share a little something that I learned from an excellent
book written by Dan Millman.

The book is entitled "Way of the Peaceful Warrior," and it is about how a
very wise man, Socrates, opens Dan Millman's eyes to his very 'foolish'
ways of living. The term itself - Peaceful Warrior is paradoxical. Here we
have one side who wants, harmony, love, joy, happiess, acceptance.... and
another side with the will to battle, to defend, and to conquer. Put these
two opposites together, and you have a living paradox.... a warrior who
fights for peace.

It is not enough that a person has the right intentions... it is not enough
that he is loving, wants to make a difference and do the right thing. He
must also carry the warrior instinct to voice and to enforce his ideals. Do
you want an atmosphere of safety? Fight for it!

Fight the bogus 'e' dealers ;(. If you like to e, find a trusted,
guaranteed source. Pre-buy your e and take it to the rave with you.

Fight theft ;(. You SHOULDN'T have to do this, I agree. But it is a reality
that you NEED to do this... from now on at least 1 person keep an eye on
everyone's belongings. Alternate dancing if you need to. You can even stay
close to the person watching the stuff. Think of creative ways to keep it
in tact. You'd have to do this anywhere else. It's not real cool that you
have to do this at a rave, but I wouldn't want to lose $200.00 worth of my
stuff because of the way I WANTED something to be, in respect to the way
things really were.

That is all for now.

Take care.

Love,

Sean

P.S. Had a blast at the Gathering. Hope I get to meet some of you at the
next                                                 party ! :)

Received: from aoaioxxysz.organic.com (localhost [127.0.0.1]) by aoaioxxysz.organic.com (8.7.3/8.6.12) with ESMTP id OAA23527 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 19 Dec 1995 14:15:10 -0800 (PST)

To: San Francisco Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: MaD rocked it...
Date: Tue, 19 Dec 1995 14:15:09 -0800
From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@organic.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


With all of the great, cheap weeklies we have going on in this town, we
almost don't need raves anymore! While I always enjoy MaD (when I can make
it :( ), last night's was particularly great. I got there just in time to
hear Jeff Taylor kicking off his set (unfortunately meaning that I missed
Jon's no doubt excellent set) and might as well have been nailed to the
dancefloor for the next hour or so. _Excellent_ tune selection on his part,
and the kind of tunes I almost never hear in San Francisco (I particularly
dug the Spiral Tribe tune he put down). After Jeff finished, Joe got up and
put down some more than decent tracks (including one of two songs by Speedy
J that I actually like!) and generally put on an inspired performance. Well
wicked.

I also appreciated the opportunity to hang out with various folks and
chat. MaD is always such a friendly, social affair, and it was cool to talk
to Wayne, Vince, Jon Drukman, Jon Santos (and his bewildering panoply of
multimedia geek friends), Fixer, and Jeff Taylor (and to loan Brian D my pen
:). All in all, it was a wonderful way to kick off the week, and I look
forward to MaD's return in the new year!

yrz,
ozy

ozymandias G desiderata      ogd@organic.com       Ravers Suck Our Sound
(415)284-6888     http://www.organic.com/Staff/ogd/       ::AOAIOXXYSZ::

> 

>         Are there any ethical business guildlines that suggest what an
> appropreiate profit margin would be for a given level of risk?

	I think the basic idea is that over time, between wins and losses, you 
end up with a reward commensurate with your talent and labor.  There are 
economic systems that say otherwise but this is my opinion.  The fact is that 
the promoter has to be motivated or he/she won't take the risk.

	Isn't this a bit obvious?  Hasn't Martin lost money in the past?  Only 
one person mentioned that (something outdoors, bad weather?), and it didn't seem 
to have much effect on the flamefest...  I know that when many promoters start 
out, before they know the ropes well, they lose lots... sort of an initiation 
fee...  Now what I consider unscrupulous is when somebody cons someone else into 
taking the risk, and keeps the reward themselves...

Andrew

BY YOUR COMMAND;

        I was brought up to believe that if you have a problem with another
human being, you talked with them about it face to face; not over the
telephone, not through e-mail. Anything less, is not human communication. I
tired of the uninformed, clueless, and ignorant taking pot shots at me from
afar, you have something negative to say to me, you say it to my face, I'm
very accessable. If you can't, please keep it to yourself, that's it. 

        Excuse me for being human, but I'm more than just a post on your
terminal, please remember that, next time your about to flame me. 

        This is why my numbers are on every sig, call me I would love to
meet you and talk with you, like adults do, when they have problems with one
another.

        If you publiclly flame me, be prepared for me to do the same to you.
An eye for an eye, is unfortuately the only way a lot of us learn what is
exceptable behaviour. If you send be a private post; over a public network;
which is negative, be prepared for me to post it publically. You are now
aware of how I deal with my e-mail, so don't be surprised.

Sin,

I was wondering where the dj is housed during a radio rave.  Can he/she see
the croud to be able to interact with the vibe.  It would be nice to have
the dj right there with all the people, but he/she would need a monitor, and
if it was kept low enough I guess it wouldn't pose a problem.  The boom
boxes couldn't be used as monitors because of the time lag to send the
signal through the transmitter and what not would screw up the mixes.  Any
thoughts?  

I love the concept of using walkmans for a totally silent party.  Everyone
with nice quality headphones and walkmans groovin in silence.  Couldn't ya
just see a couple a hundred people dancing *legally* in a public park in the
middle of the night, the cops would be pissed. ::::)))))

Let me know if you know how the dj logistics would work.

No flame wars:  this is my last post about this.

>> Why did you post this info, anyhow, Brian?
>        I'm tried of my freinds on this list getting ripped off

OK, I can handle that, and respect it.  I'm not against drug information.
I support the hyperreal archives and all like that.  But it gives me
the creeps to be reading about something that's X parts E, Y parts
"synthetic mesc", and Z parts filler.  It sounds, to me, like a
witches' brew, and that provoked my cynical reaction that was at least
partially unwarranted.

>How do you know this is Brian Darkness,
>who is Brian Darkness, is this him, or just someone using his account, is
>this real information, or just lies.

As you rightly point out, I have no idea.  And that's all my post was
saying:  your information, posted openly to this list, is not useful.
I don't know that it's actually you posting it, I don't know anything
about what "white light" looks like or smells like or whether what
you're describing matches what someone else might try to sell me.  
In order for me to believe what your post said about what's in
white light, I have to believe that it really is you, trustworthy Brian
Darkness, who posted that info.  And as you yourself just pointed out, I
DON'T KNOW THAT!

I know you are doing good stuff for our scene, Brian.  But I question
whether  you couldn't have done just as well by saying "I have some hard
data on White Light.  If you want to know more, get in touch with me."
Doing this education over the net is not trustworthy enough, I don't
think.

No insults, just opinions....

Rob Jellinghaus		robj@best.com

From: eric@nit.AirTouch.COM (Eric Pederson)
Message-Id: <9512200050.AA17274@nit.AirTouch.COM>
Subject: the gathering
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SF Ravers List)
Date: Tue, 19 Dec 1995 16:50:10 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL17]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1943      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

just wanted to drop my 2c about the gathering..

- plenty of parking.  though it's close to BART, walking in that
  neighborhood is mighty sketchy (remember whoopi ball?)
- line to enter flowed very quickly.
- great space, killer space!!  incredible space!!!
- the music was outstanding, especially the techno room
- plenty of water... even when they ran out temporarily i found a hose
  outside.
- plenty of bathrooms.  if there was a line you could always
  walk a bit and find an empty one.  also, plenty of privacy
  inside the bathrooms.
- security was OK, saw lots of confiscations, but see above.
- big outdoor area to chill & cool down
- met some sfravers (geoff, amy, crunch) yay!  said yo to ozy.
- even though the testosterone level was mighty high, the vibe overruled.
  didn't see one fight at all.  that is amazing.  lots and lots of
  smiling happy ravers with luv phasers on kill.  i think one of
  the reasons that most of the kids were in the house room is they
  may have felt out of place with so many ravers going off in the other room.
- too many people sitting down in the middle of the floor, though
  not as bad as i've seen at other raves (esp. at all ages events)
- too many piles of personal crap in the middle of the floor.  if you
  don't want your shit ripped off or stepped on, don't leave it on the ground.
  (that's what coat checks are for).
- if they opened up that fence part by the water/juice bar, the traffic
  would have flowed better.

all in all, i had a great time.  i only like to do massives occasionally,
but this was a massive done right.

ps. i was the guy with shoulder length brown hair, black sweatshirt,
black pants, and pupils the size of dimes.  yeah, that guy..

pps. $25 is cheap for 10+ hours of entertainment.

cya next year,
-- 
Eric Pederson                                        AirTouch Communications
eric.pederson@airtouch.com                                      510-279-6185

Dear Rob & All;

        Thanks, I mean that = >. I don't have much patience for Flames or
negative posts. You wouldn't believe the amount of foul, nasty, trash I get
in my mailbox, from people on our list. People wonder why I'm negative &
harse sometimes. I understand I'm a very controversial character, as most
people in history where who tried to make change happen, or bring about
awareness. This position, that I chose to take, often places me in the line
of fire. I'm 33, and still wear my Kevlar Vest, but on the postive side,
it's taught me how to defend myself, and how to get at the truth, & the
factual reality, if I chose to accept them.

        Like I said in other posts, there are days when I approach divinity,
and others when I can't see my hand in front of my face because I'm blinded
by my own darkness(pride, ignorance, arrogance ...etc darkness......)

        I would sincerely like to apologize for my use of profanity, but
your message was like the 4th or 5th one I've had to deal with so far this
week, and it's the holidays ta boot. But nonetheless, sorry = >.

        I think, this includes myself, that we all need to take a deep
breath, maybe two, and give each other a little more tolerance  & acceptance
for our wonderfully unique differences, & beliefs, which by the simple fact
of our exsistance, define our world as one of incredible DIVERSITY.

BY YOUR COMMAND;

        Very briefly, I've been talking with a few sysop's around the
country today. Our Internet is under extreme overload at present time, due
to media hype, the holidays,  www sites/homepages increasing at geometric
rates ..etc.  Please try and minimize your use of bandwidth over the
holidays, or we may experience a significant catastrophic failure of major
backbone subsystem's.

        1. Send the message only once, and wait patiently.
        2. Delete long sig's(That's my contribution, I hope it works, if not
my next messaage).
        3. Log on & off as necessary, try not to hang on line(Next contribution)
        4. Do not recopy messages inb replies (ditto)
        5. Say what you want very simply
        6. Additions welcome(Hey Allen Bennett anything else)

On Mon, 18 Dec 1995, Wayne D. Correia wrote:

> It seems 
> the only 'evil' that ever gets talked about in our scene [snip] 
> are the promoters, but when it comes to a party, large or small,
> money losing or incredibly profitable, everybody has their hand out for
> $$$, and the promoter is the one paying everybody for everything. 

	This is what differs between commerical parties and parties thrown
by collectives/single sound system. Although one may have to give up the
nice lights (hmmm, some systems have nice lights as well as nice lasers),
the reward is a cheaper party put on because they want to see the party
happen. There are plenty of DJs out there that do not charge for the time
they spend dropping needles on records. So you have a choice right?  Do
you want to party within the bounds of what is allowed and all the pretty
lights and lasers and sound that blasts your ears out and makes you go
deaf - all which requires money for everything you wouldn't even think
could be charged (ok, that's an exaggeration) - maybe you don't care if
it's permitted or safe from a bust but still want lights and a bit of
comfort (this can actually work if you get enough people together) or do
you want to writh on the edges of "civilization" like the animals we
physically are? What in the party is important to you?
	Martin's parties are very necessary, and he does a hell of a good 
job at pulling off what he pulls off. How many people on this list I 
wonder started off going to his parties? Or were pulled into the scence 
by people who went to his parties? I respect Martin for doing something 
that I do not think I would have the patience to do - expose people to 
enough of the energy that they get involved (and once they get involved 
just enough, then they find their way to what are smaller parties at this 
time with the intense vibe on the main area and the friendly open vibe 
everywhere else you go). Many of the people who simply do what they do to 
make a party to go off for no more reason than to make a party go off 
started at a Gathering or Basics. Martin's parties are commerical but 
they serve their purpose - and I think little suburbia ma and pa who are 
already scared of people partying and living a lifestyle which gives up a 
certain amount of the "rewards" of living in "civilized" times like 
disposable diapers and plastic take away containers and double plastic 
bagging will do much better looking at Martin's parties before watching 
10,000 dance with so much energy coming off of the crowd in such a small 
space that there is no way in hell you cannnot feel it even if you have 
no idea of what is going on or what it is about (and that energy can be 
damn scary if you never expereinced anything primal)...
So what is the point of my spout I wonder? Martin's parties are not 
amazing parties some of  us are looking for, but that's cuz his parties 
are not what we are looking - I doubt Martin intends them to be - and 
while we have a point when saying massives in SF lack something, it is 
only because we are looking for something else, but without those 
massives, I know very few people who might have thought to look for 
something else - you can hear all kinds of stories about intenssity and 
things tribal but until you experience them, you have no idea what it is 
- right?.

dave

Received: from TEVM2 by tevm2.nsc.com (IBM VM SMTP V2R2) with BSMTP id 3284;
   Tue, 19 Dec 95 18:05:22 PST
Date: Tue, 19 Dec 95 18:05:21 PST
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: A Little Talk About E & The Cost Of The Rave Scene
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

FROM: Robert Brown
*** Resending note of 12/19/95 13:02

SUBJECT: Re: A Little Talk About E & Pricin


>FROM: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>

>       Are there any ethical business guildlines that suggest what an
>appropreiate profit margin would be for a given level of risk?
>
>        If so, what are they?

  The most common is just charge what the market will bear.
  Maybe this will yield a slim margin or a huge one, just depends.

  With respect to the "product" you may have used earlier as an example,
  Brian, charge whatever you think people will be willing to pay for it.
  The market (your customers) will eventually determine the price for you
  (you'll have no customers or a ton, e.g.), and the appropriate price will
  be achieved after a fashion.  This may take some time given that the
  seller is not a known factor in the marketplace or the product is "new".

  Perhaps an example may be The Gathering.  Yes, it was priced
  rather high in absolute dollar terms but many people did seem willing
  to pay for it and were pleased with their choice. (I personally had
  a grand time, and that's saying a lot considering it is EXTREMELY RARE
  for me to pay that amount of money for an event.)  Of course, the promoter,
  Martin, has a track record of delivering the goods so he is able to
  satisfy despite the price.  Basically the "market" (in this case those
  who rave) have, for the most part, validated his price.  Regardless of
  the various positive and negative opinions expressed, it doesn't change
  the fact that there were quite a number of people there and they apparently
  didn't regret their "purchase".

  That's a very basic opinion, hope it was of some value, educational,
  entertainment, or otherwise.

  And, yes, just to comment *I* liked the mixing in of "Sweet Dreams"
  in the "house" room.

  Ciao!

On Mon, 18 Dec 1995, Shawna McGourty wrote:
> (& I finally got my laminte!) which was very cool, one of them even 
> recognized me from my description (Hi Marty!)

Hello all,

I had the best time and didn't even want to return to Fresno.  Glad I got 
to meet at least one person (Shawna...how could I miss those leggings).  
I think I saw Wayne but wasn't sure and too embarassed to go up and be 
wrong.  Couldn't find you either Amy.  Next time.

I stayed till the very end (never done that before) and was still 
dancing.  Couldn't sleep at my hotel because..."I swear there was a party 
going on in my head!"

Martin was as good as I heard he would be.  I was very impressed to say 
the least.  I'm thinking of Planet New Year on NY eve, but I know many of 
you hesitate to attend Cool World events.  I had a great time at their 
Cyberfest2 at H Kaiser, but then, I'm not a very critical person.  

Oh, and can we please stop these flame wars about the price.  Bottom 
Line:  If you think it's too much...don't go:)

Marty

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Dec 19 19:10:58 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA13241; Tue, 19 Dec 1995 19:10:58 -0800
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA13236; Tue, 19 Dec 1995 19:10:54 -0800
Received: from [206.15.64.230] (sr-tty20-ppp.well.com [206.15.64.230]) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id TAA20494; Tue, 19 Dec 1995 19:10:45 -0800
Message-Id: <199512200310.TAA20494@well.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 19 Dec 1995 19:15:43 +1000
To: rdriffle@ucdavis.edu (Rick Riffle)
From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: Re: RADIO RAVES QUESTION
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>I was wondering where the dj is housed during a radio rave.  Can he/she see
>the croud to be able to interact with the vibe.  It would be nice to have
>the dj right there with all the people, but he/she would need a monitor, and
>if it was kept low enough I guess it wouldn't pose a problem.  The boom
>boxes couldn't be used as monitors because of the time lag to send the
>signal through the transmitter and what not would screw up the mixes.  Any
>thoughts?

A sinple FM Transmitter, Mixer and tables draws about 180 watts.   A single
car battery and a 12 volt inverter is adequate to power the mixer, tables,
and FM Transmitter,  so these could be right near the crowd.   The DJ would
have to work from Earphones and a close speaker (perhaps from a boom box).
It is
most unfortunate that some mixers won't allow pipeing the right TT into the
right headphone,  and left TT into the left earphone plus mix them both.
I can do that with my TIAC Model 3 mixer.   It just don't have cross faders.
The output of the mixer (usually low level audio) drives the FM transmitter,
so there is NO AMPLIFIED audio in the system,  other than the headphones the
DJ is using.   Its important to keep the modulation as close to 100 % as
possible without going over (And possibly causing interference).
>
>I love the concept of using walkmans for a totally silent party.  Everyone
>with nice quality headphones and walkmans groovin in silence.  Couldn't ya
>just see a couple a hundred people dancing *legally* in a public park in the
>middle of the night, the cops would be pissed. ::::)))))

The cops would still ask everyone to leave,  but the advantages are that
the cops wouldn't know about it in the first place (unless illegally
parked cars, or other indicaters are present to attract them).   They
certainly wouldn't get any noise complaints.   :-)
>
>Let me know if you know how the dj logistics would work.
>

I just explained it...

Crunchman

Those of you here for the holidays only have a few choices.  But don't forget
to look in the weeklies; for example, on Xmas eve, Kimball Collins is playing
at Spundae.  I'm going to be gone for the rest of the week, so if anyone
has more info, please forward it to sfraves.

If anyone has picked up info for other New Year's events, please send it to me!

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

On Tue, 19 Dec 1995, Brian Darkness wrote:

> BY YOUR COMMAND;
> 
>         Rob you have no idea what you are talking about, you are not me, you
> are not here, you do not know my friends, and what I'm trying to do for our
> scene.
> 
>         So what do you know about chemical analysis, please do tell!!!
> 
> At 10:57 PM 12/19/95 GMT, Rob Jellinghaus wrote:
> >Uh huh.  What you really mean is, "This one sample of something
> >someone told me was White Light was supposedly analyzed by someone
> >with something resembling what was once an actual laboratory, and
> >it had roughly these sorts of things in it."  Ignoring the fact that
> >it's hard to extract amounts of multiple organic compounds like that,
> >let alone get percentage quantities. Also ignoring the fact that
> >if someone else comes along and says "Hey, this is White Light!" you
> >have no way to know if it's what you claim yours was.
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Dec 19 22:48:05 1995

From: Alexandra Crocket <alex_c@scs.unr.edu>
To: Lee Fogel <lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM>
cc: alex_c@scs.unr.edu, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Don't flame(Gathering) 
Message-ID: <Pine.OSF.3.91.951219222447.17158C-100000@pogonip.scs.unr.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello. I feel as if I should clear this up. I do not feel that sfravers 
are a "bunch of whiners". Sfravers are some of the most enlightened and
informative people I have ever had the chance to communicate with.

Say you lived in a beautiful house, pun intended. ;)  When you first 
moved in, you noticed the splendor everyday. But, as time wore on, you
began to focus more on the cracks in the ceiling and the misaligned
cabinets and stopped even noticing the house. Then, one day, someone
visiting from a different neighborhood pointed out the beauty you had
become immune to, thus bringing it back to your attention. Only then could
you change your focus and appreciate the house, and perhaps even renovate
it before it fell to pieces from neglect.  Get it? ;)

I can see how people feel justified expressing their ideas about the cost
of this event. However, I was simply trying to point out that people
*take our scene for granted*. When I said we have a rave here about every
two or three months, I wasn't kidding. People in this area complained
without trying to help fix things and whined constantly about things the
promoters had *no* control over. Eventually the promoters just got sick of
it. There are tons of available *legal* spaces, and at least a couple
hundred people that are just waiting to go. But no one is willing to put
up with that kind of stress and pressure for negative-level appreciation.
Events in Reno rarely make *any* money. 

I was trying to point out that SF is *incredible* and the scene 
*fantastic*. Taking it for granted is what this is all about.

Get my point? It's *OUR* scene, and if we don't do the renovating, 
nothing is ever going to change! 
				     lv, Alex


viva | Alexandra Crocket  | "Reality is anything 
plur | alex_c@scs.unr.edu |  you can get away with"

> be some who look for the negative, and this isn't always bad either.

hello everyone!
	Tony and Nini here, we are brainstorming ideas to throw a little 
party/fashion show... the idea is to have different lines of clothing 
from various amateur to established designers like anna sui to persons 
like you who are interested in designing your own vision fashion wear. 
We would like the party to be non-profit, and a fun experience for 
everyone to get involved in. Ideas for how the party should happen are 
welcome, we are thinking of something with dj's spinning killer tunes, 
people dancing and having fun and sometime in the night a coordinated 
fashion show in tune with the music and not too distracting to the people 
who just want to dance...all completely interactive with the crowd ...

the resources we have to offer are alot of our time to organize, plan, 
bring people together...happy attitudes...fun...
	
we would love to hear from any positive attitudes, great ideas, models, 
amateur models, never tried modeling but Ill try it models,designers, 
never tried it  but it sounds fun designers, anyone interested in fashion, 
music, raving, and throwing a really cool fun party!

Love Nini and Tony
(aka -hierophant)

From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: Butterfly!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I got a call from one of our DJ friends tonite, Dani, and she told me
to come down and check out her and Charlotte's weekly called Butterfly at
Casanova (Valencia @ 16th).

Casanova's a nice little neighborhood bar in the Mission, but for some
reason I had always walked by and neve stopped in before. What a mistake.
There were a bunch of great people hanging around! I got there around 10pm
when they were just ready to start spinning.

I quickly met a bunch of supporters/DJs/promoters/friends from our scene
there including: SF Raves contributor John Lee who was also spinning, Dani,
Charlotte, Scott Hardkiss, Loren and a few others that I probably forgot. I
also saw our friends Tom and Stacy there that put on the Nomad / XNTRK
parties. We all hung out and talked for a good long while and had a few
beers while listening to some great music.

It had that nice small neighborhood vibe to it with the twist that the
place was full of our various friends from the house/rave scene.

I would definitely recommend you all check it out if you have the chance.

cost: $2.00

______________________________________________________________________
900 Tennessee St.         TEL: +1.415.826.6000        <wayne@club.net>
San Francisco CA 94107    FAX: +1.415.826.6100    http://www.club.net/

>	This is what differs between commerical parties and parties thrown
>by collectives/single sound system. Although one may have to give up the
>nice lights (hmmm, some systems have nice lights as well as nice lasers),
>the reward is a cheaper party put on because they want to see the party
>happen. There are plenty of DJs out there that do not charge for the time
>they spend dropping needles on records. So you have a choice right?  Do
>you want to party within the bounds of what is allowed and all the pretty
>lights and lasers and sound that blasts your ears out and makes you go
>deaf - all which requires money for everything you wouldn't even think
>could be charged (ok, that's an exaggeration) - maybe you don't care if
>it's permitted or safe from a bust but still want lights and a bit of
>comfort (this can actually work if you get enough people together) or do
>you want to writh on the edges of "civilization" like the animals we
>physically are? What in the party is important to you?


What nice lights?????????

Someone was talking about euro massives that are very commercial, but if you
pay $100 to go to Mayday in germany (including transportation from
Copenhagen, Denmark) you get high quality: 10 live acts at least 10 top DJs,
and state of the art sound and VISUALS that really makes you go into the
other dimension.

I never do drugs, I always use the vibe, the music and the lights to get
into the trance state.
The lights at the Gathering (which by the way was my second rave in this
part of the world) was very disappointing to me, since I am used to pay
$10-15 in DK and get good sound, lights and location.

So what I am getting at is that Martin should pay some attention ($$$) to
the visuals, everything else was good.

Just my 10 oere,
Rune

> 
> 	I like Martin, and I've enjoyed the Gatherings I've been to, 
> although unfortunately I wasn't at this one. 
> 	Sometimes I think you're too cynical.  But not this time.  I 
> think you're right to ask for an accounting of where the money went.  
> Power corrupts, and it's people like you who will hopefully keep the 
> promoters in our scene true to the spirit of the rave community. 
> 	I don't think it's too much to ask how much of the money from a 
> party is going to charity, if a party is billed as benefiting charity.  I 
> don't even think it's too much to ask for a complete breakdown of 
> expenses, specific enough to be verifiable for anyone inclined to check.
> 	After all, if these are "our" parties collectively, and not just 
> the promoters', shouldn't we take all take an interest in the "bottom 
> line"?  I think such a move would go some ways toward ending the 
> "producer-consumer relationship" that prevents us coming together more 
> closely as a community, and so I join with Black Adder and others in 
> asking all promoters who care about the scene to show that you trust and 
> respect us, and open your books.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Dec 20 12:54:26 1995

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Ethan Miller <ethan@bass-station.com>
Subject: The Gathering and other Blatherings
Cc: martin@choice.communion.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings!

Those of you that have been here a while are sure to appreciate the irony
of this post, those that haven't look at the archives in the week
preceeding Martin's post that Lee just dug out of the archives for a good
laugh. Black Adder, take heart; someone's gotta do it =)

Before proceeding let me state this unequivocally: In my opinion Martin's
heart is *totally* in the right place, he gives a maximum shit about the
safety and comfort of his patrons and I have a deep respect for what he's
done over the last four years and how he's done it. It's not the path I
would have or have chosen, but in what he's done, Martin's done a far
better job than anyone else attempting similar things. So I offer these
comments in the spirit of friendship and support, knowing full well that he
truly values constructive feedback.

Last March 18th at the 1-year Friends & Family, myself and quite a number
of other people learned a very important lesson: You can have the purest
heart, the finest of intentions, plan till the cows come home, DO YOUR BEST
and still not do enough. This doesn't mean that you or the party failed, or
wasn't great, it just gives you a list of things to do different next time.

So, Martin, I had a wonderful time at The Gathering, thank you; I know you
put your whole self into it, (and we all know you did the hokey pokey) but
in some ways it wasn't quite enough; here are *my suggestions* for what to
do different next time:

  o Make the people that work for you SHOW UP ON TIME. I was at the party to
    help from 6pm til 9:00 am; monitors for Dedication didn't arrive till
    9:30pm. The person doing visuals for Dedication didn't show up till
    9:00 pm. These are only two examples, there were more.

  o Hire (or get to volunteer) *way* more staff. Lights were still on and
    visuals were still being hung in Inspiration at 10:15pm!, well into the
    *second* DJ's set. You also need Dedicated Water Crews; we formed them
    on an impromptu basis but even so there was no water for thousands of
    people for nearly 2 hours. This also happened at Freedom. Also, alert
    security that people are coming and going to get water; a good friend
    (who payed to get in!) was harshly searched by security while returning
    with  his van full of water at 6am; this should definitely be avoided.

  o Be ready to Start The Party On Time! See above two items. Both of the
    opening DJs played to the set up crew with all the lights on. Stevie got
    to play for 15 minutes...

  o Furnishings. I know it's hard to make 4000 people (or whatever)
    comfortable but the space badly needed some soft areas to lounge in. Too
    many hard cement walls and floors. Get some rugs, carpets, tapestries,
    beanbags etc. See Chrysalis for a good example.

  o Charge less. $20 is plenty; $25 is overkill. (You can pay me less if you
    need to!)

I'll be happy to help with all of the above.

I would like to commend Martin for the Toy drive. I helped carry all those
bags full of Toys in the morning (there were like 30 huge bags!) and I
think they'll put a lot of smiles on a lot of faces. Nice one Martin.

I'd like to close this on the following note: After nearly three years of
throwing parties I've come to view a successfull rave as nothing short of
Magic, and I do mean MAGIC in the traditional sense. Few people can
actually make this magic happen, can acutally open up a safe space for us
to have transcendant experiences, for us to come together. This is true for
small parties and especially true when your talking 4000 people. Besides
Martin I don't know ANYONE ELSE in the bay area that can *reliably* make
this magic happen on this scale.

So congratulations on four years of good magic Martin, keep it up.

take it easy
ethan

----------------------------( ethan miller )----------------------------
------------------( http://www.bass-station.com/FnF/ )------------------
--------------------------------( acid )--------------------------------

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Dec 20 14:35:28 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA04350; Wed, 20 Dec 1995 14:35:28 -0800

Date: Wed, 20 Dec 95 14:33:05 PST
From: george@rs.com (George Feil)
Message-Id: <9512202233.AA11260@mars.rs.com>
To: SFRAVES@hyperreal.com
Subject: The Gathering: my initiation into the scene
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello, everyone! I'm very pleased to have found this list. Kudos to Lee
Fogel for guiding my way...

First, a short bio: I'm 31, and moved here last January from New York
City. Before that, I went to school in Pittsburgh (CMU), and lived in
Providence, RI, Martha's Vineyard, MA, and suburban Cleveland before
that. I currently live in SF, and develop applications software for
$$$.

For a very long time, I have searched for a particular niche that I
really could relate to on a fundamental level. I disliked the beer
blasts with all the jocks in high school, and avoided them. Hanging out
with the local burn-outs bored me, and seemed way too unproductive.
Besides, they considered me to smart and nerdy, anyway. In college, I
started hanging out with fellow geeks, but didn't feel really great
about myself there, either. There are only so many times you can hack
all night in the computer lab, listen endlessly to spacey music, and
play RPG's.

I joined the ranks of my college's alternative music radio station. It
was the few places at school where fine arts, humanities, science, and
engineering students related. After a couple of years of great
inter-relatedness, and forging an alternative music scene in the Steel
City, academic burn-out set in, and the magic faded. I focused on
graduating, and establishing my career in New York City.

Anyway, back to the subject at hand...

I finally stumbled across the rave scene at the Gathering last
Saturday. I was back in touch with that magic once again, and at a much
higher level than I have previously experienced.  Needless to say, I
was hooked! Never have I felt so loved and respected by so many people
at one time. Looking back on the evening, I noticed how I was treading
lightly at the scene -- the openness was *very* new and different for
me. [Most of the New York clubs, by comparison, are incredibly cold and
crowded experiences.] There's more for me to give up and surrender to
next time.

The music was fabulous (I was in the Inspiration room most of the
evening), and the visuals, while somewhat primative technologically,
worked for me. Actually, I thought the liquid kaleidoscope projections
were kind of nostalgic, sort of a throwback to the 60's.

The biggest thing missing for me was furniture. Lots of soft, comfy
places to regenerate after bouncing off the floor for hours at a time
would be really nice. The group of folks I hung out with improvised,
with bags and jackets, although I'm really not to thrilled to have to
send my leather jacket out to the cleaners afterwards.

All in all, it was an incredible experience, and I'm looking forward to
the next encounter...

Peace and love to you all, 
George

Message-ID: <M.122195.023523.87@ppp028.inreach.com>
From: punk@inreach.inreach.com (Politikon Zoon)
References: <199512192009.MAA01965@Steam.Stanford.EDU>
X-Mailer: Quarterdeck Message Center [1.0]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> What's a good place to get (color) flyers made?

You want color paper or printing?

For a cheap way, just go to Kinkos.  Yeah, you can get copies cheaper at 
Safeway or somewhere...  But there machines are good and turn out copies that 
look like they were printed.  They have all kinds of color paper and you can 
even use color toner cartridges.  If you're creative, you can use three 
different toner cartidges and just run different parts of your flyer through 
for different colors.  It looks good.  What's cool is they will also do all the 
work for you for like a buck.  I did the flyer for my show on my computer and 
printed it out there on their laser printers.  Then I had them blow it up to 
fit the page better.  I also wanted handouts so I had them rescale it to fit 
two on a page.  And then had them split apart.  Each cut you make is like a 
buck.

I actually had a good experience there.

Black Adder asked:>


 Me Me!! My first official rave was the Gathering New Year's Eve 92/93 in 
>> Vallejo.  You thought last weekend's venue was huge....
>> This was the rave that got me hook, line and sinker.  I don't know how I 
>> would have taken the rave scene in had Cool World been a first for me.  I 
>> will never forget that rave at the Vallejo fairgrounds....:)
>> 
>Out of curiosity, why is there such a large amount of Cool World 
>bashing? Have many of you that staunchly support one massive and so 
>gleefully bash another actually gone to a Cool World? I haven't. I have 
>heard "through the grapevine" that they are not very good parties, and 
>wouldn't go anyways due to the price. Comments from those that have 
>actually gone appreciated.
>
>                                           Black Adder
>                   
>I ended up at Planet New Year last year and was very disappointed  that I
wasted my New Year going to this massive. I was with a few friends of mine
that were under age, and with Wicked out of the question and with free
passes to the Cool world event we decided we would go there instead of
drving aimlessly around. I think driving around would have been a better idea. 

As we got to the entrance we were suprised at the enormous line up that
snaked its way back from the building. In line were at least 700-900 people,
mostly under the age of 20, and all pushing on the rails that cordended them
off like cattle. There was a gate that opened up to let about 100 folks in
at a time , to another cordened off area right at the entrance and every
time the gate was opened the pushing from behind from impatient people
caused a few to fall to be trampled by the uncaring crowd.It looked to me
that it was a very dangerous situation, too many people and no security to
control the mayhem. Just as my friends and I were going in the gest entrance
we saw the gate crash down and a river of humanity swarm twords the
building,pushing down any barriers ( and any people that were in its wake).
About 500 of them got into the building before security made it outside to
stop them. This was the only thing at this party that made a smile come to
my face, for once the promoters who cared nothing for the people and only
about how much $ they were raking in, got thiers. A whole bunch of ravers
with no tickets ( I think they were bieng scalped there for about $25) were
able to get in when the ggates were crashed. But many were injured bieng
pushed into the barriers or trampled and it was very dissapionting to see
people caring less for eachother and more about getting into the party.

As we got inside and saw the hordes of KIDS and I do mean kids, it was
almost midnight and a rapper was on the main stage screaming out some tune
about Ex and how everybody should get high , high, high. The party was full
of gangster types, a lot of bubblegum ravers, and alot of really high
people. I overheard someone saying that they had heard about the party on
LIVE 105
and I knew I had entered the Palaidum on a much larger scale. Needless to
say I found the party to be full of people who cared nothing for eachother
or for the quality of music bieng played ( the rappers had obviously taken a
whole bunch of the E they were singing about and were off beat and tune).

The Techno and House room was an 1/8 th of the size of the 'live' room and I
found the vibe in there vagley inviting. But you couldnt breathe and you
were covered in sweat ( not all your own ) as soon as you entered. The music
was semi kickin but nobody seemed to know or care who was spinning.The
corners of this room were filled with vomit and people adding to the
quagmire with thier own. After watching this melee,. I couldnt bring myself
to join in, I went to search for the people I had come in with because the
countdown was minutes away. I located my brother and our friends and went
back to the big room to count down to the new year.When the countdown got to
Zero the mayhem lasted only a minute and then the only good energy I had
felt all evening was gone again.I saw no huggs and kisses, and the music
started right back up, the same terrible rappers. At this piont I decided to
find my friend who was involved in putting on this event , and politely tell
him I was leaving. When I did find him, he was hiding with the rest of the
crew ' backstage, totally avoiding the party and the people. I asked him why
he wasant out expieriancing his own party, and his response was " I'd rather
not go out there,. too many wierdos out there." I was disgusted by his greed
and how little he cared for the scene and for the people , both which he saw
as suckers to be taken advantage of.I left vowing I would never attend
another Cool World event, deeply dissapointed in  my friend and the souless
event I had just wasted my New Years Eve at

The icing on the cake came as I was walking back to the car. Two rather
large, obviously inihebriated guys dressed in posse wear were arguing just
outside the doors and one took two steps back, pulled his arm back and
landed the loudest and most violent punch I had ever seen to the guy he was
arguing with. The guy who got hit , slammed the ground equally as hard as he
was hit, and didnt move. For all I know that guy never got up. Nobody around
payed any attention, especially the security detail that was standing near
enough to stop the guy that had hit  and was now kicking the guy on the
ground. I was with my little brother and two other friends and thought it
would be safer to walk away, and did so feeling sick at the things I had
seen and the abomination of an event like COOL WORLD, more like CRUEL WORLD,
bieng related to our scene or even calling it a rave.

So this ends my COOL WORLD saga. In short dont go. Only if to send a message
to the folks who put on such partys undr the guise of it bieng a rave, wich
in my eyes is an event for the people not for taking advantage of them. It
is partys like this one that give
' massives' the stigma they now carry. 

To all those I miss and will see again this spring when I return to SF ( I
am currently hibernating in Canada), Happy Hollidays. Be safe 
in your revelry, and by all means be thorough. May the New year bring
expierances unequaled and happiness unbridled. Peace my sisters and
brothers......peace and love to u all.

                                                                            
                                                                            
        Walk in Beauty
                                                                            
                                                                            
         little  jen sus

      ~ Increase Your Serenity ~

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Dec 21 07:27:15 1995

Date: Thu, 21 Dec 95 15:29:26 PST
From: bart meijerink <bart.meijerink@pi.net>
Subject: New vinyl
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: Chameleon - TCP/IP for Windows by NetManage, Inc.
Message-ID: <Chameleon.4.01.2.951221162139.bart@pi-user.pi.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Some reviews:

Kape ill miester 'top/bottom' [a13]
Collaboration between Mark Broom and Steve Pickton. Bottom is very basic with a very deep 
808-kick and a hypnotic kinda sound. At 2/3 of the record some eery strings start floating in. 
Cool. Top is dark techno with a strange swing to it (the open hat).

Kosmic Messenger (Stacy Pullen) 'flash/death march' [plink plonk]
New one from Derrick May's student. Flash (nothing to do with that Green Velvet-stomper) is okee, 
but the other side I like better. Death march has a superdeep bass that sounds very well with the 
organkindlike sound. grrrreat!

Silent Breed 'Amazing pudding' [A.F.U.]
This is the first one from this label that I like. On this pink record SB combine an acidline 
with a distorted piano(?)sound filtered in a strange way. Keeps the party going...

Qorg 2 'astral' [out on a limb]
Although the out on a limb-sleeves suggest that there's some very clubby and happy stuff in it,  
the records are actually pretty okee. So is this one. The AA-side you can use at any time, 
because of the 'close your eyes and drift away-feel. The A-side combines some heavy percussion 
with an outerspace-sound. Rocks....

Beverly Hills 808303 vs. Auto Kinetic [electric music/analog USA]
>From the Auto Kinetic-side I like the second track best. It has that hypnotic acid-mood we all 
liked so much (at least I did) but now with some distorted sounds inbetween the 303's. The other 
side by the uncrowned kings of overloaded 808303-hence that name-acid. These guys are super 
underground so I don't know if their other records are available in the US. I can't get enough of 
it.  . 

Also cool:
Surgeon 'electronically tested' [downwards]
Wink & dj ESP 'stairway to headphones' [head in the clouds]
Air Liquide 'red and black ep'
Trance Induction 'sirocco ep' [prime]
Psyche 'airborne 303' [pure music]

|fax...... +31 (0)30-2625693 (call first!)
|email.... barttm@pi.net /  974s@stud.frw.uva.nl

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Dec 21 09:14:01 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA19197; Thu, 21 Dec 1995 09:14:01 -0800
Received: from relay.hp.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA19181; Thu, 21 Dec 1995 09:13:55 -0800
Received: from hpcc119.corp.hp.com (cmswk254.corp.hp.com) by relay.hp.com with ESMTP
	(1.37.109.16/15.5+ECS 3.3) id AA158646021; Thu, 21 Dec 1995 09:13:44 -0800
Received: by hpcc119.corp.hp.com
	(1.37.109.16/15.5+ECS 3.3) id AA236576020; Thu, 21 Dec 1995 09:13:40 -0800
Date: Thu, 21 Dec 1995 09:13:40 -0800
From: Scott Basford <basfords@hpcc119.corp.hp.com>
Message-Id: <199512211713.AA236576020@hpcc119.corp.hp.com>
Apparently-To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     Hi everyone,
     
     It's probably a little bit late for a review, especially given that 
     this week's calendar is already out. However I am only now beginning 
     to come back down to earth after Saturday, so here are my thoughts.
     
     I had an absolute blast! I loved every minute of it, and didn't want 
     it to end. The music, the people, the vibe, everything was simply 
     superb.
     
     This was my first "massive". Although I was expecting the party to be 
     big, I didn't expect it to be this big. Given the size I thought the 
     party was incredibly well managed. All of the problems that I have 
     seen at much smaller parties were not there. The long line at the 
     start moved very quickly. The staff certainly didn't get in my face. 
     The space was huge and well ventilated. The toilet lines were short. 
     And probably best of all I didn't encounter any negative energy from 
     anyone. By the way, do we have an official answer on the number of 
     people yet? 
     
     I was there with five very close friends. My partner in crime J-C, the 
     man who can never stand still. My old mates Rob and Leighton who 
     haven't been out dancing for a couple of months now. And finally we 
     had a couple of first timers Ann and Sophie. They are already asking 
     me when the next party is.
     
     I met quite a few sfravers which was fantastic. I bumped into Amy, 
     Wayne, Vince, Crunchman and Ethan (thanks for the tape!) again. I also 
     got to meet Shawna, Dimitriou (sp?), Tom and his friend (sorry!) for 
     the first time. I know there were others, so please excuse me for 
     leaving you out.
     
     Tom I loved your message. The last few songs of the night when the 
     lights have been turned on is always my favorite time. It's so 
     incredible to look around and see the smiles on everyone's faces. It 
     feels like the dawn of a new beginning. And yes I am saw also. I've 
     strained muscles in both my legs and in my neck, not to mention 
     blisters all over my feet. I guess that's what happens when you 
     dance for seven and a half hours with shoes and no socks!
     
     Finally some random thoughts and suggestions. 
     
     Running out of water was a bit of a pain. Unfortunately I didn't 
     find the tap like some others. Did anyone else taste that cranberry 
     juice? Yuck!
    
     I also echo the thougths regarding the need for more cushions, 
     pillows etc. Without a decent sized chill-out area it doesn't quite 
     feel like a true rave.
 
     Did anyone else think it was a little too dark, especially in the 
     bigger room. I need to see more smiles! I also agree with the 
     comments about the visuals. Give us some more lasers. 
     
     I found that the two room setup broke up the vibe for me a little 
     bit. Each time I was really in a zone dancing, and about to be 
     transported to another level, a little voice in the back of my head 
     would say something like "Your missing Jeno in the other room". I 
     guess that if that's my only real gripe, then I should just shutup 
     and dance!
     
     Thanks to Martin, the crew and everyone who was there for a 
     fantastic party. Well worth the $25. Until next time...
     
     Keep on smiling!
     
     Scott.
     
     P.S. If you are wondering who the hell I am, I was the Australian 
     bastard with long hair and half a beard, wearing the multi-coloured 
     striped overalls.
     
     --------------------
     basfords@corp.hp.com
     --------------------

        Sorry for the massive SPAM but i just had this text typed out and
wanted to get it to all the people i care about before i take off on
vacation and my net.access is limited :)

        ok, here's some more words ov wizdom c/o 'feel' zine from san fran
that a friend of mine sent to me:
        ==============================
        signs and symptoms of inner peace:

        watch for signs of peace, the hearts of a great many have already
been exposed to it and it seems likely that we could find out society
experiencing it in epidemic proportions, which then of course, could pose a
serious threat to what has up to now seemed a fairly stable condition of
conflict in the world

        1.Tendency to think and act spontaneously rather than from fears
based on past experiences
        2.an unmistakable ability to enjoy each moment
        3.loss of interest in judging other people
        4.loss of interest in judging self
        5.loss of interest in interpreting actios of others
        6.loss of interest in conflict
        7.loss of interest loss of ability to worry *this is a very serious
symptom*
        8.frequent, overwhelming episodes of appreciation.
        9.contented feeling of connectedness with others and nature
        10.frequent attacks of smiling through the eyes, from the heart
        11.increasing tendancy to let things happen rather than make them happen
        12.increase in susceptibility to love extended by others as well as
the uncontrollable urge to extend it.

        WARNING!
        If you have all or even most of the above symptoms, please be
advised that your condition of PEACE may be so far advanced as being
incurable!
        If you are exposed to anyone exhibiting several of these symptoms,
remain exposed only at your own risk. this condition of PEACE is probably
at it's most infectious stage.
        -saskia davis-

=================================

        hope ya liked it! happy holidays ;) i'm taking off for a vacation
in San Fran tomorrow so i hope that everyone has an AWESOME x-mess and a
wicked new year, i'm totally stoked to be partying in frisco but i'll be
thinking of y'all this new year. whoa dude where'd all that lingo come from
man, tubular!
                peace and hard acid :)
                         brad

On Wed, 20 Dec 1995 "Rocky Mullin" <caliban@organic.com> said: 
 
 
> are there any laws that make clubs give people water? 
in arizona, probably because of the heat, it's illegal for any public
establishment to deny a request for a drink of water if they are able to
provide it. perhaps we could enact legislation calling water a basic human 
right, thus making it illegal to selectively distribute (charge for) it.
perhaps a mandatory drinking fountain, with, of course, a minimum flow rate
so one can rehydrate at a reasonable rate. mr. hallinan? 
peace&positivity, 
greg-n-cindy

Sent from: ARTISTpres@aol.com ()

12/18/95 For immediate release:  New York City's Christmas Present to Artists

At 1:30 P.M. Sunday 12/17/95 eight plainclothes police handcuffed and
arrested three artists on Prince Street between Mercer and Greene Streets in
SoHo. The three artists, Robert Lederman 45, Lei Chang 36 and Joe Costin 68
are members of A.R.T.I.S.T. (Artists' Response To Illegal State Tactics).
Tourists and local residents doing  their Christmas shopping watched in shock
as police stuffed original oil paintings into garbage bags and sped off to
avoid an angry crowd that formed. The police also confiscated protest signs,
photos of previous artist arrests and literature detailing the bitter three
year struggle between street artists and New York City.

The arrested artists were charged with not having a vending license, despite
the fact that the Department of Consumer Affairs routinely tells artists
applying for a license that they don't need one based on the First Amendment,
or that the waiting list for a license is totally closed to the general
public and will not be open for at least the next six years. According to
Department of Consumer Affairs spokespersons there are over 5,000 people on
the waiting list. In some years not one license is issued. Confiscated art,
regardless of the cases' outcome, is rarely returned to the artists. Most of
the art is sold at the monthly N.Y.P.D. auction. The $14 million dollars
raised by selling confiscated possessions each year helps fund the N.Y.P.D..

The Commanding Officer of the Peddler Task Force, Lt. Johnson, told SoHo
artists on 12/3/95 that he had been ordered by Mayor Giuliani to arrest more
artists based on a recent ruling by Federal Judge Miriam Cedarbaum. In that
controversial ruling the judge claimed, in direct contradiction to 50 years
of Supreme Court, Appelate and State Court rulings, that visual art is not
protected by the First Amendment. The street artists, who are plaintiffs in a
Federal lawsuit [Lederman et. al. v. City of New York 94 Civ. 7216 (MGC)] are
represented by the law firm of Dewey Ballantine and Volunteer Lawyers for the
Arts and are appealing the ruling. 
 The eight arresting officers later claimed to be transit police with nothing
to do, who had been issued special orders to arrest artists in SoHo after
both Peddler Squad and First Precinct officers failed to make enough artist
arrests. Police Department sources in the First Precinct claim that City
Council Member for SoHo Kathryn Freed continuously pressures them to make
artist arrests and has arranged the reassignment of at least two police
captains in the past year because they didn't crack down hard enough on the
artists. Despite over 200 artists being arrested on N.Y.C. streets since
1993', not one case has resulted in a Criminal Court conviction. The District
Attorney's office acting in  cooperation with the N.Y.C. Corporation Counsel
has dismissed all charges in each case, thereby avoiding the possibility of
an appeal which might result in overturning  New York City's Vending
Ordinance.

Robert Lederman, the president of A.R.T.I.S.T. has been arrested 11 times for
selling his art. "We all intend to be right back on Prince Street tomorrow",
said Lederman. "We will not be bullied by these unconstitutional tactics and
false arrests". More arrests, and an ongoing protest, are expected on Prince
Street this week. Photos of the arrests are available. Also available are
transcripts of taped conversations between the Department of Consumer Affairs
and artists applying for a license; affidavits from city officials, etc. For
more info contact: A.R.T.I.S.T. (718) 369-2111 Permission to freely
redistribute granted.

SCRUTON@JOYCE.dnet.hac.com
> don't forget to put RECHARGEABLE batteries in those walkmans, peeple
> 
> ya wanna keep that mercury OUTTA the ecosystem

Actually, I don't think your standard "alkaline" battery uses mercury. 
Mercury is more typically found in watch/hearing-aid style batteries.

Also, standard rechargeable batteries are made from Nickel-Cadmium, and
cadmium happens to be far more dangerous than mercury or the contents
of an "alkaline battery". Due to the eco-toxicity of cadmium, I believe
it is against the law to dispose of a standard ni-cad battery in the
trash (take a look at the warning label on the batteries).

Ob-rave/kzsu. Did anybody happen to be nice enough to record this gig?
It would be great to have copies of the sounds, preferably before it
gets out onto the waves, preferably before the sound gets munged by
KZSU's crappy and oft-overmodulated transmitter (I used to DJ there
back in the day, so I know what goes on down there!). I'd pay $$$ to
get these tapes or DATs. 

If anybody has DATs, I'd be happy to dupe 'em since I got two DAT
players (well, one of them happens to be my tape back up on my computer
but it still lets me do digital-digital copies audio DAT deck).

I went to the Adventures at the Musicdome thing Cool World did.  It is, so
far the one and only rave I have been to.  I had a good time even though my
ears have never been the same....AAAAHHHH.....STOP THE RINGING...and I got
seperated from friends for two hours.  My boyfriend, who I met for the first
time there, said it was boring and the people had too much of a gang
mentality.  But I find he says that about a lot of things.  Well, regardless
of what anyone else says, I would go to another one and probably will for New
Years.  As long as the music is danceable I have a good time.

Since I'm going to be stuck out here away from my family for Xmas, and
I figure others will be too, I'd like to offer the idea (suggested
previously by Brian D.) of having a Xmas Eve gathering for the rootless.

My house is a good place to have such.  We have plenty of room, and a nice
secluded location for such music as we want to play.

I'd like to do a potluck dinner, followed by some talking and music.  If
any DJs want to contribute (yeah, right), I can have ready enough 
amplification for the space I have.

Plus I have lots of really old arcade games (Tempest, Joust, etc.) for
you nostalgia freaks.

I don't anticipate huge response, just a little family gathering...please
do tell ASAP if you're interested.

(I'm just off 280, near 85: about 40 easy miles from SF, 15 from SJ).

// g

>*SNIP* ( please refer to the original post for the rest of the tale)

>Thanks for the VERY thorough response. 
>
>Geoff White made a very valid point regarding people bringing the vibe to a 
>party. In your opinion, what drew such an apparently vibeless crowd?  
>
>                                            Black Adder
>
Black Adder:
I believe it was because the party was mostly attended by those who heard
about it on Live 105.. I dont want to generalize about
who listens to this station or that all the people who do are potentially
troublemakers, but I do think that it attracted many undesireables ( ie:
people who seek out fights, are  Gangster wannabe's, were there to get out
of control on drugs.. ect.. ect..).

I also think alcohol was a contributing factor to the agro vibe and a major
factor in all the fights and shoving matches that I witnessed.I believe many
of the kids came to the party to blow off steam and did so in the form of
violence and excessive drug dosing. Many folk were there from the East Bay (
again I dont want to generalize , there are many wonderful people from the EB)
and alot were dressed Gangland style. I believe that alot of them had never
been to any smaller raves and cared nothing for eachother let alone creating
a good vibe. This compounded with the uncaring crew who put on this
function, and the security who let the fights get outta controll made this
party not only vibeless, but downright SCARY. I also think that many of the
kids attending 
were angry, violent prone  and lacked compassion. No compassion for your
fellow man = no chance for a good vibe.

                                                                            
                                                                            
             Peace Y'all,
Jen Sus

      ~ Increase Your Serenity ~

On Thu, 21 Dec 1995, Harvey Susser wrote:

> >Black Adder: here is one more horror story about the Cool World, from
> another jennifer s.  I am posting to SFRAVES so all can see it. 
> Please dont ruin your New Years or support such a party by going .

Have no fear ;) I wasn't planning on going. Pacific gets my $ which I will 
gladly give, and thank them for taking it.

It was more a question of perceptions being based on reality. I have 
always heard that Cool World in particular was a "bad" party. I have seen 
it mentioned constantly on SF-Raves. In fact, I am sure at one point or 
another I have made fun of it based on what I had heard. But I had never 
seen any *SOLID* reasons why Cool World made for such a bad scene, until 
now of course. Amys' post deriding it got me to thinking about my own 
perceptions of events I had never been to, and the acceptance here of 
slamming this production company by people, many of whom have also never 
attended one of these events. So I was thinking "shame on me." These 
tales of horror however make me even more sure that I don't want to attend 
one of these parties. Thanks much for the edification....

                                              Black Adder

Hello-

Just a few thoughts-

It has been my experiance -dealling with sellers, users, buyers and selling
once myself-  that dealing with E is not a very risky business.  Sure you are
distributing an illeagal substance that could cost you a minimum of 5 years
in jail(I think) but your customers are very respectable people.  There
ravers- you probable won't be held up at gun point at a rave and a raver is
less likely to jump U for your cash flow.  When you buy powder (I used to)
you could get it for 9 bucks a cap.-When you don't cut it and you actually
get an ounce.  
   I personally would not trust the caps going around right now because it is
too easy to cut them or fill um with bunk shit unless you know the people
selling it.
     Now I have notices alot of wafers/sausers(flat discs kinda
yellowish/brown) going around that are good but I hear they have heroin in
them.  Can anyone confirm this????  I won't take em if they do.  Tylenols can
still be bunk but you have less of a chance of that than capsuls.  I've heard
these go for 10$ up to 15$ a hit.  Still a 5 dollar profit is not bad
considering what kinda profit you make off other drugs.  
     The main risks I see with selling E are getting caught with it on your
persons( being searched or pulled over and being searched),  selling to a
narc - believe me they are out there at raves, or a security spots you
selling - many security don't really care, actually (talking to some) and I
have even met some who sell (they might confiscate your stash and turn around
and sell it to the next guy - I've seen this).
      The penelty for selling drugs can be harsh and this is the main reason
I don't do it any more.  I also don't believe in selling bad drugs to anyone
- many people trust the dealer to sell them a good time and when they get
ripped off that breaks down the trust and disapoints the buyer.  I won't ever
sell drugs again even though the money is really good($500-1000 a night or
more).
    I remember back in Septembr or October there was a billion doller Ecstacy
bust in Sonoma.  These guys were major supliers of the west coast.  Following
the bust there was a lot of bunk E going around.  Now It is starting to pick
up but who knows for how long.  
     I hope this answered your question some what.  If there is anything else
I might be able to answer let me know.
                    ~\_@_/~
                         {e}
Peace,           ~\/ \
Austin                 /
                            ~

So: I actually got several responses to my post yesterday, so it looks like
we're going to have a small gathering @ Casa Miraloma (my house).

Note: Unless fifty or so people show up unannounced, this will be a relatively
small gathering -- don't expect another Blue Cube.  Do expect a gathering 
of friends in a neat house in the hills.

I'd like to start with a potluck dinner.  Let's say dinner is 6ish, and
showing up before is fine if you need to cook or reheat something.  I'll
be whipping up a big batch of marinara sauce, most likely (which turned 
out really excellent last time).  We'll eat, talk, and play crusty old
arcade games until people get an urge to dance, at which point we'll fire
up the sound.  If you have your favorite CDs/mix tapes/records, you are
highly encouraged to bring them.  If you are a DJ, you are guaranteed
deck time so long as you bring your coffin (I have no 1200s).  Feel free to
bring lights, toys, warm fuzzies, luv phasers, etc.  The gathering will
be over when everyone gets tired.  If you need to crash I have ample space.

Please email me or call 415-948-6369 if you are coming so I have some idea of
who to expect.  Spur of the moment is OK if your phone died, tho.

Here are the directions:

>From San Francisco:  Take 280 South about 40 miles out of the city, past
84 and Page Mill Road.  The next exit is El Monte Road.  Take El Monte
North (the sign on the exit ramp should say "Los Altos").  If you hit 85,
you've gone too far.

>From San Jose:  Take 280 North to El Monte Road (a few exits after 85).
Take El Monte North (the first off-ramp at the exit).  Page Mill is too far.

>From El Monte Road:  Go right @ the second light (Summerhill).  Go up the
hill, go down the hill.  At the bottom of the hill, turn right on Miraloma
(note: it's a small street, looks like a driveway).  If you hit a stop-sign,
you've gone too far.  Go up Miraloma until it turns a 90 degree right.
The driveway there to the left is mine (12580).  Park on the street (or I
can't get my car out) and walk up.  The house is red, and one story.

See you there!

// g

Ravers Rights Association - It seems the Aussies have a really good idea
that we should also try up here.    This,  in relation to a lot of "bad
press" on ravers from the local Sydney media.   A lot of people "including
me",  flooded the Daily Telegraph Mirror (A Sydney paper),  and it worked,
because they are publishing the protest letters that were flooding in.

Details outlined and proposed below...  They referece Anna Wood,  a young
girl that died as a result of taking "E",  whereas the media was having a
field day,  bashing raves BIG TIME.

>Date: Sun, 17 Dec 1995 13:51:54 -0800
>From: Andrew Burgoyne <burgoyne@world.net>
>X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.0b3 (Win16; I)
>Mime-Version: 1.0
>To: matok@Levels.UniSA.Edu.Au
>Cc: ausrave@student.adelaide.edu.au
>Subject: Re: [AR] Time for rave organisers to get a legal firm?
>Sender: owner-ausrave@student.adelaide.edu.au
>Precedence: bulk
>X-UIDL: 819245152.008
>
>Otto Koppius wrote:
>
>> OK, suggestion : try to get all (or at least most) promotors in Australia
>> together, and get them to agree to a 'tax' of $1 levied on EVERY ticket
>> sold for a rave/party/clubnight/whatever to be put into a legal fund.
>> Establish a ravers-rights-association consisting of promotors, clubowners,
>> ravers, DJs and musicians to use the money to give legal support to
>> party-organizers and to educate the general public about raves with ads etc.
>
>Great idea, but we need 100% SUPPORT from everyone.  We need the promoters
>to realise that they will suffer if something is not done.  Likewise the
>shopowners must also support the cause.  Shops like Central Station Records
>must realise that if the commercial rave 'scene' dies (which looks quite
>likely) there will be no demand for techno records and no demand for
>kiddy core rave clothes...Maybe we could even convince Central to play a
>major part in this organisation.  That way we could get Australia wide
>(almost) coverage through their shops.
>
>If the rave 'scene' continues this way and the high budget parties
>can't even get legal venues what hope is there for the small parties.
>The young ravers must be getting quite disillusioned with the 'scene'.
>Just look at the letters in 3D World and think about how much it would
>suck if you were paying up to $50 for a ticket to a party where you don't
>even know where the venue is.  And then how would you feel if you called
>a 0055 number on the night only to find out that the party you had been
>so looking forward to is either in a place which is almost impossible to
>get to without a car, is somewhere you may not even be able to find if you
>do have a car, or has been shut down.
>
>> So, what do you think of the 'silent rave' idea ?
>> If we can get the promotion right, it should generate a lot of attention,
>> methinks.
>
>Great idea if we can get a LARGE crowd of people.  Any chance of organising
>flyers to be passed around on NYE?
>
>> ObStupidQuestion : Who the f*ck is Chris Murphy ?
>
>Very high profile Sydney lawyer.  If you give him enough money he'll get
>you off anything?  He got Jeff Fenech off an assault charge, Dieter Brummer
>off a drugs charge and he's representing the girl who sold Anna Wood the
>tablet.
>

>Andrew Burgoyne

>on 23 December?

I think I mentioned that we're doing the Xmas Eve (Sunday) time for the
party, but if I didn't, that's the date/time.  Once again, dinner Sunday
@ 6ish, arrive a bit early if you need to cook/reheat/etc.

Plus, I've had more than one person tell me they'd like to go but
need a ride.  If anyone is coming down from SF and has space in their car,
please post ASAP with info so that others may get here.

Or, the Mountain View CalTrain is reasonably close.  I wouldn't want to walk 
it (a few miles) but I could pick people up if they know what time
they'll be arriving.  Keep me posted...

...by telephone, please, after today, as I don't want to have to go back in
to work this weekend to read email.

>goodness that really sounds frightening(the cool world new years of last 
>year). i hope i never end up in a place like that. it is a shame you did 
>not feel more comfortable helping that guy who got hit. vomit in the 
>corners? live (evil) 105? can we keep parties underground please???
>
>kevin
>:)

It was something ( seeing a person slammed like that) that I had never seen
before at any event I had ever gone to. I started going to raves BECAUSE the
scene frowned on violence and perpetuated the peaceful ethic. It really
shook me up to see that guy go down and nobody do anything about it, the
security was 50 yards away , saw the whole thing happen and turned thier
backs. The guy who layed the punches was 6ft tall and at least 200 lbs. I
was about to say something , or go make the security do something
but my brother said, " leave be, you migh get hurt if u get involved, lets
get outta here." To this day I still remember how hard that guy got hit, and
how helpless and angry I felt at myself for not doing anything. I still
wonder if that guy ever got up  . I will always regret not helping him  or
insisting that the security do something. :( Yes lets keep this scene
underground and attended by people who wont stand for violence . please
always promote the peace. 

                                                                            
                                                                            
                                                

                                                                            
                                                                        Walk
in Beauty & in Peace
                                                                            
                                                                            
Jen Sus

      ~ Increase Your Serenity ~
