On Wed, 20 Dec 1995, Shawna McGourty wrote:
> Was just wondering if anybody had any information about this, I mean 
> aside from what I found on a couple of websites.  One, how much is it 
> (how do they deal with that) and two, what kind of music is it? 

Shawna, this is definitely not an event to miss.  It was the most 
incredible experience I've ever had...partywise.

It's held every Labor Day in the Black Rock Nevada desert.  I think it 
cost $40 to get in but I really can't remember (it was way worth the 
money though).

Basically it's a major camping event.  You camp, you party, you dance 
all night long, you meet many new people and you'll never forget it.  
Some people go th the hot springs out there and chill out naked, or they 
simply walk around camp that way.  There are two camps, the main camp, 
and the rave camp. They are about 1 mile apart from each other because 
music plays at night long at the rave camp.

I just can't get in to details because it's overwhelming.  It is so 
excellent when the huge wooden man burns.  Everyone surrounds him in 
a gigantic circle, and the people all around are just..."trippy".  I 
loved it!  After that a big phallic looking thing gets burned, everyone 
bonds, and many drum circles are formed.  If we ever meet I can bring 
photos.  Oh, as far as the toileting situation goes, outhouses are provided
and they are very kept up.  I was sort of worried but they are kept very 
clean by someone (who knows).

I highly recommend this event to everyone. It's a must for me in 96 and 
I'd love to make plans with lots of people.  My friend I went with moved 
to Amsterdam and my normal Fresno gang probably couldn't handle it:)

Marty

Good afternoon all-

Well I did go after much contenplation.....
I did work earlier in the day so my energy level was way low and that
seriously effected my dancing time.  After going by the Soundfactory and the
X, me and a friend showed up at 2.30am...
It was at the Acme werehouse on Howard which seemed to be a fairly nice space
except for the extreme heat in the main room...  I didn't spend much time in
there except during Carlos's  set and Tracy at the end- hadn't heard her in a
while and I still like her hypnotic style.  Rob had a good house set that I
tried to dance to most of it.  Many rooms in this place - 4 or 5.   Very
friendly people - vibe was good and steady throughout the night.  I heard
some crisp hard beats during Tom's set but I spent most of my time in the
basement at the time of his set.  Too bad I had to dance sitting down after 5
or so- I had no more energy left.  Met Brian D. <what's up bro>  All in all a
very fun night for me.  Going back to sleep, good night ya'll.

Peace,
Austin

Dear John,

	Sounds like an idea worth discussing.  My one immediate 
reaction:  Any lawyers representing us should be forced to dress 
appropriately (i.e. whistles, baggy pants, PLUR shirts, floppy hats, 
etc.). There are definite limits to how far I think we should go in our 
quest for mainstream credibility.  :)

Much Love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

______________________________________________________________________________
Q:  How many lawyers does it take to screw in a light bulb?
A:  No more than two, and they have to be very small.

> >(almost) coverage through their shops.

> >Just look at the letters in 3D World and think about how much it would
> >suck if you were paying up to $50 for a ticket to a party where you don't
> >even know where the venue is.  And then how would you feel if you called
> >a 0055 number on the night only to find out that the party you had been
> >so looking forward to is either in a place which is almost impossible to
> >get to without a car, is somewhere you may not even be able to find if you
> >do have a car, or has been shut down.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Dec 27 10:29:03 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA28821; Wed, 27 Dec 1995 10:29:03 -0800
Received: from netcom11.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id KAA28810; Wed, 27 Dec 1995 10:28:56 -0800
Received: from DialupEudora by netcom11.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)
	id KAA28518; Wed, 27 Dec 1995 10:25:43 -0800
Date: Wed, 27 Dec 1995 10:25:43 -0800
X-Sender: jsl@localhost
Message-Id: <v01530503ad06a739aaf8@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: Parting stuff for '95 - long
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Usually at this time of year, bka year end, I try to sum up what has
happened, and make predicitions as to what will happen in the coming year.
This year has been fine, I guess, in terms of parties, and fine, I guess,
in terms of new talent developing or talent becoming better refined.

I hardly go out anymore, so my experiences are limited to what I've
actually witnessed, as well as some second hand reports here and there.  I
can say this much, '96 should prove to be a very interesting year for those
with the guts to buck the system, or any system. More on this later.

With that in mind, it is my hope that this scene become more diverse, more
gay, more bi, and more brown.  I heard that Martin's Gathering accomplished
the brown part, most certainly. I hope that the plethora of promoters here
in the bay area (most of which are white), realize that they have some part
to play in keeping this, "thing" alive, but that it cannot survive without
a people transfusion on some scale.

When I first started going out back in the day, the crowd was mixed, now
all one sees are shirtless males (mostly white) on the prowl, along with
disco dollies doing everything to avoid the passing glance.  Why the cat &
mouse boys & girls?  Where, or where, have my gay/lesbian brothers and
sisters gone that have turned our house into multiple single family
dwellings? And where is the brown?

In an area noted for it's diverse talent, it comes as a major suprise that
there are NO, African American Dj's avaialble for bookings.  That there are
no lesbian sisters who are spinning, and there are no gay brothers spinning
at these mega events.  Makes the conspiracy theories of Farrakhan seem
plausible at some level.  This is especially shoking since house music, and
all that IS house, comes from the black gay community.  A segment of our
society not only invisible to most, but completely absent at any of these
mainstream events (and we KNOW what "mainstream" means).  This will be
corrected if there is to be a house still standing in SF in '96.

There is some hope.  With the election of our great political maven, Willie
Brown, and Terry Hallinan, we have made a sharp turn left.  There is hope
that permits will be easier to obtain (both Brown & Hallinan are rabid
night owls), and the pit-bull bka the police, stop the harassment of club
owners and underground parties. The other bright light is African
American's like myself, and brotha Geoff White getting together to do our
part in making this scene more representative of it's roots.  Just call it
Flava.

Nope, it's not about exclusion, it's about including blacks, latinos,
asians, women, gay, bi, straight, and others, back into the fold that is
house.  These people have been ignored or pushed aside as I see it, and an
effort needs to be made to make this house from ALL the colors, hues, and
lifestyles the bay area has to offer.  Including everyone, excluding no
one.

You promoters need to buy a clue as well.  There are plenty people of color
who spin.  Try booking one of us!  There are plenty of gay & bi DJ's in the
area as well, try adding some of that flavor to a party!  There are also
the largest gorwing segment of the DJ population that has gone almost
unheard of for '95.  And that is the women.  You male promoters need to get
past that old sorry ass formula and book some of the ladies for your
events.  I'm sure you'd be pleasantly suprised!


JSL's 95 last shouts:
=====================

"...you don't like how I'm livin', well fuck you!" (NWA - Gangsta Gangsta):
My dear Mr. Martin O'Brian.  You have been doing this for years now and
have one of the best parties in the bay area no doubt.  I hope you continue
with your many projects, and each becomes better than the last.  I also
hope you get off yer butt and book some brown, as well as some ladies, in
the coming year.  As for your admission price, whatever.  I am not one who
thinks everyone should be able to go out on your $.  I think that you
should charge what YOU think is fair, and if people can't pay it, then
there are other parties, of less cost, that they would be able to afford.
Staying home as always been an option for me, others might learn from that
excersize as well.  I hope you never succumb to those voices who say "Open
your books!", since none of them would open their personal finances to you.
Basically, keep up the good work, pay little heed to your detractors (who
ain't known you for even a Mississippi minute), and keep up the quality
productions.  Oh yeah, did I ask you to book some brown and some ladies in
the coming year?  Much peace and success my brotha!

"...I sit alone in a four cornered room starin' at candles, thinking of the
people I've dismantled!" (Geto Boys - Mind of A Lunatic):
Wicked!  All I can say is, wow!  You guys have put on some great shows this
year.  With the absence of some of your members at various times, you guys
stepped right up to the plate and booked out of town talent.  And how brown
it was!  Between Pierre, Lil' Louie, and Roger S.  You guys had all the
bases covered this year.  I hope you guys continue booking people we would
normally not get to hear.  I look forward to '96 and seeing what envelope
you guys will push next.    Nice touch on the fans this year too!  Been
thinking about your crowd huh?  One little thing, can you please post a
sign out front that says "be courteous to others, refrain from using body
paint, or grease paint while dancing!"  Yuch!  Too many crackerjacks trying
to get cro-magnon during the sets.  Ruins many a t-shirt.  Oh yeah, one
other thing, try booking some local brown in '96.  Some lady DJ's would be
a nice touch as well.  You know where we are.

"...fuckin' around in a crap game, people think I'm soft..." (Ice Cube -
What They Hittin' Foe?):
Stompy Stomp.  Need I say more.  With the addition of Mark Farina to the
perm lineup we got to see Derrick Carter, some of the time at least.
Preston still throws a good party.  This year was kinda shaky for my man,
as his parties go.  But everyone can't have a 100% season.  The good
things?  Good music, good vibe, not too many shirtless males, and plenty of
betties, bras & all!  But you, my man, I know if Mark wasn't there you'd
still be booking same-ol, same-ol.  C'mon my brotha, I expect much more
brown from you in '96.  I know it will be tough, but book a sistah (as in
female), every now and then.  If you can have 2 trainwreckers from England
spin, then the ladies & brown def. deserve a shot!

I'm done.

I hope all of you have a wonderful new year, and that all your dreams for
96 come true.  Mine already have.

OOPS I almost fortgot:
Now with the change in the political climate here in SF, there has been no
better time than now to push the dance culture agenda.  The gridlock of
having parties in the parks or on beaches must cease.  We should be able to
gather peaceably in any location as long as it's safe and there are permits
issued.  The toughest thing is that every park official will tell you to
"Apply for a permit!" full well and knowing it will be revoked as soon as
it reaches some slobs desk.  THIS MUST CEASE, and with the change in the
helm, we have a chance to change these catch-22 procedures.  I will be
spending some time in '96 using a connection or two to see what, if
anything can be done.  Others need to get involved as well.


Much Peace,
John

I too welcome more brown, (though I didn't feel deprived of it), also 
more female dj's are welcome as well.  Personally I think there was a 
slight increase in female djs this year.  In the end for me the ethnicity 
or gender of the dj doesn't matter.  The music being played is what 
matters the most to me.  I would have some issues if I felt that certain 
genders or cultures were purposely being excluded.  I don't know if there 
was an increase or decrease in the gay population of our scene this past 
year. 
I too hope our parties will have less difficulty going off, and can be 
more free of bust worry.
I must say I am very thankfull for the increase in outdoor parties this 
past year.  It was nice to have choices of which outdoor party to go to 
during the summer.  Nice to see an increase in party promoters, and imo 
an increase in the diversity of music  this year.
I've had some amazing times this past year, and with all you music lovers 
out there 96 looks to be another year with more amazing times.
Thanks everyone for being a part, that makes it all what it is.

:)
peter

> to whoever was looking for alien stuff:
( I lost the original post also )

When Christmas shopping in lovely Cupertino ( my home town ) at Vallco
Village, I found there is a new store called "Rave". It is a store
simular to Contempo or Wet Seal (love waiting in the dressing area of
that one), a total junior high school clothes store. Many, many aliens
on little tight cotton half shirts, lots of bright satin stuff, all
very low quality and price. It reminded me much of Hello Kitty,
although the darling mouthless one has much more tacht in her full
court marketing assault, the audience is simular. Let's hope rave
culture effects fashion whithout effecting pop-music as much as punk
culture did in the 80s.

-Darrel
darrele@netcom.com

>On Wed, 27 Dec 1995, Peter Fogel wrote:
>
>> I too welcome more brown, (though I didn't feel deprived of it), also
>> more female dj's are welcome as well.  Personally I think there was a
>> slight increase in female djs this year.  In the end for me the ethnicity
>> or gender of the dj doesn't matter.  The music being played is what ..
>         >^^^^^^^^^^^^  OR the sexual orientation. Thank you for this bit
>Peter;). it shouldn't depend on what color,gender, or sexual orientation
>she or he may be; it is what they spin *that* counts, what they give to
>the party as far as a trusting, strong vibe. If they can bring people
>together from *all* different backgrouds and colors through the music
>they create than they have given the party a positive and beautiful gift;).
>                                  -Raygun-

It's not a matter of trying to impose a quota or something.  But if there
are black DJ's in the area, why are they not getting any air time?  Fact
is, even in our scene, things can be a bit backward.  And it does matter,
if that is truly the case.

It matters if there is an all anything party in the most diverse of cities.
It matters if female DJ's don't get to play because of people myopia
concerning the role of women in our scene.  It matters if there are DJ's of
color who are conspicuously absent from all but a very, very, few events.
And in the end, it is reflected in the crowd.  Gay DJ's, Black DJ's,
Lesbian Dj's, Women DJ's, not only bring a different flavor to a party,
they bring thier friends!  So YES, it definitely makes a difference, IMO,
who spins and where.  Yes, my brothers and sisters, it is about the music
and that is one of the more important elemnts, but without the people there
would be nothing.  Music or not!

One would be hard pressed to deny that the majority of parties thrown these
days are primarily het. events.   One would also have a tough time denying
the fact that events have gotten a bit more homogenous over the years.
With some spikes here and there for sure.  Why?  Could it be, as someone
said to me, "Natural Segregation"?  I doubt it.  The energy has changed
from a pan-sexual one to a het. one.  From an all kinds vibe to a, some
would argue, "souless" one.  Now, I do not blame the DJ's, they do what
they do for people who like what they do.  But I guarantee that if you were
to put a Foxy Brown in the house to spin some, that my gay brothers would
come out of the woodwork to dance.  To put a Nikki Rivera up would get the
lesbian sisters out to groove as well.  So I have a difficult time buying
into anything that erases our differences for communal dancing.  Hell, we
should never erase our differences, we should revel in them...TOGETHER.
Promoters have alot to do with this transformation, and they can do alot by
booking gay/lesbian/female/people of color at their events.  We've already
seen what the absence of such DJ's has yeilded.

Like I said, this was not always true, it was a bit more diverse back in
the day than it is now.  I hope to bring some of that back, WIHTOUT putting
ANYONE on the backburner.

96 to me means Bringing The House Together.


Diversity Is House, and our house music.

Much peace and thanks for the comments,
John

P.S.  Yes, I am doing something about it.

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: mikecope@ix.netcom.com (Michael Copeland ), sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Subject: Re: Pissed, upset, etc...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

BY YOUR COMMAND;

        Some friendly advice, a general biz-ness rule, start small, raves
must be promoted at least 30 days in advance; for the entire 30 days, build
a following, & let word of mouth do your selling for you. I know lots of
investors, but I would never risk my name, on an unknown, trying to throw a
large party, until they have demostrated at least an average track record.

        Nature of the biz, lots o scams, lots o rip offs, lots o people take
the money & run, everyone has seen this on our scene. Also try doing a party
with one of the more well established promoters & make sure your name is on
the lit. This will give you some credability.

        I've seen totally fat raves the could have been large money makers
for all involved, fall flat, bankrupt & in serious debt. This one comes to
mind, they had everything in this roller rink in Florida, rides, good name
regonized DJ's, a great sound system, dual projectors, a fantasic totally
professional computer controled lighting system. 30 people showed up, I had
fun, but then again I was working the event.

        What went wrong, they didn't promote the event until a week before
it went off, and it was done by people who really did know what they were
doing. So you can have everything perfect & still have it fall flat, be
careful, and start small.

	oh, something else i forgot to mention... the event is getting
	rather popular and i have been hearing rumblings that it will
	not be happening next year becasue too many people would show.

	just a rumor, but one that makes sense to me.

On Dec 22,  4:57pm, morton@CyberGate.COM wrote:
> Subject: Re: Burning Man
>
> On Wed, 20 Dec 1995, Shawna McGourty wrote:
> > Was just wondering if anybody had any information about this, I mean
> > aside from what I found on a couple of websites.  One, how much is it
> > (how do they deal with that) and two, what kind of music is it?
>
> Shawna, this is definitely not an event to miss.  It was the most
> incredible experience I've ever had...partywise.
>
> It's held every Labor Day in the Black Rock Nevada desert.  I think it
> cost $40 to get in but I really can't remember (it was way worth the
> money though).
>
> Basically it's a major camping event.  You camp, you party, you dance
> all night long, you meet many new people and you'll never forget it.
> Some people go th the hot springs out there and chill out naked, or they
> simply walk around camp that way.  There are two camps, the main camp,
> and the rave camp. They are about 1 mile apart from each other because
> music plays at night long at the rave camp.
>
> I just can't get in to details because it's overwhelming.  It is so
> excellent when the huge wooden man burns.  Everyone surrounds him in
> a gigantic circle, and the people all around are just..."trippy".  I
> loved it!  After that a big phallic looking thing gets burned, everyone
> bonds, and many drum circles are formed.  If we ever meet I can bring
> photos.  Oh, as far as the toileting situation goes, outhouses are provided
> and they are very kept up.  I was sort of worried but they are kept very
> clean by someone (who knows).
>
> I highly recommend this event to everyone. It's a must for me in 96 and
> I'd love to make plans with lots of people.  My friend I went with moved
> to Amsterdam and my normal Fresno gang probably couldn't handle it:)
>
> Marty
>
>-- End of excerpt from morton@CyberGate.COM

Personally, I think $20 is too much for a party, even if it is by Pacific.

Last year, I am pretty sure Begin Again was $15 or maybe less...and 
because of the participation of many folks, including Cyberlab and the 
New Moon, it was a beautiful party.

wonderful!  I'm afraid to go because nothing could surpass that magical 
night.  

Mooning over the past,

Ann

called Mos Isley Spaceport.

Cool sounds and not the clubby feel I get from the other Techno weeklies.

villianous Spaceport: Mos Isley...

Don't you think it's better to pay $25 + to get a memorable evening vs. a 
cheap one that was only margional.  Especially for NYE.  I would pay $100 
for the ultimate rave, with lasers out of Babalon5, just unbelevibly

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Dec 28 00:09:20 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id AAA21465; Thu, 28 Dec 1995 00:09:20 -0800
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id AAA21460; Thu, 28 Dec 1995 00:09:16 -0800

From: "Fred Heutte" <phred@well.com>

Date: Thu, 28 Dec 1995 00:09:07 -0800
In-Reply-To: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
        "Re: Parting stuff for '95 - long" (Dec 27,  2:17pm)
References: <v01530506ad070071a147@DialupEudora>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee), Reagan Reid <raygun@value.net>
Subject: Re: Parting stuff for '95 - long
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I want to chime in with pretty much full agreement with jslee's assessment
of the current SF scene.  But it's not enough simply to bring in more
non-white-male DJs into the big events -- that's a project that always
has value because there's always been a need.  Remember, even in the thick
of things in 1992 enough women got pissed off at the way things were
working that they put together Your Sisters House, which stands to me as
the example of how to do things differently and meet different objectives
than simply packing as many people into a warehouse or club as you can
and still have most everyone have a good time.  

I think in retrospect that the 1991-93 period in SF was unusual in the
temporary interaction of the club and underground scenes, which have
gradually gone their separate ways since then.  The reasons for that
unique crossover were musical, social, economic and even political in
nature, I think.  In reflecting on John's observations of who's doing
what and the general attitude out there, I think what we
have seen is a relapse into a bit of cultural conservatism (of our
own type, and I don't disinclude net.ravers from that analysis).  

The fact of the matter, if you check the gay/lesbian and African-American
oriented publications in town (and they are readily available), is that
there are quite a few non-white-male-type-people out there playing records
and CDs for the public.  In fact, quite a few of them play house and some
techno, although tastes vary, obviously, by DJ and by crowd.  The same
as we wouldn't want our scene known only because well known "flyer names"
like the Wicked crew spin what they do -- as much as I like their approach
we have lots more to choose from -- the other "sub-scenes" would also like
to be known as having more than just the few major known names we might
have heard of in passing.  I mean, just who do you think buys all those
records at BPM, Soundworks, Tweakin and even Star Alley?  It's not just
the traditional "underground rave" DJs, that
's for sure, and it's not just "collectors."  

I think we need something like a neo-speakeasy movement, where DJs of
all kinds get together "after peak hours" to spin stuff for each other's
enjoyment and that of a reasonable number of people, and outside the
usual set of venues.  That would be ideal in my world.  Other than the
venue sense, the last time I've had that kind of feeling (other than
F&F, which is in its own category entirely) is the last couple months
of Boogie Buffet, and that's two years ago now.  

Sorry about the nostalgia, folks.  Given where things could have gone
starting a couple years ago -- hell, given how they *have* gone in
many places -- the SF scene is really still good.  It's just that you
have to hop across the little cultural divides that have started to
grow up among the music subscenes like weeds, to get it.

No big schemes or global fix-its here from me, anyway, just some
semi-meanderings . . .

c ya
phred


Yeah, I'll rarely part with $20 nowadays for a party, but as far as NYE 
celebrations go (including all the non-rave events), $20 is definitely at 
the low end of what you could spend in the City. I have a couple friends 
trying to find a hotel ballroom party that won't cost them half their 
January rent. Some of the prices they found (one hotel was $150 per 
couple) would make me want to stay home and watch Dick Clark. A few of 
them included dinner, but most offered little more than a complimentary 
glass of champagne.

>             Thank you!!!!!!!
>
>
>On Wed, 27 Dec 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:
>
>> asking gay/lesbian/black/girl/boy/etc. to play simply because of these
>> attributes is sounding like affirmitive action...their energy and
>> openness, their attitude and their values are more important in the long run.
>> just my .o2 -
>>
>> kevin
>> :)
>>
>>

Well, I can see you don't understand affirmative action to well, or it's
purpose.  What you're talking about is a quota system, and I am against
that.  AA, of course, I am completely for!  So maybe that's where we
differ.  Hell, if people aren't comfortable hiring gay Dj's, then I'll hire
them.  If people are so worried about mixing it up with people from other
spheres, then I invite those from those shperes to party with me.  Yes, it
is affirmative action.  There are plenty of promoters, like in life, who
hire those people they are most comfortable with.  And the seperation of
the houses in SF is proof of this.  The old boys club that is rampant in
this city is proof as well of AA for male DJ's only.  So why be afraid if a
black male stands up and says that the forms of AA that are present in our
scene now really suck and are quite exclusionary.  Why use the term AA to
try to score political points in an attempt to undermine what I see as a
real tragedy with our scene; the division of people into their own cliques.
Is this really where you want to be?  If so fine, continue to support the
parties you like, I will continue to support those people who are about a
bigger picture, and not about a niche or genre or a spoecific group of
people.

No, I will not allow your misunderstanding of AA to cloud my true intent,
and that is to mix it up.

I agree with the second part of the statement however, and that is one
crucial element.  But to say that the vibe here hasn't changed since things
have segregated is to ignore what went on in 91-92, when the lines were not
so clearly drawn housewise.

BTW - When someone hires someone because they are comfortable with them,
that's AA.  When someone tells you about a DJ and you hire them, thats AA
too.  It's much more than a slogan or acronym, it's how America has done
business for well over 400 years.  Just ask the Getty's, DuPont's,
Vanderbilts, Ford's, etc. All of whom had wonderful AA programs to ensure
thier place in America's history.  So be care ful when you go around
insinuating that there is something wrong with AA.  When used to create a
representation of society as a whole, it is a beautiful thing.  When it is
used to further seperation, tribal rubiish, and social cliques, it becomes
nothing more than veiled apartheit.

Late.

Subject: NYE == $$$$$$$$$

Before we get into how much it's going to cost , and people "citing" how
much it's going to cost, let's be very clear:  NYE is nothing more than a
reason for everyone to ask for very large sums of cashish!  Ain't America
grand!

>From the rental of sound to the steel whell drivers (DJ's), everyone gets
paid during new years eve parties.  Entrance fees have ranged from $20
(very, very, very low by  my estimates), to upwards of $100+ (suit and ties
recommended).  In our scene the highest prices I've seen was New Years '92
Toon Town with a fee of $35 to get in!  Yikes!

Oh, but try to rent sound from any place that does sound, and you will find
the fees run 2-3 times greater than normal.  DJ's usually charge a premium
(those who can command it), as well as everyone else down the food chain.
There's no way around it, new years eve is all about gankin', jackin', &
steady mobbin' for duckets.  It's money time in the big city!

Guest passes will be hard to find for those not very well connected.  DJ's
will be offered rides from all kinds of people in the hopes of avoiding the
stiff entrance fee, ego's will be out of control, people will be crying
over how expensive exotic substances will be for this one night of bliss,
women will have plenty of escorts so the booty & bra factor should be high,
there will be more suits than you've ever seen at a party (no matter how
"underground" your stuff might be), and people should be going ballistic,
seeing aliens, religious visions, positive vibes and all.  Yes, it will be
like old sodom with a twist.

But let's not forget why there will be new years parties at all: $, $$, and
more $$$$'s, cuz' in SF, that's what new years is all about!

So when you're takin' out that last 60.00 from that ATM, remember, at least
you're not alone in the suffering.  You got friends around you to re-define
the moment.  Take solace in that thought, and have a good time.  Oh yeah,
be careful, there should be plenty of cops out this year busting one and
all who either ask or answer the question:"You want some E?".

be safe.

John S. Lee:
>   Hell, if people aren't comfortable hiring gay Dj's, then I'll hire
> them.  If people are so worried about mixing it up with people from other
> spheres, then I invite those from those shperes to party with me.

Well, it seems that the best way for some excluded group to get noticed,
and then included, is for them to go out and make it happen.  Look what 
happened with the trance enthusiasts.  Folks like Ethan and Frequency8 
started throwing their own parties, established followings and a vibe that
couldn't be ignored, and now some of these DJs are getting invited to
the bigger parties, bringing along the people who are attracted to that
flavor of energy.  So go for it John!  Hopefully there will be enough
people who want the flavor you're promoting to make it thrive and
prove itself viable enough to be tapped by more mainstream promoters.

Speaking of parties with diversity: Preston (Boogie Buffet, Stompy,
Groove Kitchen) is throwing a New Year's Day party at 1015 Folsom
that just might offer the best vibe of any this weekend.  Anyone
remember the NY DAY Boogie Buffet party he threw at the same location 
2 years ago?  It was totally sick!

Anyway, NYEve events can sometimes be disappointing - too many people
out partying just because they're supposed to; an obligation imposed by 
a calender that is very out of sync with nature.  Nevertheless, I
look forward to dancing with you all, wherever you are.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Dec 28 10:30:15 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id KAA25275; Thu, 28 Dec 1995 10:30:15 -0800

BY YOUR COMMAND;

        Much Praise & Salutations to the very teeny tiny one cell creatures
that do business on the Haight for a vunderful party last night, that packed
two floors at 1015 Folsum, hats off to DJ Tracy, Mark, Allen ...etc

        Everyone had a great time, including myself; though the music could
have been a little faster, and a little more psychoactive for my particular
dancing tastes, but then, what can you say about "something you live in";
someone say House.  Oh, with the exception of these two womyn who purchased,
guess what, Niacin while looking for #(you know), be careful out there folks.
                                
        Don't get me wrong, it's not that I don't like House, there's just
so much of it out there, here, everywhere & any thang below 140 bpm, HURTS
MY BODY TO MOVE SOOOOO SLOW. More Techno & Gabber/Goa/Cyber..etc Trance in
1996, lets make 96 be the year for Trance in SF, here here!!!!

        As far as the upstairs went, I really can't comment except with the
following exceptions. It was packed, but I don't think you can call what
they were spinning up there Jungle. In fact it seemed kinda slower than the
downstairs House, diverse, & fragmented, but regardless, the people were
definately having a good time dancing to whatever it was.

        It was fun, as it is always, seeing SF finest DJ's; like Carlos,
just out having fun, and listening to their friends spin.

        I got to meet some new Web Browser Ravers/lurkers out there like
Heather, & Zoe Hiya = >!!!! Some old friends I hadn't seen in a while, which
is always cool, like Geoff White. Our always welcome indigenous British
Nationals were out in force lastnight, adding a slight accent to a night of
bloody good fun, like Neil & Rebecca. Just when you thought it was safe to
post again, guess what, Tristan's back. I actually didn't see him at Black
Diamond but at C^3'ed party, but all the same it's good to havem back, at
least I think so. I'm actually suprised he hasn't posted yet, hope he not
getting shy on us : >.

        I got to meet Polywog & her sister; Hiya!!!, she traded me a tape
for #(you know), dat was cool. I haven't listened to it yet, the only place
I have a cassette deck is in my friends car, so it will have to wait until then.

        Oh, while I was at C^3 party last week, I met this cartoon artist
womyn, who I traded  a #(you know), for some of her work. The work was
entitled "Ideas How To Save The World Today." I wish you could see the work,
it's really cool stuff, but it's her ideas that really peaked my interest.
Some of them are; A new consumer system where you got things you needed for
free; like food & stuff, but you had to pay for everything that you threw
away. On the ever increasing population problem she proposed that more
people should become homosexual, making more room for wildlife, & it would
also help solve the issue of parentless children in adoption facilities. 

        Hiya Betsy, from C^3, didn't think I would remember you, huh!!!!!

        I really start feeling like a World Citizen when I get to meet sooo
many people from different cultures, places of origin, & back grounds at a
rave, all there to do the same thang, celabrating life together.

        Well anyway my ? is, did anyone go to Simply Done, if so, how wuz
it. Wedesdays are cool, and it looks like Tuesday's are looking up these
days with dat new weekly, well at least from a Trance perspective.

	id AA820176972; Thu, 28 Dec 95 10:55:42 PST
Date: Thu, 28 Dec 1995 10:55:42 PST
From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>
Message-Id: <9511288201.AA820176972@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>
To: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re[2]: Burning Man 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     I had a brief conversation with someone about this just yesterday.  
     And while I still feel that we should create parties in the wilderness 
     DIY style, there has to be an element of responsibility.  
     Responsibility to our environment, and within the boundaries of laws 
     (natural and government) to take care of ourselves.
     
     Now I know this is going to gank some "old-timers" who were into the 
     scene when renegades were the thing.  And I have to admit that I 
     wasn't part of the scene then, nor do I feel that renegades should go 
     away.  But if we want to grow in vibe and in numbers, gain respect, 
     and avoid hassles for what we believe in, then there has to be a part 
     of the scene that takes care of business and shows responsibility.  
     And I define responsibility as accountability, reliability, and 
     trustworthiness.
     
     Why reinvent the wheel when it's already in place?  Sure we can just 
     go out into the desert and make things happen, but any _responsible_ 
     promoter would ensure measures for care and safety of not only his 
     crew but for those in attendance.  This includes first aid, transport 
     to medical facilities, coordination and pay to the Bureau of Land 
     Management and local law enforcement agencies, adequate water supply, 
     chemical pit toilets, trash disposal, liability insurance, etc.  The 
     BM crew has thought this all out and has well established ties w/the 
     proper sources.  They've worked hard to make things run as smooth as 
     possible _and_ they've opened their arms to allow the rave camp to 
     co-exist and benefit from all their hard work.
     
     Now I've participated in enough parties and helped break down/clean-up 
     some to know we're not the cleanest, neatest bunch all the time.  And 
     some people are just out there to go off and don't know what they're 
     getting into until they're freaking out or getting their stomach 
     pumped.  When you open a party up, you need to look at your purpose, 
     audience, and scope and hopefully cover all the bases _if_ you want to 
     have a good rep. and a repeat performance.
     
     Perhaps I'm too idealistic and have my own vision of growth for the 
     scene and that's because my background has been to throw legit 
     smoke-free, alcohol-free dance parties.  But I do hope that some of 
     what I say above is taken into consideration when planning, promoting, 
     and best of all, enjoying the fruits of your labor.
     
     Just a mom at heart,
     Diane :)

> 
> 
> >Well, I can see you don't understand affirmative action to well, or it's
> >purpose.  What you're talking about is a quota system, and I am against
> >that.  AA, of course, I am completely for!  
> (snip)
> >BTW - When someone hires someone because they are comfortable with them,
> >that's AA.  When someone tells you about a DJ and you hire them, thats AA
> >too.  It's much more than a slogan or acronym, it's how America has done
> >business for well over 400 years.
> (snip)
> 
> What are you talking about?  Alcoholics Anonymous?  Affirmative Action *is* 
> a quota system!  It's base premise is matching the racial and sexual 
> percentages in a company with the racial and sexual percentages in the 
> community.  *That's* a quota system, my friend.  It makes no mention of 
> qualifications.  Affirmative Action's history is rank with horror stories 
> about great, qualified, experienced people being overlooked in favor of 
> hiring a far less qualified and experienced person simply because that 
> person is a minority.

Wrong, wrong, and er, wrong,.  You should look it up, better yet read 
what AA actually is and then we can have a discussion.  Affirmative 
Action and it ghoals are quite clear.  Integration of the workplace.  It 
is NOT a quota system.  Please read executive order 11246, and we can 
have a discussion.  You might also want to read the Civil Rights Act of 
1964, and we can have a discussion.

Affirmative Action goals are a concious and deliberate effort to bring 
qualified people of color and women into jobs and educational 
opproitunities from which they had been traditionally excluded.  So with 
that your argument that AA does not consider qualifications is false (too 
much Newt?).

I will not respond to the rest of your argument since it is based upon 
the false premise that AA does not consider qualifications, when in fact, 
it's charter is to put qualified women and people of color into positions 
that they had been excluded from  historically.

As for AA for 400 years: , dig this:

White men are 33% of the population , yet
85% of tenured professors
85% of partners of major law firms
80% of the US house of representatives
90% of the US sentate
95% of the fortune 500 ceo's
97% of school superintendents
99.9% of professional athletic team owners
100% of US presidents

But, by your logic, these people must have all been qualified for the 
jobs & positions they hold?  Gimme a break.

Nope, AA is needed alright as long as the numbers above are true.


Sorry.  Please read the publications I stated previously for a start, and 
we can have an intelligent discussion.  I don't engage in soundbite 
battles of either the left or right.

Peace,
John 

> 
> Now, to be fair, AA pushed back against a great and terrible imbalance 
> created by discrimination.  It forced businesses and, more importantly, 
> schools to be blind to racial differences.  An entire generation has grown 
> up under it's protection, grown up, been educated, trained, worked, and 
> gained experience thanks to the barriers it broke down.
> 
> AA is NOT how America did business for 400 years.  Slavery and the 
> good-ole-boy network is how America did business for the first 380 years of 
> it's existance.  It's only in the last generation that things have swung around.
> 
> But AA's time has passed, IMHO.  There are qualified people, male and 
> female,  for every job from every race.  There are laws that prohibit 
> discrimination.  A quota system is no longer needed.
> 
> Please don't pretend to lecture until you understand the topic.
> 
> S
> 
> 
> 
 

I do not pretend to lecture, maybe you should stop pretending to 
understand a topic you have done little reading on.  The fact that women 
in this country are paid 71 cents on the dollar of white men means that 
AA is still needed.  The fact that the slaries of blacks in 1971 were 57% 
that of whites, and in 1991 it shifted to 56% is further proof.

I would suggest that before you even attempt debate in this area you read 
and UNDERSTAND The 1990 census, maybe browse the Glass Ceiling Report of 
1995,  the report issued by the US General Accounting Office of this 
year, as well as reports by the US Commission on Civil Rights, papers by 
the Peter Y. Harris research Group, the Congressional research Service, 
and the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights.

No, I'm afraid that I'm well armed with facts in this area, obviously 
moreso than you.  When you get done with that light reading, and do some 
absorbtion, we can talk.  Until then sir....later.

Out, John :)

In-Reply-To: <199512281829.KAA09851@shellx.best.com> from "SDream" at Dec 28, 95 10:48:09 am

> AA is NOT how America did business for 400 years.  Slavery and the 
> good-ole-boy network is how America did business for the first 380 years of 
> it's existance.  It's only in the last generation that things have swung around.
> 

I love debunking people's shit:

1776 - The right to vote is reserved for WHITE males only.
1820 - Proprty rights are set aside for white men exclusively.
1862 - We drive the Indians (Native (REAL) Americans), off their lands 
giving homesteads away to white settlers.
1900 - Faculty at most all Universities are white males.
1960 - Construction and other work once thought the domain of men, is 
challenged via the womens movement.
1995 - Affirmative Action for women and minorities?  That's UNAmerican!

Give me a break.  I think you need a clear sense of history.  And if you 
think that just one generation is enough to undo over 15 generations of 
dmamge, you had better go back to school and get a basic understanding of 
physics (conservation of energy).

History; Learn from it, or die re-living it!

Peace,
John

Subject: Re: Re[2]: Burning Man 
In-Reply-To: <9511288201.AA820176972@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>

On Thu, 28 Dec 1995, Diane Tabellija wrote:

>      Why reinvent the wheel when it's already in place?  Sure we can just 
>      go out into the desert and make things happen, but any _responsible_ 
>      promoter would ensure measures for care and safety of not only his 
>      crew but for those in attendance.  This includes first aid, transport 
>      to medical facilities, coordination and pay to the Bureau of Land 
>      Management and local law enforcement agencies, adequate water supply, 
>      chemical pit toilets, trash disposal, liability insurance, etc.  The 
>      BM crew has thought this all out and has well established ties w/the 
>      proper sources.  They've worked hard to make things run as smooth as 
>      possible _and_ they've opened their arms to allow the rave camp to 
>      co-exist and benefit from all their hard work.


Exactly, and the above reasons are why I was more than happy to fork over 
$40 to BM for a ticket at the gate.  Hell, I would have thrown at lest 
that much in if it was donation only.

The BM crew does an incredible job of taking care of a few thousand 
people in a hostile environment, and this is due, I suspect, to quite a 
bit of experience.  If Wicked, or anyone else for that matter, tried to 
throw a rave in Black Rock simmilar to what happened this year without 
the support structure built by BM, I would fear the worst.  I must admit 
I wasn't one of the people who spent the next week after the event 
picking up trash, but I seriously doubt that enough people in this scene 
would be dedicated enough to do such a good job of cleaning up after 
themselves.  Cleaning up your own mess is one thing, but scouring the 
desert for the refuse from thousands of people is an amazing venture.

Also, BM goes out of it's way to inform people of the hazards and dangers 
involved in this venture, and has a very effective network for spreading 
this information to participants.  Would a Black Rock Rave '96 do this?  
Most "ravers" I know spent a sum total of an hour, maybe, planning for an 
event before they go, and I think having the rave part of burning man as 
a secondary focus cut down on those people who whould be horribly 
underprepared for this event.


my .02
patrick

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday noon-3pm - House and techno w/DJ Unknown and guests - KZSU
       90.1 (Stanford)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" w/DJ Seth. Ambient,
       experimental, ethereal, acid-trance-techno, industrial and
       trip-hop on KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@netcom.com
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Saturday morning - "The Uncle Noah TV Show" 6-9am, KDVS 90.3,
       Davis.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. KFJC 89.7 -
       Los Altos Hills

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

When they opened for Praxis, Mixmaster Mike played with them too. This is
not to be missed if you are at all interested in the ways of the mixer and
turntables; they are a "band" of DJs (8 turntables) who play different parts
of "songs" together: one may play hi hat and bass drum, one snare, one
dropins, and one vocals. It's amazing shit.

eh

and the Trance pary new years eve?

Last year I had Begin again tickets but was also suppose to meet up with
friends at the 938 Harrison bash. I was horror stricken :( when they informed
me there would be NO ins and outs at Begin Again!! I had planned on kind of
bouncing back and forth between the two parties as they were not too many
blocks apart. Instead I had to leave Begin again between 1 and 2 to make it
over to 938 harrison to meet friends. 

I understand the motivation behind no ins and outs in underground spaces but
I sure would like to know _ahead of time_. I would like to attend both events
new years eve and it sounds like they both will be happening in downtown SF.

I'm hoping at least one of the parties will not have this restriction.
Anybody know the in/out policies of these parties?

peace,
martin

Subject: BSP: Deadhead NYE party in San Rafael

This isn't really rave-related, but this is going to be a really good
party on NYE, and the "tapes until dawn" part is actually going to be
me and Bryce.  We'll feed 'em some house'n'techno if we can possibly
manage it :-)

So if you have any affinity for the Dead scene, this promises to be
a memorable time.  

It's being put together by my friend Michael Fasman (mlf@well.sf.ca.us),
actually starting well before the official announcement that the Dead
are retiring, so it's a bit of a last hurrah for those of us who've
been doing that for all this time.  I'm certainly looking forward to it!

If you have any additional questions about the party, please email me.
I haven't seen the location yet but I gather it's a really nice theatre
at the Jewish community center in San Rafael.

I'm also hoping to see lots of y'all at 1015 Folsom on New Year's day too!

peace
phred

--------


From: Michael Fasman (mlf@well.sf.ca.us)

There are still tickets left to the  New Years Eve to the 
GRATEFUL NEW YEARS EVE party in San Rafael, CA! 


Tickets will be sold at the door the night of the event.

The party is at the Osher Marin Jewish Community Center,
200 N. San Pedro Rd, San Rafael. Take the San Pedro Road exit
off 101, head east. The center is 1/2 mile on the right. 

For a $30 donation you get admission, beer, midnight champagne 
or sparkling cider, soft drinks and festivities galore, including 
music by "The Reptiles" ( featuring David Gans) , "Hot Links" 
(New Orleans swing/funk/rock) and dancing to tapes till dawn.
Lighting by Brotherhood of Light. The Bolinas Bakery will be 
selling food. Doors open at 7PM.

You MUST be 21 or older to attend. Security will be checking IDs.
You may bring in liquor, food, and cameras but please leave
children and pets at home. 

Proceeds to benefit the Rex and Eyes of Chaos Foundations.  
There'll also a benefit raffle with great prizes (K2 Dead skis,
a Gibson guitar signed by Ratdog Revue, a signed Herb Greene print
and merchandise).

Hope to see you there!

This event is in no way associated with the Grateful Dead, 
Bill Graham Presents or other organizations or individuals
affiliated with the Grateful Dead. The Rex Foundation is not 
sponsoring the event. No members of the Grateful Dead will be
performing, nor attending as far as we know.

> "Rocky Mullin" <caliban@organic.com>:
> > oh, something else i forgot to mention... the event is getting 
> > rather popular and i have been hearing rumblings that it will 
> > not be happening next year becasue too many people would show. 
> >
> > just a rumor, but one that makes sense to me.

>From my (admittedly brief) dealings with Larry Harvey and the rest of
the core crew (I was there for a week before the event this year):

They were about to stop because they had lost money for too long.  I heard
something like "The credit cards are all maxed out.  If we lose money this
year there might not be another."

Of course, they might just be exhausted from riding the death pony for too
long.  Damn, but that's a lot of work, and I didn't see those folks really
enjoying themselves -- mostly a lot of wandering around with CB headsets
on trying to keep people from injuring themselves or others.  I wonder at
what point people might ask themselves "So why _am_ I doing this?... Fuck it."

> Is there any reason why the Wicked crew couldn't just set up their 
> soundsystem out in the desert during labor day weekend?? Do we really 
> need the rest of the burning man organization?? Instead, why not ride 
> on their coattails and have a "burning rave" out in the desert without 
> all the B.M. brouhaha??

Will Wicked provide their own porta-potties, or will they just sponge off
of the BM project's?  Or will people just crap on the playa?  Will Wicked
deal with the BLM and Nevada police?  Will they do liaison and fundraisers
for the town of Gerlach to keep the goodwill of the locals, or will they
just sponge off the hard work done by others?  Will they spend the time
necessary to leave the playa as they found it afterward?  (Took the BM
people nearly a week.)

Much more goes into creating the BM community on the playa than any
renegade I've seen.  I think having a separate rave out there sometime
could be really cool (anyone remember Pete Ashdown's Salt Lake events?)
but leeching off BM is not the right way to do it.  Either be part of BM,
and take that responsibility, or do it separately in time and space and
take that responsibility.

> I personally can create my own virtual burning man in my head after 
> having my mind blown by wicked. No need for fire when you're swimming 
> in liquid sound!

It's too bad that you feel that way, Neils; it brings it home to me that
the ritual of the Man isn't what it once was.  Damn.

// g

>Just a note:  As i was exiting the building after tribal funks party was
>busted, I overheard  one cop asked another how they knew where the party was
>gonna be heald.  The other cop smirked and told the newbie that they get a

Yea,  well I'm not surprised.  It's been assumed for a very long time that
the pigs are probably monitoring the list.   Which is why it's important to
keep announcements of underground partys off the list,  and only via Email.

Who knows,  it might even come to the possibility of us using PGP.   But I
assume people use that for privacy anyway.

In fact,  I remember thats how I got involved in the SFRaves list in the
first place,  as I was really pumped about the ideas of using encryption,
but unknown to me,  PGP had already been discussed at length long before
joined the list.    I met Geoff White at the Cypherpunk meeting and thanks
to Geoff,  I discovered the SFRaves list.   Just a tad bit of history...

Crunchman
http://www.well.com/user/crunch

At 5:54 PM 12/29/95, John Draper wrote:
>>Just a note:  As i was exiting the building after tribal funks party was
>>busted, I overheard  one cop asked another how they knew where the party was
>>gonna be heald.  The other cop smirked and told the newbie that they get a
>>list weekly of where all the parties are gonna be heald.  Hmmmm.....wonder
>>where they get their list.....could it be....naaaaaaaa
>>FYI
>
>Yea,  well I'm not surprised.  It's been assumed for a very long time that
>the pigs are probably monitoring the list.   Which is why it's important to
>keep announcements of underground partys off the list,  and only via Email.

You know, you've been using the term "the pigs" for quite some time on SF
Raves to describe law enforcement, and I resent it.

My father is a retired (25 year duty) police officer, and even though I am
a raver and I imbibe in 'illegal' substances and attend 'illegal' parties,
that does not placate my simple respect for people that put their lives on
the line daily. This also does not mean that I 'side' with the police on
any occasion, either.

We, the underground music community, may often have differing opinions
about parties, etc. from the law enforcement community, but that is no
excuse to not give them simple respect that they deserve, no necessarily as
police officers, but as humans -- this mutual respect is often what we
expect (and deserve) from them in return.

________________________________________________
"The playa is closed. Please leave immediately."
________________________________________________

BY YOUR COMMAND;

        Ok, people, there's a time to pick daisies, a time to love & a time
to FIGHT. The  Soviet KGB for years sucessfully used a tactic called
Disinformation in an attemt to combat the CIA's attemts to spy on them, &
vice a verse a.

        Disinformation is basically carefully & well thought out constucted
lies, or false information the vaguely resembles the truth or true
intentions. This is information is basically a trap, that would lead the
spying party away or indicate a direction that has no true meaning, it is a
favorite & sucessfull tactic I've adopted over the years. Hmmm, maybe
working for mil. all those years is going to pay off after all.

        Digital Disinformation is basically the same thing only in a digital
format. So I'm proposing the people start thinging about either how we can
incorporate this methologogy/tactic on our list, while minimizing incidentes
that the ocasional raver will also fall for the trap. That can simply  be
combated by useing more & more map points, as well as fun false word of
mouth nights where a few of us take the cops for a ride. Because even with
map points all it takes  is a cop in an unmarked car to follow one of us to
the eventual location of the party and then bust it.

        We all know how cops hate waisting their time, being setup, and
following false leads. Keep in mind they use this tactic as well to confuse,
and create mistrust among the ranks of the lawless; in the eyes of our gov.

person jaded, and make it difficult to see the good in people when all 
you are dealing with is the shit.

> Behind the guns and badges, there is a *HUMAN BEING* Yes, too many of 
> them are on small-dick power trips(uuhhh I rhymed), but there are some 
> out there that are real people. How would you feel having to deal with 
> murders, rapists, child-molesters and slews of other agitated, unhappy, 
> apathetic people every day? From what I have heard it really can make a 
> person jaded, and make it difficult to see the good in people when all 
> you are dealing with is the shit.  
----------------------
yes, they are human being, and you're probably right that there are
some that are real people.  Unfortunately, 1 bad cop on a "small-dick
power trip" makes a heavier impression than the 20 decent cops who work
along side the bad one.  The fact is, most people don't have what it
takes to be a good cop, and from all appearances, most of those cops
on small-dick power trips probably need to get employed elsewhere,
because policing is too important, requires too much responsibility
for it too be taken lightly.  Cops need to walk a *finer* line than
the rest of us because of the responsibility invested in them; if that's
too much for you don't become a cop, because the only kind of cops we
need are the ones who can truly handle the job, not pigs on power
trips.  I've met some really cool cops, don't get me wrong.  A cool
cop is a real cool thing indeed.  But I've met too many pigs on 
power trips for my satisfaction and it needs to be changed.  We may
have the opportunity to see that in SF with Hallinan as DA, as he's
been in favor of greater police accountability before, we shall see.

lat,

*

I totally agree. Power corrupts, absolute power...

For antecdotal purposes: My friends brother, a stocky third degree BB in 
Kempo, with BB's in two other styles and just a very level, personable guy, 
had his application turned down for Fairfield PD because they did not feel 
that he would be "aggresive" enough. This suggests to me that it is not 
only the police themselves that need to be evaluated, but the hiring 
procedures, the people doing the hiring, and what traits are viewed as 
"desirable."    

I also agree with Wayne's statement. Calling all cops pigs is 
tantamount to calling all[insert racial/religious/sexual group] [insert 
expletive here.] If someone were to do that here, people would be 
(rightfully) all over your ass. 

I hope we all see some positve results of the recent elections. I guess 
one has occured already.... Bye bye Ribera.... ;)

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA07504; Sun, 31 Dec 1995 09:13:58 -0800
Received: from netcom13.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA07494; Sun, 31 Dec 1995 09:13:55 -0800
Received: by netcom13.netcom.com (8.6.12/Netcom)

Date: Sun, 31 Dec 1995 09:10:42 -0800 (PST)
From: Peter Fogel <peterf@netcom.com>
Subject: special rave on christmas story
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9512310840.A10483-0100000@netcom13>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Being that I don't celebrate christmas anymore so than any other day, I 
usually work and get that time and a half money.  On christmas day I was 
working on the intensive locked unit of the psychiatric hospitol that I 
work at.  Being short staffed that day, my girlfriend angela (who also 
loves to rave) was asked to work overtime onto my shift.  This was the 
first time we were working the same shift together on the same unit. :)

One of the younger patients told me she was bored, and said to me "your 
my staff person entertain me."  I told her I wasn't there to really 
entertain her but maybe we could entertain each other with some dance 
music. From there I got out the boombox put it in the middle of the unit 
and popped in a garth tape.

It wasn't long before angela and I had about 90% of the unit dancing.  We 
even got a  patient from the unit next door to come over and dance.  It 
was great to see the over weight 55 year old charge nurse come over and 
dance, saying she hadn't danced in years, and that she should do this 
more often.  It was GREAT!  At one point we all naturally formed a circle 
and dance and the vibe was just about as thick as any rave I've been to.  I 
had a huge smile on my face as I thought to myself I'm raving at work.

Unfortunately I wouldn't feel comfortable having this rave thing at work 
on any day in front of some of the staff I work with, as i think they 
might frown apon it.  But this day was great, it was nice to see the 
patients transcend their problems for a while and enjoy life for a 
while.  The dancing in the beginning of the shift  created enough 
positive energy to carry throughout the evening and helped make christmas 
more enjoyable for all.

happy new year

:)
peter

So, you've read the posts, and have decided to go to one of tha various
parties to ring in the new year.  Are you really, and I mean really ready?

Check my little prep. list to see whther this will be an amatuer night for
you, or whther you're a party professional:

-Got your wallet?  Good.  Have $40 for the entrance fee (prices all of a
sudden go up when you buy tix at the door.  SF Party Code 104).  Along with
your money, don't wimp out this year.  If they can ask for 20 or more
dollars, you are within your rights to ask for guest list.  It's easy once
you know how.  Insist that you're one of the people who handed out flyers
for the organization and demand that they pay you back by alowwing you, and
you 15 friends in for free.  Hell, you can never go to far, besides, don't
start '96 out like a newbie, approach the guest list with confidence, and
get yours!

-Have you made all the right connections before the show?  The worse thing
you can do tonite is ask one person after another, if they have been
connected.  Who knows who or what you might bump into.  Johnny Law will be
in full effect, and I'm sure he would be very interested in helping make
some new connections.  Right in city jail.

-Sobriety check points?  Get a clue, they put these things on the streets,
not the highways.

-My brain hurts, where can I get a head cool down?  Why, either at Boogie
Stompy Super Deluxe Prime-Time Crackerjack New Years Mroning Cafe, or the
End-Up if you ain't done tweekin'.  Better get there really early, cuz that
place will fill up with the deniznes of the night real quick.  If all goes
according to plan, there should be plenty of banality for all.  I should be
fairly out of it by 8:00 A.M.  Aftr that nice warm shower in the morning
I'll need some beer and Jaeger to coll down properly.

-ATM card ready?  After you've bought the first 10 rounds, it'll be time
for you to buy some more, c'mon, you got a job, unlike some of your
friends.  Spread the joy!  Oh yeah, are you connected?  Cool, lemme have
one and I'll gladly pay you tuesday....

-Please wear SUNGLASSES.  There is nothing more scary than looking at a
huge pupil at 8 in the morning.  It's like looking into the abyss or
something.  Wear shades, they're better for your eyes, and you'll look so
fucking' cool for the fashion show that is 1015.

-Er, I hate to say this, but this is a respectable venue.  Please bathe,
don't let last years funk creep over into the new year.  Besides, when
you're runway, you've got to be 150% gorgeous.  And beleive me, 1015 is
runway honey, make no mistake!

-Drop by and say hello, even if you don't smell like roses.  I'll be near
Geoff or Ron or some girls or something.  I love new years morning, even at
Preston's. I will be rather incoherent, but I'll pull it together long
enough to say hi, and engage in conversation.  If I drift off, it's due to
a bra or booty attracting my attention, sorry , a man has his priorities
;).

-Don't get all crazy and loud and pick fights or get into arguments with
people, or other lame ass shit.  It's new years, lighten up, smoke a bowl,
drink some drink, and do what comes naturally (fall down, get dizzy, puke
in the sordid men's room, come out looking like death warmed over, and
start it all over again).

-Yo?  Any ladies playin' at this event?  Didn't think so...hey, I got 5 on
it. Yo, make that a double...hey, what are such fine undergarments doing in
a place like this. Yo man, wassup, hey look, I got 3 friends with me, and
they got 12 friends each, lookie here, you know me man, I gots to get mine,
so why don't you take care of it and my friends too!  Cool G!  Yo, yo,
wassup my man, long time no see...no I didn't go out, can't you smell?


I hope you all have a good new year and that I see some of you out tomorrow
morning.  I have a day of banality planned so...

Out,
John

From: TKagnoff@aol.com

Date: Sun, 31 Dec 1995 13:59:08 -0500
Message-ID: <951231135907_81557206@mail04.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: READ THIS IF YOU HAVE TO DRIVE TONIGHT!!!!!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

non-rave related , but PLEASE!!! review this if you have to drive tonite
'cause we all wanna see ya in the new year.


DRUNK DRIVING:Ten basic questions and answers you need to 
know:

Certain features of the laws relating to drunk driving differ from state to
state. 
Some of the main differences are: the amount of alcohol in a person's 
bloodstream that constitutes being under the influence, the exact length of
jail 
sentences and the amount of fines that may be imposed. This article is based
on 
California law which is similar to the laws of many other states.
1. Q: Do you have to be "drunk" to be guilty of drunk driving?
A: No. Years ago, a drunk driving charge meant someone was "drunk" in the way
all of us 
commonly understand the word - intoxicated. But today, intoxication as we
know it is not 
required for one to be guilty of drunk driving. During the last ten years
public outcry against the 
toll of injury and death which drinking drivers inflict has changed the laws
against drunk 
driving radically and made them much more severe. So the criminal laws
against drinking and 
driving now mean operating a vehicle with considerably less alcohol in your
system than what 
we customarily recognize as being enough to make a person drunk. 
You may not think you are drunk. Those around you may not think you are
drunk. Indeed, for 
the purpose of every other situation except driving, you may not even be
considered drunk. But 
your condition may be enough for you to be found guilty of a drunk driving
offense under the 
current definition of the law. And if you are convicted, you will suffer some
very harsh penalties. 
2. Q: Legally, just what is "drunk driving?"
A: A drunk driving offense, sometimes called driving while intoxicated (DWI)
or driving under 
the influence (DUI), really has three general meanings: 
(1) Driving with any amount of alcohol in your system which causes your
physical abilities to be 
impaired in any way. 
(2) Driving with a level of alcohol in your system which amounts to a
measurement of.08 of 
blood alcohol content. To be guilty of this offense, absolutely no impairment
of any of your 
physical abilities is necessary. You may well be the world's most talented,
careful and safest 
driver, but if your blood alcohol content registers .08 or above you are
guilty of a criminal offense. 
(3) Driving with drugs in your system or with a combination of drugs and
alcohol, no matter 
what the amounts of those substances may be, where your physical abilities
have become 
impaired in any way. It does not matter if the drugs are legal , over the
counter medications like 
antihistamines, nor does it matter if you have a prescription to take the
drugs. If you are impaired 
as a result of taking them, then you are guilty of a criminal offense. 
3. Q: What amount of alcohol do I need to drink to have a blood alcohol
content of 
.08 or higher?
A: Each person's blood alcohol content from drinking certain amounts of
alcohol will vary, 
depending upon a number of factors. The main factor is your weight. To
calculate your blood 
alcohol content based upon having normal drinks such as a 12 oz. beer, a  4
ounce glass of wine, 
or a single mixed drink containing a one ounce shot of 100 proof liquor, the
following rule of 
thumb is an illustration: 
120 lbs: one drink in one hour -- .032 
two drinks in one hour -- .064 
three drinks in one hour -- .096 
180 lbs: one drink in one hour -- .021 
two drinks in one hour -- .042 
three drinks in one hour -- .063 
four drinks in one hour -- .084 
4. Q: What kind of reason does a police officer or highway patrolman need to
have 
in order to stop me to investigate whether or not I am driving under the
influence?
A: The officer must have what is legally termed a "reasonable suspicion,"
based on something 
unusual that is actually observed about the way a person is driving. This is
a very low standard 
and it can be satisfied by virtually anything which appears out of the
ordinary and that might be a 
sign of a driver being under the influence. In addition, during holiday
seasons, police officers 
typically set up field sobriety checkpoints where they routinely stop every
driver who passes 
through the checkpoint. These checkpoints do not require the officer to
observe anything 
suspicious about a person before stopping and investigating someone. 
5. Q: What happens to me if I am pulled over by the police or the highway
patrol 
for investigation of drunk driving?
A: If you are stopped, always be courteous and cooperative with the officer
even if you are 100% 
clean of any type of alcohol or drugs, and even if you are certain that your
driving did not show 
anything unusual. Never argue with the officer. Law enforcement is a tough,
often nerve 
wracking job and the "attitude" you show to the officer can often make all
the difference as to 
whether or not the encounter will be an unpleasant one for you. 
6. Q: What will happen if the officer who pulls me over suspects that I have
been 
driving under the influence?
A: The officer will ask you to get out of the car and will instruct you to
perform a series of "field 
sobriety tests." These are standard physical ability measures and they
include: 
(1) Reciting the alphabet from A to Z; 
(2) Closing your eyes and bringing both index fingers together; 
(3) Walking along a straight line; 
(4) Standing on one foot for a few seconds; 
(5) Picking up a coin dropped on the ground; In addition to these tests, some
officers typically 
have certain field sobriety testing devices which they use. One such device
is a breath meter 
which you blow into. another is a light to shine in your eyes in order to
test your pupil reaction. It 
is very important that if you suffer from any chronic physical problems, such
as difficulty with 
your balance, problems walking or with your legs or feet, that you inform the
officer of these 
things before you go through the field sobriety tests. 
7. Q: What happens if the officer believes that I have not performed the
field 
sobriety tests satisfactorily?
A: At that point you will be told that you are under arrest for driving under
the influence. You 
will be hand cuffed, searched for weapons, placed in the back of the
officer's car and taken to a jail 
for further tests. At the jail you will also be booked and held there until
you post bail or until a 
judge releases you on your own recognizance without bail. Once again, as
upsetting and as 
stressful as being arrested is, it is essential that you continue to act
courteously and cooperatively 
with the officer. Do not argue, threaten or become belligerent in any way.
This type of behavior 
will only make the experience even more unpleasant for you. 
8. Q: What is a blood alcohol test?
A: This is a physical procedure to determine how much alcohol you actually
have in your system. 
There are three ways of doing this test: 
(1) Drawing a sample of blood from your arm; 
(2) Obtaining a urine sample; 
(3) Obtaining a breath sample by having you blow into a machine called a
breathalyzer; (This is 
different from the field sobriety breath device described above. The
breathalyzer is much more 
sophisticated and exact. 
You have the choice of which one of these three tests you will take. The only
time your ability to 
choose which test you take can legally be restricted is if you are in a
locality that simply does not 
have a breathalyzer. The officer is required to tell you that the option as
to which test you take is 
up to you. But quite often officers will try to pressure or browbeat a person
into taking the blood 
test because this is the most effective procedure for the prosecution to use
against a person in 
court. You do not have the right to refuse to take any test. Legally, the
officer could hold you 
down and forcibly draw a blood sample from your veins. In practice this
rarely happens except 
where an accident is involved which caused death or serious bodily injury.
Instead, if you refuse 
to take a test, your driver's license is automatically suspended for one
year. Also, in your trial, the 
jury will be told that you refused to take the test and the judge will
instruct the jury that they can 
consider your refusal as evidence of your guilt. 
9. Q: What should I know in order to make an intelligent choice about which
blood 
alcohol test I should take?
A: As mentioned above, from the standpoint of the police and prosecution they
will always 
prefer to have the more accurate sample of your actual blood to use against
you as evidence in 
court. The least accurate and least reliable test is of a urine sample.
However, if it has been some 
period of time from when you had your last drink to when you give the urine
sample, the 
sample may test out to your disadvantage with an inaccurately high reading
against you. This is 
because in such a situation, the alcohol content in your excreted urine is
actually greater than the 
amount of alcohol you have remaining in your system. 
On the other hand, a breath test may show an inaccurately high reading
against you if you take 
the breath test shortly after your last drink. This is because of the high
alcohol content lingering 
in the mouth, esophagus, and the upper digestive system. If you have used any
kind of breath 
spray, mouthwash or even should you burp shortly before the breath test, then
the reading could 
be inaccurately high against you. Both the blood and the urine samples will
also show the 
presence of drugs as well as alcohol. However a breath test can only
determine alcohol content 
and nothing about drugs. Whichever test you take must be given to you within
3 hours of when 
you were driving. 
10. Q: What are the penalties for driving while under the influence?
A: Drunk driving penalties have become very severe in the past few years. For
a first offense, the 
maximum possible penalties the court could impose are: 
(1) 6 months in the county jail: 
(2) $1,000 fine plus up to an additional $1,950 in penalty assessments; 
(3) 6 months driver's license suspension; 
(4) Your car impounded for 30 days. 
Second, third and fourth offenses within 7 years are punished by increasingly
more harsh 
penalties. For third and fourth convictions, your license must be revoked for
3 and 4 years 
respectively. A fourth offense can even be prosecuted against you as a felony
carrying a 
maximum term of 3 years in state prison along with your car being ordered
sold and the proceeds 
going to the state. In addition to all of the above penalties, the price of
auto insurance increases 
drastically after any conviction for a driving under the influence offense. 
The bottom line legal and practical advice to draw from all of all of the
above is very clear: 
IT IS NEVER WORTH IT TO DRINK AND DRIVE. 


shalom
-T

Subject: Thoughts from the weekend
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SF Raves)
Date: Tue, 19 Dec 1995 15:59:05 -0800 (PST)
Organization: Future Productions (SF/Detroit)
Phone: 415/208-2770

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
