ReSent-Date: Sun, 31 Dec 1995 14:38:41 -0800 (PST)
ReSent-From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
ReSent-To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
ReSent-Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.951231143841.23222C@taz.hyperreal.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I went to the Gathering.  I knew it was going to be a big party,
and I really hate big parties.  I felt obligated though, as my
friend from Chicago was spinning (Terry Mullan).

I got there, I danced, I talked to some people, I danced some more,
I talked some more, then went home.  Looking back, I realize I had
a good time there.  A couple of immediate reasons jump out - there
was not overly-done production in the space (no paper-mache statues,
no 30 ft altars, no concert lighting, etc), good sound systems,
and good dj's.  I was a bit lost among so many people, and the
music wasn't always to my tastes, but overall, things were okay.

Now, I don't know how I would feel if I had paid $25 for this party.
Don't get me wrong, I am a capitalist and certainly commend Martin
for the business undertaking he successfully pulled off.  I don't
even care if he made a year of my salary on that party.  That
doesn't effect my enjoyment one way or the other.

You can always question if that same party could have been thrown
for $5 less, or $10 less.  There are no guarantees of attendance,
so every business venture has to estimate low.  The only concern
should be my personal level of cost vs enjoyment.  What may be
"worth it" to me might be "highway robbery" to someone else.

The only problem I see is that we as consumers don't make Martin
or any other promoter out to be a superstar just for running a
business...


-- 
fix.er \'fik-s*r\ n : one that fixes : as : one that intervenes to enable a
   person to circumvent the law or obtain a political favor : one that adjusts
   matters or disputes by negotiation

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 20 Dec 95 14:55:53 -0800
From: SCOTT_BASFORD@HP-PaloAlto-om4.om.hp.com
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Cc: BASFORD_SCOTT/HP-PaloAlto_om4@hpcc08.corp.hp.com
Subject: The Gathering : Some late thoughts 

Item Subject: cc:Mail Text
     Hi everyone,
     
     It's probably a little bit late for a review, especially given that 
     this week's calendar is already out. However I am only now beginning 
     to come back down to earth after Saturday, so here are my thoughts.
     
     I had an absolute blast! I loved every minute of it, and didn't want 
     it to end. The music, the people, the vibe, everything was simply 
     superb.
     
     This was my first "massive". Although I was expecting the party to be 
     big, I didn't expect it to be this big. Given the size I thought the 
     party was incredibly well managed. All of the problems that I have 
     seen at much smaller parties were not there. The long line at the 
     start moved very quickly. The staff certainly didn't get in my face. 
     The space was huge and well ventilated. The toilet lines were short. 
     And probably best of all I didn't encounter any negative energy from 
     anyone. By the way, do we have an official answer on the number of 
     people yet? 
     
     I was there with five very close friends. My partner in crime J-C, the 
     man who can never stand still. My old mates Rob and Leighton who 
     haven't been out dancing for a couple of months now. And finally we 
     had a couple of first timers Ann and Sophie. They are already asking 
     me when the next party is.
     
     I met quite a few sfravers which was fantastic. I bumped into Amy, 
     Wayne, Vince, Crunchman and Ethan (thanks for the tape!) again. I also 
     got to meet Shawna, Dimitriou (sp?), Tom and his friend (sorry!) for 
     the first time. I know there were others, so please excuse me for 
     leaving you out.
     
     Tom I loved your message. The last few songs of the night when the 
     lights have been turned on is always my favorite time. It's so 
     incredible to look around and see the smiles on everyone's faces. It 
     feels like the dawn of a new beginning. And yes I am saw also. I've 
     strained muscles in both my legs and in my neck, not to mention 
     blisters all over my feet. I guess that's what happens when you 
     dance for seven and a half hours with shoes and no socks!
     
     Finally some random thoughts and suggestions. 
     
     Running out of water was a bit of a pain. Unfortunately I didn't 
     find the tap like some others. Did anyone else taste that cranberry 
     juice? Yuck!
     
     Did anyone else think it was a little too dark, especially in the 
     bigger room. I need to see more smiles! I also agree with the 
     comments about the visuals. Give us some more lasers. 
     
     I found that the two room setup broke up the vibe for me a little 
     bit. Each time I was really in a zone dancing, and about to be 
     transported to another level, a little voice in the back of my head 
     would say something like "Your missing Jeno in the other room". I 
     guess that if that's my only real gripe, then I should just shutup 
     and dance!
     
     Thanks to Martin, the crew and everyone who was there for a 
     fantastic party. Well worth the $25. Until next time...
     
     Keep on smiling!
     
     Scott.
     
     P.S. If you are wondering who the hell I am, I was the Australian 
     bastard with long hair and half a beard, wearing the multi-coloured 
     striped overalls.
     
     --------------------
     basfords@corp.hp.com
     --------------------

>>I'm sorry you feel that way...  perhaps my opinion might change over time
>>if they would get their little pig snouts out of my face.

> ...I would just caution you
>sir, to relax, and watch how you talk to law enforcement.  If you're shit
>was half proper you wouldn't have as much problems as you do with five-oh...
>With that said I have always been offended when you call people goons,
>gangsters, pigs, whatever, since I find little use in labelling a whole
>group of people based on any singular experience.
<...
>So my man, get a clue, you offended some people by calling cops pigs, just
>stop doing it.  What's to be accomplished anyway with all this name calling
>of law enforcement?
>...

Amen, John.  Law enforcement is a real dangerous job at times, and it takes 
someone who really believes in what they're doing to work towards a position 
as a policeman/sheriff.  I have a friend up in Washington that I grew up 
with who just recently became a deputy sheriff.  His name is George Dvorack. 
 This guy is my hero.  I have an immense amount of respect and admiration 
for him.  Law enforcement isn't a job, it's a calling.  The pay is crap, you 
wind up doing crap work on occasion like handing out traffic tickets, when 
you put on the uniform everyone suddenly hates you or is wary of you, and 
every time you go out, you just hope you'll make it back in one piece.  But 
they are there to protect you and the structure of the society you live in, 
whether you choose to keep that in mind or not.  It takes a special kind of 
person to keep an even keel while doing that job.  I agree totally with 
John: act suspicious, and they will be suspicious.  Give them a hard time, 
and they can give you one right back.  

They deserve your respect.  Respect them and they'll respect you.

S

I went, it was ok, saw carlos spinning, danced for a while.
I wouldn't say vibeless, but less vibey than the SF folks, on a good
night, but it was ok.  Very young, compared to the avg 1015 crowd,
for example, though.  I thought they were nice enough.  The sound
system was kinda harsh, too much mid/treble, with distortion,
and not enough bass (hate that).  I'll give it a so, so.  Would have
been better if I was part of the operant social set, but they're
*much* younger than I, which isn't bad, just that I'm not likely to
hang out long enough to get to know many of them, and etc., etc.
The 5-6 or so I spoke with were pretty nice, friendly.

Subject: cops and all that
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 31 Dec 1995 19:44:04 -72800 (PST)
In-Reply-To: <199512312229.OAA02605@shellx.best.com> from "SDream" at Dec 31, 95 02:29:32 pm

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> for him.  Law enforcement isn't a job, it's a calling.  The pay is crap, you 
> wind up doing crap work on occasion like handing out traffic tickets, when 
> you put on the uniform everyone suddenly hates you or is wary of you, and 
> every time you go out, you just hope you'll make it back in one piece.
[...] 
> They deserve your respect.  Respect them and they'll respect you.

Ah, would it were always true.  Since I generally don't do illegal things
I don't see the results of whatever "protection" is afforded me from law
enforcement -- I only see the cops that fuck with me for no reason, like
detaining me outside the 7-11 one block from my house and questioning me
about my destination, friends, what tattoos I might have (!), etc., while
a police copter hovered overhead with the searchlight pinning me down.

My crime?  "You left the store without buying anything -- that's suspicious."
"They were out of Sunday papers, so I was going to try the liquor store
across the street."  Evidently this wasn't a good enough reason, so I got 
questioned.  Being pulled over for no reason and having my car searched,
on the street where I lived...the examples are many.  I can't
imagine what it would be like if I were Black or Hispanic; probably would
have had my money confiscated under suspicion of dealing drugs (they can
do that, right on the street) and taken down to the station.

The trouble with a job being underpaid
is that people are doing it for other reasons.  For some, they may
be noble.  For many cops I've experienced, the perk is being able to 
abuse people verbally and physically, and then hide behind a badge.

Unfortunately, the "wrong" reasons (self-gratification through abuse of
the powerless) are more powerful than the "right" reasons (protection
of one's community), as the first is reinforced every time you fuck with
someone, whereas the second is only reinforced when you actually stop 
something bad from happening and someone thanks you for it --  a rare 
event.

A friend of mine has an ex-cop brother, who from all indications was
doing it for the right reasons.  He felt very outnumbered by those that,
in his view, abused their power.  I suspect his experience is typical.

I mean, what if _you_ could safely and legally beat the shit out of anyone
who gave you lip?  What if you could fuck with people you hate, and leave
them powerless to retaliate in kind?  What if you could ruin the day, week,
or life of anyone, and have almost zero chance of being caught?

Would _you_ be able to keep your head when someone who's been fucked with
by too many bad cops starts calling you a fucking pig shithead so get your
fucking pig hands offa me, asshole!  Wouldn't it be nice to just slam them
over the hood of your car and cuff 'em?  Wouldn't you start provoking 
people, just a little, so you can feel that rush of power more often?  
Wouldn't it go to your head?  Pretty soon you've got that slow swagger 
down, the insolent voice that tells people "Come on, shitheel, try me",
the mirrorshades that nail down your 'tude, all calculated to make people
*itch* to fuck with you so you can legally beat them to the ground with
your D-cell flashlight/riot baton.  And if they run, maybe you get to
blow them away...damn.  Don't you sometimes wonder what it would be like
to drop a human instead of those stupid carboard silhouettes?  Wouldn't
it give you a sort of black joy to be able to squeeze off on the poor
bastard who thought he could run from the steel-cap boot of Justice?  
Ha!  Take that, motherfucker!

"Power corrupts, and absolute power corrupts absolutely."

Power - Responsibility = Corruption

therefore

  lim Corruption = 0
power->0

...

thus mathematically proving the superiority of anarchy.

Ha!

// g

This post not closed captioned for the intellectually impaired.  Do not
adjust your set.  Place the mask over your nose and mouth, and breathe
normally.  Contents may have settled during shipping.  Light fuse and get away.
